DOC.HEAD: CBS Suspends Andy Rooney For Remarks Attributed To Him
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf pvs, ``I do...was fair,' to CORRECT Rooney's age. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `But in his...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY21
DOC.TEXT: CBS News humorist Andy Rooney was suspended for three months without pay Thursday, although he denied making racial comments attributed to him in a gay magazine. He was suspended after meeting with CBS News president David Burke. ``I guess he (Burke) believes the person who said I said it,'' Rooney said, referring to Chris Bull, the reporter whose interview with Rooney will be published Friday by The Advocate, a biweekly magazine based in Los Angeles. Rooney's suspension is immediate. He won't be seen this Sunday in his usual ``60 Minutes'' slot, a spokesman for the program said. ``I'd like to think that my temporary departure would cause `60 Minutes' ratings to plummet,'' Rooney said a statement, ``but the show is too good without me for that to happen.'' Former CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite, Rooney's friend since the two were correspondents in World War II, came to his defense with a statement that seemed to indirectly criticize his friend's suspension. Rooney ``is not a racist,'' Cronkite said. His ``more outrageous comments'' may offend some people from time to time, he added, ``but any suggestions that such a rare journalistic voice should be silenced indicates a dangerous weakness in our pluralistic society.'' Cronkite was unavailable to elaborate on his statement, his office said. Bull's article quoted Rooney as saying that ``most people are born with equal intelligence, but blacks have watered down their genes because the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children. They drop out of school early, do drugs and get pregnant.'' ``I do deny (saying) it,'' said Rooney who has worked in news and entertainment at CBS for 40 years and has been the resident humorist at ``60 Minutes'' since 1978. In a brief phone interview, he declined to say whether he thought Burke's action was fair. Rooney's CBS biography gives his age as 70; ``Who's Who in America'' gives it as 71. But in his statement later, he said the controversy put Burke ``in a difficult position, and I accepted his offer of suspension rather than to permanently end my career at CBS.'' Rooney won his first Emmy award in 1968 for his script for a special about lacks, ``Black History: Lost, Stolen, or Strayed,'' a program narrated by Bill Cosby. In his statement, Rooney again denied a uttering a racial slur: ``I did not say, nor would I ever have thought, that `blacks have watered down their genes.' It is a know-nothing statement which I abhor.'' The Advocate article, in which Rooney also discussed homosexuals, was entitled, ``Andy, We Hardly Knew Ye,'' and had a subtitle, ``And Now, a Few Homophobic Minutes with Andy Rooney.'' Rooney's suspension came just more than two years after CBS fired Jimmy ``The Greek'' Snyder as an ``NFL Today'' commentator after Snyder told a TV interviewer that blacks were better than whites as athletes because they were ``bred that way'' during the days of slavery in America. Burke didn't return phone calls and was unavailable to say specifically why he suspended Rooney. His statement announcing the action strongly suggested that it was due to the remarks attributed to Rooney. He said he had discussed with Rooney those reported remarks, and that ``I have made it clear that CBS News cannot tolerate such remarks or anything that approximates such comments.'' ``Mr. Rooney has expressed his dismay that the values of CBS News have been called into question, and offers his deepest apologies to any in our society who are given offense.'' At the end of Rooney's suspension, Burke said, ``we will have further discussions about his future association with CBS News.'' Rooney said he wanted to continue with CBS after his suspension ends. ``I hope so,'' he said. ``I hope that I will.'' He said he would continue writing his twice-weekly syndicated humor column, which he said is distributed to about 260 newspapers. Bull, who says he didn't tape-record his interview with Rooney, on Thursday reiterated that his quotations of Rooney, taken down during a phone interview three weeks ago, were accurate. On Wednesday, Benjamin Hooks, director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, described Rooney's reported remarks to the magazine as ``ill-informed and racist,'' and New York Mayor David Dinkins called CBS to ``register shock,'' according to a spokesman. Rooney earlier got in hot water with homosexual groups because of because a remark he made in a Dec. 28 CBS special, ``A Year With Andy Rooney: 1989.'' In that show, he said that, ``many of the ills which kill us are self-induced,'' and then cited ``too much alcohol, too much food, homosexual unions, cigarettes.''

DOC.HEAD: Dunn Named Aerospace Writer to Succeed Retiring Benedict
DOC.TEXT: Marcia Dunn, who has specialized in science and medical stories as an Associated Press writer in Pittsburgh, has been named the AP's aerospace writer, based at Cape Canaveral. The appointment was announced Thursday by AP Executive Editor William E. Ahearn. She succeeds Howard S. Benedict Jr., who is retiring after 37 years with the AP, including three decades covering the space program. ``If anyone can be considered the `guru' of a beat, it is Howard Benedict,'' said AP President Louis D. Boccardi. ``He has covered the history of America in space. He has led us to the stars.'' Benedict, 61, has covered the National Aeronautics and Space Administration since the early days of the program. He has witnessed and reported on hundreds of launches from Cape Canaveral, including the first manned space flights in the Mercury program through the Gemini flights, the Apollo moon missions, Skylab and the more recent shuttle flights. Ms. Dunn, 33, joined the AP in Pittsburgh in 1979 and worked for two years in the Columbus, Ohio, bureau before returning to Pittsburgh in 1981. She has specialized in covering science and medicine, including the emergence of Pittsburgh as a national center for organ transplant operations. Ms. Dunn is a native of Washington, Pa., and a graduate of Duquesne University. She was a reporter for the Herald-Star in Steubenville, Ohio, before joining the AP. Benedict, a native of Sioux City, Iowa, joined the AP in Salt Lake City in 1953. He was named to the AP Newsfeatures staff in New York in 1956 and transferred to the Tampa bureau two years later. In 1959, he was named correspondent at Cape Canaveral (later Cape Kennedy), where he covered NASA and the ``space race'' until 1974. During the mid-1970s, a period of few manned space flights, Benedict transferred to Washington, where he covered the White House and transportation issues. He returned to Cape Canaveral in 1984. Benedict has earned many honors for his aerospace writing and is a multiple winner of the Robert Ball Memorial Award for space writing, presented by the Aviation-Space Writers Association.

DOC.HEAD: Raiders Steal Silverware, Furniture From Earl's Home
DOC.TEXT: Thieves stole more than $1.6 million in antique silverware and furniture from the home of the Earl of Roden after leaving the 80-year-old peer tied to a chair, police reported. Belfast police headquarters said in a statement Thursday that the four masked raiders broke into the earl's home Wednesday in the village of Bryansford, about 25 miles south of Belfast. Police said the thieves tied the earl to a chair and fled in a van. A neighbor found the peer and freed him Thursday morning. The silverware bore the earl's family crest. The stolen furniture included a Japanese red lacquer bureau and an 18th century French bureau. Police said a number of valuable oil paintings in the earl's home were damaged. There was no indication the raid was connected with the British-ruled province's sectarian and political strife.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Begging Goes On, With Or Without the Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: First, a judge said begging in subways and terminals was OK; then a court said beggars could be banned. Everything had changed for these panhandlers and everything was still the same. They were still hungry, and they were still homeless. ``Are you going to give us some money? No? Then go, get out of here,'' said one homeless man at Pennsylvania Station on Thursday. Another man stood at the entrance with a cup and a sign: ``Homeless and I don't drink, hungry. Thank you very much. God bless you all.'' He demanded money for an interview, saying ``I know my rights.'' He did not know that he had lost a right that he had temporarily _ the legal right to panhandle at the railroad station. On Jan. 25, a federal judge barred the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey from enforcing a rule banning beggars from the subway system and rail and bus stations. U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand ruled that panhandling was a form of free speech, protected by the Constitution. Then, on Wednesday, the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals put Sand's decision on hold while the ruling is appealed. Begging was illegal once again. Caren Gardner, a spokeswoman for the Transit Authority, which operates the subways, said the agency is resuming its ``Operation Enforcement'' and rules banning begging and other activities it believes are offensive to commuters. ``We're just going to go ahead and enforce the rules and regulations that do exist in the subway system,'' she said. Police officers said Thursday they had yet to be told to crack down on beggars or anyone else as a result of the court ruling. ``How you doing? Working hard?'' Transit Authority Police Officer Brian Newcombe asked one homeless beggarn in Penn Station as she walked past with a coffee cup containing several coins. She smiled and moved on. ``I don't throw them out,'' he said. ``I just ask them not to do it in front of token booths.'' Newcombe said the homeless fight for territory in the train station. ``The Port Authority is like a jungle,'' he said of the bus terminal located on the edge of Times Square, an area infested with drug dealers, pickpockets and homeless people. ``It's safer here.'' At the bus terminal on Thursday, dozens of homeless poked through garbage cans, loitered by stairways and remained curled up and sleeping beneath blankets on floors or benches as noon approached. Port Authority spokesman Mark Marchese said it would resume preventing the homeless from sleeping at its bus and rail station but it had never forced them to leave. ``It's not a heartless operation that we run,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Figures on Latest Cases of Aids By Category
With PM-CDC--AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Figures on new AIDS cases in the United States were reported Thursday by the federal Centers for Disease Control. Here is a breakdown, comparing 1989 figures with 1988.

Total newly reported cases: 35,238, up 9 percent from 32,196 in 1988. Male: 31,307, up 9 percent from 28,654. Female: 3,931, up 11 percent from 3,542. Gay-bisexual men: 19,652, up 8 percent from 18,130. IV drug abusers: 7,970, up 5 percent from 7,580. IV drug absers and gay-bisexual men: 2,138, 0 percent change from 2,129. Heterosexual contact: 1,562, up 27 percent from 1,229. Perinatal cases (in newborns): 547, up 17 percent from 468. Hemophilia cases: 321, down 5 percent from 339. Blood transfusion cases: 808, down 14 percent from 935. Northeast region: 10,718, down 7 percent from 11,674. Midwest region: 3,436, up 18 percent from 2,919. South region: 11,063, up 22 percent from 9,091. West region: 8,616, up 16 percent from 7,324. Metro areas under 100,000: 2,799, up 35 percent from 2,067. Metro areas over 1 million: 24,713, up 5 percent from 23,615.

DOC.HEAD: Planes, Trains and Automobiles You'd Rather Not See
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Not far from the Smithsonian's museums and galleries is a photo exhibit with shock value. Sen. Jesse Helms and his anti-pornography partisans won't be offended, but frequent travelers might consider staying home next time. Hanging along the main hallway at the National Transportation Safety Board's headquarters are 25 pictures of charred, broken aircraft, a burned-out school bus, a collapsed bridge, derailed trains, automobiles engulfed in flames and a crippled tanker sliding beneath the waves. The gruesome gallery was the idea of acting board chairman James L. Kolstad, whose agency annually investigates about 3,000 accidents _ from plane crashes to gas pipeline ruptures _ and studies such safety concerns as drug abuse among truck drivers. ``My purpose was to display graphic examples of just how horrendous these accidents can be, in the hope that they won't happen again,'' Kolstad said. ``I want to remind everyone of what can happen when mistakes are made in the cockpit of a plane, the cab of a truck or the bridge of a ship.'' Kolstad sponsored an agencywide photo contest and invited his 320 employees to send their best _ or worst _ action pictures to Washington for judging. Each of the 12 winning entries netted a $100 prize for dramatic impact. Other photos on display came from newspapers, accident witnesses and other sources. ``The unfortunate part of our business is that we get some great disaster pictures,'' said Kolstad aide John Moulden. One of the most dramatic scenes in the gallery is a color photo of the U.S. tanker American Eagle sinking in the Gulf of Mexico in 1984 after it exploded and broke in half, killing seven crew members. The notorious tanker Exxon Valdez is pictured in drydock, with inspectors examining the twisted hull that struck a reef and spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound last March. One of the board's favorites shows a near-catastrophe: a Piedmont jetliner that overshot the airport runway at Charlotte, N.C., in 1986 and plowed to a halt just yards from railway tracks carrying an oncoming train. Another narrowly averted disaster is seen in the scarred hull of the American-owned cruise liner Celebration, which was carrying 2,200 people when it collided last year with a Cuban freighter in the Caribbean. The freighter sank and three crewmen died, but none aboard the cruise ship was injured. ``Had the freighter been traveling faster and the Celebration slower, there probably would have been a substantial loss of life and a significant catastrophe at sea,'' said Kolstad. Said agency spokesman Alan Pollock: ``This is a sober reminder of the seriousness of what we do, and the tragedies we deal with.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Majority Rule or Mob Rule?
DOC.TEXT: Majority rule. Free speech. Political liberty. Government by the consent of the governed. These exalted concepts helped topple governments throughout Eastern Europe last year, but the past few weeks have shown that democracy is not necessarily the only alternative to totalitarian rule. Mob rule is another. If despotic governments can trample on human rights, so can intolerant masses. While democracy may well take root in Eastern Europe, that outcome is not preordained. ``We do not call democratic a regime in which 51 percent of the population may slaughter the remaining 49 percent with impunity,'' says Leslek Kolakowski, a Polish emigre and student of Marxism. The loosening of totalitarian reins in Eastern Europe has exposed political, ethnic and religious bigotry that the post-Marxist regimes may have difficulty containing. Bulgarians by the thousands, for example, used their newly won liberty to protest a decision by the fledgling government in late December to end _ yes, end _ oppression against the Turkish minority. The episode produced an irony. Guess which political group was perhaps the most stalwart defender of Turkish rights? The Bulgarian Communist Party, somewhat of a latecomer to the civil liberties camp. In the Soviet Union, there are some who apparently believe that one of the best uses of free speech is harassment of Jews. The anti-Semitism is such that Jews are applying to emigrate in record numbers. ``There was always anti-Semitism,'' said Meron Nekterman, an electrician who emigrated recently to Israel. ``But before, people were afraid to say what they really thought. Now they can come forward and say straightforward exactly what they want. There's no longer any room in the Soviet Union for Jews,'' Nekterman told The New York Times. The small Jewish community in East Germany may feel the same way about their country. On Monday, hundreds of skinheads goosestepped through Leipzig shouting praise of Hitler as well as bigoted chants including, ``To hell with the Jews.'' As in the Soviet Union, anti-Semitism had been largely contained in East Germany during 40 years of rigid Marxist rule. In Romania, the bright hope of many for a multi-party democracy was set back somewhat last week when thousands of government supporters laid siege to the headquarters of two opposition parties, demanding their dissolution on grounds they were trying to organize a coup. In the Soviet Union, glasnost has meant the lifting of the dead hand of repression but it also has galvanized long-suppressed ethnic hatreds in the Transcaucus region and demands by some Shiites in Azerbaijan for either reunification with Iran or outright independence. Now it is up to the new rulers in Eastern Europe to decide on a question that the traditional democracies historically have had difficulty with: How much leeway should be given to non-democratic forces in a democratic country. At what point does free expression infringe on the rights of society as a whole? Americans, given their own history, have little grounds to be smug about Eastern Europe's democratic growing pains. At the time of the nation's birth, political liberty was limited to white male landowners. Almost 200 years passed before all blacks were assured the right to vote. Columnist Charles Krauthammer predicts that once the euphoria of ousting the tyrants is passed, political disillusionment in Eastern Europe is inevitable. ``Democracy in the abstract is a glory second to none,'' Krauthammer has written. ``But liberated Europe is about to experience the first half of Churchill's famous quip that democracy is the worst form of government except for all the others.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: George Gedda has covered foreign affairs for The Associated Press since 1968.

DOC.HEAD: When Good Things Happen to Unhappy People, They Can Feel Sick
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Jonathon' in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Just in case people with low self-esteem want to hear that they may have another problem, here it is: New research suggests that happy events in their lives may make them feel sick later on. The culprit appears to be stress that arises when good fortune, such as finding a sweetheart or landing a promotion, forces them to reassess their low self-images, researchers said. ``If you think of yourself as basically a loser, and all of a sudden you're accepted in the best sorority in town, and you're doing really well in school ... you're forced to rethink some key aspects of who you are,'' said researcher Jonathon Brown. Support for the idea comes from two studies conducted by Brown, an assistant professor of psychology at the University of Washington, and Kevin McGill of Southern Methodist University in Dallas. The work appears in the December issue of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. One study included 261 students in grades 7 to 11 at a girls' school in the Los Angeles area, and the other focused on 107 students at Southern Methodist. Researchers measured the self-esteem of the students and asked them which ``major life events'' from a list had occurred to them over the previous 12 months. The list included such events as breaking up with a lover or getting a new one, or losing or adding a family member. The participants also indicated whether they considered the event to be positive, negative or neutral. In the girls' school study, students were asked four months later about illnesses they developed since completing the survey. For students with low self-esteem, the more positive events they had recorded, the more colds, sore throats, sinus infections, ear infections and laryngitis they tended to report during the follow-up period. In contrast, for students with high self-esteem, positive events led to fewer reports of illness during the followup period. The Southern Methodist study found similar results when it looked at how often the students visited the health center for physical illness. Neither study verified medically whether the students were actually sick, noted Sheldon Cohen, psychology professor at Carnegie Mellon University. Such ``illness behaviors'' as reporting symptoms or visiting the health service are not necessarily good indicators of true disease, he said. That is because some people do get medically ill but fail to recognize the symptoms, while others think they are sick when they are not actually diseased, he said in a telephone interview. Most studies on the impact of life events have looked at illness behaviors rather than verified disease, he said. Verification is costly and time-consuming, said Cohen, who has done research on the topic. While there is good evidence that life events can influence illness behaviors, a link to physical disease is ``a much iffier issue,'' he said. Recent work has suggested that only negative events increase the risk of feeling ill, he said. The new study's hypothesis about positive events is creative and interesting, he said. Brown acknowledged ``you have to be real cautious'' about saying that the positive life events were leading to disease itself. Brown said similar studies should be done in older people, to see if the effect shows up for more serious illnesses such as heart disease. He also said that although his studies included mostly females, he believed the results pertain to both sexes.

DOC.HEAD: Gene Can Suppress Prostate Cancer, Researchers Report
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have found the first gene able to suppress formation of prostate tumors, one of the most common cancers among men, according to a study published today. The gene, called the retinoblastoma gene, or RB, was found in earlier studies to block the formation of a rare cancer of the eye. In a Science magazine study published today, scientists at the University of California-San Diego say they have shown that a normally functioning RB gene inserted into human prostate cancer cells is able to suppress formation of tumors. The RB gene is usually missing, mutated or not functioning in such tumors. Dr. Robert Bookstein, one of the researchers, said the study may aid progress toward learning how to control cancer through use of tumor suppressor genes, such as RB, or the proteins that such genes produce. ``The idea with cancer suppressor genes, since the loss of the product is oncogenic (cancer nurturing), is that maybe putting it back somehow will be therapeutic,'' Bookstein said. ``That is a distant goal, but I think a valid goal. You could call it gene therapy ... that directly makes up for the defect in the tumor cell.'' Such cancer therapy, however, ``is years and years away,'' he said. Barry Nelkin, a cancer suppressor gene researcher at the Johns Hopkins University Oncology Center, said the California study ``is potentially quite important.'' ``A lot of people are looking for the genetic link to prostate cancer. The few studies that have been done have not pointed to anything specific,'' he said. Nelkin said finding that the RB gene is a suppressor in prostate cancer ``gives us a clue as to the mechanism of tumor genesis.'' Bookstein said scientists in the California study used a retrovirus to insert the RB gene into human prostate cancer cells that did not contain the gene. The genetically treated cancer cells were injected into the right flanks of 20 ``nude'' mice, a breed of laboratory mice that lacks an immune system. The scientists injected untreated prostate cancer cells into the left flank of the mice. Within two months, tumors formed in the left flank of all the mice. Three of the 20 mice did not develop any tumors in the right flank. The right flank tumors that did develop in 17 mice were up to 350 times smaller than the left-flank cancers. Bookstein said the fact that tumors formed at all in the right flank showed that the transfer of the RB gene to the cancer cells was not perfect. He said laboratory studies showed that the tumors that developed either lacked the RB gene or it was mutated. ``Cells that expressed the RB gene were unable to form tumors,'' he said. Bookstein said much more work is needed to understand the role of suppressor genes in prostate cancer formation. ``This is only the first tumor suppressor gene implicated in prostate cancer,'' he said. ``Undoubtedly there are others. I have already found cases with normal RB genes, so other genes have to be involved.'' Scientists at the University of California-San Diego laboratory headed by Wen-Hwa Lee reported in 1988 that the RB gene was able to block tumor formation in the cells of retinoblastoma, a rare eye cancer. Other laboratories have found suppressor genes for breast, bone and lung cancer. The latest study was co-authored by Bookstein, Lee, Jin-Yuh Shew, Phang-Lang Chen and Peter Scully, all of the University of California-San Diego. It is in today's edition of Science, the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Hindu Festival Features Elaborate Penance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The pre-dawn mist melted quickly but was replaced by swirling smoke from tiny devotional fires as thousands of Hindu pilgrims prepared for their annual day of penance. Their rites began at the river as they splashed in dirty water and prayed with relatives and friends. Mothers led their toddlers into the stream. A man dressed only in shorts and with his head freshly shaved stepped from the water into a shuffle dance while others chanted encouragement and lit incense. His eyes glittered, he drooled and his limbs twitched spasmodically. The chanting became louder and his dance more frenzied as sacred ash was slapped on his head. The frenzy subsided in a few minutes and he seemed to fall into a trance. Helping hands perched him on a small stool and carefully forced a metal spike the size of a knitting needle through his cheeks. A smaller rod was run through his tongue from top to bottom. Helpers attached barbed hooks weighted with limes to his back. He didn't bleed and he suffered no apparent pain. This was Thaipusam in the Tamil lunar month of Thai, when the moon is in transit across the brightest star, Pusa, in the zodiacal sign of Cancer. It was Thursday in Malaysia this year, and the scene described at Batu Caves, nine miles north of the capital Kuala Lumpur, was repeated elsewhere in the country by the Hindu devout on that day. Officials expected more than 500,000 at Batu Caves for the 2{-day festival. The annual mortification of the flesh is done to pay homage to the Hindi deity Lord Subramaniam, seek atonement, give thanks and fulfill vows. Thousands of bedazzled foreign tourists also made the trek, lending the religious ceremony the raucous atmosphere of a carnival sideshow complete with a Ferris wheel, trinkets and balloons. Featured players at the festival were the 3,000 who registered with temple officials to carry a ``kavadi.'' These ranged from relatively small wooden yokes decorated with peacock feathers, tinsel and brightly colored paper to 60-pound steel frames with dozens of spikes to penetrate the flesh at many points. The kavadi symbolizes Paravani, Lord Subramaniam's peacock steed. To the uninitiated, Thaipusam at Batu (Stone) Caves is a jolt, a stunning assault on the senses where intense religious devotion is expressed among a throng of gawking sightseers. While family and friends and devotional songs and beat drums, humans covered with hooks, cheeks pierced with spears and tongues with arrows, walked a half-mile from the river to 272 concrete steps leading to Cathedral Cave. The procession was a start-stop affair as cars edged through the dusty column and the gates were occasionally lowered at a grade crossing between the river and the cave for passing trains. Kavadi carriers passed several acres of temporary stalls offering food, drink, clothing, toys, wood carvings and pictures of Indian movie stars. Baubles, bangles and beads were available along with vitamin pills and ``Govinda's Vegetarian Pizza.'' Bearded mendicants solicited alms. Small boys sold camphor pellets to be burned as devotional flames by the faithful once inside the cave. A tour director cautioned his camera-toting charges against pickpockets. Kavadi carriers shuffled faster and whirled in circles as they approached the steps. Several insisted on making the climb in quick spurts of 20 or more steps at a time. The stairs are divided in the middle, with human traffic kept to the left going up and descended on the right. Soldiers, police and white-suited first-aid attendants helped control the crowd. The vast limestone cave was lit inside by strings of electric lights, devotional fires and a beam of daylight from a vertical shaft through the top at one end. Thousands packed the main floor of the cavern, which smelled of incense, sweat, jasmine and bat dung. Penitents headed for a grotto holding the jewel-encrusted image of Lord Subramaniam. A priest removed the spikes and some kavadi carriers collapsed in exhaustion and religious fervor. Sacred ash and lime juice was applied to their wounds, but even after the trance lifted. there was no apparent pain. Several years ago, researchers from the United States and Australia separately investigated the seeming lack of pain, but without conclusive results. They did say that the lime juice and sacred white ash, found to be mostly burned cow manure, had nothing to do with it. The few willing to talk about their deed said it was done for intensely personal reasons. One said he vowed to carry a kavadi for three years after he regained his health after a motorcycle crash. Another said he did it to honor his father. The tradition at Batu Caves originated before the turn of the century, temple chairman S. Sockalingam said. Hindus in India have many sacred places in hills and mountains, and there are celebrated cave temples. Tamils from southern India brought the observance of Thaipusam when they came to what was then Malaya to tap rubber. India has banned such self-torture but it continues here with unabated fervor. Sockalingam said some of the wooden rods used to pierce the cheeks had been growing so long that a one-yard limit was imposed this year.

DOC.HEAD: Remains of Eight MIAs Returned
DOC.TEXT: The remains of eight American servicemen killed more than two decades ago in the Vietnam War were returned home to military honors under a steel gray sky. ``Home at last,'' said a sign behind about 150 soldiers and veterans who watched the arrival Thursday of a military transport plane. A brief ceremony was capped by the traditional playing of ``taps,'' which echoed across the cold concrete airport apron as flag-draped caskets were carried to hearses. Earlier in the day, the remains identified by the Army's Central Identification Laboratory in Hawaii had been placed aboard the jet at Hickam Air Force Base. Six sets of remains belonged to Army soldiers killed in the crash of a South Vietnamese air force CH-34 helicopter shot down in Laos on Nov. 30, 1968. The remains were recovered in a joint excavation by the governments of the United States and Laos in March, Air Force officials said. The remains were identified as those of: Maj. Samuel K. Toomey III of Independence, Mo.; 1st. Lt. Raymond C. Stacks of Memphis, Tenn.; Sgt. 1st Class Arthur E. Bader Jr. of Atlantic City, N.J.; Sgt. 1st Class Gary R. La Bohn of Wixom, Mich.; Sgt. 1st Class Klaus E. Scholz of Amarillo, Texas, and Sgt. 1st Class Michael H. Mein of Cape Vincent, N.Y. Also among the eight remains were those of a serviceman who died Oct. 2, 1968. His name was withheld at the request of his family. The eighth set of remains was identified in November as that of Air Force Col. Charles D. Roby of Iowa Park, Texas. Roby was killed while flying an F-4 Phantom jet on a reconnaissance mission over North Vietnam March 3, 1967. The remains were to be kept at Travis Air Force Base, about 45 miles northeast of San Francisco, pending arrangements by relatives. By Thursday, there were still 2,309 Americans missing in the Vietnam War.

DOC.HEAD: US, Latin Officials Nearing Agreement on Drug Summit Communique
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Latin officials are close to agreement on a communique for next week's drug summit pledging U.S. help to revamp the drug-dependent economies of Peru, Bolivia and Colombia, sources say. The communique to be signed at the four-nation meeting also would commit President Bush to press other Western nations to provide economic aid to the Andean nations, said a South American diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The document is being prepared for the signature of Bush and the presidents of the three Andean countries who will meet Feb. 15 for a drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia. U.S. military assistance to the Andean countries is not spelled out in the document, but the Latins have insisted it be restricted to equipment and training rather than direct U.S. military involvement in interdiction, said the South American diplomat. Those familiar with the document described it as broad in tone, without specifying how much money the United States would give the Latin nations in exchange for their participation in the war on drug production and trafficking. However, the document will get into specific issues regarding interdiction and military cooperation, economic alternatives to the drug trade, and efforts to get other countries' aid in the anti-drug effort, said Michael Skol, deputy assistant secretary of state for South American affairs. ``We're very close'' to agreeing among the countries on final wording, Skol said Thursday. He called the document ``a very comprehensive document of cooperation on the drug issue'' that recognizes rights and responsibilities of producer and consumer countries ``without finger-pointing.'' Among the promises expected from Bush at the summit, according to those familiar with the summit communique, are: _Tighter enforcement on export of precursor drugs _ such as ether _ that are used in the production of cocaine from coca leaves. _Money for crops to substitute for the lucrative coca fields. _Promotion of private initiatives for trade opportunities and technical assistance to help the Andean countries expand their markets. _Support for expanded trade opportunities for the Andean countries. _Pressure on other nations to help the drug-production nations with economic and trade assistance. In addition to the communique, the summit may produce an agreement between Bolivia and the United States to renew an extradition treaty that has not been updated since 1900, said one diplomatic source. The White House has praised Bolivia for extradition action _ particularly the December extradition of an alleged drug trafficker, Luis Arce Gomez _ but the Bolivian law itself was written before drug crimes were considered and thus does not address them specifically. The U.S. portion of the summit communique is said to hew closely to what Bush proposed last month for the second year of his national drug control strategy. Bush has proposed $206 million in new anti-drug spending _ in military, law enforcement and economic assistance _ for the Andean nations in the 1991 fiscal year, as part of a four-year $2.2 billion plan. The administration has said that allocation of money is dependent on cooperation by the drug-producing nations in the anti-drug efforts. Peru's president, Alan Garcia, recently scoffed at U.S. proposals for anti-drug spending as insufficient to combat the multibillion-dollar industry. Garcia also was irked with the U.S. invasion of Panama in December, and agreed to attend the drug summit only after President Bush promised to withdraw the invasion troops by the end of the month. The document addresses the issues of money laundering and control of U.S. export of weapons that are used by drug lords, and could provide for information sharing on gun exports, said one source. President Virgilio Barco is known to be anxious to talk to Bush about the need to reinstate a coffee export quota system that was beneficial to Colombian farmers. It was unclear if coffee will be addressed in the presidents' communique or will be included in general terms under the category of U.S. assistance to redirect the Latin countries' economies away from drugs.

DOC.HEAD: First Oil Washes Ashore; Coast Guard Optimistic About Clean-up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with first oil washing ashore, new estimate of slick size. 9th graf: `Along the shore...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA5, LA11, LaserColor LA8
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil began washing up on a popular beach Thursday evening as clean-up boats skimmed the ocean around a tanker that spewed 295,000 gallons after apparently being punctured by an anchor. Small black globules of Alaskan crude oil splashed a quarter-mile stretch of Newport Beach, a community that includes some of Southern California's most-expensive beachfront property. The 811-foot tanker American Trader, which had carried 21 million gallons, lay off the coast surrounded by an oil containment boom and Coast Guard boats. Workers labored to patch a 3-foot hole punched through the ship's bottom near an offshore mooring station Wednesday. ``Every indication is the vessel is no longer leaking oil,'' Coast Guard Rear Adm. William Kime told a press conference after an inspection flight. The slick covered an area measuring 3 miles by 6 miles. Offshore winds held the purple sheen away from beaches until afternoon, then reversed direction and began nudging the mess onto shore. ``The main part of the oil slick is still staying three-quarters to one mile offshore,'' said Huntington Beach Mayor Tom Mays, who flew over the slick in a helicopter at dusk. ``A major portion of the spill, or the slick, is heading directly to the Newport Beach pier.'' Huntington Beach Fire Department Capt. Bill Newton said thick black gobs of crude were hitting along a quarter-mile of the beach at about 8:30 p.m. The oil didn't appear to be covering the beach in thick sheets. Mays said about 300 professional cleanup workers were waiting to begin shoveling up the oil beach beginning at low tide Friday, 9:15 a.m. Coast Guard Commandant Adm. Paul Yost said the ship's hull apparently was punctured when it hit something on the bottom as the crew prepared to hook up to an underwater pipeline that carries crude oil to shore. It was unclear if the tanker hit one of its own anchors or a buoy anchor, he said. Five skimmer boats were at work and four more were en route to the area, off the Orange County coastline about 35 miles southeast of Los Angeles. Along the shore, booms were laid to protect the environmentally delicate estuaries at the Santa Ana River mouth, Anaheim Bay, Bolsa Chica Wetlands and upper Newport Bay _ all teeming with wildlife. Biologist Esther Burket said oil coming ashore on a sandy beach would be less harmful than in an estuary such as Bolsa Chica, where birds would ingest the petroleum with the plants they eat. ``Once it gets onto vegetation, it's a nightmare,'' Burket said. Eighteen oil-soaked seabirds, mostly western grebes, were rescued from the beach and cleaned by volunteers at a lifeguard headquarters. The count of dead birds totaled eight, said state wildlife biologist Jon Fisher. Curt Taucher, a Fish and Game spokesman, said there was some initial concern about migrating gray whales but that was not the biggest worry. ``The concern is for the furbearing animals, harbor seals, animals like that,'' he said. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said in a press release that President Bush would be briefed and that ``everything that can be done is being done.'' The broad, sandy beach at this city of 180,000 in northern Orange County, plus Bolsa Chica State Beach to the northwest and Huntington State Beach to the south, draw millions of sunbathers and surfers during summer. Federally mandated alcohol tests given to the ship's captain, identified as Robert Laware, the pilot, first mate and second mate all came back negative, the Coast Guard said. Drug test results were in complete. The American Trader was last boarded by the Coast Guard on Dec. 28 in San Francisco and was found free of violations were found. Its last certificate of inspection was issued in Honolulu on May 11, 1989. After the hole in the tanker is patched the Coast Guard plans to pump the remaining oil from the punctured compartment into a barge. The same pumps were used to unload the Exxon Valdez when it ran aground in Alaska last year and spilled more than 10 million gallons of crude into Prince William Sound. There were no formal discussions on use of chemical dispersants, said Rolf Mall, deputy regional manager for the state Department of Fish and Game. Damage from chemicals has to be weighed against harm from the oil, he said. ``The further out it gets and the deeper the water, the more likely it is we'll use them,'' Mall said. Mindful of the massive Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska last year, California politicians rushed to call for tighter controls on oil shipping and stiffer penalties for spills. ``This is a wake-up call,'' said Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy. The American Trader was chartered by British Petroleum Oil Shipping Co. USA, said Joe Braderich, manager of the firm's Los Angeles field office. The spill began Wednesday afternoon while the tanker maneuvered 1{ miles off Huntington Beach to moor at a nest of mooring buoys at an offloading station for an underwater pipeline leading to a refinery on shore. The depth at the accident site was unclear. The Coast Guard put the depth at 84 feet. However, Huntington Beach Marine Safety Officer Steve Reuter said it was 56 feet. The ship, owned and operated by American Trading Transportation Co. of New York, drops two bow anchors during such maneuvering, said company president Sanford Schmidt. A swell may have lifted the ship and swung one anchor against the bottom, Schmidt said in a telephone interview after speaking with the ship's captain. A diver found a 3-foot hole in the single-hull bottom of the No. 1 forward compartment, a tank which holds more than 1 million gallons of crude. Industry critics say tankers should have double hulls for safety. The Coast Guard's Pacific Area Strike Team was called in from its base in San Francisco. BP, with its office in Los Angeles, hired a local cleanup company, Clean Coastal Waters, to recover the oil but the cost of that work will be paid by American Trading or its insurance company. The American Trader had picked up Alaskan oil from the vessel Keystone Canyon in Long Beach Harbor and was to offload some of it at the offshore pipeline for Golden West Refinery in Santa Fe Springs, said BP spokesman Chuck Webster. An oil industry newsletter, Oil Spill Intelligence Report of Arlington, Mass., said the spill was the third-largest in California waters in the last 10 years. The largest was 1.6 million gallons of bunker fuel from a 1984 sinking off San Francisco, the newsletter said.

DOC.HEAD: Theater Company Closing London Base for Four Months
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Royal Shakespeare Company has announced it will close its two London theaters for four months, citing the need for what Falstaff called a ``remedy against this consumption of the purse.'' The theater's staff of nearly 70 in London will draw half its regular pay while performances are suspended, beginning in November, artistic director Terry Hands said on Thursday. The company's two theaters in Stratford-upon-Avon, Shakespeare's birthplace, will not be affected. The current sellout productions of ``Hamlet'' and ``A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' plus the company's earnings from ``Les Miserables,'' the international musical hit, were not enough to make up for a financial shortfall, Hands told a news conference Thursday. ``I'm haunted by the specter of endless revivals of `Peter Pan' to pay for endless revivals of `Peter Pan,''' he said, referring to the J.M. Barrie play that has been a Christmas perennial. ``It is the 90s, it is a new decade, it is the moment to reassess the policies that have brought us to this point, (and) all I can say is those policies are not working,'' Hands said. It is the first time the company has taken such a move. No performances will be affected because the theaters will not be closed until November, and plays are not scheduled that far in advance. The news came three weeks after the company announced an unusually small 1990-1991 season of 21 productions. On Tuesday, the company opened a stage production of ``A Clockwork Orange'' to mixed reviews but capacity business. Hands said the 1,162-seat Barbican Theater and the studio Pit theater, with flexible seating for up to 240, will close for four months from Nov. 5. He said that would save the company about $2.75 million on its projected 1990-91 budget. Hands, who steps down at the end of the year, said he opted for the closures, keeping in mind his successor or successors to be named next week. ``I believe, in departing, that whoever comes next should be relieved of the nightmare of the past 12 years ... without having to spend three-quarters of the day raising, saving, or making money,'' he said, referring to the funding woes that have beset the company throughout the 1980s. Hands said the company's deficit will be $4.9 million by next month. Thirty percent of its annual budget of $32.1 million comes from government subsidies. More than 40 percent of the operating costs at the Royal National Theater, Britain's other flagship subsidized playhouse, are met by government grants. Hands called on the government to keep its funding in line with inflation, as recommended in a report in 1984. He said funding increases have either been at a standstill or lagged behind inflation. Of the upcoming repertory, Hands said, ``I'm putting everything back on the drawing board from June, because every single risk must be eliminated, every single penny must be made.'' The new musical ``Children of Eden,'' with music by American composer Stephen Schwartz, will open in 1991 in Stratford instead of Dec. 5 in London as planned. In 1985, the National Theater closed its Cottesloe auditorium for five months to cut costs. Sue Rose, press officer at the Arts Council, which distributes government money to the arts, said the organization was sympathetic but had ``already allocated our funding for the year.''

DOC.HEAD: Sketch of the Soviet Political Reform Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is how political events in the Soviet Union could unfold to implement President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's political reform blueprint approved this week by the Communist Party leadership: Feb. 14 _ Supreme Soviet legislature opens its next session. At any time it can take up the Cmmunist Party's proposals for a popularly elected president and repeal of Article 6 in the Constitution, the party's guarantee of a leading role in society. It can also call a special session of the Congress of People's Deputies to confirm the constitutional changes. Late February-early March _ Communist Party Central Committee meets to consider new party rules, including a switch to the election of delegates for a national party congress by all 20 million party members, rather than the current process dominated by party bureaucrats. Early March-late June _ Election of delegates to party congress. Late June-early July _ Party congress. Formal adoption of platform approved Wednesday by the policy-making Central Committee, election of new Central Committee, new party chairman and two deputies. Pravda editor and Central Committee member Ivan T. Frolov said Thursday many details are being left up to the Supreme Soviet, including the timetable for enacting the political reforms and the scheduling of a nationwide presidential election.

DOC.HEAD: Stallings' Associate Asks To Rejoin Catholic Church
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS last graf to add time element.
DOC.TEXT: A priest who had joined the Rev. George A. Stallings Jr. in the new African-American congregation that caused his excommunication is asking for reinstatement with the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington. The Rev. Bruce E. Greening told parishoners earlier this week that Stallings had asked him to resign from the Imani Temple over failure to support Stallings' public statements about separating from the Roman Catholic Church. Stallings, himself a Catholic priest, has been excommunicated, and the archdiocese has said that Catholics who follow him will receive the same treatment. Greening, who was the first priest to join Stallings last summer, sent a letter to Cardinal James A. Hickey, the Washington archbishop, saying he wants to ``remain in communion with the church'' and open a ``dialogue'' leading to reunification. ``Father Greening's letter was received today and is being carefully studied. Every avenue of reconciliation consistent with the faith and practice of the Catholic Church will be pursued,'' said a statement released Thursday night by archdiocese spokeswoman Eileen Marx.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Defends Social Security Tax Cut; Wins Little Support
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan says his plan to cut Social Security taxes would neither endanger retirement benefits nor worsen the federal deficit, but he apparently is winning little support for the plan. ``The tax rates in the bill will fully finance benefits and maintain a safe reserve fund for 20 years longer than the current arrangement,'' Moynihan, D-N.Y., said in defending his plan before the Senate Finance Committee. ``This point is conceded by all but those who favor the politics of fear,'' he said Thursday. President Bush and his advisers have argued against a Social Security tax cut on grounds it likely would lead to an increase in other taxes and jeopardize benefits for future retirees. There was little show of support at the hearing for Moynihan's bill. It was criticized by White House Budget Director Richard G. Darman; by Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office; by four of five non-government economists who testified, and by committee Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. Bentsen said he sees no way the government can afford to increase the budget deficit by the $38 billion to $55 billion that the tax cut would cost. Moynihan uses the lower figure; Darman, the higher. That $38 billion is ``no great sum to make up,'' Moynihan said, adding that most of it could be found by cutting the defense budget. ``The real point, of course, is that there are lots of ways to reduce the deficit, but the Social Security tax is not the right way,'' Moynihan said. ``By what right and for how long do we continue to make the budget deficit the peculiar burden of people who get paid by the hour?'' Moynihan wants to cut Social Security taxes so the government will no longer be able to use surplus collections to make the deficit in other federal accounts appear considerably smaller than it is. The surplus, which now is growing by about $1 billion a week, is being accumulated for the benefit of workers in the post-World War II generation who will be retiring in large numbers starting in about 2010. Reischauer, who is Congress' chief economist, said a Social Security tax cut without offsetting tax increases or spending cuts could worsen inflation and ``could harm the economy's performance over the next several years.'' Regardless of what happens to Moynihan's bill, Reischauer added, ``A permanent increase in taxes or reductions in other federal programs appears to be a certainty (in the future), since the retirement of the (post-World War II) baby boom will mark the beginning of a permanent increase in the ratio of retirees to workers.'' Darman said the bill would either seriously damage attempts to cut the federal deficit or cause an increase in income taxes or other taxes. Raising other taxes ``would hurt the very workers Senator Moynihan's proposal is ostensibly intended to help,'' Darman said. ``Indeed, it would hurt them doubly: first, by jeopardizing their future retirement benefits and second, by taking back in new taxes what it pretended to give in the way of a tax cut.'' Darman said the Bush administration agrees with Moynihan that the government should stop using surplus Social Security taxes to hide the size of the federal deficit. But the answer, he said, is the administration's proposal, which, starting gradually in 1993, would require that surplus Social Security taxes be used only to pay off federal debt. A worker now pays a 7.65 percent Social Security tax on the first $51,300 earned each year and the employer matches the payment. Moynihan's bill would repeal a rate increase that went into effect Jan. 1, restoring the rate to 7.51 percent, and cut it again next year to 6.55 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Billy Idol won't be feeling too lonely in his recovery from a motorcycle crash. His fans have seen to that. ``The tidal wave of mail has started,'' said Ron Wise, spokesman for Cedars-Sinai Medical Center. ``His room is starting to look like a flower shop.'' Idol's condition was upgraded from serious to fair Thursday after seven hours of surgery for compound fractures to his right leg and a broken right forearm. He allegedly ran a stop sign Tuesday and sideswiped a car, police said. Idol, 34, will probably stay at the hospital for two weeks, Wise said. It was unclear whether he'll be able to go ahead as scheduled with his role in Oliver Stone's movie about Jim Morrison, the lead singer of the Doors rock band. The movie was to begin shooting in five weeks. Idol is cast as Morrison's best friend, Tom Baker. Idol, known for his sneer and spiked blond hair, reached stardom with his 1984 album ``Rebel Yell.'' His first album in three years, ``Charmed Life,'' will be released April 17, his publicist Ellen Golden said.

For Olympic swimmers Tracy Caulkins and Mark Stockwell, the 1984 Games wasn't all competition. It also was the start of a romance. The two announced their engagement at Wednesday's opening of a pool named after Caulkins. ``At the Olympics, I actually had my eye on Tracy's roommate,'' confessed Stockwell, 26. ``It wasn't until a recruiting trip to the University of Florida that I realized she was a pretty neat lady.'' Caulkins went to school at Florida. They plan to wed in April 1991. Caulkins, 27, won three gold medals at the 1984 Games. Stockwell, who swam for the Australian team, won two silver medals and one bronze. Caulkins has retired as a competitive swimmer and is now an aide to Mayor Bill Boner. Stockwell said he hopes to compete in the 1992 Olympics.

Entertainer Johnny Cash, in pain from a dental operation, left midway through a taping of a television program and will undergo oral surgery, a spokesman said. Cash left the Grand Ole Opry House on Wednesday night three hours into the 4{-hour show being taped for cable television's The Nashville Network. Spokesman Hugh Waddell said Cash, 57, went to Baptist Hospital where doctors determined he needed further treatment. The surgery was scheduled for today. ``He said the pain was just terrible,'' Waddell said Thursday. The taping was finished without Cash, known for his records ``A Boy Named Sue'' and ``I Walk the Line.'' The show, a tribute to veteran country music broadcaster Ralph Emery, will be broadcast March 8.

Maynard H. Jackson III, the mayor's son, was arrested on traffic charges for the second time in a month. Jackson, 19, was stopped in Atlanta on Wednesday and charged with driving without a license and improper lane changes. Police spokeswoman Sandra Blount said Jackson was charged and released. A Feb. 21 court date was set. On Jan. 9, he was charged with possession of less than an ounce of marijuana and following a vehicle too closely after an accident in which his car struck the rear of another vehicle. He was fined $150 after pleading no contest to the drug charge; a judge found him guilty of the traffic charge and fined him $60. Mayor Maynard Jackson, in a statement issued then, said he had ordered that his son be shown no special treatment.

William Reid, founder of the band The Jesus and Mary Chain, said mum's the word onstage _ unless he's singing. ``When you make a record, you don't introduce the songs. ... It would break the spell,'' he said. ``Playing onstage is kind of magical, and when people stand up there and start saying things, it breaks the spell. ``If I go see a group, I want to see them playing as hard and as good as they can. I want the music to be one intense, long flow. I don't want people to talk to me.'' Reid said he has only broken his rule of onstage silence one time in five years _ and that was because he was drunk. ``I was abusing them. I was insulting them,'' he said. ``... The next day I was embarrassed. I regretted it.'' The Scottish band, scheduled to appear in Dallas today, is touring after it latest release, ``Automatic.''

Folk-country singer Robert Earl Keen Jr., who weaves tales of Texas in his songs, said Nashville's fast track wasn't for him. ``There was no place to play,'' said Keen, who moved to Music City in 1985 and stayed two years before returning to Texas. ``If you need to practice, there's a 100 percent chance that a lot of people are going to see you and they're going to form an opinion. When you see them in a business situation, they've already got this notion, no matter what you say.'' Keen, 34, said it also was tough because while he struggled in Nashville, his buddies Steve Earle and Lyle Lovitt made it big. ``There were so many doors open for these people I know, and there were no doors open for me,'' Keen said. Keen's latest album, ``West Textures,'' is getting good reviews around the country.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Criticizes Price Support Proposal
DOC.TEXT: Wheat farmers would be in serious trouble if the Bush administration's proposals for flexibility in the 1990 farm bill were accepted by Congress, says a wheat state congressman. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., told an Agriculture Department official at a hearing Thursday that farm income in his district would decrease under the administration plan unveiled this week. Later, English predicted that any region where agriculture depends on one crop would be in trouble under the proposal. ``I don't think most members of Congress would feel comfortable with the proposals set forth,'' English said after a hearing of the House Agriculture subcommittee on wheat, soybeans and feed grains. ``It reminds me of the budget proposal. It's almost as if they aren't trying to put forth serious proposals.'' At the hearing, English asked Agriculture Undersecretary John Campbell to explain how the administration's proposal to allow planting options under the price support system would protect farmers confined by climate and terrain to one crop from losing their share of the market. ``Farmers are pretty sharp,'' said Campbell. ``They will respond where appropriate.'' English asked Campbell to say hypothetically which commodity would be best to grow next year if the administration's proposal for flexibility were in force. ``That's up to the farmer,'' said Campbell. He would not elaborate further, saying instead that it would be better for farmers to guess about market changes than about congressional action on farm programs. English said in an interview after the hearing that he considered Campbell's responses an ``abdication of the administration's responsibility.'' In the proposals Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter sent to Congress on Tuesday, the administration is suggesting that farmers be allowed to substitute crops that are covered by subsidy programs if they see marketplace advantages to doing so. In order to assure that farmers will plant commodities consumers need, the government sets price levels for certain products. If the market price is below those levels, known as target prices, the government makes up the difference. The commodities that are subsidized this way are wheat, corn, cotton, rice, soybeans, barley, grain sorghum and oats. The administration's proposals intend to allow farmers to respond to market demands rather than government planting requirements, while still having the shelter of government subsidies. The problem, as English and other see it, is avoiding overplanting of certain crops. The congressman said he was particularly concerned about wheat producers. ``Wheat in the past has been the most vulnerable because of the kind of program we have and because you can grow it in any part of the country,'' he said. He said there's a temptation for farmers to start producing wheat if given the option. ``Usually it is followed by a sharp reduction in price and a surplus,'' he said. ``That means we are back in these wild gyrations as far as price is concerned.'' English said he expected Congress to pass legislation that provides some flexibility. ``Flexibility is something that people talk about, but no one seems to know what it means,'' he said. English said he believes Yeutter's involvement with the international trade talks known as GATT has much to do with the administration's refusal to be specific about price supports. Many countries subsidize their exports to a greater degree than the United States and Yeutter is trying to get them to stop the practice. The negotiations will continue through this year.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats to Press Ahead With Own 1991 Budget
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are working on their own 1991 budget that would launch new education and other domestic initiatives while shrinking President Bush's defense proposal by at least $4 billion to $7 billion. But Republicans predict their Democratic rivals will be unable to piece together a spending plan and move it through Congress without GOP support. Just 10 days after Bush unveiled his $1.23 trillion spending blueprint for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1, Congress' majority Democrats said they will write an alternate plan to meet the $64 billion deficit target. ``First we're going to see if we can piece together a budget resolution,'' House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said Thursday. ``If we can do that in a way that we'll have the votes to get the budget resolution passed, there won't be much reason to go ahead with'' negotiations with the Bush administration. But Rep. Bill Frenzel of Minnesota, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said he doubted the Democrats could craft a budget including all the programs they seek without adding new taxes, ``and they don't want to be the ones leading the way on that.'' ``My guess is after internal discussions, they'll decide to request negotiations with the administration,'' Frenzel said. The Democrats' fervor was illustrated when Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations defense subcommittee, brandished a mock Viking battle ax during a visit to the panel by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Murtha said members of both parties are looking for a ``peace dividend'' in the budget, reflecting possible military savings in response to the reduced Soviet threat. Democrats pressed their offensive on other fronts as well. At the Joint Economic Committee, Chairman Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., challenged Bush's claim of having submitted a budget that met his campaign pledge of ``no new taxes.'' ``In the budget, you submitted 33 revenue changes and 20 of them raise revenue, totaling an increase of $13.9 billion,'' Hamilton told Bush's chief economic adviser, Michael Boskin. Boskin argued there were only minor tax increases and that most of the receipts would come from new and higher fees for government services. Elsewhere, House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., accused the administration of using strategic arms talks with the Soviets to win permission to deploy weapons Congress does not want, including nuclear missiles and the B-2 stealth bomber. Liberal Democrats have been complaining that Bush should have cut far deeper than his $303.3 billion defense proposal for next year. That figure is $7 billion higher than this year's total, but $3.2 billion below the amount needed to stay even with inflation. Liberals would like to see defense spending drop below $290 billion. But moderates such as Panetta say they believe the figure will end up about $4 billion to $7 billion lower. Panetta's Senate counterpart, Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., has talked about military spending in the $291 billion to $296 billion range. Such figures would allow Democrats to avoid $13.9 billion in cuts Bush has proposed in programs such as the Medicare program for the elderly and handicapped, retirement payments to government workers and other benefit programs. To hit the $64 billion Gramm-Rudman target, Democrats say they will seek to raise the $21 billion Bush proposed in new tax receipts, user fees, sales of federal assets and other collections, while changing some of the components of that mix. Democrats believe enough room will be left in the budget for some new domestic initiatives, likely including education, child care, nutrition, health care and housing. Democrats still don't know what to do about a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the Social Security payroll tax. A team of top Democrats is trying to draft a party position on the proposal, which has one major problem: It would add $62 billion to the budget gap over the next two years.

DOC.HEAD: New Search in Probe of Bombings that Killed Judge, Lawyer
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents investigating a series of mail bombings in the South that killed a judge and a lawyer searched several sites in the Atlanta suburbs Thursday, the FBI said. Homes and vehicles were searched by agents carrying warrants issued by a federal magistrate, said FBI spokesman Charles Steinmetz in Washington. ``No arrests were made. Results of the searches are not being disclosed at this time,'' he said, refusing further comment. Agents in the community of Rex, in the south Atlanta suburbs, carried warrants naming Walter Leroy Moody Jr. and his wife, Susan McBride Moody, the New York Times reported in its Friday editions. Moody, 54, a self-employed editor and writing advisor, was convicted in 1972 of felony possession of an unregistered firearm in connection with a bomb that officials said was to be used in a failed extortion scheme, the Times said. Appeals of that conviction, the paper reported, have gone to the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, a target of the mail bombings in December. Killed were Judge Robert Vance of Mountain Brook, Ala., who sits on the 11th Circuit, and Savannah City Councilman and attorney Robert Robinson, who did work for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Two other bombs were intercepted, one mailed to the 11th Circuit in Atlanta and one to the NAACP in Jacksonville, Fla. A letter to a television station claimed responsibility for what appeared to be a white supremacist group, and expressed outrage over the rape of a white woman by a black man. There were similarities between the mail bombs and the bomb in the Moody case in 1972, the Times reported, quoting an official it didn't name. WSB-TV in Atlanta said its reporters at a house that was searched recognized the FBI, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and the Postal Service agents who had been working on the mail bombings. The station said the agents searched a residence and ``what appeared to be a makeshift base of operations behind a nearby church.'' The searches follow days of highly visible investigation in Enterprise, Ala. That probe there focused on Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, a salvage store owner and Brian Joseph Fleming, a print shop owner. Authorities said a typewritten letter O'Ferrell sent in connection with a civil lawsuit matched typewriting in a letter claiming responsibility for the bombs. O'Ferrell said that he apparently sold the typewriter from his salvage store and denied having anything to do with the bombings.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Fears Ex-Communists Could Head New Interim Government
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders say they fear the outgoing National Salvation Front will put former ranking Communist leaders in control of a new government that is to run the country until elections in May. The new Council of National Unity, which holds its inaugural meeting today, is to give 29 opposition parties a chance to participate in government. It will be the first real opposition role since the Communist takeover in 1947. But Valentin Gabrielescu, spokesman for the National Peasants Party, told reporters Thursday that he believed the front's outgoing seven-member ruling council may try to control the new 180-member Unity Council. Gabrielescu said the front may also try to pack the new government with former ranking members of the now-defunct Communist Party, which caved in with the overthrow and execution of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu in December. ``They can be former Communists, but not big game _ not the aristocracy of the party,'' he said. The 150-member National Salvation Front took power after the popular revolution that toppled Ceausescu. The front lost four members of its original 11-member council in the last three weeks, including two who complained of dictatorial methods. The front agreed to give up its monopoly on power last week after large demonstrations against it. The protests were prompted by the front's decision to participate in the May 20 election, despite an earlier pledge not to run. Students, who were in the forefront of the revolution, and opposition parties said the front could not be both a player and a referee in the election. Under the agreement, the front left its ruling council to run the country until the Council of National Unity started operating, and split off its political wing to run in the election. The new interim government will have 90 representatives from the front and 29 political parties, each with three seats, and 90 prominent Romanians from all walks of life not formally representing any parties. Dan Radulescu, the chief front spokesman, served notice that the front intended to try for at least some of the non-party seats. He also said he expected interim President Ion Iliescu to head the government, and ``if he isn't elected, I don't know who will lead the council.'' Gabrielescu signaled opposition to Iliescu, a former Communist, however, saying: ``Maybe he will be a candidate, but we are against it.'' Also Thursday, the minister of religion said it will take years to undo the moral damage caused by more than four decades of Communism, which he said turned Romania into a nation of ``liars and thieves.'' Nicolae Stoicescu, a former dissident and professor of medieval history, said that under Ceausescu's 24-year tenure, the Romanian Orthodox Church was ``under the direct control and supervision of Securitate,'' the dictator's feared secret police. Stoicescu said the church has ``a major role to play in rehabilitating the Romanian spirit'' and correcting damage caused by decades of Communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: China, Soviet Union Open Talks On Border Troops
DOC.TEXT: China and the Soviet Union today began a second round of talks aimed at reducing forces along their 4,300-mile border, patrolled by hundreds of thousands of troops on each side. The Soviet Embassy said the talks on cutting military forces and armaments along the frontier will continue until Feb. 22. The official Xinhua News Agency, reporting on the opening of the talks, said the two sides ``commented positively on the first round of talks held in Moscow last November and expressed readiness to make further efforts to reduce the military forces in the border area to the minimum level corresponding to their normal and good-neighborly relations.'' An embassy official said the Soviet delegation is led by G.V. Kireev, chief of the Foreign Ministry department for socialist countries in Asia, and consists of six diplomats and six military experts. The two sides agreed to open talks on troop levels along the frontier when Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev visited Beijing in May. Gorbachev said the frontier should be turned into a ``border of peace'' and pledged to withdraw 12 divisions, or 120,000 soldiers, from the border by the end of this year. The Soviet Union is believed to have some 600,000 troops along the Chinese border. China, armed with less sophisticated equipment, has an estimated 1 million troops on the frontier. The two sides are also expected to discuss the concept of creating a demilitarized zone along the border proposed when Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze visited China a year ago. The two Communist powers fought a brief border war in 1969 and there have been sporadic clashes since then around disputed areas of the frontier. Tensions have gradually eased as the two sides moved to normalize diplomatic relations in recent years, and cross-border trade has grown rapidly.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Facing '90 Vote Build War Chests; Gramm of Texas The Money Kingpin
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen of the 31 senators up for re-election in November are starting the year with at least $1 million on hand, with most getting considerable help from political action committees, according to an analysis released today. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Tex, was the fund-raising kingpin, raising $10.5 million since his last election in 1984 and beginning this year with $6.1 million in his campaign coffers, Common Cause said in a report based on recent Federal Election Commission filings. The poorest of the 31 was Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., who has raised just $90,860 since the 1984 election and began 1990 with $157,817 in campaign funds. Common Cause, which has been lobbying for changes to substantially curtail PAC activity, said 25 of the 31 senators facing re-election this year have exceeded limits that would be placed on PAC donations in a campaign finance bill the group supports. Of the 14 senators who began the year with more than $1 million, Democrat David Boren of Oklahoma was the only one who has not accepted any PAC donations. Of all 31, only Boren and Democrat John Kerry of Massachusetts _ who had $874,000 in campaign funds as of Dec. 31 _ accepted no PAC contributions. Of the 29 whose campaigns took PAC money, Gramm was also the leader, receiving $1.1 million from PACs in the last six years, according to Common Cause. Illinois Democrat Paul Simon was not far behind, reporting $976,769 in PAC contributions since the 1984 election. Kassebaum was again at the bottom of the list, accepting $19,250 from PACs since 1984. The only senator remotely close to Gramm in terms of cash on hand to begin the election year was Bill Bradley, D-N.J., who reported having $4.1 million. Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, was next with $2.8 million. Democrat Max Baucus of Montana had just more than $1 million. Gramm, considered by some a potential Republican presidential candidate in 1996, raised nearly $6 million in 1989, with most of that coming from a fund-raiser at the Houston Astrodome attended by President Bush. Bradley's active fund raising despite his virtually certain re-election has increased speculation he is considering challenging Bush in 1992 or at least mulling a 1996 presidential bid. Common Cause complains the high-powered fund raising by incumbents, many of whom face little or no opposition, can scare off potential challengers because of their ability to raise huge donations from PACs. In releasing its analysis, Common Cause President Fred Wertheimer renewed his call for Congress to quickly enact new laws limiting PAC donations and setting campaign spending limits. Common Cause said the 31 senators together raised $77.4 million since all but one last faced election six years ago, with $16.6 million of that total coming from PACs. The only senator in the group not involved in a 1984 Senate election was Republican Dan Coats of Indiana, who 13 months ago was appointed to replace Vice President Dan Quayle in the Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Five Permanent Security Council Members to Open Cambodia Talks on Sunday
DOC.TEXT: The five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council will open talks Sunday on efforts to enhance the world body's role in Cambodia peace efforts, a U.S. spokesman said. During the scheduled two-day session in New York, representatives of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China will discuss a plan for the United Nations to administer Cambodia and supervise elections there while international peacekeepers guarantee security. The full 15-member Security Council would have to approve the plan to clear the way for a heightened U.N. role in the Cambodia peace process. Arthur Zegelbone, spokesman for the U.S. Mission to the United Nations, said Thursday that the five countries will be represented at the New York meeting by officials on the assistant secretary level. The five countries agreed on the peace formula for Cambodia during a January meeting in Paris. In addition to seeking U.N. administration of Cambodia and supervision of elections, the peace plan calls for an ``effective U.N. presence'' to ensure internal security for an unspecified transition period before the voting. The Vietnamese-backed government of Cambodian Premier Hun Sen and the three allied guerrilla factions all have given at least cautious support for a major U.N. role. The five countries said the complete withdrawal of foreign forces must be verified by U.N. observers. Last September, Vietnam announced plans to withdraw its troops from Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Response to Soviet Reforms Aims at `Stability'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush claims no regrets over his restrained response to the historic political reforms in the Soviet Union and says he hopes both Moscow and U.S. allies see it as a ``stabilizing sign.'' Bush denied that his emphasizing of defense issues during his three days on the road _ coinciding with Moscow's dramatic moves toward a more democratic form of government _ was a matter of bad timing. ``I think it's fortuitous,'' Bush told reporters traveling home with him aboard Air Force One. The president was back in the nation's capital after a three-day Western trip that focused on defense policy, including his call for continued modernization of U.S. strategic weapons systems. He watched Army war games in the Mojave desert, toured the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory near San Francisco for an update on Star Wars research and toured the Strategic Air Command headquarters in Omaha, Neb. At SAC headquarters, Bush on Thursday broadcast a message to nuclear-carrying U.S. forces, telling them ``the historical changes we are seeing in the Soviet Union are in no small part due to'' U.S. nuclear deterrence.
