He told reporters aboard Air Force One later Thursday that he didn't think his assertiveness on national policy was out of sync with developments in Moscow ``because it sends a clear message that I am behind a sensible defense program and I'll stay behind it.'' ``So I hope that message comes through in a balanced way that we are not going to suddenly, drastically change our course away from a reasonable defense program,'' Bush said. ``So I think the message is one of stability, of reasonableness,'' he added. ``I'm not going to miss an opportunity in arms control, but we're going to keep a strong defense.'' Bush said he was trying to send a ``stabilizing message, not a militant message.'' ``And that's why I think the timing happened to be fortuitous, because we had planned this trip before the Central Committee meeting but it worked out, in my view, very well.'' He said he wanted Western European allies to know that the United States was not about abandon them or ``decouple'' from Europe. ``As long as I'm president, it won't take place,'' Bush said. In remarks at a Republican fund-raising dinner in Columbus, Ohio, Thursday night _ his last stop _ Bush praised party leaders in Moscow for taking ``the first step toward pluralism'' and a multi-party system.

DOC.HEAD: Waxman Wants Crackdown on Animal Rights `Terrorists'
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Henry Waxman wants federal law enforcers to treat animal rights groups that break into laboratories to make off with rabbits, monkeys and other creatures as ``terrorists, nothing but terrorists.'' Scientists told a congressional panel Thursday that extremist groups such as the underground Animal Liberation Front are creating a serious threat to university lab workers and researchers around the nation. The scientists told Waxman's Energy and Commerce subcommittee on health and the environment that they have faced arson, burglary, vandalism, theft and hate mail from such groups. Waxman, D-Calif., is proposing legislation to allow federal investigation and prosecution of people who break into and commit other crimes at laboratories receiving federal funds. He said members of the underground animal rights movement are ``terrorists, nothing but terrorists.'' The Department of Health and Human Services originally supported Waxman's measure but the Bush administration has since said it is opposed to it because of Justice Department concerns that it will be difficult to enforce, according to Dr. James O. Mason, assistant secretary for health. The anti-abortion National Right to Life Committee Inc. has joined other critics who say the bill would inhibit constitutionally protected forms of protest. Robert F. Phalen, a laboratory director at the University of California in Irvine medical school, said dogs he was using for air pollution research were stolen in January 1988 and his family was later harassed. ``In one case a caller harangued my 15-year-old son, saying that his father was `evil' and would `burn in hell,''' Phalen said. ``We always kept our doors locked, we left external lights on, we covered our phones at night with pillows, and we slept with weapons near all of our beds,'' he recalled. But the most serious threat, the scientists said, is that students are turning away from animal-related research out of fear. Animal rights groups, many of which dissociate themselves from illegal tactics beyond civil disobedience, say most of the research is needlessly cruel and could be duplicated by other, more humane means.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0413 to fix category code.
Charge Woman With Killing Lover's Wife in `Fatal-Attraction' Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: To most, Carolyn Warmus is a bright, energetic schoolteacher. To police, she is an obsessed woman who pumped nine shots into her lover's wife, then met the man for drinks and sex. It took a year of intense legwork by two detectives to put together the case that made a murder suspect out of the 26-year-old computer science teacher and insurance heiress. Warmus was charged with second-degree murder Monday. Police said she shot Betty Jeanne Solomon, 40, nine times on Jan. 15, 1989, then drove to a local hotel to meet her lover, fellow schoolteacher Paul Solomon, for drinks and a sexual tryst in her car. Her attorney, Charles Fiore, maintains his client is innocent. He said Thursday that she passed a polygraph test taken on the advice of her family attorney five days after the slaying. Warmus was not the initial suspect in the killing. Solomon was. ``You can compare it to a large puzzle with many, many pieces,'' said Lt. Cornelius Sullivan, head of detectives in Greenburgh, a New York City suburb near White Plains. Police would not say when their focus shifted to Warmus, daughter of a wealthy Michigan insurance executive, but a vacation trip to Puerto Rico five months after the killing may have been key in highlighting Warmus' alleged obsession with the dead woman's husband. Police said Solomon, 39, told investigators that Warmus followed him and a friend, Barbara Ballor, 28, to Puerto Rico. Once there, they said, she called a member of Ballor's family pretending to be a police officer and made disparaging comments about Solomon in an apparent effort to break the couple up. Police traced the call back to Warmus. Investigators then focused on other telephone records. The paper trail led them to Vincent Parco, a private investigator in New York City who told police he sold Warmus a silencer and a .25-caliber handgun, the same type of weapon used to kill Mrs. Solomon. Police say they linked the weapon that Parco sold to the killing through ballistics evidence, but did not elaborate. The weapon has not been recovered. On Thursday, Parco's New York City pistol permit was suspended and Parco agreed to give police his weapons, said city police spokesman Detective Joseph McConville. Law enforcement sources said Warmus knew Parco because she had hired him before to investigate an ex-boyfriend, a married bartender who lived in New Jersey. Police said Warmus, who lives in a high-rise on Manhattan's East Side, told Parco she needed the gun for protection, but Parco's ex-partner, Gabe Laura, told the New York Post she offered him three different reasons. ``We figured her for a flake,'' Laura said, adding, ``We told her to get us some proof about what she was saying and sent her away.'' Warmus and Solomon had been having an affair for a year, according to an indictment unsealed Monday. They met in 1987 at an elementary school in Greenburgh. At the time of Mrs. Solomon's murder, police said, Warmus wanted to intensify the relationship; Solomon wanted to cool things off. Investigators said he ended the affair after his wife's death. In her statement to police, Warmus said she called Solomon at home hours before the murder and they talked for 45 minutes about everything from his 15-year-old daughter Kristan's basketball team to a bar mitzvah he attended. They agreed to meet for drinks at a Yonkers hotel bar at 7:30 p.m. Mrs. Solomon was killed between 7 p.m. and 7:30 p.m., police said, adding that Warmus knew Mrs. Solomon would be home alone. Warmus told detectives they left the bar at 10:30 p.m., went out to her car in the parking lot and had sex before leaving each other about 11:30 p.m. Her attorney said Warmus frequently had dinner with the Solomon family at their home and that neighbors knew both her and her car. ``It would be a pretty good trick for her to knock on the door, kill her ... and leave and not be seen or have her car seen,'' Fiore said. Warmus' father is president of American Way Life Insurance Co. in Southfield, Mich., whose assets reportedly are about $150 million. She grew up in Birmingham, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Called Bias Incident
DOC.TEXT: A house recently purchased by a black man was set afire in what authorities are calling a racially motivated incident. The two-family building's previous owner, a white woman, received several telephoned threats about her planned sale of the house to the black man, said Fire Department spokesman John Mulligan. The house is in the borough of Brooklyn's Canarsie neighborhood. No one was injured in Thursday's early morning fire. No arrests have been made. Mulligan said the first-floor tenants heard someone walking up the building stairs and then a window breaking. The vacant second-floor apartment in the house, where former owner Ellen Levy lived until the sale, was torched, Mulligan said. Fire marshals determined an accelerant was poured through the broken window and ignited. Firefighters limited the fire to one room.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Joins Lawsuit Against Oil Companies
DOC.TEXT: Illinois has joined a lawsuit filed by ethanol producers that accuses nine oil companies of running ads that discourage the use of ethanol-blended gasoline. Attorney General Neil Hartigan said at a news conference Thursday he filed an antitrust action with the U.S. District Court in Danville that seeks a halt to the ad campaign and fines of $1.8 million on the oil companies. The oil companies are accused of using ads such as ``My Gas Contains No Alcohol'' and ``My Station Sells Clean Gas'' to imply that ethanol-blended gasoline is unsafe and pollutes. Ethanol, a form of alcohol often distilled from corn, helps Illinois corn growers and improves the environment because its combustion produces less carbon monoxide than gasoline, Hartigan said. Gasoline blended with ethanol also lowers fuel prices, he said. In 1988, 11 ethanol producers sued the oil companies in five states. Two of the companies that sued, Greater Rockford Energy and Technology Co. and CEPO Inc. of Batavia, were forced out of business in 1986, Hartigan said. ``This is nothing more than a consumer fraud perpetrated on an unsuspecting public,'' said Hartigan. ``Illinois may have lost millions of dollars in the last 10 years through higher fuel prices and lost economic development opportunities. Through this action, perhaps we can begin reaping the benefits of a truly fair competitive environment,'' he said. A spokesman for one of the companies, Amoco Oil Co., declined to comment on Hartigan's action, but criticized the lawsuit. ``We feel it's without merit,'' said Mike Thompson. ``We expect to contest it vigorously, and we expect to win.'' Also named in the lawsuit were Shell Oil Co.; Exxon Co., USA; Mobil Corp.; Marathon Petroleum Co.; Chevron U.S.A. Inc.; Atlantic Richfield Co.; Citgo Petroleum Corp.; and B.P. America.

DOC.HEAD: Timber Dealer Denies Conspiracy to Export Federal Logs Illegally
DOC.TEXT: A timber dealer accused of illegally exporting federal logs admitted that he sold the timber to Japan, but said he didn't know the wood had been cut from national forests. ``They were not marked as Forest Service logs,'' John J. Tortorelli of Bellevue, Wash., told a federal court jury on Thursday. Tortorelli and his co-defendant, Winston Bentley of Spokane, Wash., each denied that they conspired to export federal logs illegally to Japan two years ago. ``I never entered into any such agreement, I never conspired to, I never even thought about it,'' Bentley said. Federal law forbids the export of raw logs cut from national forests, intending the logs to be processed in U.S. mills. Raw logs, or unprocessed timber, fetch a higher price than finished lumber on the export market. Federal officials have said this case may be the first time anyone has been prosecuted for violating the export ban, which is designed to protect American jobs in mills. The concern over exports has been heightened by timber shortages blamed for layoffs and sawmill closures. If convicted, the defendants each could be sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $20,000. Tortorelli is accused of arranging to buy about 160 truckloads of logs from sawmills and independent loggers in northwest Montana, north Idaho and eastern Washington in 1987 and 1988, then exporting those logs while knowing they had been cut from federal forests. Prosecutors say Bentley assisted with some sale arrangements and routed some timber through a yard in Mead, Wash. Assistant U.S. Attorney Robert Brooks asked Tortorelli why he told a truck driver picking up the some of the logs to say they would be processed in a domestic mill. Tortorelli said if a buyer reveals that he is exporting the logs, the seller automatically wants a much higher price. In testimony earlier this week, several loggers and sawmill operators who sold logs to Tortorelli said they told him the logs had been cut from national forests. Others said some of the logs were marked with paint or U.S. Forest Service brands. Tortorelli testified that he could not recall being told that the logs were cut from federal forests, and that he dealt with many different buyers and sellers that handled private and federal timber. Cross-examination of Tortorelli was to resume today. Final arguments in the trial were scheduled for Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,288.14, down 228.10 points or 0.61 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Waiting for Big Freeze Following Spring in January
DOC.TEXT: The rising temperatures that turned the December freeze into a January-February thaw are bound to end as soon as frigid air in the far north builds enough muscle, says the Agriculture Department's weatherman. ``The question at this point is exactly when and where the dike will break,'' said Norton D. Strommen, chief meteorologist for the department's World Agricultural Outlook Board. Meanwhile, although most Americans enjoy the midwinter warmth, many farmers are apprehensive. ``It reduces winter hardiness of the winter wheat crop,'' Strommen said Thursday in an interview. ``It promotes the early development of fruit buds, and while we can benefit from the early growth of pastures ... it does set us up for frost-related problems.'' He also said ``very limited soil moisture supplies'' are being drawn on earlier than usual by the spring-like warmth and the growth of pastures and winter wheat. The Joint Agricultural Weather Facility operated by USDA and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported this week that last month ranked as ``the nation's warmest January on record, following the fourth-coldest December.'' Precipitation in January varied greatly, showing ``a large contrast between the unusually wet South and the unusually dry West North Central region,'' the report said. For example, precipitation ratings showed Wyoming had the third driest January since 1895, while South Dakota had its sixth driest, and North Dakota had its eighth driest January. By contrast, Alabama, Louisiana, Mississippi and Oklahoma had one of the wettest Januarys since 1895. ``The last four months in the primary hard red winter wheat region in the central and southern plains have been extraordinarily dry,'' the report said. ``Combined October-January precipitation across this region ranks 1989-90 as the seventh driest such period on record.'' But Strommen said there are some benefits to the warmer weather, notably for livestock producers whose feeding and watering labors have been eased. Cattle and hogs gain weight better, and there is minimal death losses from midwinter cold. ``In December, almost all the feed energy (consumed by animals) went to maintaining weights,'' he said. The January thaw ``took all that stress off that they had in December.'' For weeks, dominant high-altitude currents from the Pacific have flowed across the northern part of the United States, acting as a fence, or dike, against the savagely colder arctic air normally flowing down from Canada. ``They're really holding in a building quantity of arctic air up over the pole,'' Strommen said. ``Eventually, we've got to tap and release that cold air.''

Federal support prices for wool marketed in 1990 has been set by the Agriculture Department at $1.82 per pound, up five cents from last year. Mohair clipped from goats will be supported at $4.532 per pound, down from $4.588 in 1989, according to the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. In a related report, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said U.S. inventory of sheep and lambs on Jan. 1 was estimated at 11.4 million head, up 5 percent from a year ago. The value of the U.S. flock was estimated $998 million, up 11 percent, reflecting an increase of 6 percent in the average value per head to $87.80. The 1989 lamb crop was put at 7.74 million, up 7 percent from 1988. The lambing rate increased to 108 per 100 ewes, compared with 98 in 1988. Inventories of Angora goats were estimated at 1.9 million head, up about 3 percent from Jan. 1, 1989. Their value, at $117 million, was up 9 percent.

The value of catfish production last year dropped 4 percent to an estimated $273 million, according to an annual report by the Agriculture Department. Sales of stockers, fingerlings and fry from hatcheries rose 30 percent to $23.3 million, the report said. But sales of food-size fish from farm operations dropped 6 percent to $250 million. The report said sales to processors accounted for 90 percent of the total sales of food-size catfish. As of Jan. 1, the number of catfish growing operations declined 1 percent from midyear to 1,614 operations. Hatcheries dropped 6 percent to 562. Alabama led in the number of catfish farms as of Jan. 1 with 325, followed by Mississippi, 302; Arkansas, 189; Louisiana, 170; and Missouri, 150.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Trial Stays in U.S., Battle Over Secrets Looms
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge's ruling that U.S. courts have jurisdiction over Manuel Noriega's drug case has opened the way for the next battle: defense efforts to win access to government secrets. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler's ruling came at a status conference Thursday, the first time Noriega and his five co-defendants appeared together. Though the new Panamanian government has stripped him of his military rank, Noriega wore his four-star general's uniform. Hoeveler ordered the case to proceed after rejecting defense arguments that Noriega, as a prisoner of war, must be transferred to his homeland or a third country until an international tribunal determines his status under the Geneva Convention. ``This court does have jurisdiction to proceed,'' Hoeveler said, ``and we will.'' William Bryson, U.S. deputy solicitor general, argued the judge has jurisdiction even though the government agreed to Noriega's POW status. Defense attorney Frank Rubino strongly dissented, saying the government was trying to stretch the Geneva Convention to justify what he described as the illegal invasion of Panama and detention of Noriega. After the hearing, Rubino said he planned to ask the U.S. Supreme Court to free Noriega. Hoeveler agreed to rule in the next two weeks on an issue both sides agree is central to the case _ how U.S. government secrets relating to Noriega must be handled. Part of the expected defense strategy is to try to introduce material documenting links between the deposed Panamanian leader and the CIA and other intelligence agencies. ``We believe a tremendous amount of exculpatory material is hidden in agencies that the government maintains,'' said Noriega attorney David Lewis, a New York-based expert on the Classified Information Protection Act. ``We want to be able to go forward, and we don't want the government to restrict that,'' Lewis said. Assistant U.S. Attorney James McAdams said he did not expect an avalanche of confidential documents. He said the defense was exaggerating the amount of material at issue. ``We conducted what we would call a very thorough and exhausting search,'' McAdams said. He estimated the secrecy issue could be settled by July. Lewis, calling the case a ``megatrial,'' said the government would need at least nine months to provide the information and for the defense to respond. With less time, he argued, the trial itself could be interrupted frequently by appeals over unresolved secrecy issues. ``To quote Tina Turner, `we can do it nice and easy, or we can do it nice and rough,''' Lewis told the judge, paraphrasing a line from the singer's version of ``Proud Mary.'' Because of the secrecy issues, all sides agreed that the March 5 trial date is unrealistic. Noriega's attorneys estimated they would need up to two years to be ready, while the prosecution said it could be go to trial by the end of the year. No new trial date was set. During the hearing, Noriega occasionally leaned over to talk to co-defendant Luis del Cid, who prosecutors say was one of his aides. Also attending were defendants Luis Saldarriaga, Daniel Miranda, Eduardo Pardo and the only one out on bond, Brian Alden Davidow, whose attorney is seeking a separate trial. Ten other defendants are still at large. In Tampa, Fla., meanwhile, more than $250,000 in drug profits traced to a Tampa-based smuggler who once described Noriega as his partner was doled out Thursday to law-enforcement agencies, U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman said at a news conference. The money came from assets forfeited by Steven Michael Kalish, a convicted drug runner who told a U.S. Senate subcommittee that Noriega agreed to let him launder as much as $100 million a month through Panama as long as Noriega got his cut. Kalish said he paid Noriega more than $1 million in bribes and agreed to pay him $3 million more. After his arrest, Kalish struck a deal for leniency with federal prosecutors. In a sentencing memorandum, U.S. attorneys said the 1988 drug indictment against Noriega wouldn't have been possible without Kalish's help.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Want Joint Hearings With Congress
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Soviet lawmakers are proposing unprecedented joint hearings with their American counterparts on reducing the danger of the unauthorized or accidental launch of nuclear weapons. The hearings were proposed by Yevgeni Velikhov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet's defense subcommittee, to Armed Services Chairman Les Aspin, D-Wis., according to the U.S. office of the International Foundation for the Survival and Development of Humanity. Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said Thursday that ``joint undertakings such as hearings between the two committees'' are being considered. But a spokesman said no decisions have been made on time, place or topic. Velikhov made his proposal both as chairman of the Supreme Soviet's defense panel and as chairman of the Moscow-based foundation. It was founded in 1988 with the aim of finding solutions to problems in such areas as international security, the environment and human rights. Thursday marked the beginning of a 12-day visit by members of the Soviet legislature's defense panel to U.S. military installations. Members of the House committee made a similar inspection tour of Soviet military bases last August. ``The Supreme Soviet is struggling to become a more independent legislature,'' Aspin said. ``Anything we can do to promote democratic values in the Soviet Union is in the U.S. national interest.'' Representatives of the International Foundation said Velikhov is asking the proposed joint hearings be based on a report written by members of the group's security committee. The report, ``Reducing the Dangers of Accidental and Unauthorized Nuclear Launch and Terrorist Attack: Alternatives to a Ballistic Missile Defense System,'' has been given to members of Congress and is to be released at a news conference here on Tuesday. The Soviet legislative panel is scheduled to visit the Los Alamos National Laboratories in New Mexico, the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, NORAD and Strategic Air Command Headquarters in Omaha, Neb., Minuteman Missile and B-1B bomber facilities, Army tank units, the F-16 fighter production plant at Fort Worth, Texas, and Navy Marine Corps and Air Force units on both coasts.

DOC.HEAD: Death of Old Forests Adds Greenhouse Gas to Atmosphere, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Felling old forests in the American Northwest may aggravate global warming by releasing millions of tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere, according to a study published today. Mark Harmon, a researcher at the Department of Forest Service at Oregon State University, said that even if new trees are planted to replace the old trees, there is still a net gain in atmospheric carbon dioxide from the demise of the ancient forest. ``The young forest simply doesn't store anywhere near as much carbon as the old forest,'' said Harmon, a finding he said is the opposite of the ``conventional wisdom.'' The scientist said more than half of the wood cut from old forests is burned or used in ways, such as paper making, that quickly puts carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. Also, large trees absorb carbon dioxide at about the same rate that decaying, dead tree parts on the forest floor give it off, a balance that new forests don't reach for more than two centuries. Harmon said he and his co-investigators studied the effects of old forest harvesting on the greenhouse effect because ``we've been concerned that decision-makers are going to make important policy decisions based on inaccurate, armchair ecology.'' Carbon dioxide and some other gases in the atmosphere act as a blanket to trap heat given off by the Earth. This is called the greenhouse effect. Some experts believe that a surplus of carbon dioxide is causing the Earth to slowly overheat, and they warn that such a change could disrupt the global climate. Many scientists, however, disagree that the planet is warming up. In a study published today in the journal Science, Harmon reports that old growth forests _ areas that have never been logged _ capture and store much larger amounts of carbon from the atmosphere than younger forests. He said many believe that the old trees aggravate the greenhouse effect because old forests are littered with dead branches, leaves and other material that decays and puts carbon dioxide into the atmosphere. But Harmon said a computer study shows that an old forest, with very large trees, actually reaches a ``carbon equilibrium'' that neither adds nor subtracts from the total carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. When the old trees are cut down, however, the forest litter continues to decay, giving off carbon. And Harmon said it takes new seedlings about 250 years to grow enough to reestablish the ``carbon equilibrium.'' Additionally, he said that only about 45 percent of the wood harvested from old forests is turned into lumber or other building materials that ``store'' carbon for long periods. Much of the material is burned, rots or is used for paper, all of which release carbon into the atmosphere within a short time. In the past century, Harmon said, about 18 billion metric tons of carbon have been released into the atmosphere from harvesting of about 17.5 million acres of old growth in western Oregon and Washington. Land use changes, such as ripping out old forests, contribute only a fraction of the carbon dioxide that comes from the burning of fossil fuels, the scientist said. But Harmon said that on a global basis, the loss of forest land can be significant. Harmon estimated that of the total carbon added to the atmosphere in the past century by land use change, 2 percent came from harvesting forests in Oregon and Washington, even though the area covers only .017 percent of the Earth's land surface. ``We have very poor records of land use change and how much carbon was in a forest before it was lost,'' said Harmon. ``As a result, these estimates have not been as precise as fossil fuel. So I wouldn't be surprised if the actual value is substantially larger than we estimated.'' The forest study was coauthored by Harmon and William K. Ferrell of Oregon State University, and Jerry F. Franklin of the University of Washington. Science is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir: From Bricks To Kalashnikovs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th pvs, `More than...' to RESTORE dropped word; picks up 9th pvs, `The killings...'
DOC.TEXT: Three years ago they threw stones at Indian security men. At the first sign of retaliation, they would run for cover and flee into the narrow lanes of Srinagar, waving clenched fists as a gesture of defiance. But today, Moslem militants campaigning for Kashmir's independence have graduated to Kalashnikov rifles and firebombs in battling an estimated 40,000 Indian soldiers in the strategic state. Intelligence reports say the militants, most of them in their 20s, have acquired rocket launchers and even U.S.-made Stinger missiles. ``India now faces the risk of fighting a prolonged guerrilla war in Kashmir,'' said a retired colonel of the Indian army. ``And like most other guerrilla war situations, the odds are in favor of the terrorists.'' He spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Over the years these terrorists have graduated into becoming real fighters, not in the conventional sense, but as guerrillas,'' said Jitendra Narain Saxena, the director-general of the Jammu-Kashmir's 40,000-member police force. ``Before the police could just scare them away. But today they stand up and try to defy,'' Saxena said. Saxena would not discuss the reasons for the change of mood in Kashmir, where analysts say India faces the toughest challenge to its unity in the country's 42 years of independence. More than 80 people have been killed in the wave of separatist violence that began Jan. 20 with the arrests of more than 250 people. The killings and open defiance by the militants triggered a panic in the adminstration. Curfew was imposed for days, the army was called out and foreign journalists expelled from the state. Curfew passes of local journalists were withdrawn and Indian journalists working for foreign media were confined to their hotel. Jammu-Kashmir, home of 6 million people, is India's only Moslem-majority state. Nationwide, Moslems account for about 11 percent of the country's 880 million people. But in the Kashmir valley, the stronghold of the militants, Moslems make up 94 percent of the 3.5 million people. Kashmir became part of the Mogul empire when Akbar invaded the area in 1586. The Afghans annexed it in 1756. The Sikhs came in 1819. A Hindu king took it over in 1846. When Britain divided the subcontinent in 1947 into Islamic Pakistan and Hindu-dominated India, Kashmir was given the choice to either remain independent or join either of the two nations. After initial hesitation, the king joined India and triggered a Pakistani armed invasion. A brief war followed and India claims that of the state's 88,894 square miles of territory, Pakistan is in ``illegal occupation'' of 31,572 square miles. New Delhi also alleges that Pakistan gave away 17,094 square miles of territory to China when Islamabad and Beijing signed a boundary agreement. Intelligence reports attribute the guerrillas' popularity to fear. But many, including some junior government officials and some Kashmir police, admit privately that even if they do not support the militants they do not oppose them either. ``In Kashmir today everyone, even a 10-year-old boy, is in favor of independence,'' said Maulvi Mohammad Farooq, the chief Moslem priest of Kashmir. ``If police actions are not stopped, I have to ask the people to join the armed struggle,'' the 45-year-old Farooq said in an interview at his fortified home in Srinagar. ``The entire population has risen as one man against Indian occupation,'' said politician Abdul Ghani Lone of the People's Conference Party. ``It looks as if the Indian government wants to create peace in Kashmir, but that peace will be the peace of the graveyard.'' Gov. Jagmohan ruled out any threat to India's sovereignty. ``The issue is very simple,'' he said in a interview at his home guarded by Indian troops manning light machine gun positions behind bunkers. ``There was lack of economic development, people are frustrated. ``Once we set things right, Kashmir will again become `Jannat' (heaven),'' said Jagmohan, who uses only one name. But the scene outside his home is different. Behind a graveyard in the old Srinagar district, 11-year-old Riaz Sheikh holds his toy Kalashnikov rifle and waits for his friends. Not to play, but to discuss how to become Moslem holy worriors. ``Before we played cricket, but now we talk about how to liberate Kashmir from India,'' said Riaz, whose brother, Hamid Sheikh, a top militant leader, was shot and wounded by the police. ``Why you want to talk to us?'' he asked. ``Can you give me a gun?''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Plan to Gather Statistics on `Hate Crimes'
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials would gather data on ``hate crimes'' motivated by race, religion, sexual orientation or ethnic roots under legislation that is moving towards approval in Congress. ``If we're going to curb crimes of hate, we need to know their extent,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said Thursday as the Senate approved the bill 92-4. The Senate shrugged off complaints from Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., that the measure ``fans the fires of the homosexual movement'' as it sent the bill back to the House, which has already approved a slightly different version. The Bush administration supports the measure and so chances are good that it will be signed into law this year. It also has support from civil rights, ethnic and police groups concerned over what has been portrayed as a rising tide of hate crimes. The bill would require the attorney general to keep statistics on crimes motivated by race, religion, sexual orientation and ethnicity. The data would become part of Justice Department uniform crime reports. Under the plan, the department would count murder, non-negligent manslaughter, forcible rape, aggravated assault, simple assault, intimidation, arson and destruction, damage or vandalism of property. The Justice Department said in a May 1988 report that accurate information about the number of crimes involving bias against groups is not available. ``These types of offenses are far more serious than comparable crimes that do not involve prejudice because they are intended to intimidate an entire group,'' the report said. Simon told the Senate there have been reports of ``a rising tide of hate crimes'' by neo-Nazi skinheads and other groups. But he said some observers also believe the problem is leveling off. Unofficial estimates of the cost of gathering the data have ranged from $1 $1 million to $10 million annually. The department says there would be little if any difficulty in making ``hate crimes'' part of the uniform crime reports. Urvashi Vaid, executive director of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, said after the vote that the ``Senate today sent a strong signal to the bigots and bashers that violence against lesbians and gay men is intolerable.'' The Human Rights Campaign Fund, which describes itself as the country's largest homosexual lobby, expressed surprise ``at the overwhelming support shown in the Senate.'' Helms blasted the bill as ``the flagship of the homosexual and lesbian legislative agenda,'' citing provisions that require data on crimes motivated by ``sexual orientation.'' Sponsors said all such crimes, including ones directed against homosexuals, should be included in the count. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, a leading supporter, said he did not condone homosexual behavior but that he always opposes violent crimes against individuals. ``They're human beings, too, and they ought to be treated like human beings,'' Hatch said. ``They're citizens of this country and they ought to be treated like citizens of this country.'' The Senate overwhelmingly rejected a Helms amendment to express the nonbinding sense that ``the homosexual movement threatens the strength and the survival of the American family as a basic unit of society'' and state sodomy laws ``should be enforced because they are in the best interest of public health.'' It also said government ``should not provide discrimination protections on the basis of sexual orientation'' and ``school curriculums should not condone homosexuality as an acceptable lifestyle in American society.'' But Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., rallied opposition to the amendment when he said, ``it appears that the need for the National Hate Crimes Statistics Act has never been greater _ and that's what this is, a statistics act, it's not about anybody's behavior.'' Besides Helms, those voting against the bill were Sens. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H.; Trent Lott, R-Miss., and William Armstrong, R-Colo. Not voting were Sens. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn.; Carl Levin, D-Mich.; Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Meets Privately With Ethics Committee
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger, defending his financial dealings before the Senate Ethics Committee, says he told the panel ``some decisions would be made differently'' if he could do it over again. The Minnesota Republican met with the committee privately for an hour Thursday afternoon at his request. Although questions about Durenberger's conduct are still emerging, the senator told reporters afterward: ``The cloud of questions that has been hanging over my head since my 1988 re-election campaign has finally started to clear today. ... I have had the opportunity to address the issues in the proper forum, the Senate Ethics Committee.'' He refused to answer questions from reporters after reading a brief statement. Durenberger said he told the panel he received approval from ``the appropriate, official bodies'' for a book promotion arrangement that netted $100,000 in speaking fees and for rent that he charged the Senate for staying in his Minneapolis condominium. Durenberger previously said the Federal Election Commission approved his book promotion agreement and the Senate Rules and Ethics committees sanctioned the reimbursement he received for the condominium. The committee is investigating Durenberger to determine if he should answer charges in the panel's equivalent of a trial. The committee gave no indication when it would finish its investigation, said a Durenberger aide. The questions are whether Durenberger broke Senate rules by evading outside income limits when he made promotional speeches for the books; improperly charged the Senate for the condominium stays; and received improper reimbursements for trips to Boston that combined official appearances with visits to his marriage counselor. The rules committee found last month Durenberger improperly claimed reimbursement for staying in his condominium when the Senate was out of session, and Durenberger repaid the Senate $11,005. The committee said there were other unspecified questions about the deal that the ethics committee would have to answer. Durenberger, who is up for re-election in 1994, has apologized to Minnesotans for what he says were mistakes in judgment. Still, more than two-thirds of respondents in two recent Minnesota polls said he should resign if the committee finds significant wrongdoing. ``I have accepted full responsibility for my actions, and I have acknowledged that had I to do it all over again, some decisions would be made differently,'' Durenberger said Thursday. Accompanied by his lawyer, Jim Hamilton, and an aide, Durenberger made a ``lengthy presentation'' that took up much of the hour-long appearance before the committee Thursday, said his press secretary, Carrie Collins. Meanwhile, the Star Tribune of Minneapolis disclosed Wednesday that Durenberger obtained $1.3 million in low-interest, unsecured loans from a Minnesota bank where his cousin is a vice president. Many of the loans were at interest rates several points below prime lending rates. Durenberger said the story was a ``blatant distortion of the facts.'' He said his loans were based on a ``normal, longstanding relationship'' with the bank. But neither he nor his staff have attempted to explain why he did not disclose three of the 23 loans to the Senate, including a short-term $484,000 loan he obtained in 1988. ``I guess I would say we're looking into that,'' Collins said. Senate disclosure reports require the listing of any liabilities exceeding $10,000. Minnesota Republican Chairman Bob Weinholzer said Thursday that he expected state Democrats to increase pressure for Durenberger to resign because Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich could appoint a senator from his party to serve until an election. Weinholzer said Durenberger told him last week ``he has absolutely no intentions of resigning unless something major comes along in an ethics committee report.'' In April 1988, the ethics committee criticized Durenberger for discussing an espionage case in public the previous year, but it did not recommend disciplinary action.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Fall in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost ground against the yen Friday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply. The dollar closed at 144.72 yen, down 0.78 yen from Thursday's close of 145.50 yen. It opened at 145.08 yen and ranged between 144.65 yen and 145.15 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, a 214.37-point gainer Thursday, fell 228.10 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 37,288.14. Talk of a possible rise in the Bank of Japan's discount rate after the Feb. 18 elections for the lower house of parliament depressed stock prices, dealers said. Share trading has been light this week in anticipation of the election, and activity was calmer still Friday morning ahead of the three-day weekend, traders said. Both the stock and currency markets will be closed Monday for a national holiday. Currency dealers said the foreign exchange market was calm throughout the morning. The U.S. currency's lower start in Tokyo followed its downswing overnight in New York, where it closed at 145.32 yen, down from 145.60 yen. Although the dollar slipped against the yen, it strengthened against the West German mark as market players sold the mark for profit-taking and position adjustments from their long, or overbought, positions, a Bank of Tokyo trader said. ``The yen is getting slightly stronger against the dollar as investors buy the ye against the mark,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Concerns about the implications of a proposal to unify the two German monetary systems, along with profit-taking, helped push the mark lower Thursday, traders said.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A 3-foot alligator was returned to the wild after a night spent in a gerbil cage and a trip to an elementary school for an aborted show-and-tell session. The gator, found by 11-year-old Bradley Schlomer in his yard, was ordered removed from the classroom and sent home by the principal, then freed Wednesday by an animal control officer. Carol Joiner, a school secretary at Rosewood Elementary, said she knew just what to do when she saw the gator that had been brought in for show-and-tell: ``I went out the back. ``Last week, it was a baby coral snake,'' she said. ``They put it in a little tin box and drove up to school. And I called the mother to tell her to come back and pick up the snake and she says, `What snake?''' Bradley's mother, Sheri Schlomer, said she was unaware that her son and his sister Bobbi, 14, had hidden the gator in the house. ``I didn't know anything about it until today,'' she said. ``The funny thing is, I was in his room last night and I didn't even see the thing.''

The first half of the Legislative session ended with a Bam! Pow! as a man in a Batman suit paraded down the corridor between the two chambers and 200 uniformed firefighters swarmed through the Capitol. In addition to the usual lobbyists and students Thursday, lawmakers were greeted by celebrants of Volunteer Firefighter Day; sign-toters trying to keep the North Beckley turnpike toll plaza open; and about 50 people seeking the right to recall officials and to ballot referendums. Among the turnpike group was a man parading through the Statehouse corridors in a Batman costume and carrying a sign proclaiming: ``Batman Says Keep Tolls, Keep Jobs.'' When asked whether he felt silly wearing a cape and bat mask, the man, who would not give his name, replied, ``No sillier than the congressmen and people here.''

DOC.HEAD: `Sacred' Rice Paddies Chosen for Imperial Ascension Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: The Imperial Palace has chosen two paddies where ``sacred'' rice will be grown for a ritual that marks Emperor Akihito's first communion with the gods, a mystical part of his ascension to the throne. The ancient selection ceremony was criticized by several Christian, academic and leftist groups, which say state backing of the communion rite violates Japan's constitution. Imperial ritualists dressed in flowing robes and black headgear gathered at three palace shrines Thursday morning, and divined auspicious locations for the paddies by burning sea turtle shells over charcoal. An official of the Imperial Household Agency, which manages palace affairs, said northeastern Akita prefecture, or state and western Oita prefecture were chosen. Because of security concerns, the exact location of the paddies is not expected to be announced until the rice is harvested in September. Police fear attacks by radical leftist groups, which have announced they intend to disrupt Akihito's coronation in November, nearly two years after he actually became emperor on the death of his father, Emperor Hirohito. The leftist Middle Core Faction claimed responsibility for launching projectiles at the home of Akihito's younger brother last month. By tradition, one paddy must be to the east and one to the west of Kyoto, Japan's former capital. The rice must go through an elaborate purification process before being used in the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual, to be held after the lavish coronation ceremonies. During the nightlong ritual, tradition holds that a new emperor has his first communion with the gods of Shinto, Japan's indigenous religion. Banquets will be held for two nights after the rite, and the government has said about 1,000 dignitaries will be invited. In the last such ceremony in 1928, Hirohito offered rice to the gods at two shrines in Kyoto. Akihito's Daijosai ceremony will be held on the grounds of the Imperial Palace in Tokyo, but government officials say it will otherwise follow the example set by Hirohito. The palace's respect for precedent has led to criticism from several groups that claim the ceremony is a remnant of Japan's prewar emperor-centric nationalism. ``They have thrown themselves back into the world of myth,'' said Tsutomu Moriyama, a spokesman for the National Christian Council, an umbrella group for Christians in Japan. ``From the constitutional viewpoint, these preparations to deify the emperor are unforgivable.'' ``It is clear that the government, in planning the Daijosai, has ignored the principle that sovereignity lies with the people and not the emperor. ... The rites violate the constitution,'' said a statement issued by the Historical Studies Association, a nationwide group of historians and college professors. At the urging of U.S.-led occupation authorities, Hirohito renounced imperial divinity soon after World War II. The current constitution omits references to the old god-emperor concept, and strips Shinto of its official status. The postwar constitution also guarantees the separation of religion and state. A government committee recently released a report saying that although the Daijosai has strong religious overtones, it ``is public in nature'' and is ``extremely important'' as part of Japanese culture. The government has budgeted more than $58 million for Akihito's coronation and the ceremony. Preparations for the coronation had to await a one-year mourning period after Hirohito's death of cancer on Jan. 7, 1989. Hirohito was 87.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers See More Concessions Before South Africa Sanctions Lifted
DOC.TEXT: Several lawmakers say sanctions that have damaged South Africa's economy probably won't be repealed until Pretoria's white government makes further concessions to the black majority. But a top administration official, speaking Wednesday on condition he not be identified, said South Africa is likely to make enough progress in easing oppression against blacks over the next year to permit the lifting of sanctions. ``This is a time when the United States can do the most good by waiting and watching,'' said Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., the former chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who supported sanctions initially. South African President F.W. de Klerk's reforms, ``important as they are, do not meet all the conditions required to build the appropriate pre-negotiations climate,'' said Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., chairman of the House Africa subcommittee. Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., the ranking Republican on the subcommittee, said he continues to oppose sanctions which he thinks have hurt black South Africans more than the whites. But he predicted the sanctions will not be changed ``until a lot more has been accomplished'' because of a pro-sanctions climate in Congress. The sanctions debate is likely to become more intense if de Klerk continues to announce reforms in the white-ruled country. President Bush has said ``it is certainly time to review all policy'' when ``people move in the right direction.'' In general, there is agreement the sanctions Congress imposed in 1986 over President Reagan's veto harmed the country's economy and took a psychological toll on the white minority. Stephen R. Lewis Jr., author of ``The Economics of Apartheid,'' said, ``International trade sanctions alone have probably resulted in a $2 billion loss annually to the South African economy.'' But Lewis, president of Carlton College in Northfield, Minn., said U.S. sanctions were probably more of a blow psychologically because the United States has little economic leverage over the country. All told, there are about 123 American companies doing business in South Africa, employing roughly 1 percent of the populations. ``The political significance (of sanctions) was very substantial,'' said Lewis, saying it meant the South African government ``could no longer kid itself the United States would come down on its side.'' But Michael Johns said that although sanctions increased pressure on the government, they should be ended now to boost the nation's economy and ease pressure on de Klerk's government from blacks and right-wing white groups. Randall Robinson, head of TransAfrica, a lobbying group that encouraged sanctions, said they ``have had more impact than any previous or current pressure.'' South Africa's economy is weak because of a combination of factors, he said, including an international oil boycott, other countries' restrictions and the inefficiencies of apartheid. South Africa's economy has grown at less than 2 percent annually in recent years, compared with about 5 percent between 1950-1970, Lewis said. ``They finally made an impact on whites,'' said Pauline Baker of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, a think tank. ``The economy was in irreversible decline.'' U.S. sanctions barred new American investment in South Africa, including bank loans to the government; prohibited the import of South African iron, steel, coal and uranium and agricultural products, including sugar; prevented the United States from exporting computers to South Africa; banned all nuclear trade and halted landings by South African Airways. Last week, de Klerk legalized the African National Congress after three decades of guerrilla war against white rule, and said he would soon free Nelson Mandela, the ANC leader imprisoned in 1962.

DOC.HEAD: Across America on the Cold War Victory Tour
DOC.TEXT: Where was President Bush the week the Kremlin tottered? He was at the headquarters of the Strategic Air Command flashing a jaunty thumbs-up from the Darth Vaderesque cockpit of a B-1 bomber and reminding missile launch crews ``the pointy end is up.'' He was out on the dusty hills of the Mojave Desert in fatigues and black wingtip shoes, watching Army tanks stage war games against a Soviet-style ``foe.'' No shells; laser tag does the trick. He was at a weapons laboratory with a $1 billion budget outside San Francisco, extolling Star Wars and saluting the ``underappreciated'' staff dreaming up the weapons of tomorrow. It was, as wags along for the ride put it, President Bush's Cold War Victory Tour. Communist party chieftains in Moscow may have been talking pluralism, but for Bush this was a week to celebrate containment, deterrence and nuclear modernization.

Bush also tried to talk in San Francisco about ``demobilization,'' but a memory lapse got in the way. After explaining foreign policy to 2,500 people at the Commonwealth Club, Bush found himself at a loss for that one particular word while fielding questions. Bush allowed that there might be a bit of a dividend down the road from troop cutbacks in Europe. ``I think we will see substantial savings that are made by the _ whaddaya call it? Suddenly gone blank _ in terms of where you bring a guy back and he's no longer in the Army?'' Bush circumlocuted as the crowd broke into laughter. He never came up with the word. Later, aboard Air Force One, he chided reporters, ``None of you guys gave me any help. I looked down in the front and not one of you guys would help out. It's not going to impede your objectivity.'' ``I was groping up there, a terrible feeling. It was awful. Such an easy word,'' said Bush. ``Anyway, I made another mistake (once). Let's see, it was in 1981 ... a spelling error.'' It wasn't just the press row that failed to help him fill in the blank. He didn't get any help, either, from former Secretary of State George Shultz, seated at his right hand, or California Gov. George Deukmejian a few seats down the head table.

Bob Hope, preceding Bush at a Los Angeles fund-raising dinner, marveled at the president's energy. ``I mean, he jogs, he swims, he plays tennis, he hunts, he pitches horseshoes _ he's got to move. I think we ought to let him deliver the mail,'' quipped Hope. But Bush showed signs of tiring on this trip to California, Nebraska and Ohio and back in 60 hours flat. At a fundraising breakfast in Omaha for Nebraska Gov. Kay Orr, he wound up telling an anecdote about humorist ``Mark Train'' and thanked the crowd ``for your support for Fay.''

Bush was only too happy to pose for the camera in his aviator jacket in the cockpit of a B-1 bomber at Offut, but he kept his feet planted firmly on the ground when surrounded by tanks and armored vehicles during the military training exercises at Fort Irwin, a remote installation in the Mojave. He got close but never ventured inside, mindful of the comic picture that Michael Dukakis, his campaign rival, cut when he took an ill-fated tank ride during the 1988 campaign.

Bush tries to walk a fine line between voicing support for Gorbachev's reform efforts and trying to keep his nose out of the other guy's internal business. Many of the questions from the Commonwealth Club crowd dealt with Gorbachev. But one apparently was too much for Bush. Would he comment, please, on Gorbachev's nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize? ``I hate to say I wasn't aware of it,'' he cracked. But after dancing around a bit, he added, ``Far be it from me to try to influence the gurus who decide who wins a Nobel Prize.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Slayings, Apparent Suicide Raise Questions of Navy Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, ``Whoever was...' to REMOVE erroneous quote, show that second, not first victim would have heard gunshot; picks up 16th graf, `Sometime after ...
DOC.TEXT: Three slayings and a suspected suicide at the top-secret Trident submarine base have raised questions of espionage and complaints that the Navy has not conducted a complete investigation. The intrigue is focused on a 23-year-old submarine technician named Shyam David Drizpaul, whose body was found last month in a Vancouver-area motel, about 180 miles south of the Bangor Trident submarine base. Navy investigators say they believe Drizpaul killed two fellow submariners in the Bangor base's barracks, then killed a woman and wounded a man during a pawn-shop robbery in nearby Bremerton. They claim Drizpaul then drove to the motel and killed himself. But a lawyer for Drizpaul's family, family members and even a shipmate said the Navy's story doesn't make sense. Attorney Larry Scruggs Jr. of Milwaukee, who traveled to the base to investigate the shootings, noted that Drizpaul had a sensitive position, working on the weapons systems, aboard the USS Michigan; that Drizpaul was a computer whiz and his personal computer is missing; and that he was killed by a single bullet through his forehead, which he said was unusual for a suicide. Scruggs also said he has evidence of another person being involved in the plot, but he would give no details _ not even the person's gender. ``I think he was either murdered or compelled to do those things,'' Scruggs said of the slayings. ``... Drizpaul had high clearance, and my indication was that clearance was extremely high, extremely critical.'' ``Maybe the thing fell apart and people began to panic and couldn't accept the results. ... There is one person who can answer those questions,'' he said, referring to the other individual. Drizpaul's relatives in Milwaukee said Drizpaul was an intelligent and responsible person who did not fit the description of a killer. ``Nothing makes sense. There are a lot of questions that haven't been answered,'' said an uncle, Yoganand Kumar. ``What's going on? What are they trying to cover up? We're not saying he didn't do it. We're saying, `Tell us what happened.''' At Drizpaul's funeral last month, Petty Officer Paul Gamache of Osseo, Wis., who escorted Drizpaul's body from Washington to Milwaukee, told mourners that Drizpaul's co-workers were surprised by the allegations. Gamache, who knew Drizpaul for 18 months, said the Navy's allegations about Drizpaul did not ``really seem like the guy we knew. ... He always performed every job ever asked of him in a very professional manner. He took pride in his work.'' Scruggs said the circumstances around the shootings of two sailors in a Bangor barrack were unusual. The sailors _ identified as David Allen Parker, 21, of San Diego, and 18-year-old Scott Anthony Seely, of North Ridgeville, Ohio _ had been shot in the head, and were found about fifteen feet apart, he said. Whoever was shot second would have heard the first gunshot, but investigators found no signs of trauma or struggle in either victim, Scruggs said. Sometime after the shooting, Bangor gate guards detained Drizpaul for driving while intoxicated and took from him a 9mm automatic pistol. Navy ballistics reports should confirm next week whether that gun killed Parker and Seely, said Banger spokesman Lt. Cmdr. Keith Arterburn. The Navy has refused to respond to Scruggs' questions. Allan Michaels, 28, identified Drizpaul from photographs as the man who wounded him and fatally shot his sister, Julie Lynn Tuscher, 24, in the pawn shop where they worked. ``I don't know how much clearer that can be,'' Arterburn said. But Scruggs said Michael's identification was too detailed. ``He described him exactly the same way it was printed in the newspaper _ neatly trimmed mustache. Give me a break.'' The morning after the sailors were shot, police and Navy authorities said Drizpaul allegedly drove to Bremerton in one of the dead sailor's cars and shot Tuscher and Michaels while trying to take another gun. Arterburn said 35 investigators are still working on the case. The Drizpaul incident is the latest of several deaths close to the base. Two Navy servicemen committed suicide in the last 13 months and one crewman faces charges of killing an elderly couple north of Seattle. The shootings have raised questions about the Navy's training. Arterburn said all submarine crew members undergo psychological testing before being assigned to duty. He also said those who work around nuclear weapons are monitored by the Defense Department. ``We all believe this to be a real tragedy,'' Arterburn said of the string of shootings. ``We've lost shipmates. It's one of those things that shocks you, but you have to keep on.''

DOC.HEAD: Black Teens Who Trade Sex for Crack Worried About AIDS, Researchers Say
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-CDC-AIDS, Bjt ^By BRENDA C. COLEMAN
DOC.TEXT: Condoms should be distributed free to young users of crack cocaine, say researchers who found that many such youths sell sex for drugs or engage in sexual practices that increase their risk of catching AIDS. The researchers reported in today's Jornal of American Medical Association that 76 percent of the subjects in their study ``were worried' or ``somehwat worried'' about catching HIV, the AIDS virus. The researchers viewed the degree of worry by the respondents as positive. ``The kids were worried about contracting AIDS. Some AIDS education has gotten through,'' said Robert Fullilove, who led a team of researchers that questioned 222 young black crack users in San Francisco and Oakland, Calif. Fullilove said that he and his colleagues recommended a campaign of widespread distribution of condoms that might make it possible ``for even the worried, implusive crack user to have safe sexual encounters.'' ``Crack is such a deadly thing, (many people think) the only thing you can do is watch the community commit suicide,'' Fullilove said in a telephone interview Thursday. ``We don't see it that way at all.'' Three-fourths of the admitted crack users, ages 13 to 19, said they engaged in sexual practices that increased their risk of catching HIV, the researchers said. Fifty-five youths, or 25 percent, reported exchanging sex for money or drugs, a practice equally common among boys and girls, the researchers found. Other alarming trends among the 140 boys and 82 girls surveyed were: _Just 59 percent reported ever using a condom, and just 23 percent said they had used a condom in their most recent sexual encounter. _Twenty-seven percent of boys and 4 percent of girls said they had more than 10 sexual partners during the previous year. _Forty-one percent had a history of sexually transmitted diseases, mostly gonorrhea. _Fifty-one percent said they had engaged in sex while under the influence of crack. _Twenty-nine percent said the following statement was true of them: ``I don't usually know ahead of time if I'm going to have sex _ it just happens.'' Fullilove conceded the distribution of condoms is not a panacea to the spread of AIDS. ``Obviously, it would work best in a much more comprehensive program teaching everything from `be responsible' to `this drug (crack) is dangerous,''' he said. The National Conference of Catholic Bishops is opposed to distributing condoms. In a statement issued in November the bishops said condoms were technically unreliable and fostered ``a false sense of security that actually leads to a greater spread of disease.'' Father Gregory Coiro, a spokesman for Los Angeles Archbishop Roger Mahony, who led the bishops' Ad Hoc Committee on the AIDS statement, said Thursday, ``This notion of safe sex is a myth. It's a fraud.'' Besides encouraging sexual encounters that are immoral, Coiro said, the failure rate of condoms can be as high as 50 percent in anal intercourse, one of the main ways the disease spreads. Crack use, coupled with exchanging sex for the drug, has been cited as a factor in the recent increase in sexually transmitted disease oberved in many U.S. urban areas, according to Fullilove, who led the study for the University of California at San Francisco's Center for AIDS Prevention Studies. Subjects for the study were questioned by interviewers who were familiar with drug dealers and users in known areas of crack activity, the researchers said. The interviewers went to those neighborhoods and questioned youths who approached them either requesting or offering a sale of crack, a highly potent, smokable form of cocaine that is both inexpensive and highly addictive.

DOC.HEAD: Proposal to Protect Uranium Miners Was Ignored, Says Scientist
DOC.TEXT: The government and mining industry rejected a safety proposal in the early 1950s that would have protected uranium miners from lung cancer and other respiratory diseases, says a former government scientist. The Atomic Energy Commission ``disclaimed responsibility. They were not responsible for radiation protection until after the ore reached the mills,'' Dr. Victor E. Archer told the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources. ``The mine operators rejected it because it would cost them too much to ventilate (the mines),'' he said. ``The states reflected the mine operators' opinion, pointing out that they had no expertise in radiation safety and no money for extra mine inspectors.'' He said all three groups ``justified their inaction by arguing that it was not clear that there was a radiation hazard in U.S. mines'' despite high levels measured in U.S. mines and the lung cancer experience of miners in Central Europe. Archer, an epidemiologist with the U.S. Public Health Service in Utah in the 1950s, said the safety proposal came from Duncan Holaday, an industrial hygiene engineer with the health service. Holaday proposed in 1952 and 1953 that a maximum radon exposure limit be set and that it be enforced through mine ventilation, Archer said. The safety measures would have cost a nickel per pound of uranium, he said. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, has written legislation that would compensate victims of radiation exposure through uranium mining from 1947-1971 or above-ground nuclear tests at the Nevada test site in the 1950s and '60s. ``The level of their exposure was, in large part, due to the government's unconscionable failure to properly care for or warn these victims,'' Hatch said. Uranium mines are located in New Mexico, Wyoming, Utah and Colorado. Full protection began only when federal authorities took over regulation with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in 1971 and the Mine Safety and Health Administration six years later, Archer said. Hatch said legislation, which would create a $100 million trust fund, is necessary because courts have rejected individual claims on the grounds of government exemption from liability. Hatch said he expected the full committee to complete action on the bill when it meets Feb. 28. Rep. Wayne Owens, D-Utah, has filed similar legislation in the House. He said he expected the House to complete action within six weeks. The government carried out more than 100 above-ground tests at the Nevada Test Site between 1951 and 1958, according to Hatch's office.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says He Won't Consider National Security in Diary Request
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge says he won't consider national security and diplomatic implications in deciding whether former President Reagan should turn over some 33 diary excerpts to John Poindexter. Reagan invoked executive privilege Monday in an attempt to avoid supplying the diaries to his former national security adviser, who is scheduled to go on trial Feb. 20 on charges of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements in the Iran-Contra scandal. However, the Bush administration did not join in Reagan's move. ``The privilege relating to national security, foreign affairs and burdensomeness considerations is that of the incumbent, rather than the former president,'' U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene said in a five-page order Thursday. ``In the absence of a claim of executive privilege by the incumbent president the interests of the current presidency will not receive the benefit of the higher standard of review,'' Greene wrote. Reagan's claim to executive privilege is based on ``the constitutionally protected privacy of his diaries,'' his lawyers said Monday. The Justice Department said Wednesday that it would review secret proffers that Poindexter has submitted to the court before the Bush administration decides whether to claim executive privilege. Greene ordered that three such court filings by Poindexter be turned over to Reagan and the Justice Department by Friday. They include a June 12 filing seeking classified material and a Sept. 18 statement seeking permission to obtain material from Reagan and President Bush. The third document is a Jan. 8 memo by Poindexter explaining why documents subpoenaed from Reagan are important to his defense. Greene ordered Poindexter to supply the secret court filings so that Reagan and the Justice Department can respond to Poindexter's demands for documents. The judge said in December that he would follow such a procedure if executive privilege were invoked. In the Watergate scandal, the Supreme Court ordered President Nixon to produce White House tape recordings he had been trying to shield. Invoking executive privilege, Nixon said confidential conversations between a president and his close advisers should not be disclosed. But the Supreme Court said a ``generalized interest in confidentiality ... cannot prevail over the ... fair administration of criminal justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Says Hazelwood May Be Able To Blame Government Negligence For Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third from last graf, `Documents filed ...' to include full reference to Cole.
Eds: Hearing on legal issue scheduled for 4 p.m. EST; no testimony planned until Monday.
DOC.TEXT: A judge said he may reverse himself and permit Joseph Hazelwood's defense to allege that government negligence _ not recklessness by the Exxon Valdez captain _ caused the nation's worst oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone reopened the question after he had ruled Thursday that such a theory could not be advanced by the defense. Defense attorney Dick Madson said in his opening statement that the U.S. Coast Guard monitors weren't watching their radar screen and failed in their duty to notify Hazelwood that his 987-foot tanker was heading for disaster at Bligh Reef. A Coast Guard traffic monitor, civilian employee Gregory Taylor, testified Thursday that part of his job was to watch the radar screen for trouble and communicate with tankers if a problem was imminent. He also said he was to ``let people know what was going on to make things easier.'' He said he spoke with Hazelwood some time before the Exxon Valdez disaster and discussed ice conditions in the Valdez Narrows. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is being tried on a felony charge of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted, he faces up to seven years and three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Most of the testimony in Hazelwood's week-old trial has focused on whether the captain was drunk when the Exxon Valdez ran aground early March 24. The spill spewed more than 10 million gallons of North Slope crude, killing thousands of birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of shoreline. Taylor and another traffic monitor have said the Exxon Valdez was in a hazy area at the edge of their radar monitor and may not have been visible before it smashed into a rocky reef. Johnstone initially ruled the defense couldn't use a theory of government negligence, but later said he may reverse himself. ``What the defense seems to be saying,'' Johnstone said, ``is, `We're not reckless. We didn't create the problem. The government created the problem.' The more I think about it the more I think the defense should be able to show they didn't create it; the government did. I'm reconsidering it.'' The prosecution, which says the accident was all Hazelwood's fault, tried to block such testimony, saying if Hazelwood wanted to claim he was not reckless he could testify on his behalf. Johnstone suggested this might force the defendant to testify when he would not otherwise do so. In another ruling, Johnstone decided that jurors will not be told that Taylor, the Coast Guard monitor, tested positive for marijuana two days after the grounding. He did not immediately rule on whether a second monitor's alcohol test would be admitted in evidence. ``I find the inquiry about this marijuana has nil probative value and is far outweighed by the invasion of Mr. Taylor's privacy,'' Johnstone said. ``In other words, it's a red herring.'' Documents filed in the case showed that Bruce Blandford, the second traffic monitor, showed a blood-alcohol level of .203 percent 15 hours after the tanker went aground. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole said Blandford went home after the accident and began drinking. ``There is absolutely no evidence that Mr. Blandford was under the influence of intoxicating liquor at any time during his shift,''' said Cole, who conceded that in a later test Blandford also showed a trace of morphine in his urine. He said there was no evidence Taylor was under the influence of marijuana the night of the crash. Traces of marijuana can remain in the bloodstream months after its use.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Considering Taking Bald Eagle Off Endangered List
DOC.TEXT: Government officials say the effort to save the American bald eagle from extinction has been so successful that the national symbol may be taken off the endangered list. The eagle, which was threatened with extinction in the 1960s partly because of contamination from the pesticide DDT, would remain under protection of federal law, but its status would be lowered, officials said Thursday. ``We are not considering removing the bald eagle from the protection of the Endangered Species Act,'' said John Turner, director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Turner said the agency was gathering additional data on eagle populations before making a formal recommendation to the Interior Department to lower the status of the eagle from endangered to threatened. But the proposal has raised concerns among some environmentalists. ``The improvements in eagle numbers may be only temporary because eagle habitat is still being destroyed at an unprecedented rate,'' said M. Rupert Cutler, president of Defenders of Wildlife. Cutler said in some parts of the country, such as the Great Lakes area and some coastal areas, the eagle remains in danger because of pesticides and toxins, and development is eating up eagle territory elsewhere. The American eagle was placed under protection of federal law in 1967 after its population had been declining since the 1940s, largely because the widespread use of the pesticide DDT interfered in its reproductive process. The Environmental Protection Agency ordered a halt to the use of DDT in 1972. From an estimated low, not counting birds in Alaska, of only 400 nesting pairs in the early 1960s, their number increased to more than 2,660 nesting pairs in 1989, the Interior Department said. Turner said four of the five government recovery programs in the country are showing eagle population figures that exceed numbers that would warrant reducing the status of the bird from endangered to threatened. The bald eagle is listed as endangered in 43 states and threatened in five others. The bald eagle is not under federal protection in Alaska where the population is thriving with more than 30,000 birds. Turner said his agency would review the bald eagle population figures when the latest data comes in before making a determination whether to lower its status to threatened in the 43 states.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Refuses Talks With South Korea During U.S. Military Exercises
DOC.TEXT: Communist North Korea today declared it would boycott talks with South Korea during U.S.-South Korean military exercises in the spring, the official North Korean news agency reported. The annual Team Spirit exercises, which began last month, involve about 200,000 troops. The announcement marked North Korea's fourth consecutive suspension of talks during the exercises. North Korean representatives to three sets of talks declared in a statement that they would not negotiate with South Korea during the ``aggressive'' exercises, said the Korean Central News Agency, monitored in Tokyo. In the statement, North called the Team Spirit practice ``open treachery'' and ``an anti-national criminal act of breaking up dialogue and obstructing reunification,'' the news agency said. ``If the United States wants detente and peace on the Korean peninsula and North-South dialogue, it must immediately discontinue the Team Spirit '90 joint military exercises and promptly withdraw all their troops and military equipment hurled into South Korea for the military exercises,'' the statement said. Despite a common heritage, language and even a strong desire to unite, talks between the two Koreas constantly founder. Earlier this week, talks aimed at fielding a joint team for this year's Asian Games in Beijing broke down after 10 months when both sides differed over procedural matters after agreeing on most major issues. The two Koreas have been enemies since the division of the peninsula in 1945. In the early 1950s, they fought each other in the Korean War which ended with an armistice, not a peace treaty. Technically, they remain at war and the border between them is one of the most heavily fortified in the world. About 43,000 U.S. troops are stationed in South Korea under a mutual defense treaty. On Jan. 30, U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced the closing of three U.S. air bases in South Korea and withdrawal of 2,000 support personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Nations Divided on Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Americans and Colombians disagree on whether the Colombian government is winning its war against drug cartels, while Colombians are suspicious the United States is using the drug problem to control their government, a poll shows. Fifty-eight percent of Colombians but only 25 percent of Americans said the Colombian government is winning its war against the drug cartels of that country, according to the poll by The Washington Post and ABC News. Seventy percent of Americans, but 19 percent of Colombians, said the Colombian government is losing, the poll showed. The poll asked several questions of 1,008 American adults and 1,022 Colombian adults between Jan. 20 and Jan. 29. ABC's ``World News Tonight'' on Thursday and today's editions of the newspaper carried reports on the results. A majority of Americans _ 55 percent _ favored sending U.S. troops to help the Colombian military, and 45 percent were opposed. Only 19 percent of Colombians favored such a course and 77 percent were opposed. There was some agreement: 79 percent of Americans and 80 percent of Colombians said the international drug problem was caused by demand in the United States while only 19 percent of Americans and 9 percent of Colombians said it was caused by Colombia allowing traffickers to operate. Fifty-one percent of Americans and 57 percent of Colombians favored U.S. aid to the police and judicial system of Colombia; 47 percent of Americans and 39 percent of Colombians opposed it. Questions asked only in Colombia showed great suspicion of the United States. Sixty-five percent said they were suspicious that the United States was using the drug problem to control the Colombian government. Forty-nine percent said their government should not work with the United States while only 40 percent said it should. Asked whether their government should accept offers of the drug kingpins to wind up the traffic and end the violence if given amnesty and allowed to keep their property, 58 percent of Colombians said the government should agree while 31 percent said it should not. The government has not responded to that offer. The margin of error was said to be four percentage points in each sample.

DOC.HEAD: Peer Who Organized Prince Charles And Diana's Wedding Is Dead
