DOC.TEXT: Lord Maclean, the former chief official of Queen Elizabeth II's household and organizer of the 1981 wedding of Prince Charles, has died, his family announced today. He was 73. Maclean died Thursday at Hampton Court Palace, a former royal residence in London, where he had been chief steward since 1985. The announcement gave no cause of death. The Scottish baron became lord chamberlain in 1971. Before he retired from the post in 1984, he had established a reputation as a perfectionist in royal ceremonies while overseeing the queen's household. The wedding of Prince Charles, the queen's eldest son, and Lady Diana Spencer in St. Paul's Cathedral was a highlight of his term. In a spontaneous gesture, Princess Diana kissed him before a train carried the newlyweds away on their honeymoon. Maclean served as a Scots Guards infantry officer in World War II, fighting in France, Belgium, the Netherlands and Germany. After the war, he became a sheep and cattle farmer. In 1959, he became leader of the Boy Scouts in Britain and the Commonwealth. He went on to revolutionize the staid image of the movement founded by Lord Baden-Powell in 1908, adding sports such as gliding and cave diving to traditional scouting activities. He retired as chief scout in 1975. Maclean's first ceremonial assignment as lord chamberlain was the 1972 funeral of the Duke of Windsor, who as King Edward VIII abdicated the throne in 1936 to marry American divorcee Wallis Simpson. The assignment was difficult because of the bad feeling engendered by the abdication among other members of the royal family. But Maclean was judged to have handled the funeral arrangements with great skill. Royalty watchers noted with approval that Maclean did not bow when he said farewell to the duke's widow as she left. Maclean also organized the silver wedding celebration of Queen Elizabeth II and her husband, Prince Philip, that year. His job as lord chamberlain sometimes involved odd responsibilities. He once had to advise the queen whether she should keep her centuries-old legal right to possession of every whale and sturgeon washed up on the British coast. After some deliberation, Maclean advised her to renounce it, saying it might prove a nuisance. There was no immediate word on funeral arrangements. He is survived by his wife and their son and daughter.

DOC.HEAD: ``Oh! Calcutta!'' Dons Fig Leafs
DOC.TEXT: Theatergoers said they were cheated when the cast of ``Oh! Calcutta!'' was forced to cover up what it's been showing off for 20 years. Actors wore bras, flesh-colored underwear and G-strings during Wednesday night's show, their first clad performance since the show opened in June 1969. It has been seen by about 5,000 audiences since then. ``We've never had this problem before,'' said producer Barry Singer. ``There's nothing perverse about it. Go-go girls are much more sexually oriented than our show.'' Officials insisted the actors cover up in the show at the Shrine Mosque. State regulations prohibit nudity in a place of business licensed to sell liquor, even though the bar was closed at Wednesday's performance. ``I had a feeling I got cheated. It was like going to a musical where they didn't sing,'' said theatergoer Larry Welburn, 36.

DOC.BYLINE: AIDS: Spread Has Slowed _ But Not for All Groups
DOC.TEXT: AIDS spread at its slowest rate in the United States last year as fewer homosexual and bisexual men developed the disease and drugs delayed symptoms in people already infected, federal officials said. But AIDS is spreading faster among heterosexuals, newborn babies, women and Southerners, the federal Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The CDC reported 35,238 new cases of AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, in 1989, compared with 32,196 in 1988. That 9 percent increase is easily the slowest since the AIDS spread began in early 1981. For example, AIDS was up 34 percent in 1988 and 60 percent in 1987. ``This is somewhat of a continuing trend,'' said Dr. Ruth Berkelman, chief of AIDS surveillance for the Atlanta-based CDC. Of the new AIDS cases reported last year, 56 percent were among homosexual and bisexual males. But the cases among gay and bisexual men were up just 8 percent over 1988 levels, while heterosexual-contact cases _ just 4 percent of the total _ were up 27 percent over the year before. ``I think the leveling off reflects both a reduction in the number of new infections among homosexual and bisexual men, and also the introduction of some effective therapies (such as the drug AZT) in 1987, delaying the onset of AIDS itself among infected persons,'' Ms. Berkelman said. In 1989, 547 cases of AIDS transmission from mothers to newborns were reported, up 17 percent from 1988. And while females made up just 3,931 of the 35,238 cases last year, that was an increase of 11 percent over 1988; the number of AIDS cases among males last year was up 9 percent from the preceding year. Other larger proportional increases occurred in the South, up 22 percent over 1988; in population areas of less than 100,000, up 35 percent; and in areas of 100,000 to 500,000 people, up 32 percent. Among the regions, the South, with 31 percent, accounted for the largest proportion of AIDS cases reported, compared with 30 percent in the Northeast, 24 percent in the West and 10 percent in the Midwest. The number of new AIDS cases in the Northeast dropped 7 percent last year, to 10,718. The majority of 1989 cases _ 70 percent _ occurred in cities of 1 million people or more. The number of new AIDS cases among hemophilia patients dropped 5 percent in 1989, from 339 in 1988 to 321. And new cases associated with blood transfusions dropped 14 percent, from 935 to 808. But among intravenous drug users, the second largest group of AIDS patients, 7,970 new cases were reported in 1989, a 5 percent increase over 1988. Nationwide, the CDC has reported 117,781 cases since AIDS reporting began in 1981. More than 70,000 of the victims, or 60 percent, have died. Sixty percent of AIDS cases have occurred in homosexual or bisexual men, and 21 percent have occurred among IV drug abusers, with 7 percent among patients in both categories.

DOC.HEAD: Survey of Low-Income Women Finds Many Anemic in Pregnancy
With PM-CDC-AIDS, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Lower-income mothers don't seem to bounce back from the anemia common in early pregnancy as well as other women, and that puts their babies at higher risk of premature delivery and fetal death, a new report says. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that a 1987 survey of lower-income women showed that 38 percent of blacks and 19 percent of whites in the third trimester of pregnancy had hemoglobin levels indicating anemia. During the second trimester, 6 percent of white women and 18 percent of black women were anemic. In the first three months of pregnancy, 4 percent and 13 percent, respectively, were anemic. ``Among pregnant women who receive sufficient iron, (hemoglobin) levels normally decrease early in pregnancy, then increase through the third trimester'' to near pre-pregnancy levels, the Atlanta-based CDC said. For the women in the low-income survey, ``the failure to attain pre-pregnancy levels during the third trimester suggests that many of these women were iron deficient during pregnancy.'' The survey results mean ``many low-income women have poor iron nutrition both before and during pregnancy,'' the CDC said. Anemia during pregnancy increases a woman's risk of premature delivery, and increases the child's chances of low birth weight and fetal death, the CDC said. Nationwide, about 5 percent of non-pregnant, childbearing-age women have anemia, the CDC said. The racial differences ``may be related to a greater risk for iron deficiency in black women,'' the CDC said. But ``the explanation for the difference observed in this analysis is unclear.'' The findings came from the CDC's 1987 Pregnancy Nutrition Surveillance System, which studied anemia during pregnancy among more than 68,000 lower-income women in 13 states, most of them enrolled in the Women, Infants and Children (WIC) food program.

DOC.HEAD: California Spill Heats Up Debate on Double-Hull Ships
With PM-Oil Spill-Reax, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Southern California oil spill might have been avoided if the 811-foot American Trader had been equipped with a double hull and double bottom, said state officials and shipping experts. A number of officials speculated Thursday that a large swell caused the American Trader to fall on its own anchor Wednesday, ripping open a 3-foot hole, while the ship maneuvered alongside an offshore pipeline. ``We've always recommended that this (design change) be looked at,'' said Peter Douglas, executive director of the state Coastal Commission. ``If the information is born out that this tanker lifted up and came down on its own anchor, double-hulling the vessel may well have prevented the spill.'' The spill off Huntington Beach brought to a head debate over requiring the design change on tankers, opposed by many oil officials because of the higher cost and arguable safety advantages. Even some oil industry executives acknowledged that double-hulling and double-bottoming could have prevented this spill, a 1985 spill from a grounded Arco tanker in Port Angeles Harbor, Wash., and the devastating Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska. ``The double hull, in this case, could have avoided the spill and our own spill,'' said Jerry Aspland, president of Arco Marine Inc. and a former ship captain experienced in offshore moorings. But Aspland and Morris Croce, a Chevron USA executive and former ship captain, said the double-hull, double-bottom construction had important drawbacks. If, for example, a double-hull ship hits rocks at full speed, it could be more difficult to handle because the extra steel makes for a bigger, messier hole, They said. The space between the two hulls can fill with water, making the ship less buoyant. ``These considerations have got be addressed before one jumps to concluding that the double hull, double bottom is the solution to everything,'' Croce said. Several panels are studying the double-bottom, double-hull issue, including the American Academy of Sciences, which set to release a report this summer. Many oil companies said they would strongly consider the academy's findings. Mike Murphy, vice president for operations at American Trading Transportation Co. Inc., operator of the American Trader, was noncommittal when asked at a news conference Thursday whether a double hull might have prevented the spill. He said that as a shipping company official he had mixed feelings about the double-hull issue. ``The cost is one issue ... but there are other issues,'' he said, refusing to elaborate. The Senate and the House have passed differing oil liability bills that a conference committee is now blending into a measure both can approve by the March 24 anniversary of the Exxon Valdez spill. The main sticking point is over double bottoms and double hulls, which the House wants to see on all tankers calling at U.S. ports with oil or hazardous materials within seven and 15 years, respectively. The Senate bill calls for further study, which is the position the oil industry prefers. On Wednesday, the House voted 376-37 to instruct the conferees to include the hull-bottom provision in the bill. Though non-binding, the vote was taken to illustrate the strength of support for the provision in the House.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Loses Ground Against Yen, Stocks Slide in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar lost ground against the yen in Tokyo today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply. The dollar closed the week at 144.72 yen, down 0.78 yen from Thursday's close of 145.50 yen. It opened the day at 145.08 yen and ranged between 144.65 and 145.15 yen. The U.S. currency's lower start in Tokyo followed its downswing in New York Thursday, where it closed at 145.32 yen. Traders sold the West German mark for the yen throughout the day to take profits on marks, dealers said. ``The yen is getting slightly stronger against the dollar as investors buy the yen against the mark,'' said a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity. Concerns about the implications of a proposal to unify the two German monetary systems, along with profit-taking, helped push the mark lower, traders said. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 214.37 points Thursday, fell 228.10 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 37,288.14. Trading on the market has been light since the beginning of this week in anticipation of Japan's upcoming parliamentary elections. Traders said a lack of trading focus was another element that has been discouraging buying interest. There also was growing expectation in the market that the Bank of Japan will raise its official discount rate soon after the Feb. 18 elections, traders said. Traders said index-linked trading moved the market as most investors avoided dealing due to concern about the outcome of the elections, where the governing Liberal Democrats face a possible loss of their lower house majority. Thin trading makes the market more vulnerable to index-linked buying, they said. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 350 million shares, the lowest daily volume since last August. An estimated 430 million shares changed hands on the first section on Thursday. Both the stock and currency markets will be closed Monday for National Foundation Day, a national holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Command Head: Regional Conflicts Threaten U.S. Interests in Persian Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The head of the U.S. Central Command says the most serious threats to U.S. interests in the Persian Gulf are regional conflicts and the extensive acquisition of weapons by Iran and Iraq. Army Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf told the Senate Armed Services Committee on Thursday that although Iran and Iraq agreed to a cease fire in August 1988, the two countries have never signed a peace treaty. ``This no peace-no war situation has caused both sides to pursue rearmament programs,'' Schwarzkopf said. ``While each nation is purchasing more lethal weapons, the balance of power is dramatically in favor of Iraq.'' Under questioning from Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services panel, Schwarzkopf said the Soviet Union has been supplying modern equipment directly to Iraq. In addition, ``unbelievable amounts of modern equipment is flowing into Afghanistan on a monthly basis,'' the commander said. Based on this information, the United States has changed its strategy, altering its military plans for a regional conflict rather than a Soviet invasion of Iran. The Defense Planning Guidance, a classified report the military leaders use to plan troop levels, weapons purchases and bases for 1992-1997, which was described this week in published reports, reflects the change that Schwarzkopf described.
DOC.HEAD: Man Who Slugged Senator Found Innocent By Reason Of Insanity
DOC.TEXT: The man who slugged Sen. John Glenn in front of a television crew has been found innocent by reason of insanity. But U.S. Magistrate Deborah Robinson said Michael Breen, 31, of Washington, D.C., poses a potential danger to others and must be hospitalized for what was described in court as ``severe mental illness.'' Robinson accepted Breen's plea Thursday after reviewing psychiatric reports. In October, Breen lunged at Glenn, D-Ohio, during an outdoor television interview and landed a solid right to the jaw. Aside from redness and a few days of soreness, Glenn, a 68-year-old ex-Marine, was unharmed. According to the criminal complaint filed against him, Breen told police he was trying to get the attention of Pope John Paul II and prevent a nuclear war. Breen had been detained by U.S. Capitol Police and the Secret Service a day earlier after breaking through a police line and trying to reach out to Vice President Dan Quayle's motorcade. Breen also ``had sought President Bush at the Federal Emergency Management Agency'' a week earlier, Assistant U.S. Attorney Craig Iscoe told the court. Iscoe said Breen was responding to instructions he received in dreams.
DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Abandon Proposal To Rename Airport For Eisenhower
DOC.TEXT: Kansas lawmakers say unexpected opposition has convinced them to drop a proposal to rename Washington Dulles International Airport after Dwight D. Eisenhower. Rep. Pat Roberts had planned to introduce a resolution Thursday asking the regional airport authority to change the name of the airport located 25 miles west of the nation's capital to Eisenhower International Airport, to honor Eisenhower in the centennial year of his birth. But the suggestion drew expected opposition from area businessmen and the family of the late John Foster Dulles, who served as secretary of state in Eisenhower's administration. It was an executive order by Eisenhower in 1959 that named the airport after Dulles. ``From the outset, we had no desire whatsoever to take away from the career of John Foster Dulles or to cause any problem,'' said Roberts. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., also received criticism after he introduced a similar resolution shortly after Congress convened last month. The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority operates both Dulles and National airports.

DOC.HEAD: Squatters Settle Land That Could Be Border Crossing
DOC.TEXT: Officials have threatened to remove hundreds of squatters who have settled in the desert hills hoping the land will increase in value if and when a border crossing is built here. The government says the squatters, who hope to be reimbursed for the land by the government if the crossing goes up, have no claim to the property. The population of Anapra has grown from 300 families to 1,000 families in the last three months, since the Mexican government announced that Anapra was being considered for a new border crossing to Sunland Park, N.M. The towns are adjacent to El Paso, Texas and Ciudad Juarez, Mexico. The crossing has not yet been approved by Mexican and U.S. officials, but that hasn't stopped the influx. ``The rights of those people who have lived in Anapra from the beginning, 16 years ago, will be protected. They will get title to their land. But those squatters moving in now will be removed _ forcibly if need be,'' said Jose de Jesus Macias Delgado, the mayor of Ciudad Juarez. Most of the squatters are poor people who have been duped by leaders of civil and peasant associations, who have encouraged people to settle the land and are selling titles to it, said Alfonso Cerpa Roman, the Juarez appraisal director. Jesus Antonio Ruiz Dominguez said he paid more than $50 down on a 900-square-yard lot in Anapra that had a $400 price tag, plus another $50 for electricity rights and for an engineer to measure the land. ``They told me the money was going to Chihuahua City, where Gov. Fernando Baeza would give us title to the land,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Security Tightened After Bomb Blasts
With PM-Kashmir, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded at a post office and on a parked bus today, prompting authorities to tighten security in an attempt to halt Moslem separatist violence in the northern Kashmir region. No one was hurt or killed in the blasts, but state authorities later imposed a curfew and banned all public assembly, including Friday prayer services, forcing tens of thousands of Moslem sabbath worshipers to stay indoors. Moslem militants have been demanding for more than four decades that Jammu-Kashmir state break away from predominantly Hindu India. The latest flareup erupted last month with clashes between Indian security forces and the militants and at least 82 people have been killed, officials say. A bomb exploded in a bus parked at the city terminal, adjacent to the tourist information center, officials said. Two other buses were damaged but no one was hurt, they said. Another bomb exploded in a neighborhood post office, but there were no casualties, said the district magistrate of Srinagar, Ghulam Abbas. Most of the victims have been protesters shot while defying a curfew imposed Jan. 20 by government forces to stem rising violence. In recent days, authorities had relaxed the curfew during daytime hours, but it was re-imposed following the bomb blasts. After Moslems were told they would not be allowed to attend services, the city's chief Moslem priest denounced the decision and called on Moslem leaders worldwide to force the Indian government to allow the gatherings. ``I strongly condemn the anti-Islamic act of state authorities to impose day curfew consistently on Fridays for the last two months to make jumma (Friday) prayers impossible,'' Moulvi Mohammad Farooq said in a statement. Kashmir, once a princely state, was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Jammu-Kashmir, India's only predominantly Moslem state. Sixty-four percent of the state's 5 million people are Moslems, but nationwide, Moslems make up 12 percent of the 880 million population. Kashmiri militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, which claims Kashmir because of its predominant Moslem population, but now demand independence and the status of a neutral country. India routinely blames neighoring Pakistan of arming, training and supporting the militants. Pakistan denies the charge but says the Kashmiri people have a right to self-determination. India and Pakistan have fought two wars over the region.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Says U.S. Charge of Planned Attack `Baseless'
DOC.TEXT: Iran rejected U.S. allegations that pro-Iranian militants planned a terrorist attack in Europe to coincide with the 11th anniversary of the Islamic revolution, its state news agency said today. Iran's mission at the United Nations issued a statement late Thursday saying the charge was ``baseless'' and an attempt to discredit Iran, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. ``The U.S. authorities know fully well that the allegations have no foundation whatsoever in reality. They resort to them, however, trying to justify their illegal policies and behavior as well as their violations of international law,'' IRNA quoted the statement as saying. The report, monitored in Nicosia, gave no other details about the statement. But it said Iran would bring the issue to the attention of the U.N. secretary-general, Javier Perez de Cuellar. On Thursday, the U.S. State Department said that the United States is concerned about the possibility of a terrorist attack against Americans or U.S. facilities in Europe this weekend. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher had no specific information about the alleged threat and said the U.S. government was not urging Americans to cancel travel plans to Europe. Instead, travelers are encouraged to be alert to any danger, he said. Other officials said threat advisory messages have been sent in recent days to U.S. diplomatic posts in Europe and the Middle East. Boucher said the U.S. concern is linked to the 11th anniversary of the Islamic revolution in Iran this Sunday. Officials said that Iran has established a far-flung terrorist network targeted at American and West European interests, especially civil aviation. But officials said Thursday that they had no details on what type of U.S. facility might be a terrorist target this weekend. In December, an advisory was issued warning of the possibility of an attack against an American or Western European target but Thursday's announcement spoke only of ``U.S. interests'' as possible targets. In London, a British Transport Department spokesman said: ``The U.S. announcement does not advise of any threat against civil aviation but we have taken the notice into account.'' There were no reports of large-scale cancellation of tickets or tourism packages in Britain following the American warning, which was featured in British news reports.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Calif. State Senate Leader Resigns
DOC.TEXT: State Sen. Joseph Montoya resigned his state Senate seat today in the wake of his conviction on political corruption charges. Returning to his home town in southern California for the announcement Thursday, Montoya met the deadline set by the Senate Rules Committee for him to resign voluntarily or face expulsion action on the Senate floor. The former chairman of the Senate Business and Professions Committee was convicted last week in federal district court on extortion, racketeering and money laundering charges. He plans to appeal. Montoya is the first California legislator in 35 years to be convicted of a felony while in office. Montoya, 50, cited the energies he expects to expend on his appeal and his desire to spare his family the pain of the media spotlight as reasons for his resignation. ``As you know, I have maintained my innocence throughout the indictment and trial, and I believe in my heart that I will be eventually vindicated on appeal,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Activist Released from Prison, Says He'd Meet PLO Again
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli peace activist imprisoned four months for meeting PLO leader Yasser Arafat said upon his release today that he would gladly meet Arafat again. As Abie Nathan emerged from the prison near this town north of Tel Aviv, teen-agers from a nearby collective farm gave him a white dove, which he symbolically freed. He then shook hands with the director of the prison and said ``lehitraot,'' Hebrew for ``until we meet again.'' Nathan, 63, was sentenced to six months in prison after pleading guilty to meeting Arafat and other Palestine Liberation Organization activists in Tunisia in 1988. He entered Eyal prison Oct. 10, and the penalty was reduced by two months for good behavior. Israel considers the PLO to be a terrorist organization, and an amendment to Israel's anti-terror law passed in 1986 makes meeting with PLO leaders punishable with jail terms of up to three years. Only a handful of supporters were on hand in pouring rain to greet Nathan, who operates a pirate radio station called ``voice of peace'' off Israel's coast. ``I will meet with Palestinians and with any Arab leader who stretches his hand to talk of peace,'' Nathan said outside the prison. ``I will meet Arafat another dozen times. I have met him already seven times.'' Nathan first met Arafat in 1982 when he went to Lebanon during the Israeli siege of Beirut in a unsuccessful attempt to gain freedom for a captured Israeli soldier. He said he was willing to risk another prison sentence because ``this is my way of fighting.'' Nathan also pledged to fight to change the law under which he was jailed. ``I was put in a prison because of a law which is an undemocratic law which would not be accepted anywhere in the world,'' Nathan said. ``I will do everything in my power in order to continue my struggle to change that law.'' Among those greeting Nathan was peace activist Latif Dori, who also has met with PLO officials. Dori carried a placard with a picture of Nathan holding an olive branch and the words, ``They can't arrest peace.'' Nathan is best known for making a dramatic trip in a private plane to Cairo in 1964 to try to convince Egypt to make peace with Israel. In 1978, he went on a 45-day hunger strike to protest the building of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. His radio station broadcasts his peace message and music from a ship in the Mediterranean sea.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Suspends Andy Rooney For Remarks Attributed To Him
DOC.TEXT: CBS News humorist Andy Rooney, his future uncertain after a three-month suspension without pay, denies he made racial comments attributed to him in a gay magazine and said he wants to return to ``60 Minutes.'' CBS News President David Burke told Rooney in a meeting that CBS would not tolerate racist remarks, according to a statement from Burke, who did not return phone calls for further comment on the suspension. Rooney deined making the comments, but ``I guess Burke believes the person who said I said it,'' Rooney said. Rooney was interviewed by Chris Bull, a reporter with The Advocate, a biweekly magazine based in Los Angeles. The article was to be published today. Rooney has worked in news and entertainment at CBS for 40 years and has been the resident humorist at ``60 Minutes'' since 1978. In a brief phone interview, he declined to say whether he thought Burke's action was fair, but he later said in a statement the controversy put Burke ``in a difficult position, and I accepted his offer of suspension rather than to permanently end my career at CBS.'' Rooney's suspension is immediate. He won't be seen this Sunday in his usual ``60 Minutes'' slot, a spokesman for the program said. Also Thursday, network officials were quoted as saying anchorwoman Kathleen Sullivan of ``CBS This Morning'' was being taken off the program, which has been rated consistently below morning ABC and NBC shows. Sullivan could not be reached for comment. Rooney was quoted as saying that ``most people are born with equal intelligence, but blacks have watered down their genes because the less intelligent ones are the ones that have the most children. They drop out of school early, do drugs and get pregnant.'' Rooney denied making the slur. ``It is a know-nothing statement which I abhor,'' he said. Rooney won his first Emmy award in 1968 for his script for a special program about blacks, ``Black History: Lost, Stolen, or Strayed,'' which was narrated by Bill Cosby. Former CBS anchorman Walter Cronkite said Rooney, a friend since the two were correspondents in World War II, was not a racist. Cronkite said his ``more outrageous comments'' may offend some people from time to time, ``but any suggestions that such a rare journalistic voice should be silenced indicates a dangerous weakness in our pluralistic society.'' The article, in which Rooney also discussed homosexuals, was entitled, ``Andy, We Hardly Knew Ye,'' and had a subtitle, ``And Now, a Few Homophobic Minutes with Andy Rooney.'' Rooney's suspension came two years after CBS fired Jimmy ``The Greek'' Snyder as an ``NFL Today'' commentator after he said blacks were better athletes than whites because they were ``bred that way'' during slavery. In his statement, Burke said that Rooney's future with CBS will be discussed at the end of the suspension. ``I have made it clear that CBS News cannot tolerate such remarks or anything that approximates such comments,'' Burke said. ``Mr. Rooney has expressed his dismay that the values of CBS News have been called into question, and offers his deepest apologies to any in our society who are given offense.'' Rooney said he would continue writing his twice-weekly syndicated humor column, which he said is distributed to about 260 newspapers. Bull, the reporter, said his quotations of Rooney, taken down during a phone interview three weeks ago, were accurate. He did not tape the interview. On Wednesday, Benjamin Hooks, director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, called the purported remarks ``ill-informed and racist.'' Hooks praised CBS for moving so quickly, but said the NAACP did not ``wish to rush in judgment and we will insist that there be a further and thorough investigation.'' New York Mayor David Dinkins called CBS to ``register shock,'' according to a spokesman. Later, Dinkins said: ``Gay men and lesbians, as well as African-Americans, are justified in their outrage about both Mr. Rooney's comments and his subsequent attempts to explain them away.'' Rooney previously has gotten into hot water with homosexual groups because of a remark he made in a Dec. 28 CBS special, ``A Year With Andy Rooney: 1989.'' In that show, he said that, ``many of the ills which kill us are self-induced,'' and then cited ``too much alcohol, too much food, homosexual unions, cigarettes.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Officials Applaud East Germany for Stand on Holocaust
DOC.TEXT: Israeli officials today praised East Germany's decision to acknowledge a share of responsibility for the Holocaust but said they want practical steps before forging ties with that country. In a letter released Thursday, Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany recognized that his people bore some of the responsibility for the deaths during the Holocaust. He also pledged ``material support'' for the victims of Nazi persecution but did not elaborate. Michael Shilo, an Israeli Foreign Ministry adviser on diaspora affairs, said today, ``We have to ... chew a little bit on the wording of Modrow's declaration. But obviously it is a beginning. I don't think we have ever heard before this kind of a declaration from East Germany.'' Israel and East Germany never had formal ties because of East Germany's denial of responsibility for the Holocaust, in which an estimated 6 million Jews were killed by Nazi Germany. East Germany has maintained it was a new state created in 1949 by Communists and could not accept blame for crimes committed by the Third Reich in World War II. Communists also suffered persecution under the Nazis. However, in his letter addressed to Edgar Bronfman, president of the World Jewish Congress, Modrow said East Germany ``recognizes the responsibility of the entire German people for the past.'' ``This is a consequence of the deep guilt of Hitler fascism, which committed terrible crimes against the Jewish people in the name of the German people,'' Modrow said. The daily Jerusalem Post today reported a similar letter was sent to the Israeli government and that its text was approved in last week's talks between the two countries in Copenhagen, Denmark. Those discussions were described as a preparatory meeting to discuss establishment of ties. Israel followed the talks with a statement saying establishing relations would be linked ``to the question of the acceptance by (East Germany) of its share in the moral and historical responsibility'' for Nazi crimes against the Jews. Shilo, who attended the talks in Copenhagen, welcomed Modrow's statement in an Israel radio interview today. Asked whether Israel could now establish diplomatic relations with East Germany, Shilo said: ``A verbal declaration is just a beginning. A verbal declaration should be backed up by some tangible deeds in terms of education in school curriculum, and maybe in legislation and some other things.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu noted East Germany's shift in position came as speculation increased about uniting Germany, which was split in the aftermath of World War II. Israeli leaders have expressed fears of unification. West Germany has accepted blame for the crimes of Nazi Germany and paid $43 billion in reparations to Holocaust survivors and their families over the years. Israel Singer, secretary-general of the World Jewish Congress, said his group is now likely to handle the issue of reparations from East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Will Not Get Annual Disney Passes
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney theme parks will no longer send passes to elected officials that entitled them to a year of free admissions. From now on, legislators, congressmen, city and county commissioners and other politicians will have to call and ask for tickets if they want to visit the Florida and California parks without charge. The Walt Disney Co. said the practice was stopped because some of the elected officials found it difficult to place a value on the Silver Passes for gift-disclosure purposes. Bill Jones, executive director of Common Cause in Florida, said Disney's new policy will direct attention to elected officials who ask for free tickets. ``Now it is incumbent on the elected officials to out-and-out ask for these favors instead of having them offered to them,'' Jones said. The pass allowed officials to bring up to four guests each time they visited. In Florida, one adult admission to a Disney park costs $30.65.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Descends on Midwest
DOC.TEXT: A cold front with a 400-mile wide band of clouds stretched from the Ohio Valley to the lower Great Lakes today, ending a warm spell, while storms continued to dump rain and snow on Washington and Oregon. Northwesterly winds today cooled temperatures in the heartland far below Thursday's numerous record highs. Even with the chill, however, readings were expected to be seasonably warm. In Washington state, Snoqualmie Pass remained closed early today as heavy snow clogged roadways in the Cascade Mountains. Stevens Pass and White Pass reopened Thursday while the Northern Cascades Highway was closed for the season. Snow advisories continued in the Cascades and Olympic Mountains. Rain mixed with snow was forecast for western Washington tonight. Scattered showers were expected today from eastern Texas to northern Maine. Showers and thunderstorms developed north of a warm front over the central Gulf Coast on Thursday, dumping 2 inches of rain on New Orleans. Strong winds and bitter cold spawned dangerous wind chill readings over parts of Alaska. Bethel expected wind chills nearing 80 below zero. Thursday's low temperature in Alaska was 58 below in Circle City. Ely, Nev., claimed the coldest reading in the lower 48 states at minus 20. Unseasonably warm weather prevailed Thursday in the south-central and eastern U.S. Five cities in Michigan alone reported record high readings, including Flint, which eclipsed the old mark of 43 set 25 years ago by 10 degrees. Record high temperatures for Feb. 8 set on Thursday included 42 in International Falls, Minn., and Negaunee, Mich.; 45 in Alpena, Mich., and Binghamton, N.Y.; 47 in Mansfield, Ohio; 56 in Youngstown, Ohio; 57 in Muskegon, Mich.; 58 in Rockford, Ill.; 59 in South Bend, Ind.; 61 in Beckley, W.Va.; 63 in Peoria and Moline, Ill.; 66 in Burlington, Iowa; 70 in St. Louis, Mo.; 74 in Charleston, S.C.; and 76 in Tulsa, Okla. Thursday's hot spot was 89 degrees at Laredo, Texas. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y., 42 fair; Atlanta 53 rain; Boston 39 fair; Buffalo 53; Charleston, S.C., 59 cloudy; Chattanooga 55 cloudy; Cincinnati 56 windy; Cleveland 55 windy; Detroit 53 windy; Hatteras 48 cloudy; Jacksonville 62 foggy; Key West 74 fair; Knoxville 52 cloudy; Macon 58 cloudy; Miami 70 fair; New York 42 foggy; Philadelphia 42 foggy; Pittsburgh 53 partly cloudy; Portland, Maine, 36 fair; Richmond 49 fair; Tampa 69 cloudy; Washington, D.C., 47 fair. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 59 foggy; Bismarck 23 windy; Chicago 48 cloudy; Denver 26 partly cloudy; Des Moines 29 fair; Fort Worth 63; Indianapolis 57 windy; Kansas City 40 partly cloudy; Little Rock 65 foggy; Louisville 59 cloudy; Memphis 61 cloudy; Nashville 60 cloudy; New Orleans 68 foggy; North Platte 20 fair; Oklahoma City 47 partly cloudy; Omaha 30 fair; Rapid City 24 partly cloudy; St. Louis 52 rain; Minneapolis-St. Paul 25 fair; Sault Ste. Marie 33 cloudy; San Antonio 69 cloudy. _WEST: Albuquerque 33 partly cloudy; Anchorage 1 partly cloudy; Boise 34 cloudy; Casper 25 windy; Fairbanks -33 fair; Great Falls 17 partly cloudy; Honolulu 71 windy; Las Vegas 34 fair; Los Angeles 51 fair; Medford 40 cloudy; Pendleton 41 cloudy; Phoenix 52 showers; Portland, Ore., 46 cloudy; Reno 37 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 24 fair; San Diego 51 fair; San Francisco 51 cloudy; Seattle 43 foggy; Spokane 30 cloudy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 9 fair; Montreal 37 cloudy; Ottawa 41 cloudy; Regina 1 windy; Toronto 48 cloudy; Winnipeg 28; Nassau 70 fair; San Juan 72.

DOC.HEAD: Legislators Urge Probe of Media, Police Tactics in Stuart Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A bill creating a special commission with subpoena powers to investigate the way the media and police handled events unfolding from the shooting of Carol Stuart won support from several lawmakers and the governor. ``If this thing continues and if there is no cleansing of the wound ... a lot of people are going to be hurt,'' state Sen. Bill Owens of Boston said at a hearing Thursday before a joint Judiciary Committee. Backers of the bill said that a study is needed to determine why police focused on a black suspect in the initial investigation, and why reports about the investigation were leaked to the media. The bill would establish an 11-member commission that could meet in secrecy much like a grand jury. Charles Stuart originally told investigators that he and his pregnant wife were shot by a black mugger while leaving a childbirth class. Mrs. Stuart died of her wounds and the couple's son, born prematurely after the shooting, died later. Stuart apparently committed suicide last month, after investigators learned his story was a hoax and that he had plotted to kill his wife. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said he supports the bill. ``The creation of a commission would allow us to step back and look at the larger picture,'' he said in a letter to the committee. Members of Boston's black community criticized the way police handled the investigation, saying young black men were targeted unfairly during police searches. Many of those who spoke in favor of creating the commission said the media must take much of the blame for the way the Stuart case was presented to the public. ``The media today is a business. The media is a big business. The media is a profitable business,'' said House Ways and Means Chairman Richard Voke, whose law partner is representing members of the Stuart family. ``If people get riled up, it's good for business.'' One member of the committee, Rep. Michael Flaherty of Boston, spoke against the proposal, saying it could hurt the criminal investigation. ``The creation of such a commission would be improper, imprudent and unprecedented,'' he said. Frank McGee, attorney for the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association, said there was no need for a special commission to do what 15 agencies already have the authority to do. He said the police's actions in the case were appropriate. ``The police response was excellent,'' he said. ``If anything, they should have been even more aggressive.'' But several groups, including the National Organization for Women and the Anti-Defamation League, said a commission was needed. ``The interest in this case _ on the part of city officials, state leaders and the media _ reflects nothing short of insidious institutional racism,'' Ellen Convisser, president of Boston NOW, said in prepared remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Scouts To Admit Girls
DOC.TEXT: Breaking with an 80-year tradition and a warning in the first Boy Scout manual that girls can ``lower a man's innate character,'' the British boys' group has opened its doors to the other sex. The decision, announced Thursday by Chief Scout Garth Morrison, prompted criticism from the Girl Guides, the Boy Scouts' sister movement. A Scout spokesman said Thursday there were 680,000 British Scouts, and there had been a lot of pressure from girls eager to join, attracted by the more adventurous activities. Morrison announced local Scout groups would be able to choose whether to admit girls, noting that some ``want nothing to do with girls.'' No group would be forced to have them, he said. ``We are aware that in some places there is a pressing need for it, and we are anxious to meet that need. It is an important move and a move in the right direction,'' Morrison said. Morrison, an ex-Royal Navy lieutenant, said the Scout movement would be opened to girls ages 6 to 15, with the first girl scouts probably enrolled in 1991. The Boy Scouts of America movement has allowed girls ages 6 to 15 in its explorer division for about 19 years, according to national spokesman Lee Sneath. Dr. June Paterson-Brown, chief commissioner of the British Girl Guides Association, said she was ``very angry'' when she learned of the decision. ``I hope we are big enough to say that if the Scouts want this, it's their decision. If they try to poach our girls, then it will make things very difficult,'' she said. The two groups had just finished a two-year joint study on greater cooperation. The head of the Guides, who count Queen Elizabeth II as their most famous ex-member, added: ``They are out of step. Youth services in general have gone full circle and now generally tend to favor single-sex activity again.'' Lord Baden-Powell, the founder of the Boy Scouts, developed many of his ideas about scouting from his experiences in the Boer War and originally envisaged the group as a surveillance force to keep watch on enemy movements. When Baden-Powell founded the Scouts, he allowed girls to join. ``Although he had difficulty communicating with women and preferred the company of boys and men, it had always been his intention that the scouts would be for boys and girls,'' biographer Timothy Jeal told The Times of London. ``It was only an Edwardian outcry against the coarsening effect that such a thing would have on genteel young ladies that forced him to abandon the idea.'' The Times said eight girls had come in uniform to the first national scout rally in 1910. Baden-Powell reportedly turned to his sister, Agnes, and said, ``Do something about them, will you?'' The Girl Guides were founded two months later. Baden-Powell himself always had doubts about the effect of the female of the species on the psyche of the developing male. In his 1908 founding manual, ``Scouting for Boys,'' he wrote: ``A loud, vulgar girl could lower a man's innate character.'' Nicola Lowes, 14, who was turned down in October when she and two friends applied to join the Scout group in Wark, northern England, said she would reapply Monday. ``I was in the Guides for a little while, but I thought it was really boring,'' she said. ``Scouts seem more active, and you get outdoors more. I was really upset when I was turned down .... It just wasn't fair.''

DOC.HEAD: Koch: Soviet, Eastern European Jews Should Emigrate to Israel
DOC.TEXT: The sweeping changes in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe could lead to persecution of Jews, so they should emigrate while the can to Israel, said former New York Mayor Ed Koch. Slavic anti-Semitism, held in check by Communist governments, could explode in new pogroms if nationalist parties take over in the Soviet bloc, Koch said in a speech Thursday to the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith. ``They ought to leave and board those El Al planes as soon as they can and fly on wings of eagles to the state of Israel,'' Koch told about 640 people attending a meeting of the group's executive committee, which bestowed him with the league's Distinguished Public Service Award. Koch, defeated last year by David Dinkins in his try for a fourth term as mayor, said he now has a radio show, a television show, a newspaper column and is out of politics for good.

DOC.HEAD: Equipment Seized From NY Port Authority to Pay $910 Debt.
DOC.TEXT: A Washington consultant who has been fighting the bureaucracy of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey for months has walked into its offices here and seized repayment in office equipment, according to a published report. U.S. Marshals accompanied Frank M. Graves as he carried a fax machine, a computer and other equipment from the office of the $1.4 billion agency Thursday morning to repay the $909.80 debt, according to a story in today's editions of The Washington Post. Graves had been fighting the Port Authority for months in small claims court, saying the agency owed him the money for filling in as a speaker at a $2,500-a-head seminar run by the authority. The agency said it had made no such agreement with Graves. Graves won judgment when the agency failed to turn up for a hearing. He was therefore allowed to collect $1,524.15, adding court costs to the original amount under dispute, according to The Post. When the money wasn't paid him, Graves obtained a writ of seizure and took the two U.S. Marshals to the office to collect the full amount in cash and assets, The Post said. ``The whole case is based upon a giant mistake made by the court,'' Hugh Welsh, an assistant general counsel in New York, told The Post. As a public agency, the Port Authority has ``sovereign immunity'' from lawsuits, he said. ``I guess the answer is, you've got to come to court to say that,'' responded Superior Court Commissioner Thomas J. Gaye, who issued the ruling for Graves in November. D.C. law allows the authority to reopen the case, which it began efforts to do Thursday afternoon by hiring a local law firm to seek the return of its equipment and dismissal of the case.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary, Vatican Establish Diplomatic Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with details of past negotiations, papal visit; CORRECTS Casaroli's title; picks up 8th pvs, `Under pressure...'
DOC.TEXT: Hungary and the Vatican today formally re-established diplomatic ties that were severed in 1945, the state news agency MTI reported. The action as the latest sign of improvement in relations between the Roman Catholic church and Eastern European countries that toppled hard-line Communist leaders in popular revolutions last year. Premier Miklos Nemeth and Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, the Vatican secretary of state, signed the document restoring ties in Parliament. Casaroli arrived Wednesday on a five-day visit. In restoring relations with the Vatican, Hungary became the second East bloc country to do so in less than a year. Poland re-established ties in July. Czechoslovakia's new non-Communist government has also said it wants to restore ties with the Holy See. Negotiations between Hungary and the Vatican had been going on for months, and both sides had earlier agreed Pope John Paul II would visit Hungary next year. Parliament passed a law Jan. 24 that separates church and state, ending state interference in church affairs, and grants all denominations full autonomy. Separate legislation legislation is planned on the return of confiscated church assets. Under pressure from the Stalinist leadership, Hungary's Catholic church surrendered its autonomy on Aug. 30, 1950. That law was formally annulled Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Assembly Approves Constitution, Prepares For Independence
DOC.TEXT: The Constituent Assembly today unanimously adopted a democratic, Western-style constitution in preparation for Namibia's independence from South Africa on March 21. The constitution guarantees fundamental individual rights and limits a president to two five-year terms, a rarity in a continent where leaders often serve for life. Its unanimous adoption represents a spirit of reconciliation among assembly members who were on opposite sides during a 23-year guerrilla war for independence. The 72-member assembly approved the constitution in a session held on the front steps of the Tintenpalast, the legislative building on a hilltop in Windhoek. ``Today the masses of our people have a constitution which embodies their aspirations to be masters of their own destiny,'' said Sam Nujoma, who is expected to be the first president and is leader of the dominant South-West Africa People's Organization. The session also was attended by Louis Pienaar, the South African administrator of the territory, and Martti Ahtisaari, head of the U.N. contingent monitoring the independence process. South Africa has ruled Namibia since 1915, but agreed to grant independence under a regional peace treaty also signed by Angola and Cuba. More than 6,000 U.N. civilian and military personnel have been monitoring the process since last April. Nujoma's group, which began a bush war against South African rule in 1966, won 41 assembly seats in November's election and will form the first government. Despite a hard-fought campaign and sharp ideological differences, the seven parties represented in the assembly quickly reached agreement on the constitution. It has a declaration of fundamental rights, including freedom of movement, speech and the press. It also envisions a multiparty democracy, regular elections, an independent judiciary and a president. Most of the Cabinet posts already have been appointed by Nujoma. Today, he named a white businessman, Gert Hanekom, to serve as minister of agriculture. Nujoma has named whites, businessmen, and opposition party members to his Cabinet in a bid reconcile Namibia after the lengthy war and to ease fears of the 75,000 whites, who control most of the economy. The independence celebrations next month are expected to attract more than 20 heads of state and thousands of foreign guests to Windhoek, a town which has only a few hotels. The city has a population of about 120,000 and is by far the largest city in the semi-arid territory of 1.3 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Calls Soviet Annexation Invalid
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian parliament has declared its 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union was ``unlawful and invalid,'' and Tass today acknowledged the move as a step toward secession. The Lithuanians, whose Communist Party broke with the Kremlin in December, took the new action Wednesday. They said they want to start talks with Moscow on Lithuanian independence. Estonia took a similar action in November, declaring the annexation of the Baltic republics invalid. The legislatures of all three Baltic republics, including Latvia, already had condemned the Soviet-German agreement of 1939 that gave free rein to Hitler in Poland and to Stalin in the Baltics. Lithuanian's Supreme Soviet, or parliament, on Wednesday passed a resolution declaring that legislation passed on July 21, 1940, making Lithuania a Soviet republic did not express the will of the people and was ``unlawful and invalid.'' The Lithuanian action coincided with the final day of a meeting of the national Communist Party Central Committee, where party leaders denounced the Lithuanian party for breaking ties with Moscow. They said the split undermines the unity of the party and damages President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reform program. However, the Central Committee also said it was ready to drop its own constitutional guarantee of power and accept a multiparty system. In its report, Tass, the official news agency, said Wednesday's resolution in Lithuania ``cannot be regarded otherwise than a step toward this Baltic republic's secession from the Soviet Union.'' ``Will Lithuania and the Soviet Union proceed along the road together or take separate paths?'' the news agency asked. ``Time will judge who is right in this contention.'' The Lithuanian resolution also called for abolishing all constitutional ties of Lithuanians to the Soviet Union and returning some nationalized industries to private ownership.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Wants to Keep Public Away from Errant Bombs
DOC.TEXT: Cows can graze on land littered with errant ordnance from neighboring naval bombing ranges, but people are too curious to be allowed to hike or drive off-road vehicles there, a Navy commander said. ``We don't feel cattle are inquisitive enough to go over and start banging on a bomb with a hammer,'' Capt. Rex Rackowitz, commander of Fallon Naval Air Station, said Thursday. ``We should not ever allow the public to go on there for any recreational purposes,'' Rackowitz told the state Multiple Use Advisory Committee on Federal Lands. Rackowitz appeared to explain the Navy's ``Operation Ugly Baby'' last year to clear out or blow up bombs and other ordnance dropped outside his base's ranges for 30 years because of pilot or equipment error. About 110,000 acres of federal Bureau of Land Management property, adjacent to three Fallon base ranges starting about 60 miles east of Reno, have been closed temporarily for winter while the cleanup progresses. The bureau opposes letting the Navy acquire the land, however. Bureau spokesman Bob Stewart said any permanent closure of the land around the naval base's ranges would require congressional action. ``It's either totally open or totally closed,'' Stewart told the state panel. Environmentalists and state officials also oppose the Navy's request. During the cleanup efforts that were initially secret but made public in news reports, the Navy said it recovered 1,270 live pieces of ordnance on the three ranges, including 80 bombs, and 1,996 inert pieces of ordnance, including 52 bombs, one rocket and 88 small training bombs. The Navy believes it retrieved about 92 percent of the surface bombs dropped on the public lands where cattle have grazed and people have hiked and ridden off-road vehicles since the base opened in 1942. But the military can't get at below-surface explosives and duds that landed outside its bombing areas because of pilot or equipment error or which bounced on the desert surface and over fences surrounding the ranges, Rackowitz said. ``We have to assume there's a significant quantity of ordnance lying below the surface, which we have no capability of finding,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Politicians Urge Deeper Reforms in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev saying more reforms coming, adviser warns party must reform or lose power. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev today pledged to press on with yet more reforms once he has implemented the sweeping limits on Communist Party power he pushed through the leadership just days ago. An economic adviser warned the party faces the stark choice of reforming itself or losing power to the opponents it has agreed to legalize, and leading populist Boris N. Yeltsin said progressive Communists may break away to form their own party. The comments by economist Nikolai Petrakov were the first since the party's Central Committee agreed to end Communists' monopoly on power in which a top official raised the possibility that it actually could lose its ruling position. Gorbachev, meeting with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, said he had achieved everything he had set out to do at a three-day meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee that ended Wednesday. ``Once we have solidified this phase, we will move on,'' he said. Gorbachev gave a guarded answer when asked if he would run for president if the country implements a new, stronger office chosen by a contested election. ``Let's wait and see,'' he told reporters at the start of his meeting with Baker. Looking relaxed as he spoke with a half-dozen reporters, he added that the changes pushed through the Central Committee this week had been in the works ever since he took power in 1985. ``It certainly would be wrong for the West and everyone to believe we began these changes only in the last few days,'' he said. ``They have been under way since 1985.'' On Wednesday, the Central Committee gave Gorbachev nearly unanimous approval of his proposal to strike an article of the Soviet Constitution that guarantees the party the role of the country's leading and guiding'' force. Gorbachev said that now on the party will have to prove its right to rule. The Central Committee also gave Gorbachev approval to move up the next party Congress, which has the power to choose a new party leadership. Petrakov told Tass that after the party gives up its guarantee of power the party may face the possibility of losing power or perhaps even disappearing altogether. ``A choice stands before the party in the conditions of political pluralism: restructure itself and struggle to show in competition its right to be the ruling party, or slide into opposition, maybe even to leave the political arena,'' Petrakov said. Reformers contend that the party's decision to release its legal grip on power doesn't address the country's main problems, economic chaos and continued pervasive party control of society. Yeltsin, an unorthodox Communist who has emerged as the leading advocate of far-reaching change, on Thursday called the party's new program only a ``half-step forward.'' ``You talk about approving this program, how can I do it?'' he asked. A second party should be formed unless the congress removes conservatives from the party hierarchy, said Yeltsin, who cast the only vote against the changes Wednesday in the policy-marking Central Committee. Reformers said the party must end its seven-decade strangehold on the nation's institutions to fulfill its promise for a multiparty political system. ``It is necessary to eliminate party organizations in the army, the police, the KGB, the courts, in all the state institutions,'' saidYuri Mityunov, a spokesman for the independent Democratic Union. The movement for reform is building popular strength, with a growing number of angry crowds across the Soviet Union demanding the ouster of hard-line Communist leaders, Mityunov said. Party secretaries in Volgograd, Tyumen, Chernigov and Sverdlovsk were removed in recent weeks. The TV program ``Vremya'' showed a rally in Donetsk on Thursday where people demanded the resignation of Politburo member Yegor K. Ligachev, a leading conservative. In London, party ideology chief Vadim A. Medvedev said the country had avoided a ``cataclysmic explosion'' in putting into effect Gorbachev's program of reforms, known as perestroika. ``We have channeled this process into an area of controlled reaction,'' he told a news conference. Yeltsin, who also belongs to the Soviet Parliament, called the platform ``a half-step forward ... that lessens the tension before the (party) congress'' late in June. The party Congress will vote on the party platform and has the power to change the Central Committee. Yeltsin said the party platform, which has yet to be made available in its details to the public, contained outdated language and failed to endorse radical measures needed to undo the economic chaos created by central planning. He said the draft still endorses ``democratic centralism,'' the principle used to justify central planning.

DOC.HEAD: California Gang Reportedly Recruited in N.Y. Drug Wars
DOC.TEXT: Increased violence by drug dealers trying to establish turf in western New York has prompted some dealers to enlist members of a notorious California gang to fight their battles, police said. Police, who have suspected that members of the Los Angeles-based Crips were in Buffalo for the past 18 months, on Wednesday arrested six people believed to be Crips. ``Our investigation indicates they were being brought in to assist in retaliations of narcotics shootings in Buffalo,'' said Lt. M. James Starr, in charge of the Cheektowaga police narcotics division. Buffalo police estimate about 20 Crips now live in Buffalo. The Crips are major traffickers of crack cocaine, according to a study by the Drug Enforcement Administration in 1989. Along with the ``Bloods'' and Jamaican posses, they are described as ``extremely violent'' and ``operate on a `no innocent bystander' theory.''

DOC.HEAD: Burmese Troops Said to Capture Rebel Stronghold
DOC.TEXT: Government troops have overrun a stronghold of ethnic minority rebels along the Thai border after 10 days of fighting that killed at least 36 people, a military spokesman said today. The seizure of the town represented another in a string of victories in recent months that has crippled Burma's ethnic Karen insurgents. Thai authorities, confirming the capture of Three Pagoda Pass, said 3,000 to 5,000 civilians had fled into Thailand to escape the fighting. The capture came as rebels of the New Mon State Party and the Karen National Union were preparing to celebrate their national days. Foreign correspondents in Bangkok, Thailand, had been invited to the festivities and a news conference at Three Pagoda Pass this weekend. Col. Than Tun, a military spokesman, told reporters that 16 government soldiers were killed and 42 wounded in five major clashes leading to the capture of the frontier town Thursday. He said 20 rebel bodies were counted. Than Tun said mopping up operations were continuing in the area, located 170 miles southeast of Rangoon and 175 miles northwest of Bangkok. The Mon and Karen rebels are among several ethnic groups fighting for greater autonomy from the government dominated by the Burman majority. Col. Lertchai Pinthong of Thailand's border police said fighting was continuing today at a Mon military camp two miles from Three Pagoda Pass. He said Thais living in a village opposite the town had fled their homes and some wounded were being treated at hospitals inside Thailand. The border police also reported escalated fighting at Kaw Moo Ra, further north along the Thai-Burmese frontier. Burmese troops have been trying to seize that Karen base and had stepped up artillery and mortar barrages in recent days, the police said. Government forces have overrun a string of Karen military bases along the border, although the Karen National Union's headquarters at Manerplaw has not been attacked. The ramshackle town of Three Pagodas Pass includes a thriving marketplace, warehouses brimming with smuggled goods and the Mon headquarters. Some Karen also have been living there. The ethnic insurgents have come to rely on smuggling between Thailand and Burma to fuel their rebellions, while the Burmese government has stepped up efforts to control the jungle frontier. The Mon claim to field more than 3,000 fighters, while the Karen have a considerably larger force. The two have joined 20 other insurgent groups in the Democratic Alliance of Burma, which has vowed to topple the martial law government of Gen. Saw Maung. Saw Maung and a group of military officers put down a nationwide, pro-democracy uprising nearly two years ago, killing hundreds of people. The resistance forces now include students who fled the interior in wake of the crackdown and sought refuge with the rebel groups.

DOC.HEAD: Directors Guild Names TV Award Nominees
DOC.TEXT: NBC and ABC received five nominations each for Directors Guild of America awards for best television directing. NBC's ``L.A. Law'' earned three prime-time nominations. CBS trailed the other networks with three nominations, while PBS got two and HBO one. The guild, which previously announced its motion picture nominees, named the television nominations Thursday. Winners will be announced March 10 during simultaneous award banquets in Los Angeles and New York. Here are the nominees, including director, episode, show and network: Comedy series _ James Burrows, ``Sisterly Love'' episode for ``Cheers,'' NBC; Barnet Kellman, ``Brown Like Me'' episode for ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS; Harry Thomason, ``They Shoot Fat Women, Don't They?'' episode for ``Designing Women,'' CBS. Dramatic series, night _ Gabrielle Beaumont, ``Lie Down and Deliver'' episode for ``L.A. Law,'' NBC; Marshall Herskovitz, ``Love and Sex'' episode for ``thirtysomething,'' ABC; Eric Laneuville, ``I'm In the Nude'' episode for ``L.A. Law,'' NBC; John Pasquin, ``To Live and Diet in L.A.'' episode for ``L.A. Law,'' NBC. Dramatic series, day _ Victoria Hochberg, ``Jacob Have I Loved'' for ``Wonderworks,'' PBS: Joanna Lee, ``My Dad Can't Be Crazy,'' for ``Afterschool Special,'' ABC; Richard Masur, ``Torn Between Two Fathers,'' for ``Afterschool Special,'' ABC. Musical-variety _ Paul Flaherty, ``Billy Crystal: Midnight Train to Moscow,'' HBO; Hal Gurnee, ``Late Night With David Letterman In Chicago,'' NBC; Don Mischer, ``Gregory Hines: Tap Dance in America,'' for ``Great Performances,'' PBS. Dramatic specials _ Dan Curtis, ``War and Remembrance,'' ABC; Daniel Petrie, ``My Name is Bill W.,'' ABC; Simon Wincer, ``Lonesome Dove,'' CBS.

DOC.HEAD: `Herpes Gladiatorum' _ A Skin Ailment That Pins Wrestlers
With PM-CDC-AIDS, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: High school wrestlers focusing on pins, reversals and takedowns had better worry about ``herpes gladiatorum'' too, federal health researchers say. An outbreak of the viral skin disease swept through a high school wrestling camp in Minnesota last summer, leaving 60 out of 175 young men battling symptoms including blistery skin rash, fever, sore throat and swollen lymph nodes, the national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The disease is spread, the CDC said, through skin-to-skin contact _ obviously a problem for wrestlers. The Atlanta-based CDC said wrestlers should have skin examinations before practice or matches and wrestlers with suspicious skin lesions should sit out. The virus is herpes simplex type 1, the same one that causes cold sores; a different virus, herpes simplex type 2, causes genital herpes. And although the skin rash and other symptoms go away, the infection, like all herpes infections, can reappear months or years later. In 1985, a survey of athletic trainers found that about 3 percent of the nation's high school wrestlers had herpes skin infections during the previous wrestling season. Herpes gladiatorum was reported in 1964 in a study in the New England Journal of Medicine. It also is know to afflict players of rugby, another contact sport. ``We really don't know to what extent it is a problem, but it seems to be recognized by the wrestling community as something to watch out for,'' said Dr. Edward Belongia, a CDC medical epidemiologist at the Minnesota Department of Health. Some of the 60 young wrestlers who became ill at the Robinson Wrestling Camp at the University of Minnesota last summer already have had a recurrence, Belongia said. It's not known if they have spread the ailment to any other wrestlers in this year's competition. The outbreak was discovered during the final week of the 26-day Minnesota camp, and contact was discontinued for the final two days. Herpes conjunctivitis _ inflammation of the eye covering _ occurred in five patients, although none developed keratitis, a more serious inflammation of the cornea.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Parties Merge, Protesters Fight Police
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to RESTORE Roh's full name and title. Pickup 5th pvs, ``In an...''
DOC.TEXT: The governing party and two opposition groups formally merged today into a powerful new conservative coalition, and hundreds of radical students battled police in two cities to protest the alliance. The leader of the only remaining opposition party denounced the merger as ``a kind of coup d'etat'' that betrayed the people. No injuries or arrests were reported in the student protests in Seoul and the southern city of Kwangju. In a joint rally, 105 delegates from the governing party and two opposition groups unanimously voted to join forces as the Democratic Liberal Party and ratified its platform, constitution and basic policies. President Roh Tae-woo, along with Kim Young-sam and Kim Jong-pil, leaders of the country's second and third largest opposition parties, were named as the new coalition's ``supreme leaders'' for two-year terms. In an address read by a deputy, Roh praised the merger as a historic step that will bring stability and peace to Korea's faction-ridden politics and promised that the new party would accelerate democratic reforms. In Kwangju, about 1,000 students clashed with police after an anti-government, anti-U.S. rally at Chonam University, said the national news agency, Yonhap. It said about 1,000 riot police, backed by armored vans with tear-gas launchers, stormed into the school to break up the rally, Yonhap said. The students countered with rocks and firebombs, touching off running battles that lasted nearly an hour, Yonhap said. Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, is the seat of opposition leader Kim Dae-jung, whose party was isolated by the merger. The city was also the scene of a 1980 civil uprising that left about 200 people killed. Students demanded the expulsion of U.S. Ambassador Donald Gregg, claiming that Washington was behind the three-party merger. In Seoul, about 300 students at Yonsei and Seoul National Universities threw rocks in clashes with police after separate rallies at their schools. No injuries or arrests were reported in either protest. Dissidents and radical students have vowed to lead a nationwide movement against the new party. But Kim Dae-jung, head of the opposition Party for Peace and Democracy, denounced the merger as ``a kind of coup d'etat that reversed people's will.'' ``The merger was a step backward in democracy. It was a miscalculation and disregarded the people's power,'' he said. Kim, labeled by some government officials as a leftist, claimed many voters ``feel betrayed'' after finding that opposition legislators they elected are now members of the governing party. The new party will be registered with election authorities by Feb. 15, a procedure required by law, and begin to act as a single negotiating body on Feb. 19, when the National Assembly opens a special 20-day session. The new party will hold at least 210 of the 299 seats in the one-house legislature, a majority that enables it to revise the Constitution whenever it chooses. The legislature was previously controlled by three opposition parties, headed by Kim Dae-jung's party. One senior party official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Roh now will concentrate more on state affairs than party issues. Under new leadership to be installed at a party convention in April, Kim Young-sam would be made the chief executive of the new party, he said. Kim, 62, is regarded as a likely successor to Roh, whose term expires in 1993. Observers believe that the new party would push a constitutional change next year to replace the nation's current presidential system of government with a parliamentary system, headed by a premier. Kim Dae-jung said his party's champions several issues spurned by the new coalition _ the right to form independent labor unions, a more equitable distribution of wealth, abolishment of the national security law and further limitations on the country's intelligence agency.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Forces Exchange Sniper Fire Despite Truce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with 3 killed by snipers, UPDATES death toll. Pickup 5th graf, `A police...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BEI1
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces ignored a truce and traded heavy sniper fire in east Beirut today as hundreds of civilians scrambled to safety outside the Christian sector. Snipers killed three people as they tried to escape the low-income residential district of Ein Rummaneh, police said. Rescuers evacuated the bullet-riddled corpses of 42 victims from east Beirut districts, where most of the savage fighting took place between soldiers of Gen. Michel Aoun and Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen. Those victims raised the toll, by police count, to 418 killed and 1,680 wounded in the worst intra-Christian conflict of the 15-year-old civil war. The fighting began Jan. 30. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with regulations, said the exchange of sniper fire threatened the pact announced late Thursday to end the showdown for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave encompassing east Beirut and coastal communities to the north. Aoun's soldiers are besieging the residential district of Ashrafiyeh, a stronghold for Geagea's militia, from the northeast and southeast. The clashes have divided east Beirut and other Christian districts into hostile territories, forcing hundreds of civilians to flee into the city's Moslem sector and other areas outside the enclave. Local radio stations have been broadcasting messages from people asking about missing relatives. Mrs. Nadima Mazboudi, worried about her daughter, Therese, and crippled granddaughter, Reine, said over the Voice of the People radio: ``Where is Reine? What happened to her?'' Snipers' bullets whizzed overhead today as civilians, carrying bags of clothes and other belongings, rushed into Moslem west Beirut. In one Lebanese Forces' stronghold in the city, Ein Rummaneh, Geagea's militiamen took cover on street corners. ``Aoun will pay dearly if he tries to storm Ein Rummaneh,'' said a bearded Lebanese Forces militiaman. ``Thousands of his soldiers would be killed,'' he said and then shouted to civilians to avoid mines planted in a nearby street. Snipers from Aoun's army fired at targets in the Ein Rummaneh district, and Geagea's militias responded with salvoes from their Soviet-made AK-47 assault rifles. ``Come and take our guns if you can!'' a militiaman shouted as he fired a 30-bullet clip from his automatic rifle in the direction of Aoun's lines. Geagea held a news conference and called Aoun, ``Mad, a liar, an utter fool in politics.'' ``You shouldn't think you can finish us off. We shall fight you 100 years,'' he said. The peace pact included a cease-fire agreement and ``affirmation that there is no intention or decision to liquidate the Lebanese Forces.'' However, it said a ``national authority'' under Aoun should be formed to tackle essential issues. Aoun has accused Geagea of trying to enforce an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end the nation's civil war. The October accord, worked out by Lebanese legislators in Saudi Arabia, led to the formation of a government under President Elias Hrawi, also a Christian. However, Aoun attacked that pact because it set no date for withdrawal of the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon, who control most of the country. Aoun, who was appointed last year to head an interim cabinet, refused to acknowledge Hrawi's government. The Syrian soldiers were deployed in Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League mandate to quell the civil war fighting. However, Aoun says they violated their peacekeeping mandate by siding with the Moslems.

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Sullivan Canned As `CBS This Morning' Anchorwoman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Sullivan spokesman confirming report but no comment from CBS; DELETES incorrect reference in 7th graf pvs that ABC `World News This Morning' is part of `Good Morning America' show; adds background. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto upcoming
DOC.TEXT: ``CBS This Morning'' anchorwoman Kathleen Sullivan, who said last year that she expected to be replaced if her show's third-place ratings didn't improve, is being taken off the program, her spokesman said today. ``She was notified by CBS brass Wednesday night,'' said the spokesman, John Scanlon, who described Sullivan as ``disappointed, but proud of her contributions to the show.'' The program, co-anchored by Harry Smith, made no mention today that she is leaving. Sullivan did not say anything about it on the air. Terry Everett, a CBS News spokeswoman, said today that the network ``can't confirm or deny'' reports that she is leaving. The anchorwoman, whose CBS contract expires in November, did her part of today's show from Atlanta. Everett said the anchorwoman had gone there on personal business. Scanlon said no decision has been made yet on when Sullivan will leave ``CBS This Morning,'' but that she will help the transition process and ``is looking forward to discussing other possibilities at CBS.'' There have been reports that her successor will be Paula Zahn, anchorwoman of ABC's ``World News This Morning.'' Sullivan co-anchored that program and news segments of ABC's ``Good Morning America'' before joining CBS News in 1987. ``We have no comment at this point,'' said ABC spokesman Scott Richardson when asked if Zahn may be leaving ABC for CBS. ``CBS This Morning'' has consistently trailed ``Good Morning America'' and NBC's ``Today'' in the ratings. The latter program was in the headlines last fall when it became known that Jane Pauley, the show's co-anchor for 13 years, would be succeeded by Deborah Norvile. Norville began her new job in January. In October, during an appearance with Pauley on the ``Donahue'' syndicated talk show, Sullivan said she would be fired if her show's ratings didn't improve. The month before, she riled CBS executives when, while speaking into a microphone she didn't know was live, she joked that CBS stood for ``Cheap Broadcasting Service.'' The comment was heard on CBS' closed-circuit television system, but was not broadcast over the air.

DOC.HEAD: 12-Year Prison Term For Killer Of Zola Budd's Father
