DOC.TEXT: A man with at least seven previous theft and fraud convictions was sentenced today to 12 years in prison for the shotgun murder of Frank Budd, father of distance runner Zola Budd. Christiaan Barnard, 24, who could have been sentenced to hang, was described by Supreme Court Justice A.P. von Coller as a dishonest witness. But the judge said there was a reasonable possibility that Barnard had been provoked into the killing because Budd made sexual advances toward him. Barnard also was convicted of stealing a pick-up truck from Budd's farm. Budd, 59 at the time of his death in September, was a homosexual, according to associates and family members. Zola Budd said after his death that his homosexuality was a factor in her parents' separation in 1984 and subsequent divorce. She had very little contact with him after the divorce and did not invite him to her wedding last year. Because of her father's British ancestry, Ms. Budd was able to obtain a British passport and compete in the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. South Africans are barred from the Olympics and most international competition because of the government's racial segregation policies. In the 3,000-meter run in Los Angeles, Ms. Budd collided with U.S. star Mary Decker, and the American was unable to finish. Budd finished seventh to a chorus of boos. She later set several world distance records while living and training in Britain but returned to South Africa in May 1988, complaining of mental exhaustion because of harassment from anti-apartheid activists. She has resumed competition in South Africa, although her times are still far slower than her career bests.

DOC.HEAD: Spiritual Leader: Rushdie's Death Sentence Must Be Carried Out
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Thatcher condemning sermon, reaction from Rushdie friend. Pickup 7th graf, `The international...'
DOC.TEXT: The late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's order calling for the death of author Salman Rushdie must be carried out, Iran's spiritual leader said today. In London, British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher condemned today's sermon by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and said it was ``much to be regretted.'' In a related development, nine Iranians deported from Britain arrived in Tehran. Khamenei, Khomeini's successor, said Khomeini's fatwa, or religious decree, ``about the writer of the blasphemous book, `The Satanic Verses' is still valid and must be implemented,'' according to a Tehran radio broadcast monitored in Nicosia. Rushdie, an Indian-born British author, has been in hiding in Britain since Khomeini issued the decree Feb. 14, 1989. Moslem fundamentalists consider his 1988 book blasphemous for its irreverent treatment of the Prophet Mohammed, Islam's founder. Rushdie said this week he considered appearing in public to deliver a lecture on censorship, but had been dissuaded by his police guards. He also said he regretted the pain the book had caused but said he stood by his work. He said he was pressing for a paperback edition. Viking Penguin, Rushdie's publishers, has said no decision has been made about a paperback edition. Blake Morrison, literary editor of The Independent on Sunday and a friend of Rushdie, called Khamenei's statements ``disappointing news in a week when he (Rushdie) has made a real effort to reopen the debate in a more peaceful way.'' ``Obviously it was perhaps too much to hope that a conciliatory tone adopted here would filter through to Tehran,'' Morrison told BBC radio. The international controversy over the book increased last year when Khomeini issued the death decree and several Iranian leaders put a $5.2 million bounty on Rushdie's head. Britain, along with about 12 Western allies, recalled their ambassadors from Tehran to protest the fatwa. The European allies resumed ties with Iran, but Tehran severed relations with London, accusing it of trying to pressure Khomeini to revoke the death decree. In Tehran today, an Iranian TV journalist deported along with an Iran Air official and seven students, said it was no coincidence that their expulsions came near the anniversary of Khomeini's death decree. The London bureau chief of the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting, identified only as Keivanara, told Tehran radio ``the expulsion of the students was a political action taken on the anniversary of the death order against Salman Rushdie.'' Britain announced Feb. 1 that the nine had to be out within a week for reasons of national security. It did not elaborate, but similar expulsions in the past have been linked to the Rushdie death decree.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Meets Arab Leaders Over Jewish Emigration
DOC.TEXT: An American diplomat met with high-ranking officials of the PLO and the Arab League to discuss the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, sources in the Tunisian capital reported today. In Damascus, Syria, the Soviet ambassador suggested that Arab nations take ``active steps'' against the United States to prevent Soviet Jews from settling in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, the official Syrian Arab News Agency reported today. Soviet Ambassador Alexander Zotov did not specify what steps should be taken and did not refer to the United States by name in the statement he made to the agency Thursday. But he said, ``Arabs should take effective and active steps against those Western nations who provide Israel with large economic, financial and military aid which constitutes the essential base for Israel to continue its expansionist and aggressive policy and ignore the demands of the international community.'' The United States gives Israel $3 billion in aid annually, its largest single beneficiary. The aid cannot be earmarked for use in the occupied territories, but it amounts to a massive subsidy for the Israeli budget. Zotov said the Soviet Union understands the distress of Arab governments over Israel's plan over the next three years to settle 300,000 Soviet Jews in the territories it seized in the 1967 Mideast war. But he said Moscow cannot block Soviet citizens from settling where they wish. The Palestine Liberation Organization wants to establish an independent state in the territories and fears large-scale settlement of Soviet Jews will make a negotiated settlement impossible. The populations of the West Bank and Gaza Strip are overwhelmingly Palestinian. The Palestinian uprising in the territories, now more than two years old, has left more than 800 Palestinians and 40 Israelis dead. In Tunis, U.S. Ambassador Robert Pelletreau met with PLO official Hakim Balawi and with Arab League President Chedli Klibi, sources said, as both organizations stepped up the campaign to choke the emigration. The Palestinian news agency WAFA said the talks Thursday between Pelletreau and Balawi covered ``the gravity and the repercussions of the migration of Soviet Jews and their implantation in the occupied Palestinian territories.'' WAFA did not say whether Pelletreau and Balawi reached an agreement. The U.S. Embassy, the sole American body authorized to talk with the PLO, never comments on such meetings. Sources close to the Arab League said Klibi and Pelletreau discussed the league's plan to send a delegation to Moscow, Washington and the European Community to press for cuts in Soviet Jewish emigration. A senior aide of PLO leader Yasser Arafat was quoted today as warning that the influx of Soviet Jews into Israel might encourage Israel to invade Jordan as part of its endeavor to create ``Greater Israel.'' Arafat spokesman Bassam Abu Sharif also warned that Israel would force Palestinians out of the occupied territories to make way for the influx. ``The Soviet Jewish immigration will form a new army that helps Israel to realize the expansionist dreams of the Israeli prime minister,'' he told the Kuwaiti daily Al-Anbaa from PLO headquarters in Tunis.

DOC.HEAD: Top Anti-Apartheid Leaders Confer With Mandela; De Klerk Warns of Race War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th graf pvs, `Murphy Morobe...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with details from meeting. Pickup 13th graf, `The Rev. ...'
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two senior anti-apartheid leaders met with Nelson Mandela today for a political strategy session. Johannesburg police clubbed peaceful demonstrators marking their first week of new freedoms. Also today, President F.W. de Klerk warned that conservative whites who have criticized the concessions he announced last week could ignite a racial war in South Africa. Police beat and chased hundreds of blacks through the streets of downtown Johannesburg after the blacks spilled out of St. Mary's Anglican Church dancing and singing freedom songs. About 1,000 people had been marking last week's legalization of the African National Congress guerrilla movement. A policeman ordered the crowd to disperse, but within seconds his fellow officers converged on the activists from both sides and began hitting them with clubs. Police chased fleeing demonstrators through busy downtown streets, toppling the stalls of vendors and forcing cars to come to screeching halts. In several instances, police surrounded unarmed demonstrators and hit them five or more times with their batons. Police arrested several people and several more were hurt. Some activists threw bottles and rocks at the police after they began hitting the demonstrators. De Klerk has said his government will permit peaceful protest if permission is sought from authorities in advance. On several recent occasions police have forcibly dispersed peaceful crowds, calling the demonstrations illegal. On Feb. 2, in a speech that opened a new era in South African politics, de Klerk also lifted restrictions on internal opposition groups, ended a 30-year ban on Mandela's African National Congress and pledged to free Mandela soon. At Victor Verster prison farm, the largest delegation yet to see Mandela at his home included most members of the executive committee of the United Democratic Front, a nationwide anti-apartheid coalition. ``His feeling was, at the end of the meeting ... how he wished he could come home with us,'' said Murphy Morobe, one of the front's chief spokesmen. Mandela and his visitors ended the session by singing ``God Bless Africa,'' the anthem of the anti-apartheid movement. The delegates presented Mandela with a policy document saying negotiations with the government could start only after democratic, non-racial elections to form an assembly that would draft a new constitution. De Klerk has rejected this demand. Morobe said on his way into the prison farm that he was ``very hopeful'' this could be the last meeting in prison between Mandela and South African activists. The Rev. Jesse Jackson tentatively plans to meet Mandela on Monday as part of his 12-day visit to South Africa. The government has not confirmed that this meeting will take place, nor has it confirmed reports that the American civil rights leader will meet de Klerk on Monday. Mandela, 71, is the most popular leader among South Africa's disenfranchised black majority and has offered to serve as mediator in talks between the government and the ANC. He has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping plan the start of the ANC's guerrilla campaign. The leader of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, Andries Treurnicht, introduced a no-confidence motion Friday in Parliament and denounced de Klerk's moves to open talks with the ANC. Treurnicht contended that the security forces had been instructed to view right-wing whites, rather than the ANC, as the government's principal enemy. ``Who is being monitored now? Not the terrorists, not the infiltrators, but our people,'' Treurnicht said. The Conservative Party has threatened to employ militant tactics to force de Klerk to call an election so whites can express their views on his moves. In Parliament, de Klerk for the first time responded publicly to the right-wing criticism and warned that the Conservatives ``will plunge this country into racial war.'' De Klerk defended himself and his National Party in a no-confidence debate. ``The National Party talks of renewal and courage, and they talk of racism and aggression,'' he said. De Klerk said his own party ``will still be here 10 to 20 years from now, looking after the interests of its people and cooperating with the leaders of other people.'' De Klerk said his National Party had recognized that a ban on the ANC and the South African Communist Party ``had the effect of drawing attention away from their faults. At the same time, it was a stumbling block in the path of the politics of negotiation.'' Meanwhile, the anti-apartheid National Sports Council said a tour by an English cricket team was provoking violence and urged British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to order the players home.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Romania
DOC.TEXT: Here is a summary of the latest developments in Eastern Europe.
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today pledged to press on with more reforms once he implements the limits on Communist Party power he persuaded the party leadership to adopt. ``Once we have solidified this phase, we will move on,'' he said. He skirted a question about whether he would run for president if the country implements a new, stronger office chosen in a contested election. In the Baltics, Lithuania's parliament declared that its 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union was ``unlawful and invalid.'' The official news agency Tass said today that the move earlier this week was a step toward secession. The Lithuanians, whose Communist Party broke with the Kremlin in December, said they want to start talks with Moscow on Lithuanian independence.
DOC.HEAD: SECRETARY OF STATE BAKER:
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Gorbachev today to discuss President Bush's latest proposal for reducing U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe. ``It merits very, very serious consideration,'' Gorbachev said of the plan. Asked if Bush should have gone further than to propose leaving 225,000 American and Soviet troops in Europe, Gorbachev said: ``I don't know. It's up to the U.S. government to make its own proposal. It would be good if we cooperate.''
DOC.HEAD: TWO GERMANYS:
DOC.TEXT: East Germany is only days away from economic collapse, a West German official said today, and Bonn's top banker said the richer German state probably could afford to bail out its foundering neighbor. West Germany's foreign minister tried to allay European fears of a united Germany by saying both German states should sign a promise not to build nuclear weapons.
DOC.HEAD: CZECHOSLOVAKIA:
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia and Israel today renewed diplomatic relations, rectifying what Prague's foreign minister called the ``nonsense'' of rupturing ties in 1967. Israeli Foreign Minister Moshe Arens signed the agreement with his Czechoslovak counterpart, Jiri Dienstbier. Dienstbier and Arens voiced hope that the resumption of ties would lead to trade and increased cooperation between Israel and Czechoslovakia.
DOC.HEAD: HUNGARY:
DOC.TEXT: Hungary and the Vatican today formally re-established diplomatic ties that were severed in 1945. The action as the latest sign of improvement in relations between the Roman Catholic church and Eastern European countries that toppled hard-line Communist leaders in popular revolutions last year.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA:
DOC.TEXT: BUCHAREST, Romania _ U.S. Secretary of State James Baker will make an unscheduled stop in Romania this weekend after his trip to Moscow, the government announced. Baker would be the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit Romania since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communists Threaten to Walk Out of Parliament
DOC.TEXT: Ex-Communist members of Parliament threatened to walk out of the chamber today after a Solidarity deputy suggested they had no moral right to vote on the design of Poland's new official emblem. The emblem _ a crowned white eagle on a red background _ will replace the uncrowned white eagle that decorated government offices and official documents during the 45 years of Communist rule after World War II. Parliament in December voted to restore the pre-war crown, symbolizing Poland's sovereignty. The vote today in the Sejm, Parliament's lower house, was on the specific pattern of the emblem. Despite heated appeals by religious-oriented deputies, Parliament rejected a design change that would have included a small cross on the crown. Solidarity Deputy Jan Lopuszanski then rose to address the 173 Parliament members elected to seats guaranteed last year to the now-dissolved Communist Party. ``I have a moral appeal to the left side of the hall, I think that this voting should take place without you. I think you would be right to abstain from voting on this issue,'' he said. The appeal was met by murmurings in the hall, with about a dozen of the ex-Communist deputies rising as if to leave. Sejm Speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewicz immediately called a short recess to avert a walkout. In recent months, there has been an increasing questioning of the legitimacy of the ex-Communist deputies, who now have become independent or joined one of two new social-democratic parties. They were elected to seats set aside for Communist Party members under last year's talks. The agreement reached in April by the Communists and the then-opposition set up what were at the time the most democratic elections in East bloc history. Poles voted June 2 on candidates for a new, completely freely elected Senate and 161 Sejm seats. The Communist candidates won none of the freely contested seats.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Wants Import Restrictions Relaxed on Bees
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department wants certain import restrictions relaxed so honey bees and bee semen can be imported from New Zealand. James W. Glosser, head of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said today that New Zealand ``is free of, and has adequate defenses against, honey bee diseases and parasites, and undesirable species of honey bees, so our import restrictions can now be removed.'' However, Glosser said the proposed rule change would allow only non-stop shipments from New Zealand to ensure the health of bees and semen entering the United States. Public comments on the proposal, docket number 89-117, can be sent by Feb. 21 to: Chief, Regulatory Analysis and Development, PPD, APHIS, USDA, Room 866, Federal Building, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Clears Way For Trial In Historic Nuclear Testing Suit
With PM-Radiation Victims
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has cleared the way for a trial by former Nevada Test Site workers who claim in a decade-old suit that they contracted cancer and other diseases from nuclear weapons testing. U.S. District Judge Roger Foley on Thursday rejected a government appeal of his earlier ruling stripping government immunity from the lawsuits, and ordered both sides to determine by mid-May which of the 400 cases should go to trial. In denying the appeal, Foley had harsh words for a government he said once felt it had the right to ``sacrifice its citizens at the nuclear altar.'' ``Thank God the government has found its conscience,'' Foley said in a ruling that was greeted with applause by family and friends of the former workers who crowded into the courtroom. Foley said Thursday that evolving legal precedent and a heightened awareness among federal lawmakers have made such claims ``a whole new ball game'' and said a trial should be held as soon as possible. ``I don't see any basis for trotting this issue back to the court of appeals,'' the judge said. Attorneys for the plaintiffs, who first filed suit in 1980, said the ruling may bring the case to trial by early next year. ``This is a big day for us,'' said Stewart Udall. Udall and fellow attorney Larry Johns said they plan to select six litigants as a representative sample for the trial, including former test site employee Keith Prescott, who first sued for $101 million in May 1980. Prescott, now 64, worked at the nuclear proving ground from 1961 to 1968 and later developed multiple myeloma, a disease that destroys bone marrow. The original litigation included 220 former test site workers _ all but 18 of whom are now dead _ but was later expanded to about 400 plaintiffs who are seeking more than $1 billion in damages. Foley, in his ruling, had harsh words for the government's management of the nuclear testing program. ``At the highest level of government it was believed and decided that national security required for human safety to be subjugated to the greater national need of the nuclear weapons test,'' he said. Foley said minutes of an Atomic Energy Commission meeting unearthed in another test site suit revealed the government's did not want to warn its citizens of the perils of nuclear testing ``because they'll raise a protest ... they must be sacrificed.'' Although Foley suggested that some surviving workers be included in the group, Johns said that may not be possible. ``Not too many are still alive,'' he said. ``Cancer is a fatal disease. That's the reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Plans Romania Stop
With PM-Baker-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to indicate that sty should have moved as a 1st Ld-Writethru to a0439, UPDATING thruout with report on Baker visit. No pickup. ^By EDITH M. LEDERER
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will make an unscheduled stop in Romania this weekend after his trip to Moscow, the government announced today. Baker would be the highest-ranking U.S. official to visit Romania since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It would follow strong U.S. criticism of the provisional government's attempts to impede opposition parties taking part in the May 20 general election. Dan Radulescu, spokesman for the governing National Salvation Front, said Baker would spend ``a few hours'' in Bucharest, probably Sunday morning. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutweiler recently indicated that Baker would not stop in Romania because his presence might give the wrong signals about U.S. support in the campaign. Baker met with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow today for a third day of arms control discussions. Baker's visit to Romania was announced as the new Council of National Unity, which gives 29 opposition parties a voice in running Romania until the May election, was holding its inaugural meeting. The 180-member council replaces the seven-member ruling council of the National Salvation Front, which came to power at the height of the revolution. The front, which has transformed itself into a political movement to contest the election, is considered the front-runner because of its role in overthrowing Ceausescu. The National Peasant Party, the largest opposition party, said it fears the front will try to control the new council and give seats to high-ranking Communists. The front expanded the ruling council to include more opposition members after widespread criticism of an anti-opposition demonstration that appeared to have been orchestrated by the provisional government. The United States was among the nations issuing criticism. The United States has been criticized in Romania for not giving enough help to the country following the revolution, the only one of the six revolts against hard-line communism in Eastern Europe that became a bloodbath. Ion Radulescu, who was appointed by the front to coordinate foreign relief, said the biggest donors have been France, Belgium, Holland, West Germany, Italy, Soviet Moldavia, which has a large ethnic Romanian population, and other East bloc countries. ``From the United States ... we are still waiting,'' he said. The United States gave $500,000 worth of aid to the International Committee of the Red Cross for Romania and donated $250,000 in medicine plus $25,000 from the U.S. ambassador's discretionary fund. ``The problem is that we didn't put red, white and blue on our aid,'' said U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Agota Kuperman. In the last two weeks, Bruce Gelb, head of the U.S. Information Agency, and Richard Schifter, assistant Secretary of State for human rights and humanitarian affairs, have visited Bucharest and met leading government and opposition figures.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Bush Troop-Cut Proposal Merits Serious Consideration
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 10th-11th grafs pvs, Bakere, who ... with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Baker going to Romania after Moscow talks
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Secretary of State James A. Baker III met for nearly four hours today and Gorbachev said President Bush's proposal for reducing troops in Europe deserves ``very serious consideration.'' Baker and senior aides were in their third day of talks with Gorbachev and other Kremlin leaders on arms control and other issues in advance of an expected superpower summit next summer. Gorbachev and Baker, accompanied by close aides, met for one hour and 45 minutes and then the two met for another two hours without aides. Baker saw Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze before and after his meetings with Gorbachev. U.S. officials said their focus was on arms control, which experts from the two sides tried to advance during the day at their own meetings. Shevardnadze said the ``discussion of the disarmament problem is proceeding very well.'' At the start of today's meeting with Baker, Gorbachev praised Bush's troop-reduction proposal for cutting the number of U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe. ``It merits very, very serious consideration,'' he said. The Soviet leader has called in the past for even broader disarmament measures. Asked if Bush should have gone further than to propose leaving 225,000 American and Soviet troops in Europe, Gorbachev said: ``I don't know. It's up to the U.S. government to make its own proposal. It would be good if we cooperate, just as we are cooperating now.'' The Soviet leader appeared relaxed as he shook hands with Baker and a half dozen U.S. officials. Baker ends his visit here Saturday and will fly to Bucharest, Romania, where that government says he will spend ``a few hours,'' probably Sunday morning. The State Department earlier had indicated Baker would not stop in Romania because of U.S. criticism of the provisional government's attempts to impede opposition parties taking part in the May 20 elections. Before today's sessions with Gorbachev, Baker met with Shevardnadze, who told reporters, ``I think we may speak of progress at the talks.'' Deputy Foreign Minister Alexander Bessmertnykh told Tass, the Soviet news agency, said the talks had a ``particularly businesslike and constructive character.'' Baker was eager to hear Gorbachev's assessment of Bush's proposal to cut troops. So far, the reaction from Shevardnadze and other Soviet officials on a proposal by President Bush to limit both sides' troops, tanks and non-nuclear airplanes in Europe has been positive. But Gorbachev, whose own disarmament goals are more ambitious, had the opportunity in today's meeting to push for even deeper cutbacks than Bush's proposal to limit both sides to 225,000. Bush's troop reduction proposal included limiting U.S. and Soviet troops in Central Europe to 195,000 on each side. He proposed allowing another 30,000 Americans elsewhere in Europe. Gorbachev spoke on a wide range of other issues before going into his meeting with Baker today, including his own future as head of the Communist Party now that the Central Committee has decided to revoke the party's monopoly on power. Asked how the action would affect him, Gorbachev said ``I would not think anything particular happened to me. What we wanted to achieve at this plenum we did achieve,'' he said. He said the changes began when he came to power five years ago and ``once we have solidified this phase we will move further.'' Over two days of meetings, Baker and Shevardnadze made some headway toward a treaty, as well as on another accord due for signing at the Washington summit meeting in June to reduce long-range nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines by 30 percent to 50 percent. On another front, the two sides are finding themselves in agreement in opposing Israel's resettlement of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union on the West Bank. ``It is quite possible that as a result of the Soviet-American talks a common viewpoint will be expressed on this issue, condemning Israel's attempt to resettle immigrants on someone else's occupied territory,'' Gennady I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Thursday night. ``There are no differences between the United States and us on this issue.'' Shevardnadze and Bessmertnykh echoed the positive U.S. appraisal of the arms control talks. ``The discussion of the disarmament problem is proceeding very well,'' Shevardnadze told Tass. Baker offered at least one concession that would permit the Soviets to exclude from a projected ceiling some of the combat aircraft they contend are defensive. The Soviets, meanwhile, dropped their demand for a provision that would allow them to scrap a treaty to reduce long-range nuclear missiles by 30 percent to 50 percent if Moscow concluded U.S. anti-missile defenses in space were illegal. But the U.S. official who reported the concession acknowledged the treaty would include a common escape clause. Either side could abandon the restrictions if it concluded the treaty did not serve its national interest. The separate briefings produced evidence of discord, too. Gerasimov said the United States still refuses to consider reducing naval forces. And he said the Soviets would not sign the treaty if a dispute over sea-launched cruise missiles was not resolved. Here, too, the Bush administration refuses to accept limits on the weapons carried aboard nuclear submarines and surface ships. The net result of the talks so far is that the superpowers' steadily more cooperative relationship apparently will not be inhibited by the decisions at the Central Committee meeting. In fact, Shevardnadze said, ``It will mean that we have more elements of trust in our relationship. We simply cannot afford lowering our international activity.''

DOC.HEAD: NRC OKs Low-Power License For Comanche Peak
DOC.TEXT: TU Electric today began loading nuclear fuel at Comanche Peak, the final, tedious step in the construction of the twin-reactor plant that took 15 years and $9 billion to complete. The utility received a low-power testing license Thursday from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which said it was satisfied with the plant's safety. The license authorizes TU Electric to test Unit 1 of the plant at up to 5 percent of full power. ``During that phase they will check things out, they will do a lot of testing, checking things out. They cannot go to full power without the commission's approval,'' NRC spokesman Bob Newlin said. ``Assuming these early operations are successfully conducted, in about three months we will be able to gradually increase output and be in full commercial operation this summer,'' said David Fiorelli, a spokesman for the utility. Newlin, however, said he could not predict when the utility would win a full-power license. The license action upset members of Citizens for Fair Utility Regulation, a Fort Worth-based activist group that asked the NRC Wednesday to indefinitely postpone licensing the plant. The group, which is also battling the plant in court, argues that TU Electric managers have not learned how to recognize and resolve serious safety problems at Comanche Peak. Betty Brink, a group member, said she does not think the plant will ever operate at full power, but if it does, ``I fear the very worst.'' But the NRC, in a news release, said the safety questions have been resolved satisfactorily. Construction on Comanche Peak began in 1975, and original estimates put the total cost at $779 million. The facility's price is now $9.1 billion. TU Electric serves 5 million customers in 85 counties in Texas, including the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Admits Responsibility for World War II Crimes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 15th, 16th grafs, In Jerusalem ... to UPDATE with further Israeli reaction; picks up 15th graf pvs, At the ...
DOC.TEXT: After denying for 40 years that it had anything to do with the Nazis' extermination of 6 million Jews, East Germany now admits responsibility for war crimes committed by the German people. The decision adopted by the East German cabinet was conveyed in a letter by Prime Minister Hans Modrow to the World Jewish Congress. The East German government also has decided to compensate survivors of the Nazi atrocities, according to the statement released Thursday in the United States and in East Berlin. The shift in East Germany's position brings it a step closer to West Germany, which in 1951 accepted full blame for the war crimes of the Third Reich. West Germany has since paid $43 billion in reparations to Israel, to Jewish organizations and to survivors and their families. But East Germany until now rejected any share of the blame and refused to compensate victims of the Nazis, arguing that the country had only come into existence in 1949 and did not bear responsibility for the deeds of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. The communists who founded East Germany had themselves been persecuted by the Nazis and viewed themselves as victims rather than perpetrators. ``The German Democratic Republic recognizes the responsibility of the entire German people for the past,'' said the government statement conveyed by Modrow in the letter to WJC President Edgar Bronfman. ``This is a consequence of the deep guilt of Hitler fascism which committed terrible crimes against the Jewish people in the name of the German people,'' according to the statement. The GDR ``recognizes its humanitarian duty with regard to the survivors of the Jewish people who suffered under Nazi oppression and confirms its readiness to provide material support to former persecutees of the Nazi regime of Jewish origin,'' the letter said. There are only about 4,000 Jews in East Germany and some 37,000 in the West _ down from a pre-war high of 530,000. Community leaders have estimated that billions of dollars worth of Jewish property was seized by the Nazis in what is now East Berlin. The GDR ``stands unaltered in its commitment to do everything against racism, Nazism, anti-Semitism and hatred among peoples,'' the statement said. East Germany is eager to establish ties with Israel and with the Jewish community in the United States, apparently as a means of attracting investments and U.S. support for its declining economy. Modrow urged Bronfman to visit East Germany soon ``in order to further our common aims.'' A WJC official said Bronfman probably would visit Modrow after East Germany's first democratic elections, scheduled for March 18. ``The acceptance of the GDR of its historic moral responsibility is an important first step'' toward speedy reparations for the victims of the Nazis, the WJC said. Bronfman leaves for Israel next week to discuss the development with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. In Jerusalem, Israeli officials today praised East Germany's decision but said they want practical steps before forging ties with that country. ``We have to ... chew a little bit on the wording of Modrow's declaration. But obviously it is a beginning. I don't think we have ever heard before this kind of a declaration from East Germany,'' said Michael Shilo, an Israeli Foreign Ministry official. At the initiation of East Germany, its representatives met last week with Israeli officials in Copenhagen for preliminary talks on establishing diplomatic relations. Israel said diplomatic relations would be contingent on East Germany's acceptance ``of its share in the moral and historical responsibility'' for the Nazis' persecution of Jews. Most of the Eastern European countries moving from communism toward democracy have recently established diplomatic ties with Israel.

DOC.HEAD: State Suspends Permits for Foreign Journalists
DOC.TEXT: The government has canceled the work permits of all foreign correspondents and ordered them to reapply for accreditation. The measure also affects local journalists working for foreign media in Uganda. Radio Uganda quoted Ben Otto of the Ministry of Information as saying Thursday the government took the action to streamline reporting by foreigners in the east African nation. There are 15 correspondents and local stringers for foreign media in Uganda. It was not immediately clear if the order was related to government charges that two local journalists defamed Zambia's President Kenneth Kaunda at a news conference Jan. 29 in Kampala. A court in Uganda dismissed the charges Tuesday after defense attorneys pointed out that the statute under which they were brought required publication of the defamation. But Alfred Okware, 34, of the independent monthly magazine Newsdesk, was held on another charge of being in possession of a seditious article. Festo Ebong, 29, of the government-owned New Vision newspaper, was rearrested without charge when leaving the court. At the news conference Jan. 29, Okware asked Kaunda why he did not consider relinguishing Zambia's presidency after 25 years in power. Ebong asked Kaunda why Zambia's national airline flies from Johannesburg to New York when the president is in the forefront of those calling for sanctions against South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Formally Charged in Shooting of Nagasaki Mayor
DOC.TEXT: A member of a right-wing group was formally charged Friday with attempted murder in the shooting last month of the mayor of Nagasaki, prosecutors said. The victim, Hitoshi Motoshima, had received death threats for more than a year after saying that the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for Japan's involvement in World War II. Local prosecutors said they filed attempted murder charges with Nagasaki District Court against Kazumi Tajiri, 40, who has reportedly confessed to shooting Motoshima in the back on Jan. 18. The 67-year-old mayor is in fair condition, his doctors said. Police said Tajiri told investigators he ``couldn't condone'' the mayor's comments about Hirohito and intended to punish Motoshima, not kill him. Tajiri is a member of a rightist group called Seikijuku, or Sane Thinkers' School, police said. Rightist groups in Japan rever the imperial family. As Hirohito lay dying of cancer in December 1988, Motoshima enraged many rightists by saying the emperor ``shares responsibility for the war, as well as all of us who lived in that period.'' Hirohito died Jan. 7, 1988, at the age of 87. His involvement in the war was never fully clarified.

DOC.HEAD: Government Bans Public Meetings on Moslem Sabbath
DOC.TEXT: The government kept the city under curfew and barred thousands of Moslems from gathering at weekly prayer services on Friday, the Moslem sabbath, to prevent violence by militant separatists. Despite the measures, two bombs exploded in Srinagar, a stronghold of Moslem secessionists who seek independence for the Moslem-dominated region of Kashmir. Officials said no one was injured in the blasts. At least 82 people have been killed since Jan. 20 in frequent street clashes between militants and security forces in Srinagar and nearby areas of Kashmir. Most victims have been Moslem protesters defying curfew. Srinagar District Magistrate Ghulam Abbas said one bomb exploded in a post office at 9 a.m., before the staff arrived. The building was severely damaged, he said. An hour later, another bomb blew up an empty bus parked at the city terminal beside the tourist information center, Abbas said. Two other buses parked nearby also were damaged, he said. The city imposed curfew from 11 a.m. and banned public assembly, including the Friday prayers, in the city of 1 million. The prayers normally begin at 1:30 p.m., and officials say they have been used to incite unrest. The city's leading Moslem clergyman denounced the government decision. ``I strongly condemn the anit-Islamic act of state authorities to impose day curfew consistently on Fridays for the last two months to make Jumma (Friday) prayers impossible,'' Moulvi Mohammad Farooq said in a statement. ``It is an attack on the fundamental right of worship, and I appeal to ulemas (religious heads) and leaders in and outside the country to raise their voice against it,'' he said. Despite the ban, many of the city's 200 mosques broadcast prayers through their loudspeakers. Curfew was strictly enforced and only dogs and horses were seen on the streets as paramilitary troops kept watch from bunkers at major intersections. Kashmir is a part of the state of Jammu-Kashmir, India's only Moslem-dominated state. It was divided into Indian and Pakistani segments in 1948, a year after the countries gained independence from Britain. India and Pakistan, which also claims Kashmir because of its predominantly Moslem population, went to war over the region in 1965, but the border dispute remains unresolved. India accuses Pakistan of training and aiding the Kashmiri militants, a charge that has been denied. Pakistan, however, supports the separatism, calling it a struggle for self-determination. Nationwide, Moslems make up only 12 percent of India's population of 880 million.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Agrees to Leg Amputation to Save Life
DOC.TEXT: An elderly woman who was the focus of a court battle over her refusal to have lifesaving surgery has agreed to have the operation, a relative said Friday. Ruth Trabelsi consented to the operation after a visit from Mordechai Eliahu, chief rabbi of Israel's Sephardic Jews, said a man who described himself as one of Mrs. Trabelsi's grandsons. ``The chief rabbi spoke to her ... explained the situation to her. He came out with a positive answer,'' the grandson said in a telephone interview from Poriah Hospital in Tiberias. He said doctors were planning to perform the operation later Friday to remove the 84-year-old woman's gangrenous right foot. The case went to court Wednesday after Mrs. Trabelsi refused to have the surgery, saying she wanted ``to enter the Garden of Eden on both feet.'' Doctors said she would probably die without the operation, and the government went to court under a law that requires it to protect people who may not be capable of making decisions for themselves. The case was dropped Thursday after a geriatric specialist testified that Mrs. Trabelsi was fully capable of making her own decisions. But some of the woman's 258 children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, along with leading rabbis, said they would continue pressing Mrs. Trabelsi to have surgery. The case was widely publicized in Israel and the subject of much debate over the right to die. The broadcaster who announced the outcome of the case Friday on Israel radio introduced it by saying, ``Now to the leg affair.'' Rabbi Eliahu said he agreed to talk to Mrs. Trabelsi after the family stopped arguing over the case. ``The family is all united ... Sometimes amputation is also healing,'' Eliahu said on Israel radio. Eliahu said before his trip that he felt Mrs. Trabelsi should accept doctors' advice to have her leg amputated. Rabbis who shared his view said that if she refused, she would be violating religious law by in effect comitting suicide. Other rabbis had argued that the surgery should not be forced on Mrs. Trabelsi, who developed the gangrene in her right leg as a complication from hardening of the arteries and blood clotting.

DOC.HEAD: State Expells Western Reporters
DOC.TEXT: Two only two Western reporters in Malawi said the government ordered them to leave the south African nation by midnight Friday but gave no reasons for the expulsions. Mike Hall, 27, of Britain, and Melinda Ham, 25, a Canadian, said Thursday the government canceled their residence permits Monday and gave them five days to leave. Hall, a reporter for the British Broadcasting Corp., Reuters and the London Financial Times, and Ham, a stringer for The Associated Press and a specialist African magazines, received permission to report from Malawi in October 1988. They were the first Western journalists to receive government accreditation to work here since the expulsion of a British correspondent in 1971. He was ousted for what the government called ``negative reporting.'' On Oct. 17, 1989, Hall and Ham were ordered out of the country but were allowed to return three weeks later. No official reason was given for that expulsion. Since the former British colony of Nyasaland became independent Malawi in 1964, President-For-Life Hastings Kamuzu Banda has shunned media attention and curbed activities of the local press. Several Malawian journalists have been detained without trial and others have fled their homeland, alleging widespread human rights violations. The United States has criticized Malawi's human rights record but recently described the presence of Hall and Ham there as ``a positive development.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Measuring 4.8 Hits Algeria
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake shook the Algerian capital Friday, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or serious damage. Algeria's Center for Research in Astronomy, Astrophysics and Geophysics said the quake struck at 10:31 a.m. and was centered about 45 miles west of Algiers. It measured 4.8 on the Richter scale. The earthquake lasted about 15 seconds and was followed almost immediately by a smaller tremor. Several small tremors have been recorded in the Algiers region over the past several weeks. On Oct. 29, an earthquake registering 6.0 on the Richter scale struck west of Algiers and caused 30 deaths and hundreds of injuries. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: One Police Officer Dead, Four Wounded in Clash With Suspected Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Attackers believed to be leftist guerrillas raided a suburban police station with rockets and submachine-gun fire, and one police officer was killed and four were wounded, authorities said Friday. Police said the attack was on a precinct of the investigative police in San Ramon, a working class district in southern Santiago. Police said several ``terrorists'' in a car launched the attack Thursday shortly before midnight, injuring an officer standing guard. Police gave chase and caught up with the attackers several blocks away. In the ensuing gunfight, officer Jaime Gonzalez was shot to death and three more officers were wounded, police said. The assailants fled.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged `White Woman' Comment by Ann Richards Stirs Controversy
DOC.TEXT: Gubernatorial candidate Ann Richards, who gained national attention for a speech at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, has stirred up controversy by seeming to refer in a debate to a ``white woman.'' Ms. Richards, the state treasurer, denies that she used the term ``white woman'' during Wednesday's debate among the three leading Democratic candidates, saying her comment was misheard and she was saying ``why a woman.'' Rival Jim Mattox, state attorney general, said the comment shows Ms. Richards represents the ``white, feminist fringe.'' That prompted Ms. Richards' campaign manager, Glenn Smith, to say Mattox had exceeded the ``bounds of decency.'' At issue was an answer Ms. Richards gave during the televised debate. Ms. Richards said she would veto a bill that would forbid abortions for girls 16 years of age or younger. ``No legislator, no judge and no bureaucrat has any business in determining whether a white woman has an abortion or not,'' she appeared to say. After the debate, Ms. Richards said she didn't recall exactly what word she used, but added that ``white women ... is not a phrase that I use. I think what I said was `why women.' '' Smith insisted Thursday that Ms. Richards was saying ``whether or why a woman'' in her answer. But Mattox said that his opponent had offended many Texans. ``Based on the comments last night, and based on the calls that have been coming into my office, Ms. Richards owes the black and Hispanic communities of Texas an apology. ... It's very clear that in her mindset that she represents the white, feminist fringe in Texas,'' Mattox told a Houston news conference Thursday. Smith said Mattox was panicking because of polls showing him running third among Democrats in the March 13 primary. Incumbent Republican Gov. Bill Clements is retiring. ``Mattox is acting desperate, but this goes beyond the bounds of decency,'' Smith said, adding that Mattox should be criticized for ``injecting race into the campaign.'' Neither Mattox nor the third leading Democratic candidate, former Gov. Mark White, nor a panel of journalists questioned Ms. Richards about the remark during their debate. The subject was raised during a post-debate news conference. A spokesman for White called for clarification Thursday. ``I don't think Ann intended to make a racial slur. However, I think that she needs to clarify what she said,'' said Gary Rasp, White's press secretary. Ms. Richards made the keynote address during the 1988 Democratic Convention, and poked fun at then-GOP presidential candidate George Bush, saying he was born with ``a silver foot in his mouth.''

DOC.HEAD: Deputy Marshal Hides in Shack, Witnesses Taunting Drivers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that deputy hid in shack, not chief. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `It just...'.
DOC.TEXT: Non-union truck drivers waited until federal marshals left before taunting union strikers outside a coal preparation plant wracked by confrontations between the two sides, the chief marshal says. Chief U.S. Marshal Walt Biondi said the taunts were witnessed by a deputy marshal who hid in a picket shack at Rum Creek Coal Sales Inc. to see what would happen after the other marshals left. ``I'm extremely angry that after all we've tried to do to calm the situation in the last two weeks, that this has happened,'' Biondi said. The chief marshal said he was told that the drivers made ``lewd gestures'' to the strikers and used ``obscene language.'' ``It just incenses me that something like this could occur,'' Biondi said. ``I was particularly angered after risking the safety of my people and the reputation of my people down there to restore calm.'' The United Mine Workers have been picketing the Rum Creek Coal plant since it reopened in August with non-union contractor Con-Serv Inc. running it. A non-union trucking company also is used to haul coal from the facility, which previously was worked by union employees. Last month, strikers tried to block a bridge leading into the plant with their cars, and truck drivers for several days pushed through the barricade, damaging cars and injuring several strikers. The union criticized federal marshals for not stopping the trucks and claimed the government was siding with Rum Creek Coal Sales, a charge Biondi has denied. A UMW official said Thursday's incident supports the union's long-standing accusations about company-provoked violence. ``What we've been alleging all along is that these people are there to provoke us,'' said Howard Green, the District 17 international executive board representative. Con-Serv Vice President Mike Holbrook said he doesn't condone the truckers' action but understands it. ``Both sides do it. I get the finger daily every time I cross the picket line. That's just a fact of life on Rum Creek,'' Holbrook said. The UMW and Rum Creek Coal Sales are holding closed-door negotiations aimed at settling the dispute.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Facing '90 Vote Build War Chests; Gramm of Texas Money Kingpin
With AM-Senate Money-List
DOC.TEXT: Most of the 31 senators up for re-election in November began the year with bulging campaign war chests, with nearly half having at least $1 million on hand and one a whopping $6 million. The fund-raising kingpin was Republican Phil Gramm of Texas, who has raised more than $10 million since his 1984 election and began the year with $6.1 million, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission. An analysis of those reports, released Friday by Common Cause, said political action committees have played a significant role in helping incumbents gain huge fund-raising edges over most potential challengers. Indeed, 25 of the 31 senators facing re-election this year have accepted PAC donations that would exceed PAC contribution limits included in a campaign finance reform proposal being pushed by the public interest group. The closest senator to Gramm in terms of fund-raising prowess was New Jersey Democrat Bill Bradley, who is expected to coast to re-election and is often mentioned as a possible presidential contender in 1992. Bradley told the FEC he had $4.1 million on hand as of Dec. 31. The poorest of the 31 was Sen. Nancy Landon Kassebaum, R-Kan., who has raised just $90,860 since 1984 and began 1990 with $157,817 in campaign funds. A breakdown of PAC donations provided in the Common Cause analysis supports the organization's claim that PACs are providing hefty assistance to most incumbents. Of the 14 senators who began the year with more than $1 million, Democrat David Boren of Oklahoma was the only one who has not accepted any PAC donations. Of all 31, only Boren and Democrat John Kerry of Massachusetts _ who had $874,000 in campaign funds as of Dec. 31 _ accepted no PAC money. Of the 29 whose campaigns took PAC money, Gramm was again the leader, receiving $1.1 million from PACs in the last six years, according to Common Cause. Illinois Democrat Paul Simon was not far behind, reporting $976,769 in PAC contributions since the 1984 election. At the bottom of the PAC list _ except for Boren and Kerry _ was Kassebaum, who has accepted $19,250 from PACs since 1984. Simon faces a tough challenge from Republican Rep. Lynn Martin, who leads all Senate challengers with about $800,000 in campaign funds. Three other House Republicans challenging or expected to challenge incumbent Democratic senators, Bill Schuette of Michigan, Thomas Tauke of Iowa and Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island, trailed the incumbents in fund-raising but not by as large a margin as most of the lesser-known challengers. Schuette, who faces a primary in his effort to challenge Sen. Carl Levin, had about $350,000 on hand to begin the year while Levin had $2.3 million. Tauke, trying to unseat Sen. Tom Harkin, had $300,000 to beging the year while Harkin had $1.1 million. Schneider began the year with about $540,000 in the bank, not far behind Sen. Claiborne Pell, who had nearly $650,000. Schneider is expected to announce her candidacy soon. Common Cause said the 31 incumbent senators together raised $77.4 million since all but one last faced election six years ago, with $16.6 million of that total coming from PACs. The only senator in the group not involved in a 1984 Senate election was Republican Dan Coats of Indiana, who 13 months ago was appointed to fill the seat vacated by Vice President Dan Quayle.

DOC.HEAD: Commuter Train Collision Kills 5, Injures 70 in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: A crowded commuter train slammed into the rear of another early Friday, killing five people and injuring 70 others, a railway spokeswoman said. The accident occurred at 7:30 a.m. near the Oswaldo Cruz station 10 miles northwest of Rio's main downtown station, spokeswoman Jane Pellizone said. ``One train was stopped at a signal and the other rammed it from behind. We don't know if it was a faulty signal or human error,'' Ms. Pellizone said. The trains had eight cars each and were packed for the morning rush hour, she said. All the deaths occurred on the moving train. It was not known how fast the train was going when it hit the other. Most of the injured passengers were treated for scratches and released, but 18 were hospitalized with serious injuries, said Ms. Pellizone.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cites Philosophical Commitment to Return More Power to States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 10 grafs new with Bush comments; picks up 3rd graf pvs, The most severe.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today he has a ``broad philosophical commitment'' to returning more political power to the states and vowed to help them in cutting federal red tape. Speaking to a group of state legislators at the White House, the president praised state and local governments for ``looking for new approaches for solving old problems.'' He spoke as a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures said that half of the states face deficits or unexpectedly low revenues. At the same time, only a few of these states are likely to resort to election-year tax increases, the conference said in its report. Bush told the state lawmakers not to expect quick fixes from Washington for pressing problems. He noted his new federal budget contains increased money for education and for ``financing experimentation in the states.'' And he promised to help find ways of making federal regulations less burdensome on states. ``More federal money should not, in my view, automatically mean more federal management,'' he said. But Bush said that, in the long run, more political power needs to be returned to the states, vowing ``further implementation of this broad philosophical commitment to federalism.'' Federalism is the word the Reagan administration used for a variety of proposals to transfer programs _ and the associated costs _ from the federal government to states. In its report on state finances halfway through the 1990 fiscal year, the organization of state legislatures said on Thursday that slower revenue growth in the states is attributable to both regional economic problems and a general slowdown. The most severe financial problems are in the Northeast and New England states, but mid-Altantic and Southeastern states face shortfalls as well. ``Funding for education, for Medicaid and for expanding prison capacity will be at the top of the agendas in many states,'' said Lee Daniels, a Republican who is president of the National Conference of State Legislatures and minority leader of the Illinois House. ``But finding funds for these purposes will be more difficult than in the past few years, with half the states reporting slow economic growth is reducing revenue below projections for the current fiscal year,'' he said. The conference, an organization of lawmakers from all 50 states, released its report on state fiscal conditions as it held a leadership meeting in Washington. Only a few states are likely to impose election-year tax increases, the group said. But it predicted more tax increases in 1991, particularly if the economy declines. The report said potential deficits are expected by the end of fiscal 1990 in Massachusetts, Vermont, New Hampshire, Rhode Island, New York, New Jersey, Virginia and West Virginia. Massachusetts, where Gov. Michael Dukakis pointed to as an example of strong economic growth when he was the 1988 Democratic presidential nominee, ``suffers the states' most spectacular problems,'' according to the report. Its deficit may reach 10 percent, despite tax increases last year. In all of those states, governors and legislatures have moved to reduce spending and some are considering increased taxes, the group said. Arizona and a few Midwest states joined the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic states in facing possible revenue shortfalls in fiscal 1990 _ that is, revenue collections are running below projections, although reserves may be sufficient to make up the difference. Those states were: Maine, Connecticut, Pennsylvania, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Tennessee, Alabama, Mississippi, Florida, Missouri, Kansas, Minnesota, Michigan, North Dakota, Montana, Wyoming and Arizona. ``The recession that has crippled budgets in the Northeastern states remains regional, but a slowing revenue stream is creating difficulties for most of the Mid-Atlantic and Southeastern states as well,'' the report said. ``Far Western states are generally in good condition, as are many of the states in the nation's heartland.'' Some of the farm states that faced economic hardship and tax increases in the 1980s have seen an upturn, the report said. Energy states, which saw their state finances crash with their economies in the 1980s, are stabilizing, the report said _ although it said Louisiana's 1990 surplus was based on temporary tax measures. The report said significant tax increases are likely in 1990 in Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Louisiana, and Arizona. Kentucky, Oklahoma and Texas are considering increases for public education.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty-Iraq CORRECTIVE
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used the Nicosia, Cyprus dated story on a0570 and a0696 of Jan. 31 are asked to use the following story:
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously on Jan. 31 in connection with an Amnesty International report on human rights in Iraq, that there was coordination between Amnesty International and the London-based Organization of Human Rights in Iraq. Amnesty International and the Organization of Human Rights in Iraq do not coordinate their work.

DOC.HEAD: Man Kills Stepsons After St. Louis Hostage Incident, Police Say
DOC.TEXT: A man took his two young stepsons hostage this morning after a dispute with his estranged wife, then fatally shot the boys and wounded himself in the shoulder, police said.t, according to Capt. Robert Bauman. The names of the children were not immediately released. Police said Atkins went to visit his estranged wife, Norma Atkins, early this morning and became angry when he discovered that her boyfriend was in the apartment. He chased both adults out of the apartment and took three children hostage about 4 a.m., police said. He released one young child, who was a nephew, after police arrived, Bauman said. Police aren't sure when the two children were shot with a .22-caliber rifle, but they said hostage negotiators did not hear any shots until the one that caused police to break down the door about 9 a.m., Bauman said. One boy was found in the living room, and the other boy was found in the bathroom, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Income Plays Major Role in Higher Death Rate Among Blacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th graf pvs, `Those are...', to add further background on reasons for higher rate among poor people. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `The study...'.
DOC.TEXT: Middle-aged blacks die at a rate more than twice that of whites, but income is a major factor in the difference, according to a government study published today. A 13-year study by the national Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta found that blacks between the ages of 35 and 54 die at a rate 2.5 times greater than that of whites in the same age group, according to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association. It said 38 percent of the difference in the death rates between the races can be attributed to income disparity. ``That's a big proportion to be concerned about because it's not something that public health workers and physicians can do much about,'' said Dr. Mac W. Otten, an epidemiologist at the CDC and one of the authors of the study. ``Those are issues for health policy makers and political officials,'' Otten said in a telephone interview Thursday night. ``We need health policy makers to seriously study those factors related to income.'' Otten said lower-income people may have less access to prevention services, such as screening for cervical cancer with Pap smears, or for breast cancer with mammograms; screening for diseases like diabetes or hypertension; disease prevention programs for weight control or stopping smoking; and educational efforts to reduce risks that can be prevented. The study said another 31 percent of the difference in the death rate for blacks can be explained by their higher incidence of disease from preventable risk factors such as high blood pressure, alcohol consumption and smoking. Researchers said the other 31 percent of the difference in death rates is unexplained, though part of it may be due to lack of access to health care or factors they didn't study, such as exercise. He said researchers studied data collected between 1971 and 1984 from 8,806 black and white Amercans living in rural and nonrural areas and in communities of all sizes. ``The causes of death among blacks were the same as in the general population _ heart disease, strokes, cancer and so on _ they are dying of the same things only at higher rates,'' Otten said. ``Violence and homicides did not contribute to the excess death rate.'' Otten said researchers adjusted death rates within the study group for family income and for the preventable risk factors of smoking, blood pressure, weight, diabetes, cholesterol level and alcohol intake to come up with their conclusion. It has been known that blacks in most age groups die at rates much higher than those of whites. But the national study broke ground by quantifying the importance income plays in the different death rates between the races, Otten said. The study also marked the first time the effects of high blood pressure, diabetes and other risk factors were quantified to explain the difference in death rates, he said. Black medical leaders around the country said Thursday that the study will help overcome the perception that blacks lead unhealthier lifestyles. ``The time has come to consider universal entitlement to health care in this country,'' said Dr. James A. Goodman, president of Atlanta's predominantly black Morehouse School of Medicine. Dr. Bailus Walker, former president of the American Public Health Association, said that poverty's dominant role in preventing access to health care means that ``tinkering with the system _ expanding Medicaid to this group, granting catastrophic care to that group _ will no longer work.''

DOC.HEAD: Blacksburg Mayor Arrested on Shoplifting Charges
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of Blacksburg was charged with shoplifting two Valentine's Day cards and a candle, police said. Mayor Geraldine Dixon, 47, was arrested Thursday after she was detained by Wal-Mart Discount City employees, Gaffney police Sgt. Danny Griggs said Friday. Ms. Dixon was charged with taking $3.54 in merchandise and released after paying a $237 bond, Griggs said. Ms. Dixon did not immediately return telephone messages left at her office Friday. A member of the Blacksburg Town Council has called for Ms. Dixon's resignation. ``I have compassion for her family and everything. I just feel that there's no way she could effectively lead us anymore,'' David Hogue said.

DOC.HEAD: 1960s Rock 'n' Roll Singer Del Shannon Found Dead of Apparent Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edits throughout to add detail, CORRECT age to 55 based on information from coroner. Changes 2nd reference to Shannon throughout. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GS1, NY19
DOC.TEXT: Del Shannon, whose distinctive falsetto style on such rock classics as ``Runaway'' and ``Keep Searchin''' pushed him to the top of the charts in the 1960s, was found dead in his home from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, authorities said today. He was 55. Shannon's wife, Bonnie, found her singer-songwriter husband's body at about 11:25 p.m. Thursday with a bullet wound to the head, said Los Angeles County sheriff's Deputy Roger Hom. A .22-caliber rifle was found next to Shannon's body in the den, Hom said. He said the death was being investigated as a possible suicide, but the exact cause of death had not been established by coroner's officials. Shannon was born Charles Westover in Grand Rapids, Mich., on Dec. 30, 1934, according to coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher. Dambacher said an autopsy would be conducted over the weekend. Shannon's first and biggest hit was ``Runaway,'' recorded shortly after his discovery by Detroit agents Harry Balk and Irving Micahnik. As with many of his songs, it dealt with the pain of young love gone astray. The single made No. 1 in the United States in early 1961. His other Top 20 singles included ``Hats Off to Larry,'' ``Little Town Flirt'' and ``Keep Searchin'.'' Shannon's popularity declined in the mid-1960s, but English duo Peter and Gordon gained success with his ``I Go to Pieces.'' He tried varying his sharp, early 1960s sound by recording with producer Andrew Loog Oldham toward the end of the decade, but it was a commercial failure. In 1982, he signed a new contract with Elektra records, which released his album ``Drop Down and Get Me,'' produced by longtime admirer Tom Petty. That album met with critical approval but did not sell significantly. In 1986, television producer Michael Mann had Shannon re-record ``Runaway'' with new lyrics for the series ``Crime Story.'' In a recent interview, he discussed the stress of having a flash of fame in the music industry. ``This business will eat you up,'' he said. ``If it becomes your love and you don't have humans to love, I think you're in a lot of trouble.'' Santa Clarita is about 35 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Hold Sit-Ins at Selma City Hall, High School
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with protesters locking school doors; pick up 3rd graf, `Black protests ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Black protesters spent the night in City Hall and Selma High School, then locked the doors of the school this morning while all public schools in the city were closed for a third day because of a racial protest. Police said they had no reports of problems during the night, during which about 150 black students and adults, some in sleeping bags, camped out in the high school cafeteria. About 50 others spent the night in City Hall. Police made no immediate effort to enter the high school this morning after the protesters locked the doors. J.L. Chestnut, a Selma lawyer helping negotiate for the protesters, urged caution. ``If they go in there to arrest somebody, all kinds of things may very well happen,'' said Chestnut. Black protests have escalated since six white members of the 11-member Selma School Board voted last week to dismiss Schools Superintendent Norward Roussell, who is black. The board voted Tuesday to rescind its action, but by then the protests had widened to include other issues, including police treatment of a woman protesting the superintendant's ouster. On Thursday, school officials announced that all 11 public schools would remain closed until Monday. Thursday night, a mostly white group of nearly 1,000 parents arrived at the high school for a meeting but had to go to another school because black students blocked the entrances to the high school. Witnesses said there was no friction between the two groups. Diane Crisman, a leader of the parents' group, said, ``We were just told by some adults that that group had as much right to occupy the building as we had to meet there.'' Rose Sanders, a black protest leader who claimed a white policeman abused her during an arrest Monday, said the protest should spotlight education as next month's 25th anniversary of the 1965 Selma-to-Montgomery voting rights march approaches. ``I think the focus has to be on separate and unequal education,'' said Mrs. Sanders, a Selma lawyer. She has said Officer Ronnie Rushing touched her ``private parts'' with his billy stick as she was dragged to police headquarters earlier this week. Mayor Joe Smitherman said a report would be released this afternoon on the arrest of Mrs. Sanders and three others on misdemeanor charges after they entered his offices to protest the dismissal of Roussell. He said Rushing had been reassigned pending an investigation of the confrontation. The mayor earlier said Rushing was injured by Mrs. Sanders when she forced police to physically remove her from City Hall. Mrs. Sanders was briefly hospitalized after the incident. Scores of blacks crowded into City Hall corridors Thursday, promising not to leave until Rushing is suspended. Hundreds of students and adults settled in at Selma High. ``We as students are sick and tired of being sick and tired,'' Catrena Norris, a 1986 graduate of the high school, told The Selma Times-Journal. ``We're here, and we won't leave until our demands are met.'' Mrs. Sanders was released Thursday as protest leaders turned the spotlight on her case. Her husband, state Sen. Hank Sanders, has said he would ``use any means necessary'' to personally respond to abuse of his wife. ``I admire what he's doing as a husband, but I don't think we can lose sight of the issue,'' Mrs. Sanders said. ``The issue is not Roussell, not me, because many communities have the same problem, unequal education. I'm hoping other people will take a close look at their school systems.''

DOC.HEAD: School Suit: Blacks Need Individual Education Plans
DOC.TEXT: A committee of blacks has sued the county school board, charging the district discriminates against minority middle school children. The lawsuit by the Committee of Organized Groups asks that the district give every black middle school student an individualized education plan. ``What has become clear is that in regular education, particularly black and Hispanic children are simply ignored,'' said attorney Gabe Kaimowitz, who filed the lawsuit Thursday in federal court in Orlando. The individual plans created by guidance counselors, parents and psychologists now are written only for students in special-education classes. The committee wants similar plans for black middle school students to ``eliminate the last vestiges of the dual school system,'' said Kaimowitz. Orange County middle schools have about 22,000 students, and about 24 percent are black. Superintendent James Schott said writing individual plans would be costly and cumbersome. Kindergartners and new students up to third grade are evaluated and placed depending on their needs, Schott said. Teachers and counselors do similar evaulations throughout a student's schooling, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Demonstrate Against New Party
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 3rd graf to add that party is conservative. Pickup 4th, `Yonhap, the...
DOC.TEXT: The governing party and two opposition groups completed a merger Friday that gives them a huge majority in Parliament, and radical students responded with protests, firebombs and rocks. Kim Dae-jung, who leads the leftist Party for Peace and Democracy, the largest opposition faction, called the merger ``a kind of coup d'etat that reversed the people's will.'' The new Democratic Liberal Party, a conservative group, will have at least 210 of the 299 seats in the single-house National Assembly, well over the two-thirds needed to pass constitutional amendments. Kim Dae-jung's party and the two defecting opposition groups previously held a majority. Yonhap, the national news agency, said about 1,000 students in Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, fought police after an anti-government campus rally at Chonam University. Kwangju is Kim Dae-jung's base and was the scene of a 1980 student uprising in which soldiers killed 200 people, by official count. Unofficial estimates put the total much higher. Friday's battle began when about 1,000 riot police, backed by armored vans with multiple tear gas launchers, stormed the campus to stop a rally acy. It was a miscalculation and disregarded the people's power.'' He said many voters ``feel betrayed'' now that opposition legislators they elected have joined the government. Insiders said collective leadership of the new party would continue until a single leader was chosen at a convention in April. A senior party official said Kim Young-sam would be made party chief at the convention. Kim, 62, is considered a likely successor to the presidency when Roh's single term ends in February 1993. Analysts expect the party to amend the constitution next year to replace the current presidential system with a parliamentary system headed by a prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: House Reportedly Searched in Investigation of Mail Bombings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with report agents seized a typewriter from Alabama business. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `In their...'.
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents investigating a series of mail bombings searched the home of a self-employed editor and writing adviser who was convicted in a 1972 explosives case, according to reports published today. The Atlanta Constitution quoted federal sources as saying agents seized string, tape and brown paper in a search of a house in this Atlanta suburb. The mail bombs were wrapped in paper and tape and tied with string. Agents also reportedly seized a typewriter from a business in Alabama. Although the FBI would not identify the Georgia property or its owner, both the Constitution and The New York Times reported that the agency's search warrants targeted the property of Walter Leroy Moody Jr. The Times said the papers also named his wife, Susan McBride Moody. ``Agents searched a house, storage area and three vehicles. There were no arrests,'' said Nestor Michnyak, an FBI spokesman in Washington. He would not say if authorities knew the whereabouts of the property's owner or give other details. Neighbors said investigators have been in the Clayton County town, about 25 miles south of Atlanta, for weeks but there were no visible signs of them this morning. The FBI, has spent about three weeks investigating two men in Enterprise, Ala., for possible links to the bombings. Ten miles away in Elba, Ala., FBI agents searched the Dorsey Trailer Co. ib Thursday, according to its general manager, Nick Culich. He declined to give details, but WAGA-TV in Atlanta quoted an unidentified employee of the company as saying he was told the agents seized a typewriter. Agents have been looking for a typewriter to match typed followup letters to the bombings. In their reports today, the two newspapers said the 54-year-old Moody, a self-employed editor and writing adviser, was convicted in 1972 of felony possession of an unregistered firearm for having a bomb that officials said was to be used in a failed extortion scheme. Prosecutors claimed Moody had planned to send the bomb, along with an extortion note demanding $65,000, to an Atlanta auto dealer who had repossessed his car. But the bomb exploded when Moody's then-wife, Hazel, opened the package. She lost part of a finger and a portion of a thigh. Moody served two years in prison. Appeals of that conviction went to the 11th Circuit court, which turned the appeal down in June, the Times said. In December, an 11th Circuit judge, Robert Vance of Mountain Brook, Ala., was killed by a bomb delivered to his home. Another bomb killed Robert Robinson, a Savannah city councilman and attorney who did work for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Two other bombs were intercepted, one mailed to the 11th Circuit in Atlanta and one to the NAACP in Jacksonville, Fla. The Times, quoting an unidentified official, said there were similarities between the mail bombs and the bomb in the Moody case in 1972. The Constitution said today that Moody was charged in 1983 with three counts of attempted murder involving a diving expedition in the Gulf of Mexico. The case ended in a mistrial when the jury deadlocked. WSB-TV in Atlanta said its reporters saw FBI, Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and Postal Service agents carry boxes of unidentified material out of a house in Rex. The station said the agents also searched ``what appeared to be a makeshift base of operations behind a nearby church.''
