A longtime resident of Rex, Evelyn Rogers, said today that FBI and Georgia Bureau of Investigation agents had turned a local convenience store into a temporary headquarters all week. But there were no signs of agents there today, and a employee of the store refused to comment. Mrs. Rogers said she first heard of Moody several weeks ago when a friend noticed that agents were searching a van near his property. In addition to the searches here, authorities conducted a widely publiziced investigation in Enterprise, Ala., focusing on Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, a salvage store owner, and Brian Joseph Fleming, a print shop owner. Authorities said a typewritten letter O'Ferrell sent in connection with a civil lawsuit appealed to the 11th Circuit matched typewriting in a letter claiming responsibility for the bombs. O'Ferrell said that he apparently sold the typewriter from his salvage store. He denied having anything to do with the bombings.

DOC.HEAD: US Appeals Court Upholds Ruling Against AMA in Chiropractors' Lawsuit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10-11th grafs to CLARIFY that judge found that AMA's actions were primarily sincere, but economic reasons also a factor. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `At the...'.
DOC.TEXT: The head of a national chiropractors group today hailed a appeals court's decision to uphold a 1987 ruling that the American Medical Association illegally attempted to destroy his profession. The ruling will ``make up for years of oppression chiropractors have suffered from the AMA,'' Louis Sportelli, chairman of the American Chiropractic Association, said in a telephone interview today. ``There's no question about the fact that the ruling paves the way for chiropractic to proceed without hindrance,'' Sportelli said. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Wednesday affirmed the finding of U.S. District Judge Susan Getzendanner, who found the AMA boycott of chiropractors to be in violation of antitrust law. She permanently barred the nation's largest organization of physicians from boycotting chiropractors, who treat patients with physical manipulation focused on the spine. ``The experience of the AMA in this case should now put other medical associations, and hospitals dominated by them, on notice that chiropractors will fight for the rights of their patients,'' said attorney George McAndrews, who represented the chiropractors. Those rights include fair treatment by hospitals, insurance plans and other groups that have limited patients' access to chiropractors, McAndrews said. The AMA has not decided whether to appeal the case further, said association attorney Kirk Johnson. ``Although the AMA disagrees with the Court of Appeals decision, the ruling should have no material impact on physicians or patients,'' he said in a statement. After an eight-week trial, Ms. Getzendanner issued a permanent injunction on Sept. 25, 1987, barring the AMA from ``restricting, regulating or impeding'' its 275,000 members or the hospitals where they work from associating with chiropractors. The judge said the AMA had proved it was motivated mostly by sincere concern about whether chiropractic was scientifically valid, though evidence indicated there was also selfish economic reasons behind it. A three-judge appellate panel, which heard arguments in the case in December, unanimously agreed, saying Ms. Getzendanner had reached a ``reasonable'' decision in granting the injunction. At the time of her ruling, Ms. Getzendanner also directed the AMA to publish a copy of her nine-page order in the Journal of the American Medical Association, and to separately mail all of its members and employees copies of the order. She also required that the AMA amend its Current Opinions of the Council on Ethical and Judicial Affairs, the group's guidelines on ethical behavior, to reflect that it is ethical for medical doctors to associate with chiropractors. The AMA printed the ruling in the AMA journal but was granted a delay on the other two requirements pending appeal. The lawsuit, filed in 1977 by four chiropractors in four different states, sought no monetary damages but challenged the refusal of medical doctors to acknowledge chiropractors' professional abilities. There are about 45,000 chiropractors in the United States, according to the American Chiropractic Association. Chiropractors are required to finish two years of college plus four years of chiropractic college. The AMA has said previously that during the 1960s, it advised physicians not to refer patients to chiropractors because the group believed some of their treatments had no scientific basis. The policy was prompted by concern for patient safety, not by doctors' fears of competition from chiropractors, the AMA said. Even so, the policy was abandoned in 1980, the AMA has maintained.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany Nearing Collapse, Official Says; East Germans Deny it
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with East Germany, West German government spokesman denying collapse imminent; picks up 6th pvs: The plummeting...
DOC.TEXT: East Germany is only days away from economic collapse, a West German official said today, but East Germany denied the grim assessment. A West German government spokesman later also said East Germany is not in danger of collapsing in the next few days, but that some West German leaders believe that is the case. There was no clear reason for the conflicting assessments from Bonn, where officials have different opinions about how to bail out the neighboring country and the pace of reunifying the nations. Earlier today, a senior government official, speaking to reporters on the condition of anonymity, said the East German economy has moved to the point where ``insolvency could be within a few days.'' That would mean the Communist nation, where the government owns virtually all components of the economy, would be unable to pay workers or make payments on its foreign debt. The official in Bonn said Chancellor Helmut Kohl would address the situation during his weekend visit to Moscow, where he will meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Later, East German government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer denied that his Communist-led nation is in such dire circumstances. Bonn government spokesman Hans Klein also issued a statement saying that Bonn was not officially predicting an East German collapse. ``The federal government is not of the opinion that East Germany in the next days will be insolvent,'' Klein said, but he noted that some individual leaders ``fear such extreme possibilities.'' The plummeting economy has hastened _ and been worsened by _ the mass immigration of East Germans to West Germany. The crisis spurred mass unrest last year that toppled the hard-line Communist regime. The interim Communist government says it will hold free elections on March 18, when a new government is likely to take control. But it appears likely that that government, instead of being the answer to East Germany's future, will oversee the transition to reunification of the Germanys. Kohl has been pressing for a combining of the two country's currencies to give the East Germans a palpable reason to stay home. Bundesbank President Karl-Otto Poehl, the chief of West Germany's central bank, told reporters in Bonn today that such a monetary union _ most likely the circulation of West German currency in the East _ will require major sacrifices by both countries. But Poehl, who earlier had cautioned against giving East Germany a quick monetary fix, appeared to soften his stand. He said West Germany could afford merging currencies with East Germany and may in fact have little choice. Some Europeans fear a united Germany could again become a military threat. In a speech in the East German city of Potsdam outside Berlin, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher sought to allay European fears by saying that both nations should soon sign an agreement not to build nuclear weapons or encroach on the borders of neighboring countries. The superpowers worry that such a union could crumble their military alliances. NATO has about 255,000 troops in West Germany, most of them Americans. More than 380,000 Soviet soldiers are stationed in East Germany, a key member of the Warsaw Pact. East Germany Premier Hans Modrow has proposed that a united Germany be neutral, but Western nations have uniformly rejected that stand. In Paris, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said in an interview published today that France does not oppose the reunification of Germany but is against a neutral Germany, which he said would lead to European instability. Officials in Bonn have proposed that what is now West Germany could remain with NATO and the territory that was East Germany could technically be nuetral. Kohl's talks with Gorbachev no doubt will deal with the willingness of the Soviet Union to accept the loss of perhaps the key component of its military strategy.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Give China $10.4 Million to Help Build Subway
DOC.TEXT: The federal Export-Import Bank is making a $10.4 million grant to help China build a subway in Shanghai, the bank announced Friday. The grant will be part of a $23.1 million financing package to encourage the Chinese government to buy equipment from American companies, against competition from similar subsidies offered by France and West Germany. ``Had Eximbank not finalized its financing at this time, the contracts won by American companies would have been jeopardized,'' the U.S. announcement said. Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger earlier this week went before committees of Congress to defend the Bush administration on its China policy. Members from both parties have accused President Bush of being too quick to lift sanctions against the Chinese government after its bloody suppression of the movement for democracy. The U.S. grant will come from a $109.5 million ``war chest,'' being used in China for the first time. Congress voted the money to help U.S. businesses compete against similar government subsidies from Japan, West Germany, France and other industrial countries. Jeni Falkiewicz, public affairs officer for the bank, said the French and West German offers to China violated an international agreement. The agreement was designed to limit the subsidies given by governments of industrial countries to promote foreign sales. The rest of the U.S. financing package will consist of a guarantee from the government bank of a $12.7 million loan to the Private Export Funding Corp., which works closely with it. Because of the guarantee, the corporation can offer easier terms to the Chinese government than would otherwise be available in this country. Ms. Falkiewicz said the bank is also working with the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID) to finance export deals with money appropriated to help raise living standards in poor countries. Competing governments also use aid funds in this way. The bank's announcement said major contracts for the Shanghai subway were awarded to West German suppliers, after a financing offer that included a grant of 73.2 percent while the U.S. grant accounts for only 45 percent. The French won a contract for tunneling equipment, while U.S. companies were chosen for signaling, fire alarm detection and other systems. The biggest U.S. exporter is General Railway Signal, Inc. of Rochester, N.Y. Officials, who spoke on condition that they not be named, said criticism in Congress led to a U.S. request to the World Bank to postpone until Feb. 27 its consideration of a $60 million loan to help China's farmers. A Treasury Department spokesman, Robert Levine, said he could neither confirm nor deny that the postponement was sought by the United States. The World Bank is owned by 151 governments and is the biggest source of aid to the Third World. This loan would be part of a $780 million package that bank president Barber Conable postponed in June, just after Chinese government tanks went into Tiananmen Square. Bush later asked that these loans be held up. A $30 million World Bank loan to China announced on Thursday was for relief of an earthquake that occurred in October and so was not part of the package.

DOC.HEAD: World Health Organization to Launch East European Program
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization plans a new campaign to fight AIDS in East European countries, which only recently began reporting cases of the deadly disease, officials said Friday. Dr Jonathan Mann, head of the U.N. agency's AIDS program, said East bloc countries form the ``new frontiers of the global epidemic'' that has claimed hundreds of thousands of victims, primarily in the Americas, Africa and West Europe. During a news conference, he urged the new governments that came to power in the Eastern European pro-democracy movement to help the campaign by looking at AIDS ``as a health rather than an ideological issue.'' He told a news conference that Romania was expected to be the worst hit country in Eastern Europe because of the large number of children infected by contaminated blood and needles. But he said WHO was also concerned about developments in other countries, citing signs that drug users in Poland have become infected with the HIV virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Dr. David Heymann, a WHO specialist who returned late Thursday from a visit to Bucharest, said about one third of 1,500 Romanian children screened for the disease were infected with the HIV virus. Mann said another WHO team will travel to Romania next week to begin making plans for a program to fight the disease there. The WHO campaign for all of Eastern Europe will officially be launched at the end of February, he said. Heymann said that at the beginning of February, Romanian authorities had reported 74 cases of AIDS, including 50 children. Those figures are likely to increase once testing for the disease is more widespread, the doctor said. Priorities of the WHO campaign include improving medical care in East European countries, ensuring the use of sterile needles in hospitals, counseling for victims and their families, and providing better training of medical workers. WHO has already sent 100,000 screening kits to Romania as initial assistance to help authorities determine the true extent of AIDS in their country. Mann stressed the need for a nationwide education program to publicize the risks of AIDS, which was long concealed by the regime of former dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, who was overthrown Dec. 22. ``Romania shows the dangers of the silence on AIDS,'' he said. AIDS is often spread through sharing of needles or syringes by drug abusers. Hard-line Communist leaders of the past viewed drug abuse as a Western problem that did not affect them. A private organization, Doctors of the World, said this week that Romania is in the grips of the first known epidemic of AIDS in children because of the backward practices in its hospitals. Mann said that by the end of 1989, about 300 AIDS cases had been reported from all Eastern European countries. Albania was the only country in the region with no registered cases. Worldwide, more than 215,000 cases of AIDS had been reported to WHO by the end of last month. However, many cases go unreported. AIDS attacks the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to a variety of infections and cancers. It is spread most often through sexual contact, needles or syringes shared by drug abusers, infected blood or blood products, and from pregnant women to their offspring.

DOC.HEAD: Young & Rubicam Pleads Guilty in Jamaica Tourism Case
DOC.TEXT: Young & Rubicam Inc., one of the world's largest advertising agencies, pleaded guilty today to making $130,000 in illegal payments in its efforts to win the contract for the Jamaican tourism account. The New York-based company was fined $500,000 for conspiring to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by making payments to a Jamaican businessman, Arnold Foote Jr., who in turn made payments to Eric Anthony Abrahams, the former minister of tourism in Jamaica, said U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy. The government alleged that Young & Rubicam made the payments in order to win and retain the lucrative Jamaican tourism account, for which it produced the award-winning ``Come Back to Jamaica'' campaign in the early 1980s. The government, citing ``exculpatory evidence recently turned over to the government,'' dropped charges against two Young & Rubicam executives, executive vice president Arthur R. Klein and former account supervisor Thomas Spangenberg. A third Young & Rubicam worker, Steven M. McKenna, faces federal perjury charges. Foote and Abrahams have also been charged, but they remain in Jamaica and have not appeared in the U.S. to face charges, Twardy said. The settlement came the day after jury selection began in federal court in the trial of the agency, which until today had steadfastly denied any wrongdoing. On Wednesday, U.S. District Judge Peter Dorsey denied motions to dismiss racketeering charges against the executives, paving the way for jury selection to begin. The case is believed to be the first attempt to use the Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act against an advertising agency. Young & Rubicam had faced up to $7.5 million in fines.

DOC.HEAD: After Years of Bannings, Activists Are Free At Last
DOC.TEXT: Since 1956, the government has charged Helen Joseph with treason, detained her repeatedly, placed her under house arrest and made it a crime to quote her. But the 84-year-old white anti-apartheid activist survived 34 years of bannings and on Feb. 2 became one of nearly 500 people, living and dead, whose restrictions were lifted by President F.W. de Klerk. ``I didn't think I'd see this day,'' Mrs. Joseph said, adding that she was a bit disappointed the government no longer considered her a threat. ``I'm a stubborn old bag and I wasn't expecting things to change.'' Police restrictions have been a way of life for many anti-apartheid activists. Hundreds detained without charge during the 3{-year-old state of emergency were released but then placed under virtual house arrest. The restrictions varied, but often prohibited the activists from leaving their neighborhoods, required them to be home each night, prevented them from attending meetings or participating in politics, and often made it impossible to hold a job. Zwelakhe Sisulu, son of recently released African National Congress leader Walter Sisulu, was freed from prison in December 1988 after two years in detention. But he had to report daily to police and was unable to resume his job as editor of the New Nation newspaper until de Klerk rescinded his restriction order. Few have endured as much as Mrs. Joseph, a former social worker and union official now confined to a wheelchair much of the time. The government charged Mrs. Joseph, ANC leader Nelson Mandela and more than 150 others with treason in 1956 for their anti-apartheid activities. All were acquitted in a trial that lasted until 1961. However, Mrs. Joseph, a divorcee with no children, remained under a banning order and in 1962 became the first South African placed under house arrest. For the next nine years, police were the only visitors allowed to enter her comfortable white house with a red roof and a flower-filled garden in a Johannesburg suburb. Her house arrest ended in 1971 while she was undergoing a cancer operation, but until Feb. 2 she remained a ``listed'' person, meaning she could not be quoted in South Africa. She has been arrested numerous times, most recently in 1983 when she sang a freedom song and gave a clenched-fist, black power salute while attending a treason trial. As part of his reform program, de Klerk lifted the police orders on 374 people who had been restricted after their release from detention. He also removed the names of all 110 people who had been ``listed'' and could not be quoted. Many of the listed people are either dead or have left South Africa. They include: _Most of the African National Congress leadership, such as President Oliver Tambo, who is recovering from a stroke in Sweden. _Donald Woods, whose book ``Cry Freedom,'' about the life and death of black activist Steve Biko was made into a movie by the same name three years ago. Woods now lives in London. _Numerous whites, including Anne Heymann, who died of pneumonia Feb. 3 at the age of 66, and her husband, Isaac Heymann, who died of cancer four days later at the age of 79. The Heymanns, both listed since the 1960s, lived only a few blocks from Mrs. Joseph and often visited her at her front gate during the years when she wasn't allowed guests inside her home. ``So many people suffered for so many years,'' Mrs. Joseph said. ``I'm not grateful (for the lifting of the restrictions). It was not an act of compassion. It never should have been done in the first place.'' Despite failing health, she occasionally travels to anti-government protests, such as an ANC rally last October in the township of Soweto, where she received a rousing cheer from the mostly black crowd of 70,000. Mrs. Joseph, whose requests to visit Mandela were repeatedly denied, finally was granted permission and the two met last Dec. 21 for the first time in 28 years. ``He looked different after so many years, but then so did I,'' Mrs. Joseph said. ``He was in very good form, full of jokes, full of laughter.'' Four days later, Mrs. Joseph had Christmas dinner with Walter Sisulu and dozens of other activists at the home of a friend. After her house arrest was lifted, she began a tradition of making a toast at noon on Christmas to remember all the anti-apartheid activists who were in exile, in prison or had died. Word of the tradition had spread to exiles and prisoners, and Sisulu told Mrs. Joseph it was observed during his years in jail. She hopes one day all the activists will be able to hold a Christmas toast together in South Africa, but she doubts she'll be around to take part. ``I don't think I'll see the end of apartheid, but I'll see it diminish,'' she said. ``You can't wash away 300 years of cruelty and injustice overnight.''

DOC.HEAD: Cold Pushes January Wholesale Prices Up Fastest in 15 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 11th graf, The price, to make it snap beans and dried beans nearly doubled, sted more than doubled
DOC.TEXT: Record price increases for vegetables and fuel oil combined in January to produce the highest monthly wholesale inflation rate in 15 years, a temporary spurt economists attributed to the holiday cold snap. The Labor Department's Producer Price Index soared a seasonally adjusted 1.8 percent last month, the sharpest rise since a 2 percent gain in November 1974, in the midst of the OPEC oil embargo. January energy prices rocketed 13.6 percent for the largest monthly gain on record since the department began tracking the sector in 1974. Food costs jumped 2.1 percent, the biggest increase in six years. The month's overall price climb was triple the already brisk 0.6 percent gain in December and far above economists' average forecast of about 1.2 percent. If wholesale inflation persisted at the January pace, it would produce an annual price rise of 24.1 percent in 1990. However, economists expressed little worry and stock and bond prices actually rose immediately after the report because the ``core rate'' of inflation _ prices of goods excluding food and energy _ rose a slight 0.1 percent. The core rate is viewed as a better measure of underlying inflationary pressure. Economists warn that the wholesale food and energy jolt is filtering through to consumers and is likely to push up the Consumer Price Index, the best-known inflation measure. But the effect at both the retail and wholesale levels will be temporary, they said. Analysts are predicting the wholesale inflation rate, which more than doubled between 1988 and 1989 from 2.2 percent to 4.8 percent, will retreat to about 4 percent this year. ``Without food and energy, commodity price inflation was very low'' in January, said economist Allen Sinai of the Boston Co. ``The report suggests much of the activity was weather-related and will diminish in coming months.'' As temperatures plummeted, fuel oil prices rose a startling 25.3 percent, the biggest jump on record. As refineries switched production to fuel oil, supplies of gasoline grew short, sending those prices up 16.7 percent. Natural gas costs rose a brisk 3.2 percent. The price of fresh and dried vegetable rose 58 percent for the month, the largest seasonally adjusted gain recorded since the department began tracking that category in 1967. Prices for cabbage, lettuce and tomatoes more than doubled while snap beans and dried beans nearly doubled, the department said. ``It was snowing in Brownsville, Texas, and Orlando, Fla., on the same day. I doubt that ever happened before. That means we lost both the Texas and Florida (vegetable) crops,'' said economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State University. Egg, fruit and fish prices also rose, while rice, pasta, chicken and turkey costs fell. In other categories, wholesale prices rose 2.9 percent for children's clothing, 0.8 percent for men's and women's clothing, and 0.9 percent for home electronic equipment. Ratajczak suggested the decline in the value of the dollar since fall could be behind the increase in the cost of clothing, much of which is imported. Balancing that were drops of 1.3 percent for tobacco, which had risen 2.2 percent in December, and 0.7 percent for automobiles, the result of a new round of discounting at auto dealerships. The various changes put the Producer Price Index at 117.5 in January. This meant that a hypothetical marketbasket of goods, which cost $100 at the wholesale level in 1982, cost $117.50 last month, up from $111.10 a year earlier. Soaring energy costs also drove up inflation in earlier stages of the production process. The price of intermediate goods rose 1.2 percent overall, but only 0.1 percent excluding food and energy. The price of crude goods was up 2.4 percent overall and 0.2 percent minus food and energy. An example of the three stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude.

DOC.HEAD: Novello Says She'll Speak for Those Who Can't
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs `If confirmed, ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT spelling of name to Fajardo, sted Fajarda
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Antonia C. Novello said Friday that she would be a voice for those who can't communicate for themselves if confirmed as Surgeon General. Novello also said she would speak out against tobacco companies that target minorities. ``I have always felt that I am here to speak for people who have never been able to communicate for themselves,'' Novello told the Senate Committee on Labor and Human Resources. ``And, as a pediatrician, I have been the doctor of little people who have no voice in society.'' If confirmed, Novello would be the first woman, Hispanic and Puerto Rican to serve in that position. The 45-year-old native of Fajardo would succeed the outspoken C. Everett Koop, who served for seven years. Committee Chairman Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said he supported the confirmation, and was especially pleased at her answer when asked whether she would speak out against tobacco companies that target minorities as did Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. ``Absolutely,'' she said. ``I feel as irate as Dr. Sullivan when advertising is used to make a target for people who cannot take care of themselves.'' R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. recently withdrew plans to introduce a cigarette aimed at blacks after being criticized by Sullivan and others. Absent from the low-key hearing was any mention of abortion. When Novello was selected in November, the White House said she supported President Bush's stance. Bush opposes abortion except to protect the life of the mother or in cases of rape and incest. He opposes extending federal funding to abortions in cases of rape or incest. ``Smoking, HIV infection, substance abuse and the use of alcohol are just some of the many areas of concern which demand our attention,'' Novello said. Attending the hearing were Novello's husband, psychiatrist and talk-show host Dr. Joseph Novello, and her first transplant patient, 24-year-old Prosper Sanchez of Silver Spring, Md., who received a kidney in 1977.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Arrest Four Suspected of Spying for KGB
DOC.TEXT: West German authorities arrested four people suspected of delivering to the Soviet KGB U.S.-made computers that could have military use, the federal prosecutor's office said Friday. The three men and the wife of one of them are suspected of delivering high-tech Western products to the Soviets since mid-1988, the office said in a statement. The four allegedly acquired a computer made by the U.S. company Digital Equipment that can also be used for military purposes, and delivered it to the KGB during a trip to East Germany, the statement said. Three weeks later, they allegedly delivered an identical computer through a third person. The group also allegedly tried to acquire a computer program that could be used in space flights, the statement said. Two of the suspects are in investigative custody, while two have been freed but remain under investigation. The statement did not identify the four. It said two of them were salesmen.

DOC.HEAD: Administrators Want to Stop Hazing in Black Fraternities and Sororities
DOC.TEXT: College officials who gathered at a conference on black fraternity and sorority hazing said Friday their goal was to end the practice, which one speaker called a form of self-hatred. ``It is a realistic goal ... that speaks directly to the issue of self determination,'' said Eric Abercrumbie, director of minority programs and affairs at the University of Cincinnati. Speakers at the two-day conference at Hampton University defined hazing as the physical, psychological or financial intimidation or abuse of pledges to the social groups before they are initiated. ``I don't find it necessary to first dehumanize a person, then turn around at a later time and call him brother,'' said Carroll Hardy, dean of minority affairs at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg. Organizers of the event, which drew about 400 college officials and students, said they hoped to find alternatives to hazing. Students at the conference planned to discuss the issue Saturday. Manning Marable, a professor of political science and sociology at the University of Colorado, told the group that blacks ``must build strong organizations with a new vision of brotherhood and sisterhood. ... Is hazing, is violence like this, the kind of example we want to set?'' Abercrumbie said hazing is a form of self-hate. His experience was that groups that used hazing to strengthen their feeling of cohesiveness generally pledged people who did not graduate and who had problems with drug abuse. Penny Saffold, dean of students at San Francisco State University, said fraternities and sororities are being asked to change. ``Our community is in a state of crisis; we need crisis measures. Somewhere along the line, many of our chapters have forgotten the ideals that established their organization. We need to talk about what the fraternities and sororities can do to help the African-American community.'' Last year, a Morehouse College student died in a hazing incident. Raymond E. Crawford, the school's vice president of student affairs, said pledging of fraternity and sorority members has been suspended at the Georgia school until a commission can decide whether there is a role at Morehouse for the groups. College administrators said the fraternities and sororities need to replace hazing with community service and a dedication to academic excellence. ``We need to ask what are the kinds of initiations, what are the kinds of preparations for leadership that we need for our community. We need leaders who are more passionate, more courageous, more willing to take on the odds,'' said Vincent Harding, professor of religion and social transformation at the Iliff School of Theology in Denver, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Baseball Owners Say Lockout Still On, But Talks Continuing
DOC.TEXT: Baseball owners today said they would going ahead with plans for a spring-training lockout, but seemed to soften their hard-line stance and said talks would continue. ``There is no change in our strategy,'' Milwaukee owner Bud Selig said after owners met for two hours to discuss contract negotiations. ``But there is going to be another meeting with the players on Monday, and this is going to be a day-by-day negotiation.'' Camps are scheduled to open next Thursday. Clubs have been told by the owners not to start spring training unless an agreement is reached with players on a new contract. Today's meeting had been expected to produce a declaration that a lockout by the owners was all but a sure thing. Selig, chairman of the owners' Player Relations Committee, tried to avoid the word ``lockout.'' When pressed, he said, ``nothing has changed.'' Chuck O'Connor, head of the PRC, said, ``the clubs are not free to go to camp on Feb. 15. The status quo remained.'' Commissioner Fay Vincent, who attended the meeting with owners, said he hoped something could be accomplished in next week's bargaining sessions. ``I'm eager to find a resolution to this problem. I am trying, in a way I hope is relevant, to be useful.'' Rick Dempsey, heading into a players meeting with union chief Donald Fehr Thursday night, said he thought owners haven't ``come to the table with their true offer yet. When they do, which will probably take another week _ in 2{ weeks I think we'll be playing again.'' Opening day for the regular season is supposed to be April 2. Vincent has said he will not order camps opened, as former commissioner Bowie Kuhn did in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Restores Vatican Ties
DOC.TEXT: Hungary on Friday became the second Soviet bloc nation to re-establish diplomatic ties with the Vatican that were severed more than four decades ago. The agreement was signed in Parliament by Hungarian Premier Miklos Nemeth and Cardinal Agostino Casaroli, the Vatican secretary of state. Nemeth told a news conference that a nuncio would represent the Vatican in Hungary and that Budapest will send an ambassador to the Vatican. Restoration of relations ``will also contribute to the success of Pope John Paul II's visit in 1991,'' said Nemeth. Cardinal Casaroli said that by restoring relations, ``both parties wanted to show that this move is in their mutual interest.'' Hungary follows Poland, which restored Vatican ties in July. Other East bloc nations are likely to do the same following revolutions that ousted hard-line Communist governments and cleared the way for Western-style reforms. Casaroli, who arrived here Wednesday on a five-day visit, also said the agreement signed Friday ``will not jeopardize the autonomy of the churches, but rather will serve to protect and strengthen their autonomy.'' The restoration of diplomatic ties with the Vatican comes after Hungary abolished restrictive laws on religion as part of the country's move toward democracy. Relations between Hungary and the Vatican were broken after the government expelled the Vatican's envoy in 1945. The Hungarian Roman Catholic church gave in to pressure from the Stalinist leadership Aug. 30, 1950, agreeing to surrender its autonomy. Nemeth recalled that in 1964 the two sides signed a partial agreement ``which reflected our differences but also contained agreements which made further cooperation possible.'' ``Despite the differences, the dialogue between the Vatican and Hungary always had its sincere adherents,'' Nemeth said. Negotiations between Hungary, which has a Roman Catholic majority, and the Vatican had been going on for months. Casaroli jointly celebrated Mass on Thursday with Hungarian Cardinal Laszlo Paskai in the Basilica at Esztergom, the seat of Hungary's Roman Catholic Primate. At a ceremony following the Mass, interim President Matyas Szueroes denounced the trial of Cardinal Jozsef Mindszenty under Stalinist rule as a ``show trial,'' marking the late primate's de facto rehabilitation. In reply to a question Friday about confiscated church assets, Nemeth said: ``I myself raised the matter in our talks. The government is seeking ways of returning the illegally seized church assets. This will be done gradually and in ongoing consultations with the churches.'' Parliament enacted a law Jan. 24 that separates church and state, ending state interference in church affairs and granting all denominations full autonomy. Commenting on the pontiff's visit to Czechoslovakia in April this year, Casaroli said it would be a brief one, while the Hungarian trip would be a full Apostolic visit. ``Czechoslovakia was more isolated from the Holy See, and therefore it was deemed desirable to make an early brief visit,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Spiritual Leader Says Rushdie Must Be Killed
DOC.TEXT: Salman Rushdie must be killed, as the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini ordered, for blaspheming Islam and the prophet Mohammed in his novel ``The Satanic Verses,'' Iran's new spiritual leader said Friday. In Britain, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said the announcement by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei was ``much to be regretted.'' A friend of the British novelist called it a rejection of Rushdie's recent peace overtures to Moslems. There was no immediate comment from Rushdie, who has been in hiding since Khomeini declared the novel blasphemous and decreed on Feb. 14, 1989, that faithful Moslems should kill its author. Several Iranian leaders put a pricce on the writer's head of $5.2 million. Khomeini died in June, but the death sentence was not lifted. On Friday, his successor as spiritual leader of Iran's Shiite Moslems said the religious decree ``about the writer of the blasphemous book `The Satanic Verses' is still valid and must be implemented.'' Tehran radio said he made the statement in a sermon at weekly prayers on the Moslem sabbath. Rushdie, who was born in India to Moslem parents, said this week he had considered appearing in public to deliver a lecture on censorship, but his police guards dissuaded him. In a 7,000-word essay published in the British newspaper Independent on Sunday, and in an interview earlier this week with Newsweek magazine, Rushdie expressed regret for the pain the book had caused but said he stood by it. He said he was pressing for a paperback edition and declared that charges of reneging on his faith were invalid because he had not been a practicing Moslem for years. Independent on Sunday's literary editor, Blake Morrison, described the Iranian position as a disappointing rebuff and told BBC radio: ``It was perhaps too much to hope that a conciliatory tone adopted here would filter through to Tehran.'' Bob Gregory of Viking Penguin, which published ``The Satanic Verses,'' said that when Khomeini originally announced the death sentence, ``We condemned it in the strongest language we could think of, and we do precisely the same again.'' Iran's main opposition group condemned the reaffirmed threat to Rushdie. In a statement telexed to The Associated Press from its headquarters in Baghdad, Iraq, the Mujahedeen Khalq accused Khamenei of trying to divert attention from internal conflicts in Iran. Dr. Kalim Siddiqi, director of the Moslem Institute in Britain, said in an interview with British Broadcasting Corp. television: ``There is a sentence of death which will be executed ... by the political and judicial authorities of Islam, not by private citizens living in Britain or anywhere else.'' Siddiqi said he met with Khamenei in Tehran this week and was told Iran would not compromise on the death decree. Asked whether he approved of such threats, Siddiqi said: ``I approve of it entirely. It is not a death threat. It is a death sentence passed by the highest judicial authority in the world of Islam, and it is according to Islamic law.'' Britain and a dozen Western allies recalled their ambassadors from Tehran last year in protest. All but Britain have resumed relations. On Friday, the Foreign Office said Britain sought normal relations on condition Iran renounced threats and violence, helped obtain the release of British hostages held in Lebanon and freed Roger Cooper, a British businessman imprisoned in Tehran. Nine Iranians deported from Britain arrived in Tehran on Friday. They included an Iranian television journalist, an Iran Air official and seven students. The London bureau chief of Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting, identified by Tehran radio only as Keivanara, said: ``The expulsion of the students was a political action taken on the anniversary of the death order against Salman Rushdie.'' Britain ordered Feb. 1 that the nine leave within a week for reasons of national security. It did not elaborate, but similar previous expulsions were linked to the Rushdie decree.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Completes Drug-Summit Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has completed a drug-summit agreement with three South American countries committing the United States to broad economic and military assistance to counteract the Latin nations' economic reliance on drugs, an official said Friday. In addition to the $423 million anti-drug package President Bush is proposing for Peru, Bolivia and Colombia, the administration will pledge to help track illegal export of U.S.-produced firearms used by drug dealers and crack down on drug-related chemical exports, officials said. The four-nation pact also calls for Bush to press other Western nations to provide economic aid to the three Andean countries, said a South American diplomat familiar with the document. The presidents of the four countries are expected to sign the agreement when they meet at the Feb. 15 drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia. ``We've got agreement'' on the final wording, said Michael Skol, deputy assistant secretary of state for South American affairs. He described the agreement as ``a very comprehensive document of cooperation on the drug issue,'' significant for its recognition of rights and responsibilities of producer and consumer countries ``without finger-pointing.'' The U.S. portion of the document closely tracks Bush's national drug strategy plan, Skol said. The agreement deals with the general categories of interdiction and military cooperation, economic alternatives to the drug trade and efforts to get other countries' aid in the anti-drug effort. ``There's a promise of asking for increased spending'' by Congress, but no dollar amounts in the document, he said. For the second year of his national anti-drug strategy, Bush last month proposed $423 million for fiscal 1991 in total drug-related spending for the Andean countries _ in military, law enforcement and economic assistance. Some $206 million of that is an increase in spending as part of a five-year $2.2 billion plan. Skol said the communique will discuss money laundering, arms exports, and extradition as well as military assistance and economic aid _ including such matters as balance of payment assistance and substitute crops to make up for destruction of lucrative fields of coca, which is used to make cocaine. He described the weapons export provisions only by saying that they discuss cooperation among countries on the process to ``make it work better.'' A spokesman for the bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said that refers to a new U.S. policy that will station two ATF agents in Colombia to help local law enforcement officials trace the origins of recovered weapons. The policy is aimed at addressing the Latin nations' complaints about U.S.-exported arms _ which can be legally exported with a State Department permit and end-user certificate _ falling into the hands of drug lords, said spokesman Tom Hill. The Bush administration has linked aid to the drug-production countries to their cooperation in the anti-drug efforts. The drug-summit communique does not spell out details of U.S. military assistance to the Andean countries, but the Latins have insisted it be restricted to equipment and training rather than direct U.S. military involvement in interdiction, said the South American diplomat. There are no plans to use the military except in a training capacity, said Skol. A new Washington Post-ABC poll shows a majority of Americans _ 55 percent _ favored sending U.S. troops to help the Colombian military, and 45 percent were opposed. Only 19 percent of Colombians favored such a course and 77 percent were opposed. Fifty-eight percent of Colombians but only 25 percent of Americans said the Colombian government is winning its war against the drug cartels. Those familiar with the summit agreement said it commits the United States to: _Tighter enforcement on export of precursor drugs, such as ether, that are used in the production of cocaine. _Money for crops to substitute for coca. _Promotion of private initiatives for trade opportunities and technical assistance to help expand Andean markets. _Pressure on other nations to help the drug-production nations with economic and trade assistance. One diplomat said that is expected to be a topic at the economic summit later this year in Houston. The summit also may produce agreement between Bolivia and the United States to renew an extradition treaty that has not been updated since 1900, said one diplomatic source. The White House has praised Bolivia for extradition action, particularly the December extradition of alleged drug trafficker Luis Arce Gomez, but the Bolivian law was written before drug crimes were considered and thus does not address them specifically. Colombian President Virgilio Barco is eager to talk to Bush about the need to reinstate a coffee export quota system that was beneficial to farmers in his country. It was unclear whether coffee will specifically be addressed in the summit communique. In addition, Peru's president, Alan Garcia, is expected to push for larger commitments of U.S. spending on anti-drug efforts. On another issue, Garcia may want to personally convey to Bush his heated opposition to the December U.S. invasion of Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Praises Evert as `Model for Our Young Women'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday awarded the Flo Hyman Award for excellence in sports to former tennis pro Chris Evert, calling her ``the role model for our nation's young women.'' Bush presented the award at the White House on behalf of the Women and Girls in Sports Foundation, following activities for National Girls and Women in Sports Day on Thursday. The award is given in memory of the Olympic volleyball star who died suddenly in 1986. In presenting Evert the glass trophy, Bush said the winner of 18 Grand Slam tournaments had ``represented not just the game of tennis, but your country. And you've done it so very well and with grace, dignity and good sportsmanship.'' ``I know that all of your friends and colleagues here will agree that you certainly are the role model for our nation's young women, and we all miss you on the professional tennis circuit,'' Bush said. The president quipped, however, that tennis pros Pam Shriver and Martina Navratilova, who waged tough matches against Evert, ``won't miss you on the tennis circuit.'' Evert said she wanted to stress the importance of physical education in schools and sought the president's help in pushing that point as part of his education package. Bush told the small gathering of female athletes that his wife Barbara ``is this very moment out swimming her mile.'' Mrs. Bush swims at least a mile each day in the outdoor White House pool.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Mayor of Mid-1970s Dies at Age 76
DOC.TEXT: John H. Poelker, an accountant who served one term as mayor following 10 years as comptroller, died Friday following a long battle against cancer. He was 76. Poelker, a Democrat who launched his political career in 1953 when he became the city's youngest assessor, was mayor from 1973 until 1977. He did not seek re-election. Poelker, who was born in St. Louis, was admitted last week to Deaconess Hospital for treatment of pneumonia he had contracted in his fight against cancer. Poelker's is survived by two daughters and one son. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Biologist Heads To USSR To Study Endangered Siberian Tiger
DOC.TEXT: An American wildlife biologist embarks Saturday for the frozen wilderness of Siberia, where he will begin a Soviet-American research project to help save the endangered Siberian tiger, the largest cat in the world. Thousands of Siberian tigers used to roam Asia in an area roughly the size of Europe. Today, fewer than 500 are fighting for survival in a region smaller than Pennsylvania, according to Howard B. Quigley, assistant biology professor at Frostburg State University in western Maryland. ``Based on the way the population has gone down in the past 100 years, if we don't take some dramatic steps, we could lose this species in this century,'' he said. ``If we don't do something, the only place you might see tigers in the year 2000 is in zoos.'' The remaining Siberian tigers live near the Soviet-Chinese border on the east coast of the Soviet Union. But their habitat is being eroded by Chinese and Soviets who are clearing forests for timber, and to make room for farms and urban development. ``The loss of habitat is the most important, but a close second is that people are hunting wildlife _ the same prey as the tigers,'' Quigley said. ``If you take away all their prey, there is nothing for them to eat. ``If we can get cooperation from both (countries) to develop a comprehensive conservation plan, the tiger will be the winner.'' The Siberian tiger, which can measure up to 12 feet from nose to tail, has brownish-yellow and burnt orange fur with black, vertical stripes. White and ivory-colored fur accents its throat, belly and inside legs. A full-grown Siberian Tiger weighs between 450 and 800 pounds. It is the biggest of cats _ bigger than the African lion, often called ``the king of beasts,'' and bigger than the Bengal tiger, the one most commonly seen in zoos and circuses. African lions weigh up to 500 pounds; Bengal tigers average about 400 pounds. Humans admire the animal for its strength, grace and independence, but they also fear the tiger, which has on some occasions attacked people. ``Generally, they're more afraid than we are,'' Quigley said. During the past two decades, three of the eight subspecies of tigers have become extinct, he said. There are no more Caspian tigers roaming central Asia and the Javan and Bali tigers in Indonesia have died out. The populations of Bengal, Sumatran and Indochinese tigers are stable. But there are only 20 to 30 Chinese tigers left in south-central China. ``There are some Chinese scientists looking into the situation,'' Quigley said. ``There isn't enough habitat and I'm told it's hopeless.'' Quigley, 37, is traveling to the Soviet Union with Maurice Hornocker, director of the University of Idaho's Wildlife Research Institute in Moscow, Idaho. The wildlife institute and Frostburg State are helping sponsor the project, which will cost an estimated $75,000. They will fly to Vladivostok, a port city of 550,000 just north of North Korea, and journey into the wilderness with three Soviet scientists to survey the tigers' habitat. They plan to begin their field work 11 months from now. The researchers plan to trap the animals and put fist-sized transmitters attached to collars around their necks. Using radio signals, they will be able to track the tigers. The researchers want to know what the tigers eat and how far they roam. They want to find out how often they reproduce in the wild and the size of their litters. ``The Soviet researchers have learned about all they can using the technology they have available to them,'' Quigley said. ``It's time to use modern technology to expand on our knowledge of the animal's ecology.'' ``The Siberian tiger is one of the most impressive predators to ever walk the face of the earth,'' Quigley added. ``If we as humans _ the dominant species in the world _ can't protect their existence by setting aside a tiny island where they can live, how dignified can we say we are?''

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Set for Teen-Ager
DOC.TEXT: Funeral services are set Monday for a teen-ager who received the first experimental lung-assist device. Melicia ``Mimi'' Harvey of Arthur City died Wednesday in Salt Lake City of complications from the respiratory disease that led doctors to insert the device. She was 16. Miss Harvey gave birth in January to a son. Her mother died Jan. 31 of complications from diabetes. She received the IntraVascular Oxygenator at LDS Hospital in Salt Lake City on Feb. 2. The IVOX, a 20-inch bundle of hundreds of synthetic tubes as fine as human hair, was designed to give damaged lungs time to rest and recover. The hospital said the device functioned properly from the time it was implanted until Miss Harvey's death. They attributed her death to pulmonary failure. Miss Harvey is survived by her son, father, a brother and a sister.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: College studies that stress classic Western art and literature over works of blacks, women or other groups are a form of white supremacy, says Amiri Baraka. Baraka, the poet and playwright also known as Leroi Jones, told a University of Virginia audience Thursday the cultural revolution that accompanied the civil rights movement subsided in the last decade and was replaced by attitudes similar to those of the 1950s. Baraka challenged the more than 200 people in the audience to take an active role in turning the tables. In his keynote address for the university's black history month, Baraka urged students and professors to fight literary canons that elevate classic European art and literature above all other forms. Art and literature should not be segregated but should instead reflect the variety of people in the world, he said. In the 1960s, ``we wanted a poetry that would come out of the library and into the streets where the people were,'' said Baraka. In the 1950s, poetry was an emotionless craft that mirrored the traditional values of the era, he said, while the catch-word of the following decade was revolution. ``We were challenging the whiteness in works of art,'' Baraka said. Baraka's writings include 24 plays, seven works of non-fiction and 11 books of poetry.

A Valentine's Day concert by LaToya Jackson has been canceled because her presence would violate the values of Malaysian culture, the Culture and Tourism Ministry said Friday. The department secretary, Mukhtar Abdullah, said Jackson, who had posed nude in Playboy magazine last year, did not meet some of the conditions imposed by the government on foreign artists performing in Malaysia. He did not say what these conditions were. He said he was surprised the promoter, Genesis Promotions, went ahead through newspapers and television ads without getting the ministry's approval.

A 6-foot-tall, 7-year-old Ukrainian boy being treated for a rare pituitary gland tumor that has caused an overproduction of growth hormone will start elementary school Monday. Igor Ladan, who's being treated at the Mayo Clinic, will enroll in the Lincoln at Mann Elementary School's program for children with limited English, officials said. Wearing a Mickey Mouse shirt that has become his trademark since coming from Kiev to Rochester in September, Igor said he's looking forward to school because he wants to ``learn English and see pictures of Mickey Mouse.'' The boy spoke through an interpreter, but showed he already knows a few words of English, including Mickey Mouse, ice cream, cake and pizza. Igor's mother, Svitlana, started adult English classes Tuesday. The boy had surgery in January and a second operation is scheduled for March. He is taking drugs that doctors hope will shrink the remaining shell of the benign pituitary gland tumor removed in the first operation. His mother said she may take Igor back to the Soviet Union in about three months.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Former baseball commissioner Bowie Kuhn bought a $1 million home in an exclusive subdivision here, newspapers reported Friday. St. Johns County court records show that Kuhn bought a home in Marsh Landing from Jacksonville developer Chester Stokes, The Florida Times-Union said. Kuhn, baseball commissioner from 1969 to 1984, was a partner in the New York firm of Myerson & Kuhn, which filed for bankruptcy in December. Marine Midland Bank and former law partners are looking for Kuhn to serve him legal papers relating to the bankruptcy. In court papers filed Tuesday, Marine Midland charged that in the last two weeks, Kuhn, seeking to place his property out of the bank's reach, sold his Ridgewood, N.J., home and brought the home in Florida. His firm reportedly owes the bank $3.1 million, along with other debts. Florida law does not allow creditors to seize residences in the state in bankruptcy proceedings. For two weeks, deputies from the St. Johns County Sheriff's Office have tried to serve court paper on Kuhn, without success, The New York Times reported Friday. Kuhn and Harvey D. Myerson, a New York corporate lawyer, formed the firm with great fanfare in 1988. After a dispute with Shearson Lehman Hutton and internal disagreements among the partners, the firm collapsed. ``I have been unable to get in touch with him since December,'' Myerson said Thursday. Marine Midland's laywer, William J. Brown, has asked the U.S. District Court in New York to attach Kuhn's stock holdings there, as well as his summer home in Quoque, N.Y., to prevent him from making any additional transfers of assets. Officials from Shearson, to which Myerson & Kuhn owes $488,000, also have been unable to find him.

DOC.HEAD: Drug War Director Blasts District of Columbia Officials
DOC.TEXT: Drug policy director William J. Bennett on Friday accused District of Columbia officials of lackluster efforts in the war on drugs and a Bennett aide said the city let $2.4 million in federal funds slip away. ``I don't know why it's heresy when I say it,'' Bennett told the Senate Budget Committee. ``Everybody in this town knows that this government is not fulfilling its responsibilities to its citizens.'' The testimony came at a hearing in which Democrats on the Senate Budget Committee queried Bennett about efforts to combat drugs in the District of Columbia. Chairman Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., sought to spotlight the rampant problem in this city, whose mayor, Marion Barry, is in a Florida alcohol and drug clinic after his arrest on a cocaine possession charge. An aide has said Barry is being treated primarily for alcoholism. Sasser reminded Bennett that when he became drug policy director a year ago he promised to make Washington a test case in the fight against drugs that still can be bought on streetcorners ``only blocks from this Capitol.'' Bennett said action by federal officials ``cannot take the place of local government, federal initiatives cannot replace local initiatives.'' ``We're tired of being flogged for a problem that is not of our making,'' Bennett told the committee. District police estimate that more than 60 percent of the record 438 murders recorded in the nation's capital last year were drug-related. Sasser said District of Columbia officials have complained that they have not gotten the assistance from the federal government promised in the early days of the drug war. Bruce L. Carnes, director of planning, budget and administration under Bennett, told the panel that the federal government has made a commitment to provide more than $90 million of the $102 million that the District sought. He said, however, that despite repeated warnings District officials allowed $2.4 million in Defense Department funds for bolstering the National Guard as a drug-fighting tool to slip away through inaction. ``Almost every penny of that lapsed because the District did not draw down that money,'' Carnes told lawmakers. ``I kept telling them, the clock is ticking. ... You've got to draw down that money or it's going to lapse. It lapsed.'' He was asked by a reporter after the hearing if he had delivered his warning personally to the mayor and said he had not. He was then asked if he had warned City Administrator Carol B. Thompson, who is operating a caretaker government while the mayor is in treatment. ``I'm not going to get into that,'' Carnes said. ``I said it to various District officials.'' Lurma Rackley, a Barry spokeswoman, said the mayor ``chose to have no comment on Mr. Bennett when he was here. I'm sure that he would rather have Mr. Tucker or Ms. Thompson, who are the administration's spokespersons on drugs, handle this.'' Sterling Tucker, the city's anti-drug policy coordinator, was out of town and unavailable for comment Friday, a Tucker aide said. Thompson did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Activist Released; Soldiers Shoot Arab
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli peace activist walked out of prison unrepentant Friday and vowed to meet again with PLO chairman Yasser Arafat, the crime that put him behind bars for 122 days. ``I will meet Arafat another dozen times,'' Abie Nathan told a handful of supporters who gathered outside the prison gates in the pouring rain. ``I don't mind spending the rest of my life in prison. ``I will meet with Palestinians and with any Arab leader who stretches his hand to talk of peace,'' he said. ``This is my way of fighting.'' Also Friday, Israeli soldiers killed an Arab youth in the occupied West Bank town of Qabatiya, and Palestinians observed a general strike to mark the beginning of the 27th month of the uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied lands, army and hospital reports said. The army said soldiers shot Abed el-Kader Iknin, 19, after he tried to stab them. His death raised to 655 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians since the uprising began in December 1987. At least 181 Palestinians have been killed by their fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of cooperating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have died. A group of leading left-wing authors and poets published an ad in the independent Haaretz newspaper Friday demanding the repeal of the amendment to Israel's anti-terrorism law that makes meeting with PLO officials a crime punishable by up to three years in jail. Nathan, 63, was sentenced under that law to six months in prison after pleading guilty to meeting Arafat and other Palestine Liberation Organization officials in Tunis in 1988. He entered Eyal prison Oct. 10, and the penalty was reduced by two months for good behavior. As Nathan left prison he shook hands with the warden and said ``lehitraot,'' Hebrew for ```til we meet again.'' A group of teen-agers from a kibbutz, or collective farm, then presented him with a white dove, which he symbolically released. Peace activists also handed Nathan a bouquet of flowers and an olive branch. ``I was put in prison because of a law which is an undemocratic law which would not be accepted anywhere in the world,'' Nathan told The Associated Press. ``I will do everything in my power in order to continue my struggle to change the law.'' Nathan's first of seven meetings with Arafat was in 1982, when he went to Lebanon during the Israeli siege of Beirut in an unsuccessful attempt to gain freedom for a captured Israeli soldier. He is best known for making a dramatic trip in a private plane to Cairo in 1966 to try to persuade Egypt to make peace with Israel. In 1978, he went on a 45-day hunger strike to protest the building of Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: Civilians Die as Cease-Fire Prospects Shrink
With AM-Lebanon-Scene, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Snipers killed three civilians fleeing an embattled district of east Beirut on Friday as rival Christian forces battled with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. Police said the three, a married couple and a friend, were killed as they tried to escape the low-income neighborhood of Ein Rummaneh about noon. Earlier in the day, police said rescuers took 42 bullet-riddled corpses from east Beirut districts that were the scenes of most of the savage fighting. The command of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun also reported the deaths of 10 soldiers and two officers in the last two days of hostilities. That brought the overall casualties to 430 killed and 1,680 wounded in the worst intra-Christian conflict of the 15-year civil war, pitting Aoun's soldiers against Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen. A police spokesman, who cannot be named under standing regulations, said the factions blamed each other for provoking the intermittent skirmishes across confrontation lines dividing the Christian enclave in east Beirut. The shooting forced Maronite Catholic churches to cancel services on the occasion of St. Maroun's day, the patron saint of the sect. Mass was celebrated instead in the studios of the Voice of Lebanon radio station in east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh neighborhood. It was said by Archbishop Khalil Abi Nader, an aide to Maronite Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, and was broadcast live. The French Embassy, based in east Beirut, issued a statement saying France's minister for humanitarian affairs, Bernard Kouchner, would try ``to pursue efforts aimed at stabilizing a cease-fire in Lebanon.'' A French source, who refused to be further identified, said Kouchner, who had sponsored the evacuation of 16 wounded victims from east Beirut for treatment in France, was ``not optimistic about the future of the cease-fire.'' The police spokesman also said the combatants ``do not seem to be preparing to withdraw.'' ``The tanks are still in combat formation. Fighters are still in firing positions. These are not indications that a truce is in the making,'' he said. Papal Nuncio Pablo Puente, who had launched repeated efforts to halt the bloodshed, left Beirut to undergo an operation that he had postponed for a long time, a statement said. It did not elaborate. A security committee grouping representatives of Geagea and Aoun held a two-hour meeting in Bkirki north of Beirut. A statement afterward said both sides assured Puente, who attended the meeting, that they would strictly adhere to a cease-fire. They also agreed on reopening the Christian enclave's three main highways. More than a half-dozen previous cease-fires have collapsed. ``This is your last chance. His holiness Pope John Paul II insists there will not be a second chance. You have to resolve your difference on a basis of coordination in military affairs and plurality in political affairs,'' the statement quoted Puente as telling committee members. The clashes in the Christian enclave have forced hundreds of civilians to flee to safety in Moslem west Beirut and other areas outside the enclave. The fighting between rival Christian forces for control of the Christian heartland is the latest in the 15-year cycle of sectarian bloodshed. Aoun has refused to recognize a Syrian-backed Christian-Moslem government and has battled to drive out Syrian troops siding with Moslem militias in west Beirut. Rival Shiite Moslem factions also have battled intermittently for control of Beirut's southern slums.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba, U.S. Trade Charges About Firing on Freighter
DOC.TEXT: Cuba accused the United States on Friday of playing modern-day buccaneer by attacking a Cuban-chartered freighter, but the U.S. ambassador said the Coast Guard acted properly. Ambassador Alexander Watson told the Security Council the U.S. actions were ``fully consistent with international maritime law and practice. The action taken by the Cuban government was not.'' The freighter Hermann, registered in Panama, was hit at least twice by fire from a U.S. Coast Guard cutter Jan. 31 when the crew refused to allow a search and U.S. authorities suspected the vessel was involved in drug smuggling. The freighter then sailed into Mexican waters, and the U.S. cutter Chincoteague ended its pursuit. Ambassador Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada of Cuba accused the United States of endangering security in the region and violating international law by interfering with the freighter in international waters. He said Cuba ``is not ready to grant the United States the right of practicing piracy, nor will Cubans allow themselves to be intimidated by imperial arrogance.'' ``What difference is there between this repressive action and actions undertaken by buccaneers of the old pirate days?'' Alarcon asked. He said the Hermann had no connection with drug trafficking and urged the 15-member Security Council to put an end to U.S. actions he described as threatening international peace and security. Cuba requested the meeting of the council, which adjourned without action. Cuba is council president for February and passed the gavel temporarily to South Yemen. Watson, the deputy U.S. permanent representative, said the United States had obtained permission from Panama to search the Hermann if necessary. He said Cuba ``inexplicably ordered the civilian crew of the Hermann to resist the lawful efforts of the Coast Guard to inspect the vessel as part of a routine law enforcement operation.'' That showed ``blatant disregard'' for international efforts to stop the illegal drug trade, the ambassador said. Since Cuba had allowed previous searches in similar circumstances, Watson said, the incident proved President Fidel Castro's government wanted to provoke a confrontation. ``The incident is not a spat between the U.S. and Cuba, although the Cuban government, for reasons that are opaque, tries to make it one,'' he said. ``The only states involved are the United States and Panama. ... The government of Cuba acted as if it had the right to frustrate a lawful inspection duly authorized by the flag state. That is a prescription for chaos at sea.'' Watson said the Hermann's captain refused to identify the crew by nationality and caused suspicion because his answers to authorities on the cutter were unusually brief and evasive. He said previous searches of vessels on the same route had yielded illegal narcotics. Although the Hermann crew told the Coast Guard the vessel had no cargo aboard, the freighter was low in the water, creating further suspicions of illegal activity, the U.S. ambassador told the council. He said the cutter tried to disable the Hermann by firing shots into its stern when other attempts to stop it failed. Before firing at the freighter, Watson said, the cutter's crew displayed blue law enforcement lights, sprayed water across the Hermann's decks and down its stack, and fired warning shots across its bow.

DOC.HEAD: Blind Man Standed When Wife Struck And Killed
DOC.TEXT: A blind man was left stranded and screaming for help after his wife was killed by a hit-and-run motorist, police said. Police said Charles Walker told them he and 55-year-old his wife were walking Thursday when he heard a ``swishing'' noise and he could no longer find or hear his wife. A resident heard Walker's screams and called officers. Police, Young County deputies and Texas Department of Public Safety officers found Mildred Walker's body in a field about 50 feet from where she had been struck. Police said Charles Ike Herpeche, 34, of Graham, was arrested on a charge of failure to stop and render aid after officers tracked down the automobile by checking chrome fragments left at the scene. Herpeche was being held Friday in the Young County Jail in lieu of $50,000 bail.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Reagan Agrees to Testify at Poindexter Trial _ on Tape
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan today agreed to give videotaped testimony at former aide John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial. In a court filing, Reagan's lawyers asked that the former president be allowed to give the deposition in Los Angeles on Feb. 16, four days before Poindexter's trial is scheduled to begin on charges of conspiracy, obstructing Congress and making false statements in the Iran-Contra affair. MORE

DOC.HEAD: President of Mozambique to Visit With Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquim Alberto Chissano of the People's Republic of Mozambique will meet with President Bush during a March 13 visit, the White House announced Friday.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: Contra scandal.
DOC.TEXT: Reagan, who asserted executive privilege Monday in connection with approximately 33 diary entries he has been ordered to turn over to Poindexter, said he won't assert the privilege with regard to a videotaped deposition. ``The former president has determined to accept and comply with the court's judgment that a videotaped deposition is an appropriate vehicle for the resolution of these difficult issues,'' said Theodore Olson, one of Reagan's lawyers. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asks End of Duties on Some Caribbean, Central American Goods
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration asked Congress on Friday to remove import duties on clothing, shoes and other labor-intensive products from the Caribbean and Central America but said it opposes any tampering with sugar quotas imposed on the region. Endorsing an extension and expansion of President Reagan's 1983 Caribbean Basin Initiative, U.S. Trade Represenative Carla Hills said lifting the present duties would ``mitigate the need for (foreign) aid and raise our own exports'' to the region. However, she said changing import quota formulas on sugar to assure the Caribbean a stable U.S. market to the possible detriment of other exporters, such as Australia and the Phillippines, would violate international trade agreements. When asked at a Senate hearing if she would recommend that President Bush veto a bill that includes a guaranteed minimum for sugar imports from the Caribbean, Mrs. Hills said she didn't know. Congress is expected this year to make permanent the current program, now scheduled to expire in September 1995. But expanding it to include duty-free status on a wide variety of goods that compete with U.S. products is encountering widespread opposition. ``Supporters should keep in mind the adverse consequences,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's subcommittee on international trade. Lawmakers, Baucus said at Friday's hearing by his panel, ``have close ties with the Caribbean, but they have even closer ties with their own constituents.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., for example, strongly oppose removing the present duties on shoes and leather products. Their states are major producers of both. The House last year approved a bill by Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla., to make the initiative permanent but struck provisions that would have extended the duty-free status for several products. However, the bill would cut duties in half for a wide variety of products, including non-leather footwear, handbags, luggage and work gloves. It and a companion bill by Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., would increase the duty-free allowance for tourists returning from the Caribbean from $400 to $600. Congressional sources said the Senate version could be ready for a floor vote by late March.

DOC.HEAD: Namibian Assembly Adopts New Constitution Unanimously
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs with administrator announcing amnesty for security force members convicted of violations.
DOC.TEXT: An assembly of 72 members who were on opposite sides of a 23-year war unanimously adopted a democratic constitution Friday in the last major step to independence from South Africa. It guarantees fundamental individual rights and limits a president to two five-year terms, a rarity on a continent where leaders often serve for life. The constitution will take effect with independence March 21. A spirit of compromise and reconciliation was evident during the 80-day drafting process, although the members' constituents ranged from black Marxists to right-wing whites. ``This is indeed a historic day,'' said Hage Geingob, chairman of the Constituent Assembly and an official of the South-West Africa People's Organization. SWAPO guerrillas ended a 23-year bush war against South African rule last year, and in November the movement won 41 of the assembly seats to assure itself control of the new government. Delegates adopted the constitution in a ceremony on the front steps of the Tintenpalast, the legislative building on a hilltop in Windhoek, capital of the vast, sparsely populated territory South Africa captured from Germany in World War I. Former guerrillas and the territorial police, once enemies, stood beside one another to watch the events. ``Today, the masses of our people have a constitution which embodies their aspirations to be masters of their own destiny,'' said Sam Nujoma, leader of SWAPO. The assembly is expected to elect him as Namibia's first president on March 20, the day before independence. Nujoma praised the assembly delegates for ``confounding all the doubters'' with their speedy and harmonious work. Moses Katjuiuonga, leader of a small black party, said the drafting process should provide inspiration to South Africa, where the white government is edging toward negotiations with the black majority. Namibia's new flag was displayed at Friday's ceremony and a 13x20-foot copy of the constitution's preamble served as a backdrop. Those attending included Louis Pienaar, the South African administrator of the territory, and Martti Ahtisaari, head of the U.N. group monitoring the independence process. South Africa agreed to grant independence under a regional peace treaty also signed by Angola and Cuba, which also called for withdrawal of the 50,000 Cuban soldiers in Angola. More than 6,000 U.N. civilian and military personnel have been in Namibia since April 1989. Despite a hard-fought election campaign and sharp ideological differences, the seven parties represented in the assembly quickly reached agreement on the constitution after beginning work in November. In addition to a declaration of fundamental rights, the charter provides for freedom of movement and speech, and a free press. It outlaws capital punishment and detention without trial, and envisions multiparty democracy, regular elections, an independent judiciary and an executive president. Janie de Wet, leader of the largest white party, said at the ceremony that most of his constituents planned to stay in Namibia and contribute to its development. Nujoma has chosen a white businessman, Gert Hanekom, as agriculture minister and selected other whites and opposition party members for important posts in an effort to unite Namibians and ease the fears of the 75,000 whites, who control most of the economy. Independence celebrations next month are expected to attract more than 20 heads of state and thousands of foreign guests to Windhoek, which has only a few hotels. With about 120,000 inhabitants, it is by far the largest city in this mineral-rich territory, whose total population is only 1.3 million. In another development, Namibia's administrator Louis Pienaar announced amnesty for members of the South Africa-led security forces convicted of crimes ``in the performance of their duties.'' It was not immediately known how many would qualify for amnesty. Pienaar also said the South African government would release five prisoners serving sentences in Walvis Bay, a South African enclave on Namibia's western coast. The five were convicted of public violence. Pienaar said the releases were taken in the spirit of reconciliation as shown in the unanimous adoption of the constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises States `New Approaches,' not `Quick Fixes'
