DOC.TEXT: President Bush told state lawmakers Friday not to expect quick fixes from Washington, but promised federal help to promote ``new approaches to solving old problems.'' Speaking to a group of state legislators at the White House, the president promised to help cut burdensome red tape that restricts the flow of federal funds to the states. ``My formula for federalism comes down to ... more flexibility and fewer mandates,'' Bush said. His remarks came a day after a report by the National Conference of State Legislatures said that half of the states are facing deficits or unexpectedly low revenues. Bush said his fiscal 1991 budget proposal calls for increased spending on the environment and education and for combatting drugs and crime. That might help financially strapped states deal with these problems, Bush suggested. ``More federal money should not, in my view, automatically mean more federal management,'' he said. But, he added, ``We don't need a quick fix, we need quick action.'' Using the ``states as laboratories'' theme he has sounded before, Bush said he was prepared to support more ``demonstration projects, both fostering and financing experimentation in the states.'' ``From criminal justice to education, from child care to the environment, state and local governments are looking for new approaches to solving old problems,'' he said. The president also voiced a ``broad, philosophical commitment to federalism.'' Federalism is the word the Reagan administration used for a variety of proposals to transfer programs _ and the associated costs _ from the federal government to states. Bush told the lawmakers he was committed to ``the return of American political power to the states. That's where it began; that's where it belongs.''

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Warns of Race War; Police Beat Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs with two whites jailed for involvement with ANC released, quote.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-SAfrica-Restrictions, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk accused his right-wing opponents Friday of stirring up black-white animosity that could plunge South Africa into a race war. In Johannesburg, police beat blacks with batons and chased hundreds through downtown streets to break up a peaceful anti-apartheid demonstration in which they marked their first week of new freedoms. And 22 senior anti-apartheid leaders met with Nelson Mandela but said the jailed African National Congress leader had no information on his release, which is widely expected this month. De Klerk, responding to his critics in the pro-apartheid Conservative Party, said his National Party ``talks renewal and courage, and they talk racism and aggression.'' On Feb. 2, in a speech that launched a new era in South Africa, de Klerk lifted restrictions on more than 60 opposition groups, including Mandela's ANC guerrilla movement, and pledged to free Mandela soon. The Conservatives, who won 31 percent of the white vote in elections last year, say de Klerk has capitulated to the 28 million black majority. They also have threatened to stage boycotts and protest strikes. ``They (the Conservatives) will plunge this country into a racial war,'' de Klerk told Parliament. But, he added, ``The government and I will not allow anyone or any party to set fire to this country.'' De Klerk said his own party, which has ruled South Africa since 1948, ``will still be here 10 to 20 years from now, looking after the interests of its people and cooperating with the leaders of other people.'' De Klerk says he wants to bring South Africa's disenfranchised blacks into the national government within five years. But he opposes a one-man, one-vote system, the basic demand of all leading anti-apartheid groups. At the Victor Verster Prison outside Cape Town, the 22 anti-apartheid leaders met with Mandela in what they hoped was the last such political strategy session before he is freed. ``His feeling was, at the end of the meeting ... how he wished he could come home with us,'' said Murphy Morobe, one of the activists. The delegation _ the largest yet to see Mandela at his house on the prison farm _ included most members of the executive committee of the United Democratic Front, a nationwide anti-apartheid coalition. The front's delegation gave Mandela a policy document that said negotiations with the government could start only after democratic, non-racial elections to form an assembly that would draft a new constitution. De Klerk has rejected this demand. There are daily rumors that Mandela is about to be freed. However, according to sources, Mandela is expecting visitors through Monday, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson. Neither the government nor Jackson has confirmed the meeting date. The American civil rights leader is on a 12-day tour of South Africa. Mandela, 71, is the country's best-known black leader and has offered to serve as mediator in talks between the government and the ANC. He has been jailed since 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping to launch the ANC's guerrilla campaign. In Johannesburg, more than 1,000 demonstrators rallied in St. Mary's Anglican Church to mark last week's unbanning of the ANC. After the two-hour service, activists spilled out into a pedestrian mall and began dancing and singing freedom songs. A policeman ordered them to disperse, but within seconds his fellow officers converged from both sides and began hitting the activists with clubs. Police chased demonstrators through busy streets, toppling the stalls of vendors and forcing cars to come to screeching halts. In several instances, police surrounded unarmed demonstrators and hit them five or more times with their batons. Some activists later hurled bottles and rocks at the police. Police arrested several people and several more were hurt. De Klerk has said his government will permit peaceful protest if advance permission is sought from authorities. On several recent occasions police have dispersed peaceful crowds, calling the demonstrations illegal. In another development, two whites who had been jailed for their involvement with the African National Congress were released Friday. Barbara Hogan and Rob Adams, both sentenced to 10 years in 1982 for treason, were freed in Johannesburg. Dozens of activists jailed for belonging to the ANC and other previously banned organizations are expected to be released now that the groups are legal. ``The unbanning was a triumph for the movement and we both feel vindicated for our involvement,'' Ms. Hogan said.

DOC.HEAD: Fundamentalist Hindus Defer Plan to Build Disputed Temple
DOC.TEXT: Fundamentalist Hindus decided Friday to postpone building a temple at a disputed religious site claimed by both Moslems and Hindus. Avaidyanath, a Hindu priest who uses one name, told reporters the World Hindu Conference decided to postpone construction of the temple for at least four months so the government can find a solution to the long-running dispute. Construction was to have started Feb. 14 on land that also contains a 16th century mosque. Prime Minister V.P. Singh said building the shrine would inflame religious passions and lead to widespread violence, and he urged Hindus to call off construction. ``We have decided to accept the prime minister's appeal,'' said Avaidyanath, who wore the saffron robes of a Hindu ascetic. ``We'll give him four months to solve the issue.'' Last year, at least 300 people died in violence sparked by the Hindu group's decision to build the temple and raze the mosque. The foundation stone for the shrine was laid Nov. 9, but construction was postponed because of the dispute. Hindus claim the site is the birthplace of the Rama, an incarnation of Vishnu, one of the most important Hindu gods. They say the Babri Masjid, or the mosque named after Moghal emperor Babar, was built over Rama's birthplace. Moslems say it is difficult to say where Rama was born and they will not accept destruction of their mosque. The issue has become a flashpoint for tensions between India's majority Hindus, who make up 82 percent of its 880 million people, and its Moslems, who form the country's largest minority but still comprise only 12 percent of the population. The dispute became a major issue in last November's general elections, and analysts say it was one of the causes of the downfall of the previous prime minister, Rajiv Gandhi. Singh, his successor, has not come up with any specfic plan to solve the problem but has promised to set up a government committee to meet Hindu and Moslem representatves and try to come up with a solution. ``The problem has been hanging for 450 years,'' said Ashok Singhal, general secretary of the World Hindu Conference. ``Four months more will not matter.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Unisys Official Sentenced for Defrauding U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A former Unisys Corp. official was sentenced to a year in prison Friday for conspiring to make illegal campaign donations and obstructing the FBI's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud. John B.G. Roberts III, a former marketing manager for the defense contractor, was sentenced on his guilty plea to charges of conspiracy to defraud the government and charges of obstruction of justice. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton in Alexandria, Va., also fined Roberts $10,000 and ordered him to serve a two-year term of supervised release after completing the prison term. Roberts could have received a 10-year prison term for his guilty plea. He admitted that he arranged for the submission of false claims to the Pentagon for consultants' services when the money was actually funneled to members of Congress who had infuence over defense procurement. In pleading guilty Nov. 30, Roberts also admitted that he arranged for the filing of false statements with the Federal Election Commission to conceal illegal corporate donations to a number of lawmakers. Roberts admitted that he suggested to defense consultants working for Unisys how much money to donate to various lawmakers' campaign funds and prepared figures for the company's annual budget. Several Unisys consultants have pleaded guilty in connection with making illegal campaign contributions. Dennis Mitchell, a former Unisys Corp. official, received a 90-day prison term in a halfway house for arranging $4,000 worth of illegal campaign contributions. Donations went to Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y.; the late Rep. Joseph D. Addabbo, D-N.Y., who chaired the House defense appropriations subcommittee; Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa.; Rep. Roy Dyson, D-Md.; Rep. Bill Young, D-Fla., and the late Rep. Bill Chappell, D-Fla. Prosecutors have said they found no evidence that the lawmakers had known their campaign funds were receiving illegal donations. Roberts also admitted that he destroyed documents in his home when he first learned about the FBI's investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud, nicknamed ``Operation Ill Wind.''

DOC.HEAD: Terrorism Trial Ends, Verdict March 9
DOC.TEXT: A Tunisian accused of directing a bombing campaign that killed 13 people in Paris said in court Friday that his trial marked the beginning of a holy war against the West. Fouad Ali Saleh and nine others face 10 years to 20 years in prison if convicted on charges of terrorist conspiracy, possession of illegal arms, trafficking in explosives and a variety of drug offenses. The trial closed Friday after two weeks. A verdict is expected March 9. Saleh, 31, his French wife Karima, and eight other men are to be tried again later this year on murder charges in connection with the wave of bombings that killed 13 people and injured 250 in 1986. Eight other people are being tried in absentia in the current trial. Judge Henri Malergue offered Saleh a chance to speak in his defense, and the defendent began by invoking the ``name of God, all powerful.'' ``Today this criminal trial of the West is the prelude to the big war promised by God in the Koran. The crimes (of the West) are unpardonable and the punishment will be apocalyptic. ... You are the barbarians, Judeo-Christians, not us,'' he said. He went on until the judge stopped him 25 minutes later. Police say Saleh recruited and directed terrorists who hid explosives smuggled in from Lebanon and placed the bombs at key locations around Paris. He is accused of taking orders from leaders of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah extremist movement in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Renews Ties With Israel
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovakia renewed ties with Israel on Friday in the latest move by an East bloc nation to scrap a Soviet-ordered policy of the past. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel called the restoration of diplomatic ties a first step toward ``very good and very friendly relations.'' Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier of Czechoslovakia and Arens both said they hoped the resumption of ties would lead to trade and increased cooperation between Israel and Czechoslovakia, which was one of Israel's strongest supporters when it was founded in 1948. Arens paid tribute to Prague's supplies of weapons and training of Air Force pilots during that period, noting that ``Czechoslovakia was one of the few nations that lent important assistance to Israel in its hour of need during the war of independence in 1948.'' Czechoslovakia and other East bloc nations followed Moscow's mandate and broke ties with Israel because of the 1967 Middle East War. Romania maintained ties at the time and East Germany never had established relations. Since the revolts that toppled old Communist regimes in Eastern Europe, Soviet bloc nations have been moving toward a more Western orientation in their foreign policies. Czechoslovakia became the second Soviet bloc nation to re-establish ties with Israel, after Hungary. On Friday, Hungary became the second nation to restore relations with the Vatican, following Poland last year. Arens told Czechoslovak television late Friday he expected relations with Poland to be resumed by the end of this month, and with all other East European nations and the Soviet Union within months. East Germany has never had relations with Israel because of East Berlin`s consistent refusal in the past to acknowledge any guilt for the Nazi Holocaust that killed 6 million Jews, or to pay compensation to victims. Now, however, East German Premier Hans Modrow has acknowledged East Germany's part in the Nazi past. Arens declined to react to Modrow's statement, saying only that it would be very carefully examined. ``Initial contacts'' between the Israeli and East German Foreign Ministries on establishing ties had identified the admission of guilt as a key issue, he noted. Dienstbier signaled the clean break that he and President Vaclav Havel are trying to make with the Communist past. ``I'm very happy that we could meet and remedy that nonsense of cutting off relations with Israel,'' Dienstbier told Arens. The Israeli in turn said his nation is watching Czechoslovakia`s transition to democracy ``with great sympathy and admiration.'' Czechoslovakia has long maintained ties with the Palestine Liberation Organization, elevating those to full diplomatic relations in 1988. Havel has offered to mediate in the Middle East if required. Havel and Arens discussed that offer Friday afternoon, with the Israeli thanking Czechoslovakia for its concern for peace, the state news agency CTK said. It said Havel was invited to visit Israel, but made no mention of whether his offer to mediate would be taken up. Before signing Friday's agreement, Arens toured Prague's ancient Jewish Quarter and visited the former site of a Nazi concentration camp at Theresienstadt. Before World War II, there were 240,000 Jews in Czechoslovakia. Prague was for centuries one of the leading centers of Jewish education and culture. Today, there are only about 6,000 Jews in Czechoslovakia, most of them in the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Accountant Says Collapsed Thrift was `Giving Its Money Away'
DOC.TEXT: Lincoln Savings and Loan Association ``was manufacturing profits by giving its money away,'' an accountant who examined Lincoln's books at the government's request testified Friday. Roger Johnson said in U.S. District Court that the collapsed thrift, owned by Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating and seized by federal regulators last April, recorded $135 million in pre-tax gains on 15 land transactions in 1986 and 1987. In reality, however, there was ``a net outflow of cash from Lincoln'' in each instance, said Johnson, a certified public accountant for Kenneth Leventhal & Co. The net cash expended by Lincoln to accomplish the sales totaled $217 million, according to a draft of a report prepared last July by Johnson's firm and introduced in court. Reading from the report, Johnson said the Irvine, Calif., thrift was ``made to function as an engine designed to funnel insured deposits'' to Keating's Phoenix holding company, the American Continental Corp. The cash outflow is ``precisely the opposite of what you would expect. ... The profits reported should have been reversed,'' Johnson told U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin. Lincoln is suing the government's Office of Thrift Supervision, seeking a court order to remove the conservatorship and receivership regulators imposed last year to seize control of the thrift. American Continental Corp. benefited from the 15 transactions under a tax-sharing agreement in which Lincoln made payments to its parent. ``Seldom in our experience as accountants have we encountered a more egregious example of the misapplication of generally accepted accounting principles,'' testified Johnson, reading from the report. Lincoln ``created profits by making loans. Many of the loans were bad,'' said Johnson. ``Lincoln was manufacturing profits by giving its money away.'' In two hours of testimony, Johnson described a series of deals in which Lincoln sold land to buyers who didn't have enough cash to make the down payment. Ten of the 15 transactions involved an area in Arizona known as Hidden Valley, 8,500 acres which Johnson testified likely won't be developed ``during the remainder of this century.'' In one transaction, Lincoln received a $3.5 million cash down payment for the sale of 1,000 acres to Westcontinental Mortgage Investment Corp., a firm with only $87,000 in assets. Westcontinental got the down payment the day before the sale from a company operated by businessman E.C. Garcia. Garcia's company, in turn, had received $19.6 million from Lincoln the same day Garcia lent the $3.5 million to Westcontinental. Calling Westcontinental a ``straw buyer,'' Johnson said Garcia placed the property involved in the sale on his books in June 1988. Johnson said ``we find no evidence'' that Westcontinental or Garcia has paid any principal or interest on a $10.5 million note held by Lincoln for the remainder of the deal. Lincoln reported an $11.1 million profit in the transaction. Garcia, who had no loans outstanding with Lincoln at the beginning of 1987, had $128 million outstanding by the end of that year, said Johnson.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to `Wait And See' About Campaigning for Job
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday refused to say whether he would run in a campaign to keep his job, a once-unthinkable scenario made possible by his party's historic acceptance of a multiparty system and direct elections. ``Let's wait and see,'' he said in a relaxed encounter with reporters. Gorbachev is riding high on success after persuading the Communist Party Central Committee Wednesday to adopt a new platform favoring reforms. Besides opening the way for competition with new parties and abolishing the party's constitutionally guaranteed leading role, the platform favors a stronger presidency to be filled in a contested election. Gorbachev has never faced a popular election during his five years in power. The Soviet parliament named him to a five-year term last summer, and there has been speculation that he will be allowed to serve a second term without having to submit to voters. There also has been speculation that Gorbachev eventually will step down as leader of his splintering party and concentrate on his duties in a strengthened presidency. Gorbachev told reporters that the party platform contains only the current stage of his long-planned reforms. ``Once we have solidified this phase, we will move on,'' he said. The changes pushed through the Central Committee had been in the works since he took power five years ago, Gorbachev said. ``It certainly would be wrong for the West and everyone to believe we began these changes only in the last few days,'' he said. ``They have been under way since 1985.'' Gorbachev made his comments before meeting with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who is in Moscow in hopes of forging an arms agreement to be signed at the June summit. One of Gorbachev's assistants, meanwhile, offered the first high-level warning that the Communist Party must reform or lose power to the opponents it has agreed to legalize. ``A choice stands before the party in the conditions of political pluralism: Restructure itself and struggle to show in competition its right to be the ruling party, or slide into opposition, and maybe even leave the political arena,'' economist Nikolai Petrakov said in an interview with the official Tass news agency. Petrakov also said the party's platform accepts private ownership of factories, which would amount to a second dramatic reversal of long-standing Soviet policy. The economic section is based on ``many forms of ownership of the means of production and other things, including cooperative and individual property,'' he said. In Marxist jargon, ``means of production'' are factories and equipment. Other Soviet officials have said the platform bans property that involves ``exploitation of the working man,'' defined as the appropriation of some of the value created by a laborer. The contradiction implies that the Kremlin leadership plans to redefine Marxist terms to fit the new policy. Activists have criticized the new Communist platform as inadequate because the party will continue to exert control through party units in factories, army units, the police, courts and most public organizations. But on Friday, an official Soviet trade union cut its ties with the party and government, Tass reported Friday. Tass said the action by the fishing industry union was a first for the Soviet Union. Official unions have been used for decades to keep workers under control and prevent strikes. The fishing union also took control of its own budget and set up a strike fund, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Auction House Shows Off Ancient Silver Collection
DOC.TEXT: A collection of 14 ancient silver dishes worth an estimated $70 million that will ``rewrite the history of Roman art'' will be sold unless its authenticity or ownership is challenged, Sotheby's said Friday. The Sevso Treasure has four large plates, five pitchers, a tall jar, two buckets, a basin, a lady's toilet casket and the copper-alloy cauldron in which the silver was believed to have been found in Lebanon in the mid-1970s. The pieces, decorated with mythological and contemporary figures of the fourth and fifth centuries, in total outweigh the combined weight of the 98 pieces of the two other main silver treasures of the period, the auction house said. ``Every time I look at it I get goose pimples,'' said Marcus Linell, senior director of Sotheby's of Europe. ``It is a startling find in every respect.'' ``It is so good and so grand and of such good quality that it will make a reappraisal of the art of the period necessary,'' he said. ``This is an incredible moment,'' said Michael L. Ainslie, president of Sotheby's Holdings Inc. ``This is the most important collection of Roman silver known to exist. This will rewrite the history of Roman art.'' He said Sotheby's was estimating its worth at $70 million but added that the treasure was too unusual to easily put a price tag on. But one reason Sotheby's is displaying the collection is to spread the word in case anyone wants to challenge its ownership or authenticity. If not, it is expected to be offered in the fall in Zurich, Switzerland by Sotheby's, which also plans to entertain private offers. Sotheby's says it has confirmed the collection's authenticity through extensive laboratory testing as well as scholarly and scientific research. It also had the owner's export licenses examined and ratified by the Lebanese Embassy in Switzerland and sent descriptions and photographs of each piece to cultural attaches in Switzerland for each of the 29 countries which were in or part of the Roman Empire in the fourth century. To increase scrutiny of the collection, Sotheby's announced it would publicly display it from Saturday to Feb. 20, while 5,000 scholars and academics gather for the College Art Association conference. The collection was acquired piecemeal during the 1980s from its owner in Lebanon by the Marquess of Northampton Settlement, a family trust in Guernsey, England. Linell refused to disclose how much the estate paid for the silver. The collection was named after a hunting plate which carried the name of its owner, Sevso. Linell said it was likely that the person who discovered the treasure sought anonymity so others would not know about the money paid for the silver.

DOC.HEAD: Prospects Better
DOC.TEXT: Orange harvest prospects have improved from a month ago, but production is still down sharply from last season because of widespread freeze damage in late December, the Agriculture Department said Friday. The new estimate of 169 million boxes was based on Feb. 1 indications and is up 7 percent from the January forecast of fewer than 158 million boxes. Even so, the freeze-damaged crops is expected to be down 19 percent from 209 million boxes in 1988-89. Most of the reduction was attributed to a 32 percent decline in the Florida crop. ``The severe freeze in Florida's citrus belt on Dec. 24-25 further reduced an already short orange crop,'' the report said. ``The increase (in total output) from last month reflects better-than-expected salvage operation in Florida and increased expectations in California.'' Florida's orange harvest was estimated at 100 million boxes, down from 146.6 million last season but up from 92 million forecast last month. The Texas crop was forecast at 1.2 million boxes, down from 1.85 million in 1988-89 and 1.25 million forecast in January. California production, estimated at 66 million boxes, is up from 58.8 million last season and 63 million indicated last month. Arizona production was expected to be 1.7 million boxes, unchanged from January and the same as last season. Total grapefruit production was forecast at 41.6 million boxes, down 9 percent from the January forecast and 36 percent below last year, reflecting the freeze in Florida and Texas. ``Higher-than-expected fruit droppage in Florida due to the freeze is a main reason for this continued decline,'' the report said. Florida grapefruit production was estimated at 34 million boxes, down 11 percent from January's forecast and 39 percent below last season. The Texas crop, unchanged from January, was forecast at 2 million boxes, down 58 percent from 1988-89.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta Mayor Proposes Licenses for Beggars
DOC.TEXT: Advocates for the homeless are blasting a proposal under consideration by Mayor Maynard Jackson to require people who want to beg for money to buy a license first. The licenses are part of a proposed program that would also include counseling and job-placement programs paid for by local businesses. Details including the license fee haven't been worked out. ``We're going to present the strongest law possible because it (begging) has gotten out of hand,'' Jackson said this week, adding that he plans to offer his panhandling plan within a month. As many as 10,000 homeless people live in Atlanta, said Anita Beaty, co-director of the Task Force for the Homeless. Ed Loring, director of the Open Door Community, an Atlanta shelter, called the license proposal ``awful'' ``A person with enough money to get a license is not a panhandler,'' he said. But the licensing plan is supported by some downtown business leaders. ``Business leaders are concerned about street crime, about panhandling that goes far beyond begging and about the conduct of some people who are being abusive,'' said Joe Martin, president of Central Atlanta Progress. ``At the same time, we feel it's important to take a positive approach to the needs of the homeless, including providing opportunities for temporary and permanent jobs and forging a comprehensive strategy to deal with the causes of the problem,'' he said. Atlanta already has a law that makes panhandling illegal, but it is rarely enforced. A federal judge in New York recently said a rule banning panhandlers from that city's subway system and bus and rail stations could not be enforced. He said begging is protected free speech. After his ruling, the New York agency that runs the bus and rail stations began issuing permits to beggars, as it does to anyone who wants to solicit. But an appeals court has put the New York ruling on hold, and panhandling is again illegal. Jackson said he personally sympathizes with beggars. ``Ninety percent of the people who panhandle have no money and are desperate, and they beg,'' he said. ``My policy is when someone asks for money, I give it.''

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Traveling to Asia
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney will visit South Korea, the Philippines and Japan during a two-week series of discussions with Asian allies beginning next week, the Pentagon announced Friday. The secretary is slated to meet with civilian and military leaders in each country ``to discuss a wide variety of global, regional and bilateral issues,'' a statement said. Cheney, who leaves Saturday, travels first to Hawaii to consult with Adm. Huntington Hardisty, the commander-in-chief of U.S. forces in the Pacific. The secretary will visit South Korea on Feb. 14-17; Hong Kong, Feb. 17-18; the Philippines, Feb. 18-20, and Japan, Feb. 20-24. At each stop except Hong Kong, Cheney is to meet with the U.S. forces stationed there. He is to review host-nation forces in Korea, the Philippines and Japan. He returns to Washington Feb. 24.

DOC.HEAD: DC Mayor Informant Gets Delay in Drunken Driving Case
DOC.TEXT: The former fashion model who helped the FBI arrest Washington Mayor Marion Barry got a continuance in her drunken-driving case. Hazel Diane Moore, 38, of Burbank, also known as Rasheeda Moore, was to be arraigned March 2 in Van Nuys Municipal Court, under an order issued Friday by court Commissioner Mitchell Block. Ms. Moore, who did not appear in court, was arrested Jan. 1 for investigation of driving under the influence. Her blood alcohol level was 0.12 percent, over the legal limit of 0.08 percent, police said. Ms. Moore, a friend of Barry's, worked as an undercover informant for the FBI, calling Barry to a Washington hotel room where he was arrested Jan. 18 for investigation of possessing cocaine. Ms. Moore's attorney in the drunken-driving case, Ronald J. Lewis, said Ms. Moore will probably plead no contest at her arraignment, depending on the outcome of discussions with the city attorney's office.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Secretary of State to Stop in Bulgaria en Route to Romania
With AM-Baker-Soviet, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III will make a stopover Saturday in Bulgaria en route from Moscow to Romania, the state BTA news agency reported. The one-paragraph dispatch Friday offered no details beyond saying Baker would arrive in the afternoon. It will be the first visit to Bulgaria by a U.S. Secretary of State. Baker's visit to Romania was announced earlier Friday. He is the highest-ranked American government official to come to Bucharest since the December revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and ended two decades of Communist Party rule. Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's hard-line Communist ruler, was ousted in November, and his more reform-minded Communist successors have promised free elections and other reforms. Baker's brief visits to the two countries appear meant to signal American interest in the process of democratization. In Romania's case, the visit also seems calculated to defuse criticism by Romanian officials that Washington's reluctance to send a ranking official signals disinterest in the reforms. U.S. officials have been cautious about the chances of true democracy in the two countries. While both plan elections in May, the officials have pointed to the continued Communist grip on power in Bulgaria and to the prolonged reluctance of Romania's self-installed interim government to share the running of the country pending the planned elections.

DOC.HEAD: Three Reformers Leave Bulgarian Party Leadership
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Communist Party suffered another setback Friday with the announcement that three reformers quit the party leadership, one week after they were voted into the newly created Supreme Council. The state news agency BTA said all three representatatives of the Alternative Socialist Organization _ Koprinka Chervenkova, Kiril Vassilev and Ivan Nikolov _ quit the 153-member Supreme Council. The ASO is a reformist faction within the party. The party is in a deep identity crisis, and the resignations thwarted efforts by senior leaders to give it a more progressive public image. An even more serious challenge faces the party. Nikolai Vassilev, leader of the Alternative Socialists and Kiril Vassilev's son, told The Associated Press on Wednesday he expected two-thirds of delegates to an ASO congress on Feb.11 to vote to leave the Communist Party and reform along Social Democratic lines as an Alternative Socialist Party. At a four-day Communist Party congress ending Feb. 2, new party chief Alexander Lilov and other major officials said the party had parted with Stalinism and was embarking on a road of ``socialist democracy.'' On Thursday, new Premier Andrei Lukanov presented to Parliament the country's first all-Communist government, admitting failure to persuade members of the democratic opposition to join it. The Agrarian Party, for decades a docile ally of the Communists in the Cabinet, refused to join Lukanov's government. It said it would not make sense to be in a ``government of national concord'' that does not include the opposition. Ms. Chervenkova announced her resignation on Tuesday. Kiril Vassilev and Nikolov said they were stepping down in a declaration published Friday in the Communist Party daily Rabotnichesko Delo. Rabotnichesko Delo had reported on Thursday that another Supreme Council member, Hristo Ganev, had quit. Todor Zhivkov, Bulgaria's Communist ruler for 35 years, was driven from power last November in the pro-democracy reforms sweeping Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Officials Meet to Select Atlantis Launch Date
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle managers began a two-day meeting Friday to select a date for launching Atlantis on a classified military mission. The working target has been Feb. 22, but officials want to assess the readiness of all launch elements before setting a firm date Saturday. NASA said a delay in replacing a faulty engine turbopump could cause a one-day slip, but the agency said it was hoping the time could be made up. A new pump was installed Friday and leak checks will be conducted Saturday. If the Feb. 22 date holds, Atlantis is scheduled to blast off at 1:14 a.m. with a crew of five astronauts. For security reasons, neither the Pentagon nor NASA will identify the satellite, but sources close to the project report it is a highly sophisticated reconnaissance satellite that will gather information over the Soviet Union and a wide area of the globe.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names Inspector General for Thrift Bailout Agency
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday named John J. Adair to be inspector general of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency created to help manage the cleanup of the savings and loan industry. Adair, 48, most recently has been associate director of audit oversight at the General Accounting Office, an auditing and investigatory arm of Congress. The post, a new one, requires Senate confirmation. Congress created the corporation last August as part of the legislation restructuring the troubled S&L industry. It oversees the federal cleanup and closing of failed institutions. The White House also announced these other nominations: _Jonathan Moore, 57, of Washington, as U.S. representative to the U.N. Economic and Social Council. Since 1989, he has been alternate U.S. representative to the U.N. for special political affairs. _Shirin Raziuddin Tahir-Kheli, 45, as U.S. representative to the U.N. for special politial affairs. Born in India, she was on the National Security Council staff at the White House from 1986-1989 and is a former associate professor of political science at Temple University in Philadelphia. _Graham C. Mullen, 49, a Gastonia, N.C., as judge for the U.S. Western District of North Carolina. He would succeed James B. McMillan. _Samuel A. Alito Jr., 39, U.S. attorney in Newark, N.J., as judge for the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. He would succeed John J. Gibbons. _Stephen M. McNamee, 46, the U.S. attorney in Phoenix, as judge for the U.S. District of Arizona. He would succeed Charles L. Hardy. _Robert H. Cleland, 42, prosecuting attorney for St. Clair County in Michigan, as judge for the U.S. Eastern District of Michigan.

DOC.HEAD: President Makes Declaration
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Friday declared a state of disaster in American Samoa, opening the way for federal relief for damage resulting from Hurricane Ofa this month. The emergency declaration makes available assistance such as temporary housing, grants, low-cost loans and other aid to help individuals, local governments and businesses recover from the Feb. 2 hurricane.

DOC.HEAD: MSG Hearing: Very Spicy
DOC.TEXT: Arguments on both sides of the monosodium glutamate issue spiced up a hearing on a proposal to make restaurants disclose their use of it. Leading the charge against MSG, a flavor enhancer, was San Francisco Supervisor Wendy Nelder, whose proposal has angered restaurateurs. At the hearing Thursday, Nelder accused her critics of not caring whether diners live or die. ``It is really no skin off anyone's nose to make restaurateurs let people know what they are eating,'' said Nelder. But restaurateurs disagreed. ``I've had more people with problems with mayonnaise,'' said Colleen Meharry of Miz Brown's Restaurant. ``I have people who come in and say they are allergic to mayonnaise, but I don't post that mayonnaise is dangerous to them.'' Supervisor Angela Alioto chimed in, ``Don't give her any ideas.'' Nelder said Friday that her proposal would require restaurateurs to put a small mark on their menus next to dishes that are made with MSG. Among those who testified on behalf of Nelder's proposal was Jack Samuels, an investment banker from Chicago who told the committee, ``If I don't stay away from this stuff, I'm going to die.'' Samuel said he came to testify because ``San Francisco is a very important, trend-setting city.'' Apparently, the Atlanta-based Glutamate Association agreed, because the trade organization _ comprised of MSG manufacturers _ has sent its executive director to San Francisco four times in the past month to fight the proposal. The Food and Drug Administration, despite anecdotal evidence, has categorized MSG as a safe ingredient. By the time the meeting ended, Nelder had stormed out, angry because she didn't have enough votes to support the measure until the city's health and small business commissions issue their opinions. The committee will take up the issue again next month.

DOC.HEAD: Imports Will Be Trimmed, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is expected to trim total grain imports to about 38 million metric tons this year, up 1 million tons from estimates last month, the Agriculture Department said Friday. But that would be down from 39 million tons of grain imported by the Soviets in 1988-89. The imports are for the trade year that runs from July 1 through the next June. The department's Foreign Agricultural Service said Moscow reported in late January a 1989 total grain harvest of 211.1 million tons. The department's earlier forecast of the Soviet harvest was 208 million tons. A metric ton is approximately 2,205 pounds, about 36.7 bushels of wheat or 39.4 bushels of corn. Moscow's harvest figures would make the 1989 harvest one of the largest on record, up from 195.1 million tons in 1988 but fractionally below the 1987 harvest of 211.4 million tons, according to the report. The record was 237.4 million tons in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Foods as diverse as chocolate, sea slugs and calf brains have been touted as aphrodisiacs throughout history, says the co-author of a book on the subject. ``Almost everything you can think of has been used as an aphrodisiac _ including tree bark, shark's fin and hippopotamus snout,'' said George Armelagos, co-author of ``Consuming Passions.'' Often foods perceived to enhance sexual desire simply may add to physical or mental well-being because they are good sources of protein, such as eggs, caviar and oysters, he said. ``The prune was thought to be such a strong aphrodisiac that the brothels in Elizabethan England would serve them to their customers,'' said Armelagos, chairman of the University of Florida's anthropology department. When Ireland's population boomed, the English assumed the potato was an aphrodisiac, he said. Many seafoods are considered erotic eating, partly because the ancient goddesses of love, Aphrodite or Venus, were said to have emerged from sea foam. One 17th-century French physician reported that his people felt most amorous during Lent, when they ate a lot of fish. Chocolate, a popular Valentine Day's gift, has a substance called phenylethelalanine that accumulates in the pleasure centers of the brain, mimicking what happens during sexual activity, he said. Alcohol, especially champagne, is commonly thought to be an aphrodisiac, reflecting poet Ogden Nash's sentiment that ``Candy's dandy, but liquor's quicker,'' Armelagos said. ``Although champagne is a noted ingredient in seduction scenes, whatever effectiveness it may have is probably due to the flattery of being offered an expensive commodity,'' he said. Still, no food has ever been proven to be an aphrodisiac. ``The brain is the most important sexual organ,'' he said. ``If you think Saltines will work, then you've got a good, cheap aphrodisiac.''

Because Mayor Morris Fisher changed his mind, Pacific Grove's nickname ``Butterfly Town, U.S.A.'' remains appropriate. Last month, Fisher was with the majority as the City Council voted 4-3 to allow development of 2.7 acres of privately owned land, one of two nesting sites in town for monarch butterflies. But on Wednesday, Fisher reversed his decision and the proposed development was voted down. The Monterey Peninsula community is one of the best known California nesting sites for the orange and black monarchs, who migrate each autumn from Alaska and Canada. The butterflies nest in pine and eucalyptus trees in Pacific Grove. Butterfly lovers from the area and elsewhere criticized the council for its January vote. ``Even a partial elimination of the Pacific Grove monarchs would be a very sad national loss,'' Edward O. Wilson, professor of science at Harvard, wrote to the council.

DOC.HEAD: Kathleen Sullivan to Leave as `CBS This Morning' Anchorwoman
By JAY SHARBUTT
AP Television Writer
DOC.TEXT: In what will be the second exit of a network morning anchorwoman in a year's time, Kathleen Sullivan is being replaced on ``CBS This Morning,'' her agent said Friday. CBS said it can't confirm or deny that. Sullivan, whose CBS contract expires in November, got the word Wednesday in a meeting with CBS News President David Burke and other executives, said her agent, Ron Konecky. No date is set for her departure, he said. ``Not really,'' he said when asked if they gave any reason why they wanted to replace her on the two-hour morning show that she has co-anchored with Harry Smith since its premiere Nov. 30, 1987. ``I think that was a management decision they felt they had to make,'' Konecky said. ``I'm having ongoing, positive meetings with them with a view to other assignments for Kathleen at CBS.'' There have been reports she will be succeeded by Paula Zahn, co-anchor of ABC's ``World News This Morning,'' and the news segments of the following ``Good Morning America.'' Scott Richardson, an ABC spokesman, said he had no comment on whether Zahn will leave ABC. CBS spokeswoman Terry Everett said CBS can't confirm or deny if Sullivan, 36, is out at ``CBS This Morning.'' Asked if Sullivan's co-anchor, Smith, is staying at the CBS show, a CBS official who spoke on condition he not be identified by name said yes. From its start, the program has been a distant third in ratings to ``Good Morning America'' and NBC's ``Today.'' Speaking last October on the syndicated ``Donahue'' show last fall, Sullivan predicted ``my days are numbered'' if the ratings didn't improve. Ironically, another anchorwoman appearing with her on ``Donahue'' was Jane Pauley, who as part of the most controverial change in ``Today'' left that show in December after 13 years as its co-host. She was succeeded in January by Deborah Norville. Sullivan co-anchored Friday's ``CBS This Morning'' from Atlanta. During the broadcast, she made no mention of her impending depature. Neither did Smith or news anchor Charles Osgood. She couldn't be reached for comment Friday. Everett, who said the program will originate from Florida next week, said Sullivan had gone to Atlanta on personal business. Ted Turner's Cable News Network is based in Atlanta, but Konecky said she wasn't there for talks with CNN officials, nor was he negotiating with them for her. He said CBS officials have asked her to stay on at ``CBS This Morning'' during its transition to a new anchorwoman ``and she's happy to do so.'' The news of Sullivan's impending exit, coupled with the three-month payless suspension of ``60 Minutes'' humorist Andy Rooney for a racial slur attributed to him, came at an awkward time for CBS executives. A spokesman said that Burke, ``CBS This Morning'' executive producer Erik Sorenson, and other CBS officials were in Phoenix on Friday, attending a regional meeting of executives from CBS-affiliated stations.

DOC.HEAD: Deeper Crack Found in Damaged TMI Unit
DOC.TEXT: A crack in the steel barrier encasing the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor apparently is deeper than initially thought, officials said Friday, raising new questions about the severity of the 1979 accident at the plant. GPU Nuclear Corp. said in a statement that the discovery was made Thursday, when scientists examined pictures of a metal sample taken from the 5-inch thick bottom shield in the Unit 2 reactor. The discovery is ``an indication that the consequences of the accident could have easily been much worse,'' Robert Pollard, a nuclear safety engineer for the Union of Concerned Scientists, said. Pollard said he was surprised that the nuclear reactor remained intact, adding, ``Apparently it did so by a small margin.'' Company spokeswoman Mary Wells said what appeared to be surface cracks in a steel lining shield were discovered last summer. New pictures show the crack apparently extended through the lining and into the bottom steel wall of the reactor. The company's statement said the crack appears to extend most of the way through the 3-inch thick sample cut from the reactor bottom. Ms. Wells said the steel wall that contains the apparent crack is ``the final steel wall before we get to concrete.'' A 13-feet thick concrete wall separates the shield and the reactor from the ground. Ms. Wells said it is too soon to tell if the discovery means the accident was more serious. ``This is a sample and it has to be analyzed,'' she said. ``When all the scientists have analyzed them, they will draw the conclusion as to what it means.'' She said, however, that there is no indication that radioactive material escaped from the reactor vessel. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission was notified of the development, but spokesman Frank Ingram agreed it was too soon to draw conclusions. Eric Epstein, of the anti-nuclear group Three Mile Island Alert, said the finding ``clearly indicates that we do not know the full extent of the damage to the reactor. We question whether the plant is in a stable condition.'' The 1979 accident was caused by a combination of human and mechanical errors, which resulted in protective cooling water being drained from the reactor. It is considered the worst commercial nuclear accident in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Puts $3.3 Million Into Water Quality Projects
DOC.TEXT: Five Agriculture Department agencies have committed $3.3 million this year to water-quality demonstration projects in eight states, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced Friday. Yeutter said USDA plans to add 16 more projects over the next five years to ``accelerate the adoption of water quality technology that's been developed but hasn't yet achieved widespread recognition.'' The agencies involved are the department's Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service, $900,000; Economic Research Service, $150,000; Extension Service, $1 million; Forest Service, $100,000; and Soil Conservation Service, $1.1 million. Projects listed by Yeutter included: _California. Sacramento Valley Demonstration Project (Butte, Colusa, Sutter and Yuba counties), the economic and environmental feasibility of pesticide management practices that reduce pesticide residue levels in irrigation return flow water. _Florida. Lake Manatee Watershed Demonstration Project (Manatee County), the use of profitable irrigation and crop management systems, based on computer decisions models, for the reduction of fertilizer and pesticide loadings to surface and groundwater. _Maryland. Monocacy River Watershed Demonstration Project (Carroll, Frederick and Montgomery counties), focus on economically feasible and environmentally effective methods for farmers to reduce the application of fertilizers and properly manage animal wastes, thus reducing the potential to pollute surface and groundwater. _Minnesota. Anoka Sand Plain Demonstration Project (Anoka, Benton, Chisago, Hennepin, Isanti, Mille Lacs, Ramsey, Sherburne, Stearnes, Washington and Wright counties), demostrate cost-effective nutrient and crop management systems that reduce loadings of nitrates and pesticides in a groundwater recharge area. _Nebraska. Mid-Nebraska Water Quality Demonstration Project (Adams, Butler, Clay, Fillmore, Hamilton, Kearney, Polk, Seward, York and Webster counties), demonstrate on irrigated cropland the integrated use of cost-effective nitrogen, irrigation and pest management to reduce chemical inputs, production costs and groundwater contamination. _North Carolina. Herrings Marsh Run Demonstration Project (northwestern Duplin County), demonstrate crop and nutrient management systems that maintain farm profitability and reduce pesticide and nutrient loadings to both ground and surface waters in areas with shallow groundwater tables. _Texas. Seco Creek Demonstration Project (Bandera, Medina and Uvalde counties), demonstrate cost-effective vegetative management systems to increase water yield and reduce pesticide and nitrogen leaching in a groundwater recharge area. _Wisconsin. East Rover Watershed Demonstration Project (Brown County), demonstrate crop management systems that reduce the level of nitrogen, phosphorus and pesticides required to produce competitive crops, thus enhancing farmers' net income and reducing the loading of nutrients and pesticides to surface and groundwater.

DOC.HEAD: Taxi Drivers Strike over New Anti-Pollution Measures
DOC.TEXT: The capital's 17,000 taxis were idle Friday after their owners went on strike to protest an anti-pollution measure banning some of their cars from the smog-choked city center. The new measures announced Thursday bans taxis and other vehicles without required smog control devices from downtown during weekdays. It was another in a series of official moves aimed at improving the flow of traffic in Athens and to combat pollution. Previous measures have proved to be ineffective. The taxi owners, staging a 24-hour strike, denounced the arbitrary decisions taken without consulting them and said their income would be seriously affected. Environment and Public Works Minister Costas Liaskas said taxis and other vehicles equipped with anti-pollution devices would be permitted to circulate within the restricted zone. New car buyers would be granted tax discounts as an incentive to buy cars with the latest technology, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Cooperation Rises, As Do Colombian Economic Collapse Fears
With AM-Drug Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. diplomat said Friday that Colombia and the United States had never cooperated more closely in the antidrug war, but a Colombian economist suggested the economy here could collapse if that war succeeds. The statements came days before President Bush is to join presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia in Cartagena, Colombia, to discuss ways of better cooperating in the fight. Bolivia and Peru together produce most of the coca leaf used to make the world's cocaine. Colombia is the processing center before the drug is smuggled abroad, and the United States is the world's largest consumer of cocaine. ``To me the real story leading up to the drug summit is the way people in the United States and Latin American drug-producing countries are beginning to talk about the problem in the same, serious way,'' the U.S. official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told reporters at a briefing at the U.S. Embassy. He said he expected the Feb. 15 summit to produce ``the kind of agreement in which each country that is part of the problem becomes part of the solution.'' Since August, Colombia has intensified a crackdown on traffickers that drew praise from U.S. officials. But the crackdown, focusing on capturing traffickers responsible for a terrorist campaign here, has failed to significantly reduce the supply of cocaine reaching the United States, U.S. officials say. Colombian officials, economists and news commentators complain in turn that Colombia is spilling its blood to protect U.S. interests while the Bush administration fails to compensate it economically for the effort. Bogota economist Salamon Kalmanowitz says in an interview published in El Espectador newspaper, ``Colombia should demand from the United States adequate compensation for the losses, both human and material that the war against drug trafficking has produced.'' Kalmanowitz, a professor at the Bogota's National University, said drug traffickers invested $6.5 billion in Colombia over the last 10 years and predicted an economic collapse if the drug fight continues without what he calls adequate compensation. He said Colombian drug traffickers also invested $35 billion in other countries, including the United States, the past decade. ``If we add up the value of all of Colombia's equity inside the country and abroad, we see that 35 percent of the national wealth accumulated over 100 years of modern history is in the hands of a bourgeois class of gansters,'' Kalmanowitz said. Kalmanowitz has spent years analyzing the possible economic impact here of an end to the drug trade, but did not spell out in the interview how he arrived at his figures. U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration officials here have questioned how Kalmanowitz and other economists obtain their information on the the shadowy drug trade, but have rarely disputed the results of the studies. The Bogota economic magazine Coyuntura Economica calculated last December that drug traffickers' foreign exchange profits accounted for 3.8 percent of Colombia's annual gross national product, estimated at $40 billion. It said the drug trade accounted for 3 percent of national employment. The United States gave Colombia $20 million in economic aid and $80 million in military assistance in 1989, the U.S. official said. He said military aid will rise to $95 million in 1990, and that the amount of economic aid will be announced at the summit. Colombian officials have indicated that the amount of aid planned for Colombia this year by the Bush Administration falls short. Ambassador Victor Mosquera Chaux told a congressional committee in Washington last month that Colombia will need $1 billion a year in economic and military assistance. Foreign Minister Julio Londono said in a recent interview in El Espectador that more economic cooperation was needed between the two countries if the drug war was to succeed.. Colombia asked the United States to help it renegotiate an international coffee pact broken last year, resulting in a steep drop in coffee prices. Coffee is Colombia's top official export. The price drop has already cost Colombia $187 million and Barco says it stands to lose up to $400 million a year.

DOC.HEAD: Armed Man Killed by Guards While Trying to Enter Mubarak Residence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with Mubarak remarks. Picks up 5th, `The statement...'
DOC.TEXT: A student described by his mother as ``very disturbed'' crashed a car into the gate of President Hosni Mubarak's residence Friday and was killed in a gunfight with guards, the government said. Mubarak was visiting the southern city of Aswan. A government statement carried by the official Middle East News Agency said Adham Shoheib Mohamed Hafez, 17, smashed the Fiat he was driving into the iron gate, got out and shot at the guards, wounding two before they fired back and killed him. The state news agency quoted Mubarak in Aswan as expressing ``pain, sorrow and astonishment'' on learning of the shooting. The president said he was ``affected'' by the incident because it was committed by a youth who belongs to a ``good family,'' according to the agency, which said the boy was carrying a Smith and Wesson pistol registered in his father's name. The statement quoted Hafez's mother as saying her son was ``very disturbed'' over family problems when left home in the Heliopolis district, the district that also includes the presidential residence. She said her son threatened to ``commit a terrible act'' unless the family met his demands, the statement said without elaboration. A reporter who visited the scene said the situation was normal, except for a small crowd of spectators.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Set-Asides Should be Scrutinized: Justice Department
DOC.TEXT: Federal set-asides for minority businesses should be given the same ``strict scrutiny'' that the Supreme Court applies to state and local programs, the Justice Department said Friday. ``Any such racial classificiation must be narrowly tailored to achieve the compelling governmental interest identified by Congress,'' the Justice Department said in a filing with the Supreme Court. The Justice Department made its statement in a friend-of-the-court brief filed in a case challenging the Federal Communications Commission's policy of giving preference to minority businesses seeking broadcast licenses. The high court is considering a challenge to the FCC policy of giving extra weight to applications for broadcast licenses by businesses owned by blacks, women, Hispanics or other minorities. The Justice Department said the same standard under which the high court last year threw out a minority set-aside program for construction contracts in Richmond, Va., should be applied to the FCC case. ``In our view, racial classifications adopted by the federal government must also withstand the `strict scrutiny' applied to those adopted by state and local governments,'' the Justice Department said. ``Thus, federal minority preference programs, no less than state and local programs, must serve a compelling government interest and by narrowly tailored to achieve that interest,'' the department said. The Justice Department said the high court owed ``greater deference'' to a finding by Congress that ``there is compelling need for remedial action'' than a similar conclusion by a state or local government. Nevertheless, ``there remain important limitations on Congress' power to adopt racial preferences.'' ``But this additional measure of deference is appropriate only if Congress itself makes the critical determination that such a program is required, and only if this determination has an adequate basis in fact,'' the department said. ``And any such racial classification must be narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling governmental interest identified by Congress.'' When the Supreme Court upheld a federal minority-set aside program for construction contracts in 1980, it found that ``Congress had abundance evidence'' that discriminatory practices had hurt minority contractors, the department said. The Justice Department said the high court should not give any deference to the FCC's policy of giving preference to minority license because the program was not specifically mandated by Congress. ``Here, there can be no claim that Congress had before it evidence suggesting that minorities have been denied any opportunity to acquire broadcasting facilities because of official or private acts of discrimination.'' The Justice Department said it found no legal support ``for the proposition that a federal administrative agency, acting under a general grand of authority to regulate a particular industry in the public interest, should be entitled to any special deference if it makes a finding of prior discrimination within that industry ... that might support the use of racial classifications.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets See `Star Wars,' Energy Projects
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military leaders on Friday toured Las Alamos National Laboratory, where they viewed Strategic Defense Initiative research and a project intended to develop nuclear fusion technology. Ten members of the Supreme Soviet Committee on Defense and State Security received briefings and tours of two Los Alamos projects during the half-day visit. The event was a counterpart to a U.S. tour of Soviet military installations last fall. Accompanied by Soviet scientists, officials and interpreters, committee members saw parts of an experiment to develop a device that would fire a so-called particle beam in space. They also saw the Aurora laser project, part of an effort to develop nuclear fusion, a technology cleaner that the current fission process used in nuclear-powered electric plants. Reporters were excluded from the tour and officials gave only a sketchy account. In response to a reporter's shouted question ``What do you want to see here?'' and relayed through a translator, a member of the Soviet delegation responded, ``You,'' and gestured with a smile at the laboratory. The group was led by committee Chairman Vladimir Lapygin, who was greeted at the lab's main headquarters by James Jackson, deputy director of Los Alamos. Rep. Steve Schiff, R-N.M., and four members of the House Armed Services Committee accompanied the Soviets. Schiff said that during the delegation's 60-mile helicopter ride from Kirtland Air Force Base in Albuquerque he discussed the Soviet government with some of the visitors. He said the Soviets were interested in seeing any research they could at the government-funded Los Alamos lab, one of the stops on a nationwide tour of research facilities. The tour was part of a U.S.-Soviet arms monitoring accord and follows a tour of the Soviet Union by the Armed Services Committee in August. The delegation was headed to San Diego after the Los Alamos visit. The $60 million particle beam program, part of the SDI or ``Star Wars'' effort to develop a space defense against nuclear missiles, was tested successfully over White Sands Missile Range in July. The Aurora, a krypton fluoride laser, was used in experiments in September that demonstrated the utility of such lasers for fusion research.

DOC.HEAD: Family Allowed to Visit Jailed Journalist for First Time
DOC.TEXT: A prominent Chinese journalist who was arrested eight months ago for supporting pro-democracy students recently was allowed a visit from her family, her daughter said Friday. Dai Qing's husband and daughter visited her for the first time at Qincheng prison on the outskirts of Beijing late last month, just before the Lunar New Year, the most important holiday in China. Wang Xiaojia, the daughter, denied a news report in Hong Kong that her mother had been released from prison and put under house arrest. Authorities told the family the investigation of Dai's case was completed recently but she would continue to be held under ``guardianship,'' Wang said, and the family had no idea when she might be freed. Dai worked for the Guangming Daily, a newspaper for intellectuals. She was one of China's most prominent journalists, well-known for critical, frank reports on political, environmental and feminist issues. She joined other journalists last spring in calling for guarantees of greater press freedom. On May 14, fearing a crackdown, she pleaded with student demonstrators to leave Tiananmen Square. Immediately after soldiers drove the protesters from the square June 3-4, killing hundreds and perhaps thousands of unarmed civilians, Dai publicly resigned from the Communist Party. Security forces took the journalist from her home July 13. Wang said her mother seemed well and appeared to be holding up emotionally. She said Dai did not appear to have been beaten and was not handcuffed or restrained during the hour in a visitors' room. Wang, 21, said it was the first time she and her father were allowed to visit Dai. ``We brought her some food _ chocolates and packaged meat,'' she said. ``Mostly, we just talked about family matters.'' Wen Wei Po, a newspaper in Hong Kong that supports Beijing, said last week Chinese authorities recently had allowed many imprisoned pro-democracy activists to have visits from their relatives. The visits coincided with the Lunar New Year and were granted to ``intellectuals and academics,'' the paper reported. It said Wang Dan, one of the democracy movement's top student leaders, and Liu Xiaobo, a teacher who was a hunger striker, were among those visited. The decision was made in tandem with the lifting of martial law in Beijing in mid-January. It said both moves were to indicate that China's political situation is ``daily becoming more stable.''

DOC.HEAD: Rain Showers in Nation's Midsection, Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: A band of rain showers extended from Texas to Vermont on Friday, and rain also fell along the northern Pacific Coast. A cold snap in Alaska streched into its 15th day with no relief expected until at least Monday. The overnight low was minus 58 degrees at Fort Yukon. Rain showers and thunderstorms reached from west-central Texas across northern Texas, southeast Oklahoma, northern Arkansas and southwest Missouri. Thunderstorms in Texas brought hail to Waxahachee, Granview, Ferris and Peoria. Rain showers stretched from northeast Louisiana to eastern Mississippi, across northern Alabama, northern Georgia, northwestern South Carolina, Tennessee, Kentucky, West Virginia, northern Virginia, Ohio, western Pennsylvania, parts of New York state, and Vermont. Rain reached over the northern Pacific Coast, changing to snow in the higher elevations and extending into the northern half of the Rockies. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at 1 p.m. EST included 1.22 inches at Quillayute, Wash., about three quarters of an inch at Louisville, Ky., Tuscaloosa, Ala., Meridian, Miss., and Astoria, Ore. There were no reports of measurable snowfall during the same 6 hours. High temperature records were set for the date in Baltimore, 65; Beckley, W. Va., 64; Boston, 60; Bridgeport, Conn., 54; Cape Hatteras, N.C., 72; Mansfield, Ohio, 54; New York, 63; Philadelphia, 64; Portland, Maine, 55 and Richmond, Va., 72. The nation's low in the Lower 48 states was 12 below zero at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 13 degrees at Warroad, Minn., to 84 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: American Man Found Shot to Death in Cuzco, Peruvian Tourist Center
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3 grafs SUB for grafs 4-5, U.S. Embassy ... to UPDATE with State Department identifies victim. Picks up 6th, `Tourism is .. .
DOC.TEXT: An American man was found shot to death amid ancient stone ruins in the Andean city of Cuzco, Peru's tourism center and once the capital of the Incas, police said Friday. Cuzco police spokesman Maj. Rafael Zavala said the body was found shot in the head on Thursday at Sacsayhuaman, a group of huge Incan stone ruins on a hill that overlooks the city. Zavala said a U.S. passport carrying the name Charles John Williams, 42, was found with the victim. However, the State Department in Washington identified the dead American as William Carlos Yount, 41, of Southern Pines, N.C., and said no American named Williams had died in Cuzco. U.S. Embassy spokesman Tom Leary said in Lima that police notified the embassy of the death and embassy personnel went to Cuzco to bring back the body. Zavala said he had no information on whether the victim was a tourist or how long he had been in Cuzco, which is 355 miles southwest of Lima. He said police had no suspects, but that the investigation was continuing. Tourism is a major source of revenue in Peru, bringing more than $400 million a year into the country, according to the government. However, the number of tourists coming to Peru has dropped for several years due to guerrilla violence that is affecting much of the Andean highlands and some urban areas. Cuzco has been relatively unaffected by the political violence, and thousands of tourists still pour through the city each year. Police said earlier Friday that Maoist guerrillas of the Shining Path shot nine people to death in scattered violence throughout Peru. The victims included two policemen, a teacher, a government worker, and three men the rebels accused of stealing cattle. Two women also were killed in their home. The policemen were gunned down in an outlying district of Lima by a group of rebels in a passing truck Thursday night, police said. The attackers stopped and took the victims' revolvers before fleeing, the police said. The bodies of three men who had been shot were found Friday in the highland village of San Pedro de Sano, 140 miles east of Lima. A handwritten sign found on one of the victims read, ``This is how cattle rustlers die,'' police said. The village of 3,000 is currently without a local government. The mayor, judge and police chief have resigned due to rebel threats. Rebels killed a high school teacher Thursday by shooting him in the head in his home in Ayacucho, 235 miles southeast of Lima, police said. Also Thursday, the bodies of a 45-year-old woman and her 22-year-old daughter were found in their home in Ayacucho. Police said the two women had been shot to death. Other rebels Thursday stopped two men in a truck as they were driving to a government irrigation project in Huanta, 200 miles southeast of Lim, according to police. The passenger, an employee at the project, was ordered by the rebels to lie on the ground. He was then shot in the head, police said. The driver told police the rebels did not kill him because he told them he was not associated with the government project. The Mao-inspired Shining Path launched its armed insurgency against Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Former Danbury, Conn., Mayor Acquitted of 6 of 7 Counts in Corruption Trial
DOC.TEXT: A former Danbury mayor accused of extorting more than $100,000 from developers while in office was found innocent Friday of all charges in his federal corruption trial except a single count of tax fraud. James E. Dyer broke into a slight smile as U.S. District Judge Jose Cabranes repeated the words ``not guilty'' six times before reading the jury's guilty verdict on the final of seven counts. Dyer had been charged with one count of racketeering, two counts of extortion and four counts of filing false federal tax returns. He was the first elected official in Connecticut ever charged under the federal Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations Act. ``All I can say for now is I'm relieved,'' Dyer said after the verdicts were returned. He called the verdicts an ``absolutely, unmitigated victory.'' Dyer thanked jurors as they filed out of the courtroom, then hugged his wife, Alice, who wept as the verdicts were read. The jury deliberated 2{ days before reaching a verdict. ``This is a case that was worth bringing,'' U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy said. ``It was a tough fight, it was a fair fight and it's over.'' Dyer, who is to be sentenced April 10, faces up to three years in prison and a $250,000 fine for his conviction on a single count of filing a false income tax return. He failed to list on his 1986 tax return a capital gain of $10,000 from the sale of his condominium. After learning he was under investigation, he filed an amended return and paid the $3,500 in taxes due. Dyer had faced 72 years in prison and $1.6 million in fines if he had been convicted on all counts. His attorney, Hugh Keefe, said they hadn't decided whether to appeal the single count, or discuss what sentence the government will seek for Dyer. ``They just nicked Jimmy and they can't very well punish him for something the jury didn't convict him of,'' Keefe said. The jury rejected the far more serious allegations that Dyer, Danbury's Democratic mayor from 1979 through 1987, took nearly $115,000 from developers to assure his support for their projects in the city, and ran the mayor's office as a racketeering enterprise during his last five years in office. Dyer called witnesses who testified that they paid him off ``a load of liars.'' ``The idea that I sat in my office and asked these guys for money is ridiculous,'' Dyer said as waited for the verdict to come in Friday morning. Twardy said Dyer would be barred from running for public office again as a convicted felon. Dyer said his only immediate plans are to spend time with his family and return to work as the marketing director at Applied Data Inc. in North Haven.

DOC.HEAD: Anderson's Sister to Meet Arafat, Hopes to See Gorbachev, Iranians
DOC.TEXT: Peggy Say, whose brother Terry Anderson is the Western hostage held longest in Lebanon, said Friday she will meet with PLO chairman Yasser Arafat in an effort to win his release. She said she also hopes to see President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Iranian leaders. Anderson and most of the 17 other Western captives in Lebanon are believed held by Shiite Moslem extremists loyal to Iran. During a three-week tour of Europe and the Middle East, Mrs. Say will confer with Pope John Paul II, Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie and leaders of the Red Cross, human rights organizations and other groups. On the eve of her fourth trip to the Middle East, she told a news conference: ``I've come back empty-handed before and I fear I may do so again.'' Mrs. Say spoke to reporters after meeting with Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. She said she was convinced the United Nations and President Bush were working for the release of her brother, who is chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press and was kidnapped March 16, 1985. The Bush administration appears to care more about the hostages than the Reagan administration, which she had criticized for inaction, Mrs. Say told the news conference. She added that U.S. ``policy is dictated by the American people and, frankly, the American people don't care about the hostages.'' She and her husband, David, leave Saturday with an AP delegation in hopes of gaining news of her brother, who is one of eight Americans among the hostages. Mrs. Say, of Cadiz, Ky., also will visit the U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's director, Federico Mayor, in Paris and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa of Syria in Damascas. She will meet Arafat in Tunis, Tunisia, where the PLO has its headquarters. She said she hoped to see Gorbachev and that better U.S.-Soviet relations and the improved international climate are positive factors for the hostages. ``This is a time of freedom around the world,'' she said. ``The hostages have suffered enough.'' Iranian officials have not responded to efforts to arrange a meeting. Sheik Mohammad Hussein Fadlallah, the spiritual head of Hezbollah, believed to be an umbrella group for Shiite Moslem kidnappers, refused to meet with the group outside Lebanon. Mrs. Say said a visit to Iran would be very important and expressed hope that release of the hostages would be part of an overall improvement in U.S.-Iranian relations. ``It is important for the sake of those hostages who died that some good come out of it,'' she said. Asked whether she would be willing to visit Lebanon, she said she ``never ruled out Lebanon, but I'm not going unless I am assured that it would be part of bringing Terry out of there.'' She said she would go if she were invited by those who hold her brother and if they promised her security. ``I have a husband and children and grandchildren'' she said. ``It's got to be worth the risk. I am not foolish.'' Besides Anderson, there are seven Americans among the 17 hostages.

DOC.HEAD: Palau President Says Compact Failed to Pass
DOC.TEXT:
Voters in this remote western Pacific archipelago failed to approve a political arrangement that would give it more self-government, its president officially told the U.S. government Friday. A majority of voters supported the proposal but the island chain's constitution requires a 75 percent majority. President Ngiratkel Etpison, in a letter written Friday to Assistant U.S. Interior Secretary Stella G. Guerra, said he has asked Palau's Congress for legislation to amend the constitution to allow a Compact of Free Association to be approved by simple majority of the voters. The 30-member Congress is expected to go into special session late this month. The proposed compact, already U.S. law, provides for self-government, more control over internal and foreign affairs, and nearly $500 million in economic aid. It also would end Palau's nearly 43 years as a U.N. strategic trusteeship under U.S. authority. Ten other territories formed in 1947 under the trustreeship system have achieved independence or self-government.
The United States captured the islands in 1944 from Japan. With about 85 percent of the votes counted from a plebiscite Tuesday, about 60 percent of Palau's voters supported the proposed compact and its subsidiary agreements. The vote was 3,906 for the agreements, 2,573 against. Counting of the remaining 1,164 ballots was to resume Saturday morning. It was the seventh attempt in seven years to obtain the 75 percent margin. Opponents of the pact complained their land could be used by the United States for military purposes or they wouldn't receive adequate compensation for their land. Some opposition was based on anti-nuclear sentiment, although the United States has said it won't store, test or dispose of nuclear or other unconventional weapons in the islands. The compact would allow nuclear-capable ships and aircraft to use Palau waters and airspace. The cluster of 200 islands 600 miles east of the Philippines and 4,500 miles southwest of Hawaii has an estimated 15,000 people residing on eight of the volcanic islands. An estimated 5,000 to 7,000 Palauans live overseas.
