DOC.HEAD: Selma Protest Continues; Report Finds No Police Brutality
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with city's report on Monday's melee and allegations of police brutality, protesters vowing to continue occupation, quotes, further details. Picks up 4th graf pvs: `Blacks staged ...'
DOC.TEXT: Protesters targeting the majority white school board and alleged police brutality promised to continue their occupation of Selma High School and City Hall for a second night Friday. Also Friday, city officials said an investigation of the alleged brutality had cleared an officer accused of using excessive force when he arrested a black protest leader. Mayor Joe Smitherman released a preliminary report into the claim that Officer Ronnie Rushing abused protest leader Rose Sanders when she was arrested Monday and carried from the mayor's office. City Attorney Henry Pitts, who announced the findings of the city's investigation, said: ``There is no evidence to support any allegation of physical or sexual abuse.'' Mrs. Sanders, who charged into the mayor's private office as a melee erupted in an outer room, claimed the policeman touched her ``private parts'' with his nightstick and dragged her to police headquarters with her jogging pants around her knees. According to the city's report, Rushing twice asked Mrs. Sanders to leave the police car when they arrived at jail, but she refused. The officer then put his baton between her handcuffs and pulled her from the car. During the walk to the jail Mrs. Sanders went limp, and Rushing and another officer had to drag her to an elevator, the report said. ``From the time she was first arrested, she was uncooperative and refused to obey his orders,'' the report said. Although the city's probe cleared the officer of wrongdoing, Rushing was placed on administrative duty Friday until the FBI, Justice Department and Alabama Bureau of Investigation complete their investigations. Blacks staged all-night sleep-ins at City Hall and Selma High School awaiting the report. At the high school, where about 150 students, former students and adults spent Thursday night in the cafeteria, doors were locked Friday morning, but police did not try to enter. Students said they discussed black history and watched films, including ``The Color Purple.'' Later Friday, six parents and about two dozen students briefly occupied city school board offices in a building one block from City Hall. They left without incident after chanting ``No contract, no school'' _ a reference to protesters' calls for the white majority school board to extend the contract of Superintendent Norward Roussell beyond June, when it expires. Roussell is the first black school superintendent in Selma. The board voted in December against extending his contract, setting off weeks of protests and periodic school boycotts. His supporters contend the majority white board refused to extend his contract because he is black and because he lessened the impact of a ``tracking system'' that allegedly tended to separate blacks from whites on the basis of classroom levels of achievement. White board members, who removed Roussell from office last week but reinstated him Tuesday as racial tensions forced the closing of two schools, have cited a critical evaluation of Roussell's managerial skills in his $80,000-a-year post. All 11 public schools in the 70 percent black, 6,000-student system have been closed since Wednesday because of what school officials call the threat of violence. The schools are scheduled to reopen Monday. Besides protesting Roussell's treatment, black protest leaders have called for a change in the way the school board is formed. The board, with six whites and five blacks, is appointed by the City Council, which has five whites and four blacks. The protest broadened to include the treatment of Mrs. Sanders after she and four others were arrested on misdemeanor charges Monday. But she said the protest's focus should not be on her but on what she called a racially unfair educational system. Her husband, state Sen. Hank Sanders said the main issue is not that schoolchildren are missing three days in class. At stake, he said, ``is the quality of education for the future.'' Ozell Sutton, regional director for the Justice Department's community relations service division, said he arrived for meetings with both sides. ``Everybody is receptive,'' he said. ``The problem is everybody wants the situation resolved in their favor.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Opens Door for Hazelwood to Blame Coast Guard Negligence in Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, `On Thursday...the accident,' to UPDATE with state Supreme Court rejecting Hazelwood claim of immunity. Pick up 8th graf pvs: `Most of...
DOC.TEXT: A judge cleared the way Friday for Joseph Hazelwood's lawyers to blame U.S. Coast Guard negligence rather than the skipper for the nation's larget oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone said he had decided to allow cross-examination of two Coast Guard traffic monitors on the role the agency's Vessel Traffic System played in the March 24 grounding of the 987-foot tanker Exxon Valdez. After brief legal arguments, he allowed for the monitors to be questioned about how closely they were watching radar and whether they had a duty to notify Hazelwood that his ship was approaching rocky Bligh Reef. However, Johnstone refused for now to admit in evidence a blood alcohol test given to one of the monitors 13-15 hours after the disaster at sea. The test showed that Bruce Blandford had a blood alcohol reading of .203, more than twice the legal limit for driving in Alaska. Blandford has said he had four drinks of bourbon and water when he returned home after the accident. Johnstone said he would reconsider his ruling if Hazelwood's lawyer, Dick Madson, can prove relevance. Madson said he planned to call experts to say that a few drinks after work could not have produced such a high blood alcohol reading in Blandford. He maintains the monitor was drinking while on duty. On Thursday, Johnstone refused to admit the results of a urine test showing that the second monitor, Gregory Taylor, tested positive for marijuana three days after the accident. Also Friday the Alaska Supreme Court rejected Hazelwood's request for a hearing on whether he was immune from prosecution. The former skipper had claimed he was the first to report the spill and that state and federal law grants immunity from prosecution to those who make such reports. Most of the testimony in the trial's first week has focused on liquor. The prosecution maintains that Hazelwood spent the hours before his ship set sail drinking vodka with his shipmates and was drunk when the Exxon Valdez ran aground just after midnight. The tanker spilled almost 11 million gallons of North Slope crude, blackening hundreds of miles of shoreline, killing thousands of animals and hundreds of thousands of birds. Exxon says it has spent some $2 billion trying to clean up the mess. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is being tried on a felony charge of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison, and $61,000 in fines. Testimony was to resume Monday with Taylor and Blandford scheduled as witnesses.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Spill Sends Oil Globules Ashore on Miles of Beach
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 13-17, `Cleanup costs...', with seven grafs to UPDATE with coast guard estimating cleanup cost in `millions', oil skimmed and state figures on birds. Picks up 18th graf, `Except for...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA7, LA8 and LaserColor LA9
DOC.TEXT: Workers blotted up gooey blobs from along miles of beaches and boats skimmed oil offshore Friday as the slick from a punctured tanker drifted off the scenic coast. The spill of up to 300,000 gallons of Alaskan crude oil from the tanker American Trader sent globules and a sheen ashore Thursday night at spots along several miles of beaches south of Los Angeles. Newport Beach, five miles down the coast from Huntington, got a brown tide of quarter-size globs and that city declared a state of emergency. The 811-foot tanker carried 21 million gallons when its single-wall hull was punctured, apparently by an anchor, as it approached an oil pipeline mooring about 1{ miles offshore Wednesday night. Several hundred workers hired by the oil shipper and volunteers worked around the clock to soak up the goo at Newport. They had filled some 800 large trash bags with towels, sand and oil by Friday morning. Sixteen-year-old Lisa Virak skipped school Friday and came to the beach with a roll of paper towels and a pair of rubber gloves. ``I came because it's part of our community. You've got to keep the beach clean. The newspaper says it will take two years, but I don't think it'll take that long with everyone's help,'' she said. Newport Beach city officials were pleased by the effort, said city fire Capt. Ray Pendleton. ``The impact has been less than we thought,'' he said. ``Are we out of the woods? No, not yet,'' said Charles Webster, crisis manager for British Petroleum America Inc., which owns the oil and chartered the tanker. ``But we're working to stay ahead of the curve.'' Booms had been placed across the entrances to the Bolsa Chica Wetlands, the Santa Ana River and upper Newport Bay, and there were no reports of oil reaching those wildlife habitats. Coast Guard Rear Adm. William Kime said the soiled shoreline measured 1{ miles at Huntington and three-quarters of a mile at Newport. The slick stretched 5 miles by 7 miles from Bolsa Chica State Beach to Newport Beach. There was concern the slick might drift south to Laguna Beach, a scenic art colony fronted by rocky tide pools. Webster said a cleanup firm was on call there. The cleanup bill ``has already reached the millions of dollars,'' Kime told a news conference in Huntington Beach. He noted that results of federally mandated drug and alcohol tests of the ship's officers were negative. Cleanup costs were to be borne by the ship's owner, American Trading Transportation Co. Inc. of New York, Webster said. British Petroleum said it had 390 cleanup workers along a 20-mile stretch of coast from Bolsa Chica to Laguna Beach. Eight skimmers were at work and five more were due by day's end. Four others were en route. Skimmers had collected 16,800 gallons of oil by 7 a.m. Friday, Kime said. The tanker remained off Huntington Beach as the Coast Guard pumped remaining oil and water out of the forward hold which may have been gashed by its anchor as it was mooring at an offshore pipeline. Ships unload their cargo into the pipeline for transport to an inland oil refinery. ``It looks like the vessel rode up over its anchor and punctured itself,'' Kime said. The 1 million gallons of oil left in the forward compartment was being pumped onto a barge. The ship has stopped leaking, the Coast Guard said. Since the spill began, 49 oil-soaked sea birds have been brought to a wildlife aid station for cleaning, said California Department of Fish and Game biologist John Grant. Twelve died. Except for the change in wind direction that pushed tentacles of the slick ashore, sea and weather conditions were favorable. Federal and local authorities noted their luck but remained cautious. ``To date we've been lucky,'' said John Turner, director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. ``There's a lot of oil that could come ashore.'' The spill is tiny in comparison to that unleashed when the tanker Exxon Valdez struck a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound last year, spewing more than 10 million gallons. The Alaska spill had more than 30 times the amount of oil as the current California spill. Turner said the state Department of Fish and Game director had decided against using chemical dispersants on the slick and he concurred. ``The proximity to the shore was a key in the decision here,'' he said. The potential toxic affects of the chemicals on animals was also considered along with the fact that chemicals and a dispersal plane could not have reached the scene for 36 hours, Turner said. By then the spill was too broken up for chemicals to be effective, he said. Fish and Wildlife experts also went out in a boat to try to determine the extent of harm to the environment. Huntington Beach is a city of 180,000 about 35 miles southeast of Los Angeles. Newport Beach, about five miles down the coast, has about 70,000 residents.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Agrees to Videotaped Testimony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 8th graf, bgng: Greene said xxx to UPDATE with filing from Bush administration raising no objections.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan on Friday agreed to answer questions about his role in the Iran-Contra affair in videotaped testimony for the upcomig trial of John Poindexter. Reagan said he will respond to questions from Poindexter, but said he or the Bush administration could invoke executive privilege to avoid answering specific questions during the deposition. The ex-president proposed in a court filing that he give the videotaped deposition in Los Angeles Feb. 16, four days before the scheduled start of Poindexter's criminal trial. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene scheduled a hearing for Monday to consider the timing and circumstances of the videotaped deposition. On Monday, Poindexter was given approval by a federal judge to ask Reagan 154 questions about the Iran-Contra affair. Greene gave Reagan until Friday to decide whether he would invoke a blanket claim of executive privilege in an attempt to avoid giving the deposition altogether. Reagan ``recognizes that this court has a considerable responsibility to protect and preserve the rights of the defendant in this case as well as to be sensitive to the interests of the former president and the constitutional rights and duties of the presidency,'' Reagan's lawyers said in court papers. They said Reagan recognizes that the ``videotape deposition format will provide an appropriate mechanism ... to protect sensitive, classified national security information and confidential deliberations.'' Greene said Monday that Poindexter would be permitted to ask follow-up questions in addition to the 154 main questions. The subject areas include Reagan's knowledge of Oliver North's activities and whether Reagan authorized written responses to Congress for which Poindexter now faces felony charges. In a separate filing, the Bush administration said it would also waive executive privilege to allow the former president to give the deposition. But Bush administration reserved the right to invoke the privilege to prevent Reagan from answering follow-up questions during the deposition that might involve the ``foreign policy deliberations within the president's office.'' Specificially, the Bush administration expressed concern about ``questions that seek to delve into the nature of various communications between former President Reagan and foreign heads of state, which are, to our knowledge, still undisclosed and sensitive.'' But in the filing, the Justice Department said it did not find ``serious problems'' with the 154 questions for Reagan that have been approved by the judge. Giving testimony by videotape away from public view will provide an opportunity to stop the questioning if it impinges on sensitive national security or diplomatic matters. Greene will attend the deposition and rule on disputes. ``The former president will defer to the incumbent president with respect to issues of executive privilege that may arise during the ... deposition,'' said Reagan's lawyers. Reagan could still invoke executive privilege with regard to specific questions if his lawyers deemed it appropriate, possibly terminating the deposition and triggering a protracted legal battle in the courts. Assuming the deposition is completed, the edited videotape would be shown at Poindexter's trial. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements, charges that carry a maximum of 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines upon conviction. Poindexter asserts that Reagan approved of activities that led to criminal charges against his former national security adviser. On Monday, Reagan invoked executive privilege in an attempt to avoid turning over to Poindexter approximately 33 presidential diary entries. That claim is being reviewed by Greene, who is presiding in Poindexter's case. Greene wanted the question of Reagan's testimony resolved before the trial, saying it would be difficult, if not impossible, for Poindexter to formulate a coherent strategy without knowing in advance whether the former president will answer questions. The ex-president would be asked about his knowledge of the relationship between North and specific individuals in both the Iran arms sales and secret assistance to the Contras. Reagan told the Tower Board on Jan. 26, 1987, that he did not know the staff of the National Security Council, where North worked, was helping the Contras. The board said it was aware of no evidence to suggest that the president was aware of North's activities. Reagan also would be asked whether he approved responses to Congress inquiring into whether North was assisting the Contras. In the responses, Poindexter endorsed letters sent to Congress a year earlier by national security adviser Robert McFarlane, Poindexter's predecessor, denying that North was raising money or providing military advice to the Contras. McFarlane in 1988 pleaded guilty to withholding information from Congress in connection with the letters. One question Reagan would be asked: ``Did you advise Admiral Poindexter to inform the congressional committees that the information sought ... had already been provided to them and that this information made it clear that the actions of the NSC staff were in compliance with the law?'' Reagan also would be asked about discussions with Poindexter regarding a chronology on the Iran arms sales that is involved in four of the five criminal charges against Poindexter. The chronology, prepared by others at Poindexter's direction, falsely states that no one in the U.S. government knew until January 1986 that a CIA-assisted November 1985 shipment from Iran to Israel contained Hawk missiles. President Ford gave a videotaped deposition in the criminal trial of Lynette Fromme in the assassination attempt on Ford. President Carter provided a videotaped deposition in the criminal trial of a state senator and a sheriff on gambling conspiracy charges. Carter, while in office, also gave videotaped testimony for a grand jury investigation of an alleged White House attempt to quash extradition proceedings against an international fugitive.

DOC.HEAD: Eisenhower Granddaughter Marries Top Soviet Scientist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD romance began while collaborating on a book, plan to maintain homes in Moscow, Washington, details. Sagdeev is cq
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB8,9
DOC.TEXT: A granddaughter of the late President Dwight D. Eisenhower married one of the Soviet Union's top space scientists on Friday in a ceremony at the U.S. ambassador's residence in Moscow. Susan Eisenhower, 38, wed Roald Sagdeev, 57, former head of the Space Research Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences. Sagdeev also is a member of the Congress of People's Deputies, the Soviet parliament. Tass, the Soviet news agency, described the wedding of two celebrities in Moscow as ``a sensation.'' The wedding was closed to news media, but people at the ceremony said it was attended by Elena Bonner, widow of Soviet human rights champion Andrei D. Sakharov, and by many Soviet parliamentarians. After the ceremony, the bride, in a white suit with gold trim, and the groom, in a double-breasted blue suit, cut into a three-tier wedding cake. Sagdeev, a physicist, was a close associate of Sakharov and is considered a political reformer. He is well-known in the Soviet Union. Before reforms took hold in the country, his institute was considered top secret. The couple met at the annual Soviet-American Chautauqua conference in the United States in 1987, and later encountered each other at international conferences. The romance intensified while they collaborated on a book about ``survival, how a very thin layer of intellectuals survived through difficult years, through purges'' before Gorbachev came to power in March 1985, Sagdeev said last month. Tass quoted the couple as saying they did not expect quick approval from authorities for their wedding plans, but that approval was soon coming, ``a fresh indication that times are changing for the better.'' The bride is the daughter of John Eisenhower, the president's son. She has her own consulting firm. She was married twice before and has three school-age children. Her brother, David, is married to the former Julie Nixon. Sagdeev said he has two grown children. The couple plan to maintain two homes, living in Washington to be with her children during the fall and spring, and spend summers in Moscow.

DOC.HEAD: Malaysian Government Bans LaToya Jackson Concert
DOC.TEXT: Singer LaToya Jackson's Valentine's Day concert in Kuala Lumpur has been canceled by the Culture and Tourism Ministry. Culture Department Secretary Mukhtar Abdullah told reporters Friday her presence would be ``against the values and norms of the Malaysian culture.'' Ms. Jackson, sister of superstar Michael Jackson, had been scheduled to give free concerts at the Putra World Trade Center Feb. 14 as part of Valentine's Day celebrations sponsored by a tobacco company. Mukhtar said Ms. Jackson, who posed nude for Playboy magazine last year, did not meet some of the conditions imposed by the government on foreign artists performing in Malaysia. He did not say what these conditions were. ``I am very disappointed and was really looking forward to meeting my wonderful fans in Malaysia and warming their hearts on Valentine's Day,'' Ms. Jackson said late Friday. ``I guess this means I will cancel my order for candies for members of the government.'' Ms. Jackson is in London as part of a two-week European tour that will take her to West Germany and Italy. An application for her Malaysian concert made by Genesis Promotions, promoters for the performance, was only received by the ministry on Jan 30, Mukhtar said. He expressed surprise that Genesis went ahead with promotion of the concert through newspapers and television without first getting permission from the ministry. Mukhtar denied the cancellation had anything to do with pressure from opponents of the concert. In recent months, extremist Moslem student groups have demonstrated outside Western musical shows here.

DOC.HEAD: Mulroney Comment Sends Canadian Dollar Plunging
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian dollar went into a tailspin Friday after Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said interest rates will likely fall when a federal budget aimed at reducing the deficit is released this month. The drop forced the Bank of Canada to jump into the market, where it bought unwanted dollars and forced rates higher to defend the currency. ``After the next budget (on Feb. 20), you will begin to see the downward trend of interest rates ... by year's end,'' Mulroney said in an interview with The Canadian Press. The currency began falling minutes after Mulroney's remark was reported. It closed at 83.21 U.S. cents, a drop of more than half a penny from Thursday's close and nearly three-quarters of a cent down from its Friday high. Mulroney later stood by his comment. ``I believe the policies taken by (Finance Minister Michael) Wilson will have the general effect of lowering interest rates. I believe those policies will increase Canada's competitiveness and enhance our economy.'' Like the U.S. government, Canada is wrestling with a large budget deficit, which can drive up interest rates when money is borrowed to finance it. In the year ending March 31, Canada ran a deficit of $30.5 billion Canadian on a budget of $143 billion Canadian in a country of 25 million people. The Canadian dollar has been under siege since last month when the Bank of Canada reversed its long-standing policy and eased interest rates. The move triggered a run on the dollar and the market has been jittery ever since. On Thursday, the Bank of Canada boosted its bellwether bank rate to 12.79 percent _ the highest level in 5{ years _ in a bid to stop the continued sell-off of Canadian dollars. It marked the third week of rate increases, which influence the level of broader consumer and business loan rates.

DOC.HEAD: Boston Attorney Says He Has New Evidence In MacDonald Murder Case
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer said Friday he has new evidence to file for a retrial in the case of Jeffrey MacDonald, a former Army doctor found guilty in 1979 of murdering his pregnant wife and two children. ``This time we've got it nailed cold,'' said Harvey Silverglate, who was acquainted with MacDonald while both were students at Princeton University some years ago. Silverglate, who hasn't previously represented MacDonald, refused to disclose the nature of the evidence but said it was startling. ``Some of it is newly discovered, some of it is known to the prosecution and was suppressed at the time of the trial,'' Silverglate said. ``We have the heart of the evidence but we are still pursuing a few strings and ... are in the process of pulling it all together.'' The attorney said he planned to file a retrial motion in the spring, at which time the new evidence would be made public. A book about the case, ``Fatal Vision,'' was written by Joe McGinnis and later made into a television movie. MacDonald, a former physician and Green Beret, was convicted of fatally stabbing and bludgeoning his 26-year-old wife and daughters while he was stationed at Fort Bragg, N.C. in 1970. He has contended his family was victimized by a band of drug-crazed hippies. His conviction was reversed in 1980 by a Richmond, Va.-based appeals court on grounds he was denied a speedy trial. But the U.S. Supreme Court subsequently overturned that ruling. In 1985, a federal court denied MacDonald's request for a retrial, but Silverglate said this time ``it was a different story.''

DOC.HEAD: English-Only Sign Triggers Discrimination Complaints
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to correct spelling of sign to Ingles sted Inglish. Pick up 2nd graf, `But even...
DOC.TEXT: The sign said ``No Ingles, No Travato'' _ a mangled attempt at the Spanish for ``No English, No Work.'' But even if it had been spelled right _ ``No Ingles, No Trabajo'' _ the placard posted outside a construction site near Greeley probably would have been illegal, state and federal officials say. Jorge Amaya, state director of the League of United Latin American Citizens, said he confronted the construction foreman at the Sand Livestock Systems construction trailer Thursday after he spotted the sign. ``That sign was telling a whole group of people to get lost, and that's discrimination,'' he said. ``It's exactly the kind of thing we feared when the official English amendment passed (in a 1988 referendum). I'll tell you, if we put up a sign saying `no more white people' we'd get nailed in seconds.'' The posting marks the latest shot fired in the battle over ``Official English'' statutes, which have been enacted in dozens of states in the past few years. They are intended to discourage bilingual education and other concessions to non-English-speaking immigrants. On Tuesday, a federal judge in Phoenix tossed out Arizona's Official English law, saying it violated the right to free speech. That law required state and county governments in Arizona to conduct most of their business in English only. Colorado's constitutional amendment is less specific _ it simply declares English to be the official state language, without describing what that means. To officials at a hog farm under construction for National Farms in Kersey, about 10 miles east of Greeley in north-central Colorado, the amendment meant that Spanish-speakers could be discouraged from applying for work. ``We had some pretty poor communications around here,'' said project superintendant Al Benson. ``We were getting so many people who couldn't speak English. For example, I have a cement finisher I can't even talk to.'' The sign was posted last summer, Benson said. He insisted that it was legal. ``We checked,'' he said. ``Because of the English-only bill we know it's legal.'' But state and federal officials disagreed. Ed Gibbs, regional officer for the Colorado Civil Rights Commission in Greeley, said the sign was ``definitely illegal.'' No one had filed a complaint with his office, but Gibbs said he would investigate the incident and the company could be ordered to pay damages to anyone who could prove they were discriminated against because of the sign. Joe Esquibel of the U.S. Labor Department said the sign is ``probably illegal'' because the construction business isn't one that requires English to be spoken. Another Labor Department official, Loren Gilbert, said that unless English is an occupational qualification _ as, for example, for a disc jockey _ it is illegal to refuse to hire people because they don't speak the language. ``You can't tell me that English is a requirement for digging post holes,'' he said. Amaya of the League of United Latin American Citizens said he intends to file complaints with the Labor Department and the state civil rights commission. The local manager for National Farms, Bill O'Hare, said he had been unaware of the subcontractor's sign. He said National Farms allows ``all people to apply for jobs and we do not discriminate in any manner.''

Gov. Mario Cuomo announced Friday that New York plans to sue the federal government over its requirement that states develop dumps for low-level radioactive waste. Cuomo had promised several weeks ago to file the suit after meeting at the state Capitol with opponents of the proposed dump. Cuomo said the federal law's requirement ``that we take ownership of waste that is produced by others is an unprecedented intrusion that irreparably damages the essential level of state sovereignty that makes our federal system work.'' The governor said state Attorney General Robert Abrams would file the suit next week. Cuomo also said Michigan Gov. James Blanchard was planning to file a similar lawsuit.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Announces Brilliant Pebbles Test
DOC.TEXT: The first flight test of the so-called ``Brilliant Pebbles'' system under the Strategic Defense Initiative is scheduled for this summer, the Pentagon announced on Friday. The Defense Department has ruled that the test ``complies with the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972,'' which bans anti-missile weapons in orbit, SDI officials announced. President Bush touted the ``Brilliant Pebbles'' concept earlier this week when he visited a major Star Wars research laboratory in California. In his latest budget, Bush has asked for $4.5 billion for the so-called Star Wars space-based anti-missile shield in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1, nearly a $1 billion more in the current fiscal year. Congress cut $1 billion from Bush's $4.8 billion Star Wars request for this year. The ``Brilliant Pebbles'' idea envisions deploying thousands of tiny maneuverable satellites, packed with sensors to detect enemy missiles, in low-earth orbit, where they could ram and destroy the missiles if commanded to do so. At a briefing and in documents handed to reporters, SDI officials said the cost of putting a ``Brilliant Pebbles'' system in space under the Strategic Defense Initiative has been cut by some 20 percent because of technological advances. ``Technological progress and an evolving architecture for the space-based portion of Phase I now permit projected cost figures near $55 billion,'' expressed in dollars of 1988 buying power, the SDI office said. In June 1988, officials estimated the cost of a Phase I missile defense to be $115 billion, but that estimate was reduced to $69 billion in October of 1988. The new, lower estimate appears to be due to the shifting of emphasis to the ``Brilliant Pebbles'' sypstem, and because the advances allow scientists to make smaller, less expensive devices, the documents indicated.

DOC.HEAD: Three Dead, 19 Injured in Twin Blasts at Carbide Plant
DOC.TEXT: Three people were killed and 19 injured when two blasts rocked a carbide factory early Friday about 100 miles southwest of Berlin, police said. The blasts _ eight minutes apart _ occurred at the Schkopau chemical plant 7 miles south of Halle, said a police spokesman in Halle. About 15,000 people are employed at the factory. Cause of the accident, in the heart of East Germany's chemical industry, was not immediately clear. Police spokesman Volker Grasser said three people died in the accident at the VEB Chemische Werke Buna in Schkopau and 19 were injured, some of them seriously. ``There was a horrible blast. Suddenly everything around us was black, and the air literally caught fire,'' the official ADN news agency quoted an unidentified worker as saying. Grasser said the blasts occurred in a closed-off hall where carbide ovens are located.

DOC.HEAD: Richland County Courthouse Sealed Off Amid Reports Sheriff Being Held
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with sheriff being held, details, family members of suspects on the scene. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: Authorities cordoned off the Richland County Courthouse Friday after the sheriff exchanged himself for a hostage held by twin robbery suspects. Sheriff's officer Gregory Kemp said Sheriff Dale Shetler had exchanged himself for Deputy Deb Strine, who had been taken hostage by the 18-year-old brothers. The brothers, who were believed to be armed, had not made any demands, and hostage negotiators were on the scene, Kemp said. He described the situation as ``a stalemate.'' The brothers had been arrested for robberies in north-central and northeastern Ohio. Ms. Strine was released about 6:20 p.m. Shetler 43, has been sheriff since August 1987, and been with the sheriff's department since 1977. Police on Jan. 31 arrested twins Brad and Chad Jordan in connection with a string of armed robberies in Mansfield, Canton and Bellville. Their mother, Sandra Peters, and brother, Kenneth, were on the scene Friday night, the Mansfield News Journal reported. The Jordans were arrested after a clerk at a Bellville convenience store triggered a silent alarm. Authorities arrested one brother in the parking lot of a nearby bank, while the other surrendered from a relative's home. Fire and emergency medical units were on the scene or on standby, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: 26 Killed in Bus-Truck Collision
DOC.TEXT: At least 26 people were killed when a bus and a truck collided Friday in the western Indian state of Rajasthan, a news agency reported. United News of India said the accident occurred near Beawar, 240 miles southwest of New Delhi, but gave no further details.

DOC.HEAD: Norway to Drop Economic Sanctions of Namibia
With AM-Namibia
DOC.TEXT: Norway will drop its trade embargo and other sanctions against Namibia as the nation becomes indepedent of South Africa, the government announced Friday. Parliamentary approval for lifting the trade ban is expected in time for Namibia's first day of freedom, March 31, the Foreign Ministry said in a statement. Sanctions were expanded in March 1987 to put pressure on South Africa's apartheid system of legalized segregation and white minority rule. Namibia was included in the boycott because it was occupied by South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: In Plea Agreement, Young & Rubicam is Fined in Jamaica Tourism Case
DOC.TEXT: The Young & Rubicam Inc. advertising agency pleaded guilty Friday to making improper payments to a Jamaican businessman in its efforts to win the Jamaican government tourism account. In a plea agreement, the government dropped racketeering and bribery charges against the New York-based agency and two of its executives. The company was fined $500,000 for conspiring to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act by paying $130,000 to Arnold Foote Jr., while ``having reason to know'' that Foote might offer bribes to Eric Anthony Abrahams, the former minister of tourism in Jamaica, said U.S. Attorney Stanley A. Twardy. The company had faced fines of up to $7.5 million on the bribery and racketeering charges. U.S. District Judge Peter Dorsey also placed the company on probation for two years and said he would consider ordering the agency to perform community service. Young & Rubicam said Friday that ``some of its employees did on occasions hear reports of alleged bribery efforts,'' but that the company still has no reason to believe that Foote ever bribed Abrahams. Further, the company said, the government now agrees that Young & Rubicam won the Jamaica account fairly. The agency pointed out that the ``reason to know'' section of the Corrupt Practices Act was considered controversial and was removed by Congress in 1988. ``Ironically, if the case were brought today, there would have been no such charge,'' the company said. The government alleged in an indictment last year that Young & Rubicam made the payments of $900,000 to win and retain the lucrative Jamaican tourism account, for which it produced the award-winning ``Come Back to Jamaica'' campaign in the early 1980s. In the indictment, the government characterized Foote as an adviser to Abrahams and thus a public official as defined under the Corrupt Practices Act. Until Friday, the agency denied any wrongdoing, maintaining it hired Foote to help with the account and that he was not a public official. Federal prosecutors, citing ``exculpatory evidence recently turned over to the government,'' dropped charges against two Young & Rubicam executives who faced racketeering charges: Executive Vice President Arthur R. Klein and former account supervisor Thomas Spangenberg. A third Young & Rubicam employee, Steven M. McKenna, faces federal perjury charges. His trial is scheduled to begin Feb. 26. Foote and Abrahams have also been charged, but they remain in Jamaica. Twardy said he has been advised by the Justice Department that he cannot extradite Foote and Abrahams on racketeering charges under current Jamaican law. The settlement came the day after jury selection began in federal court in the trial of the agency.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Said to Possess Information Libya is Making Poison Gas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 6th pvs, `The Libyan' with U.N. delegate's denial. Picks up 7th, `Albrecht Mueller...'
DOC.TEXT: West German opposition politicians said Friday their government has information that Libya's controversial Rabta chemical plant has begun producing poison gas. A government spokesman in Bonn, when asked about the allegations, said: ``We cannot take a position at this time.'' Reinhard Kraemer, a spokesman for the environmentalist Greens party in Bonn, said the Greens have received information that the plant has produced enough poison gas for 1,000 artillery shells. A U.S. official in Washington said Friday that the Libyans have been producing ``very small'' amounts of chemicals, possibly for weapons use, for about a year. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the plant 60 miles south of Tripoli is producing nowhere near its design capacity and that the United States is monitoring the situation, but that nothing has occurred the past year to raise further alarms. The Libyan government of Col. Moammar Gadhafi has denied the Rabta plant was designed to produce poison gas, saying it instead is for the production of pharmaceuticals. Ali Sunni Muntasser, Libya's deputy representative to the United Nations, said Friday night, ``All these stories about manufacturing gases or chemicals or anything is untrue.'' Albrecht Mueller, a federal lawmaker with the main opposition Social Democratic Party, said he was told by a West German government official the Rabta plant is making poison gas. He said the information was released during a meeting Wednesday of the parliamentary Economics Committee. ``I gathered from the meeting the production started last year,'' Mueller told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. He said an Economics Ministry official identified the chemical name as ``Lost,'' which is a military term for dichlordiaethylsulphide, a poison gas that renders opponents unable to fight when it comes into contact with the skin. Mueller said he had heard from other sources that the Rabta plant has produced more than 20 tons of the poison gas since last year. He would not identify the other sources. Kraemer, the Greens spokesman, said: ``We have information that the Libyan chemical plant in Rabta has produced large amounts of `Lost' gas, enough to arm 1,000 shells.'' Kraemer said he could not be more specific on where the party had obtained the information. Other sources in Bonn, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the matter came up at closed-door meetings of the parliamentary Foreign Committee as well as the Economics Committee. The Rabta plant caused a huge scandal for West Germany last year with U.S. allegations that West German firms helped build the plant. West Germany at first denied the U.S. allegations, but ultimately launched its own investigation and accused the Imhausen-Chemie firm of helping build the Libyan plant. The investigation has not yet been concluded. Mueller said he did not recall the name of the Economics Ministry official who released the information. He said members of the committee were ``deeply disturbed'' when they heard the allegations. Mueller said he did not know where the Economics Ministry official got the information, but that he assumed it came from intelligence sources. ``This was a very embarrassing affair from the state, and continues to be one,'' said Mueller.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Visits Atlanta, Says He's Optimistic About World Affairs
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan said Friday he is optimistic about the state of world affairs and praised Soviet Leader Mikhail Gorbachev as the Soviet Union's ``best and only hope.'' ``I am more optimistic than ever in my life about world peace and democracy,'' the former president told 1,000 Days Inns hotel franchisers at a convention. ``These are the days of triumph and freedom.'' Reagan, 79, said the only trouble spot is the Middle East. Alluding to biblical passages about the end of the world, he said, ``It's important to remember that the battle of Armageddon was to begin in an area in Israel, according to the prophecy. ``The problem there is they have leaders like (Moammar) Gadhafi,'' he said. ``It was not just an accident that some airplanes flew his way one day,'' he said referring to the 1986 bombing raid on Tripoli, Libya. Reagan also praised Gorbachev for reforms in the Soviet Union, a country Reagan once referred to as ``the evil empire.'' ``He is totally different than any Soviet leader before him,'' Reagan said. ``The only threat against him is from within.'' Reagan also praised President Bush for leaving most Reagan administration programs largely intact. ``He came into continue what's been on going for eight years,'' Reagan said of Bush. Reagan, who spoke for 25 minutes and answered questions for 30 minutes, received an estimated $60,000. Former First Lady Nancy Reagan also was in Atlanta and toured a special care nursery for ``crack'' babies at Grady Memorial Hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Golden Crown Restored to Poland's National Emblem
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Friday restored a golden crown to Poland's national emblem, the eagle, recreating the prewar symbol of independence after a debate so emotional one member suggested former Communists had no right to vote. Deputies elected as members of the now-dissolved Communist Party started to walk out in protest, and a hasty recess was called before Parliament voted overwhelmingly to go back to the national symbol used from 1927 until the Nazi occupation in 1939. The white eagle with a golden crown, beak and talons, its wings outspread and turned to the right on a red shield-shaped background, will replace the uncrowned white eagle that decorated government offices and official documents during 45 years of Communist rule after World War II. ``It was with this eagle that we lost our independence, first under Western (Nazi German) and then under Eastern (Soviet) force,'' said Piotr Nowina-Konopka, a minister of state to President Wojciech Jaruzelski, who proposed the new symbol. ``Despite that, it survived in Polish homes and families, as well as among Poles abroad, as a symbolic sign awaiting better times ahead.'' The postwar Communist government rejected the crowned eagle as a symbol of Poland' monarchial past. Poles began agitating for restoration of the crown almost as soon as the Solidarity-led government replaced the Communists in September. Parliament voted 316-3 with 52 abstentions Friday to return the crown, reshape stars on the eagle to avoid any resemblence to Soviet red stars, and remove a border around the shield that was the heraldic symbol of illegitimacy. Documents, currency and other uses of the old emblem will be valid until the end of 1995, although official signs must be changed by Dec. 31, 1992. The debate Friday was whether the eagle's crown should have a cross, too. When Poland was restored as an independent nation following World War I, the eagle's crown included a small cross. This was removed in 1927, reflecting the nation's religious diversity. But Poland is more than 90 percent Roman Catholic now, following the obliteration of the Jewish population during World War II and the annexation by the Soviet Union of Polish lands home to its Ukrainian and Byelorussion minorities. The cross was rejected, however, and Solidarity Deputy Jan Lopuszanski then rose to address the 173 parliament members elected to seats guaranteed last year to the Communist Party. ``I have a moral appeal to the left side of the hall, I think that this voting should take place without you. I think you would be right to abstain from voting on this issue,'' he said. Amid murmurings, about a dozen ex-communist deputies rose to leave. Sejm Speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewicz immediately called a recess of the lower house to avert a walkout. Later, a deputy said the Solidarity caucus rejected Lopuszanski's view.

DOC.HEAD: Top Colleges Still Cater to an Elite, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Students at the nation's top colleges now are more likely to be from upper middle-class families than from old money, according to a study released Friday. The new elite is defined more by intellectual achievement than family tradition, but is an exclusive one nonetheless, two sociology professors say in their study of the freshman class that enrolled in 1986. ``It's not the old gentry any more,'' said Professor Lionel S. Lewis of the State University of New York at Buffalo. ``They've incorporated the upper middle class and professional class.'' Lewis and his co-author, Paul William Kingston of the University of Virginia, compared freshmen entering all colleges and universities that year to those who enrolled in the 76 most selective schools, as defined by the American Council on Education. Those are schools where the freshman class averaged at least 1,175 of a possible 1,600 points on the Scholastic Aptitude Test. ``That would be the Ivy League schools and the prestigious colleges _ Oberlin, Swarthmore, Haverford, places like that,'' Lewis said. More than 60 percent of the freshmen at the selective schools came from families with income of at least $50,000 a year, compared with 31 percent overall. Nearly 25 percent of the freshmen at selective schools came from families with incomes of $100,000 or more, compared with 7 percent overall. The freshmen admitted to those schools are unquestionably chosen for their academic merit and extracurricular achievements, rather than family wealth or connections, but merit is measured on a yardstick that favors the affluent, Lewis and Kingston said in an article in the journal Academe. ``Most students who are meritorious in the conventional sense come from high-income families where they have enjoyed special opportunities; children from lower-income families acquire relatively fewer linguistic and cultural skills,'' the professors wrote. ``The `all-around' person is an upper-class value, and the dominance of this value in the admissions process has made it possible for elite private institutions to tighten their academic requirements for admission and still cater to the privileged.'' Many of the top schools say their admissions policies are ``need-blind'' and promise to give all students as much financial aid as they need, but Lewis said those policies aren't designed to attract students from lower-income backgrounds. ``The first part of financial aid is always a student loan. Then they give work-study. Then, after that, they might give some kind of a grant,'' Lewis said in an interview. ``If you accept any form of student aid, you're going to have to borrow, and some people choose not to do that.'' He said an increase in merit-based scholarships might be part of the solution, but other issues would remain, such as the possibility that poorer students might feel uncomfortable at those schools or that the SAT and other admissions criteria discriminate against the poor and minorities. ``I don't have a pat and easy answer,'' he said. ``The problem is the problem of inequality in our society.''

DOC.HEAD: Journalist Killer's Conviction Upheld
DOC.TEXT: A state appeals court on Friday upheld the murder conviction of a Taiwanese gangster for the 1984 slaying of a Chinese-American journalist who had written critically of Taiwan's government. Tung Kuei-Sen, 37, admitted taking part in the shooting death of Henry Liu and said he did it out of patriotism after being told Liu was a traitor. The 1st District Court of Appeal said Tung's motives weren't the equivalent of ``heat of passion,'' which makes an intentional killing manslaughter rather than murder. The 3-0 ruling upheld Tun's sentence of 27 years to life in prison. Liu, 52, a Taiwanese-born U.S. citizen and author of a critical biography of Taiwan President Chiang Ching-Kuo, was shot to death in October 1984 at his home in Daly City, south of San Francisco, by gunmen who were later traced to the United Bamboo Gang in Taiwan. Military courts in Taiwan convicted five men of responsibility for the murder, including the nation's defense intelligence chief, Vice Admiral Wong Hsi-Lin, who was found to have ordered the gangsters to silence Liu. Wong was sentenced to life in prison. In December the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in a civil suit that the government of Taiwan was legally responsible for Wong's actions. The suit was filed by Helen Liu, the journalist's widow.

DOC.HEAD: INS Agent Was Paid Up To $1 Million To Allow Aliens Into U.S.
DOC.TEXT: An official said on Friday that a Chinese smuggler paid a U.S. immigration agent up to $1 million to allow more than 200 Chinese emigrants into the United States by way of the Virgin Islands. At a detention hearing, Magistrate Jeffrey Resnick ordered jailed without bail inspector Juanito Creque of the Immigration and Naturalization Service; Leonard Y. Hu, the alleged smuggler, and five illegal immigrants. Creque and Hu are charged with conspiracy to smuggle illegal aliens across a U.S. border. Hu is charged with bribery and Creque with accepting a payoff. U.S. Attorney Terry Halpern said in asking for their detention, ``They are international travelers with connections in many foreign points along the route used to bring Red Chinese from mainland China to St. Croix and St. Thomas.'' Customs agent Ramon Davila, who posed undercover as a co-conspirator during the investigation, said in an affidavit that the aliens traveled to the Virgin Islands by way of Hong Kong, London and the West Indies island of Antigua. Davila said Hu paid Creque $5,000 each _ or up to $1 million _ for more than 200 illegal Chinese immigrants Creque allowed to enter the Caribbean territory and continue on to the the mainland United States last year. Davila said Hu paid him $15,000 in bribes to allow five Chinese safe passage to the United States in November. He said in the affidavit that Hu and the five aliens were kept under surveillance and traced to a restaurant on Mott Street, in New York City's Chinatown district. Hu, Creque and six others were arrested this week at St. Thomas airport as the aliens were trying to travel to New York. The six others _ Antiguans Everton Coates and his wife Millentine, and Chinese Tong Xiang Yang, Zhou Tu Ni, Jufoi Wu and Dian Min Zheng _ were charged with conspiracy and entry without inspection. According to Davila's affidavit, Coates was the Antiguan contact and his wife coordinated the alien shipment and was in communication with Creque. Mrs. Coates was released on $35,000 property bond. All the other remained in jail. A trial date has not been set.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers from Panama Invasion Honored
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-two soldiers who fought in Panama received medals for bravery Friday. ``The United States Army has never stood taller than it has today,'' Gen. Carl E. Vuono, Army chief of staff, said as he presented medals to members of the 5th Infantry Division (Mechanized), nicknamed the Red Devils. ``You had some of our toughest fighting. You heard the whine of richochets, and you perservered. There is no one in the world who can stand up to what we have to offer. The medals included two Silver Stars, the third-highest award for bravery. One Silver Star went posthumously to Cpl. Ivan D. Perez, who was killed in the Dec. 20 assault on La Commandancia, headquarters for Gen. Manuel Noriega and the Panamanian Defense Forces. The other went to Spec. Roderick B. Ringstaff, a medic who ignored his own wounds to give aid to fallen comrades during the attack. Six soldiers were presented the Bronze Star with valor, and 14 received the Army Commendation Medal with valor.

DOC.HEAD: Minneapolis Restricts Cigarette Vending to Curb Buying by Minors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds one graf at end with similar effort failing in Indiana Legislature. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette vending machines will be banned from gas stations, some restaurants and other areas open to the public in a measure intended to curb sales of cigarettes to minors. The City Council first considered banning cigarette vending machines from all places open to the public, but that effort failed. The revised measure, passed unanimously, includes three exceptions to the ban. The machines will be allowed in factories and workplaces, in restaurants with liquor licenses and in hotels. But machines at the hotels and sanctioned restaurants must be in view of a clerk, according to the ordinance. And in the case of hotels, the machines must be equipped with remote-control shut-off systems. Minneapolis joins four other Minnesota communities that have banned or restricted unsupervised cigarette vending machines. In Indiana Friday, a similar measure, which would have ordered removal of cigarette vending machines from family restaurants, shopping malls and other places accessible to children, failed to clear a state Senate committee.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak President Havel to Visit Canada on Feb. 18-19
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel will visit Canada this month for two days prior to his trip to the United States, Czechoslovak officials said Friday. Embassy spokesman Juraj Kosmel said Havel, 54, is to come to Ottawa on Feb. 18 and will travel to Toronto on Feb. 19 before going on to Washington and New York. Kosmel said Havel was invited by the Canadian government and will likely meet with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and External Affairs Minister Joe Clark in Ottawa. His tentative plans include an official lunch and dinner and a meeting with Ontario Premier David Peterson. Local Czechoslovaks, meanwhile, said Havel is to speak at the University of Toronto on Feb. 19. Jan Merta, president of the Ottawa chapter of the Czechoslovakian Association of Canada, said there will likely be a welcoming event in Ottawa, home to about 1,200 Czechoslovaks. Havel, a playwright and longtime civil rights activist, was jailed about five years by the former Communist regime for his dissident activities, on charges of ``attempted subversion.'' When he became president in December, he was the first non-Communist head of state in Czechoslovakia in 41 years. Merta said the visit is cause for great excitement. ``For us, it's the same as the way Catholics look up to the Pope.''

DOC.HEAD: Relations Strained Over PLO Failure to Condemn Tour Bus Attack
DOC.TEXT:
The PLO came under fire Friday in a government newspaper editorial for failing to condemn a terrorist attack on a bus carrying Israeli tourists in Egypt that left nine dead. Sources close to the government say relations have chilled with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which could endanger efforts by the United States to initiate Israeli-Palestinian peace talks because Egypt is acting as surrogate for the PLO in the process. In a related development, one of the Israeli survivors has given a authorities a videotape he took of last Sunday's attack, which may help track down the assailants, newspaper reports said. Ibrahim Nafei, editor of the leading government-owned newspaper Al-Ahram, said in an editorial Friday that a PLO statement on the attack was ``flimsy and weak, to say the least. It is not at all commensurate with the magnitude and monstrosity of this (bus) incident.'' He said he was ``reluctant to say the statement conflicts with the PLO's renunciation of terrorist acts.'' In the ambush, two masked gunmen killed nine Israelis and wounded 20 with hand grenades and automatic weapons fire on a desert road between Cairo and the Suez Canal. An Egyptian tour guide also was wounded. The sources said Egyptian-PLO relations have deteriorated so far that the estimated 35,000-40,000 Palestinians in Egypt have come under government scrutiny. They said breaches of travel and residence rules have been uncovered in the checks that followed strong hints of a Palestinian connection in the bus incident. It was the worst chill since President Hosni Mubarak shut down seven PLO offices in Egypt for seven months in 1987. The closure was to protest criticism by the Palestine National Council, the organization's parliament in exile, of Egypt's 1979 peace treaty with Israel. Egypt resents a statement issued Monday from PLO headquarters in the Tunisian capital Tunis that failed to condemn the bus attack. It appeared to equate the killing of Israelis on the bus with the killing by Israelis of Palestinians in the 2-year-old uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza. Faisal Husseni, a leading pro-PLO activist in the territories, had condemned the attack, saying such violence ``comes from groups who are fed by the stubbon Israeli position'' in the peace process.
The statement by the PLO, distributed by the organization's news agency Wafa, also obliquely criticized Egypt's peace with Israel and U.S. disregard of the PLO in Washington-led peace efforts. On Thursday, Mubarak sent a message to PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat, which the sources said was believed to have conveyed Cairo's displeasure over the organization's position. The PLO's Cairo representative, Saeed Kamal, said he relayed Mubarak's ``verbal message'' to Arafat by telephone. Neither he nor Egyptian officials would discuss its contents. About 100 people, mostly Palestinians, have been detained for questioning in the attack, including the bus driver and the man who rented the Peugoet, according to a police source. In an interview published Saturday in the Cairo newspaper Al-Gomhouria, Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa said a videotape shot by Pinchas First, one of the Israeli survivors, recorded the voice and faces of the attackers. ``I used my camera right from the start of the attack, and I'm sure that I managed to film the assailants,'' First said in an interview with the Israeli newspaper Yediot Ahronot.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Asks International Labor Organization for Help
DOC.TEXT: Turkey asked the International Labor Organization on Friday to help it improve mine safety following an explosion and fire at a coal pit two days ago in which 66 miners were believed killed. An ILO spokesman said West German mine expert Meinhart Funkemayer will prepare a report on safety situation within the Turkish mining industry. The ILO then expects to offer Turkey consulting services on how to improve mine safety, based on Funkemayer's recommendations. Funkemayer already is at the disaster site at Merzifon in northern Turkey, sent by West Germany to help extinguish the fire, ILO spokesman Peter Sutcliffe said. Of 68 people in the mine when the explosion occurred Wednesday night, two were rescued alive. Eight bodies were recovered and 58 others are believed entombed in the mine.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev, Baker Make Headway on Arms Control, Troop Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 7-8: ``The two,'' with background on chemical weapons; drops last graf to trim
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III reported progress toward agreements cutting long range nuclear warheads, troops in Europe and chemical weapons in marathon talks Friday with Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Soviet officials. The Soviet president urged Bush to modify his new proposal for troop reductions in Europe to eliminate a 30,000-soldier advantage for the United States, and Baker labeled the counterproposal ``very interesting.'' Baker said he and the Soviets made headway on a number of other fronts _ and clashed over Cuba _ in negotiations designed to pave the way for a summit next summer between Gorbachev and President Bush. ``If you ask me if I am pleased at what we are able to do here, I am very pleased,'' Baker said at a midnight news conference after long sessions with Gorbachev and then with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. He said the talks made headway ``very very smartly'' toward a treaty on long-range missiles. The two sides also prepared to announce on Saturday Soviet approval of a U.S.-proposed phased plan for the abolition of chemical weapons. The two superpowers _ the only nations to acknowledge possesion of chemical weapons _ already have agreed in principle on the deep cuts outlined by Bush at a United Nations speech last September. Bush proposed that both countries cut their arsenals of chemical weapons to 20 percent of the current U.S. inventory while a 40-nation treaty is worked out requiring U.S. and Soviet cuts to 2 percent of the current U.S. level in eight years. That 2 percent would be destroyed within 10 years if all countries capable of building such weapons agreed to a total ban. Bush, in his State of the Union address, called for troop limits of 195,000 each for the United States and the Soviet Union on the ``central front'' _ for the United States, basically West Germany _ with the United States allowed to retain 30,000 soldiers elsewhere on the continent. Gorbachev proposed applying the 195,000 limit to all of Europe, thus cutting the U.S. advantage. Alternatively, Gorbachev proposed a ceiling of 225,000 throughout Europe. Since most Soviet troops are in Central Europe the total there could be boosted to 225,000. Baker said the idea of a 195,000 limit for all of Europe was ``very close to the president's proposal,'' but he said he would consult the U.S. allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization before responding formally. He is to meet with the 15 foreign ministers at a conference in Ottawa, Canada, next Monday and Tuesday. Officials from the seven Warsaw Pact nations will be on hand as well to consider ``open skies'' and other measures designed to reduce East-West tensions. While virtually all Soviet soldiers on the continent are stationed in the central region of Poland, East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Hungary, the United States has forces in Britain, Greece, Italy, Spain and Turkey. Baker said the Soviets ``don't want to deal with Central Europe as such.'' And, he said, ``the United States obviously is not wedded to the concept of linkage.'' Baker winds up his visit here on Saturday with an unprecedented appearance before the International Affairs Committee of the Supreme Soviet _ the Soviet parliament. He will then fly to Sofia, Bulgaria, and on Sunday to Bucharest, Romania. The two East European allies of Moscow are in the midst of rocky transitions from hard-line communism. Baker will meet with opposition leaders as well as government officials in those countries, the State Department said. While the issue of troops drew most of the attention, Baker and the Soviets made headway on a number of other fronts _ and clashed over Cuba. Baker confirmed reports the Soviets are in the process of providing MiG fighter-bombers to Cuba, but evidently was unable to persuade the Soviets to relent. On Afghanistan, he said the United States was willing to permit President Najib to remain in office while peace negotiations are conducted between the Soviet-backed government and U.S.-armed guerrillas. But Baker said Najib would have to step down once an agreement was reached to end the 11-year war in the Southwest Asian country. On another regional front, Baker criticized Israel for settling some Soviet Jewish immigrants on the West Bank and in Gaza. He said the settlements were an obstacle to peace. However, Baker said that since Israel is ``a strong ally'' of the United States he had rejected a Soviet proposal to join in condemning the settlement of the Jewish refugees. They amount to about 1 percent to 2 percent of the Jewish exodus to Israel from the Soviet Union. Gennady I. Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Thursday night the two sides were likely to adopt such a public stance together. On several arms control fronts Baker also reported progress. He said the issues of revealing missile test data in flight to the other side and where to store non-deployed missiles were settled. And, Baker said, a third complex issue _ how many air-launched cruise missiles could be carried on bombers _ was settled except for questions about their range. These were the three complex issues Bush and Gorbachev, at their Malta summit meeting in December, had turned over to Baker and Shevardnadze for resolution. They are part of the negotiations on a treaty to slash long-range U.S. and Soviet nuclear missiles, bombers and submarines that Bush and Gorbachev would like to sign at their summit meeting in Washington in June. An even more ticklish issues _ what to do about sea-launched cruise missiles _ apparently will be finessed with a statement outside the treaty itself stating each side's policy. Baker said he did not think the declaratory statement would be submitted to the U.S. Senate for ratification along with the treaty. What to do about the missiles, which are carried on submarines and surface ships, has been the most difficult problem in the treaty's path. The Soviet news agency Tass said Gorbachev told Baker that new U.S. proposals ``make it possible to bring the positions closer on several items and inspire hope that the program of preparations for the summit in Washington will be successfully implemented.''

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Move Into City Hall In Protest Over Alleged Abuse Of Leader
DOC.TEXT: Public schools, closed three days by protests over white management of the city's mostly black school system, will reopen Monday, officials said Thursday. The demonstrations continued in this 1960s battleground of the civil rights movement, as about 250 people crowded into City Hall to protest the alleged sexual abuse of a protest leader when she was arrested earlier in the week. The protesers promised to stay in City Hall until the police officer involved is suspended. About 45 people remained there Thursday night as City Council members met to seek a resolution of the situation. School officials announced that all 11 public schools would remain closed Friday. Schools Superintendent Norward Roussell said later that the schools would reopen Monday. Rising racial tensions forced the closing of two schools Tuesday morning. All schools in the 70 percent black, 6,000 student system closed that afternoon, and remained shut Wednesday and Thursday. The six white members on the 11-member board dismissed Roussell last week, but reinstatated him Tuesday, and he returned to work Wednesday. White board members voted in December against renewing his $80,000-a-year contract it expires in June, prompting the five blacks on the board to announce their resignations. Roussell and his supporters claim the board was terminating his contact because he is black, rather than because of his alleged lack of managerial skills as claimed by his critics. The latest protests were over the arrest Monday of Rose Sanders in a melee at City Hall. Mrs. Sanders claims a policeman touched her private parts with his billy club as she was dragged to police headquarters. She was released from the hospital Thursday. The wife of state Sen. Hank Sanders, who was hospitalized Monday with injuries she said she received at the hands of police, was released from the hospital Thursday. Sanders and a law partner of his met Thursday with Mayor Joe Smitherman, who said the matter was under investigation and a report is expected Friday. Smitherman said the policeman, Ronnie Rushing, has been given office duty. The mayor said earlier that Rushing was injured by Mrs. Sanders when she forced police to remove her from City Hall. ``He said Rose bit him and he had to have medical treatment,'' Smitherman said. ``I don't believe it at all when she said she was mistreated.'' ``I know Rose Sanders would not say anything if it did not happen,'' said one of the protesters, the Rev. L.L. Ruffin. ``Nor do I believe she instigated it.''

DOC.HEAD: Eric Bogosian's `Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll' Opens Off-Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Subway panhandlers. Aging rock stars. Blue-collar punks. Rappers. Ruthless lawyers. Self-satisfied doctors. Street crazies. Drug heads. Eric Bogosian hears America singing and the song is one of excess _ and how people handle it. His blistering portraits come to life in ``Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll,'' a terrific collection of monologues that Bogosian unleashed Thursday at off-Broadway's Orpheum Theater. The dark, frizzy-haired performer has done one-man shows before, specifically ``Funhouse'' and ``Drinking in America,'' but in his latest effort Bogosian captures even more successfully the schizophrenic nature of his characters' lives. Nightmarish and comic at the same time, they sum up the late, not-so-lamented 1980s as the decade of greed and preoccupation with self. Even Bogosian's bums have an ego. ``I'm a product of my environment,'' snarls an aggressive subway beggar. ``I want your money.'' Some of the material is savagely funny, particularly a geriatric pop idol who, now that he has made his dough, has discovered the evils of dope, the risks of sex and the plight of the Amazon rain forest. Or there's Bogosian's almost slapstick picture of a lower-class Italian kid who takes a good friend out on a bender the night before his wedding _ an escapade that results in the trashing of a McDonald's and a postponement of the ceremony. There's a chilling effect to the evening too, especially in the final, almost scary monologue where a stoned young man talks about computers taking over the world. These machines are going to get you one way or another, he warns. And you believe him, no matter how high he is. A tough social critic, Bogosian has a kind of weird affection for these misfits. He understands them. Bogosian also has become a better actor since his last New York appearance. For example, director Jo Bonney has coaxed out of him an acerbic portrayal of a nasty, combative lawyer who is as hilarious as he is frightening. The man keeps repeating ``sue me'' so often that it begins to sound like a religious chant. A lot of Bogosian's monologues have a rhythm, an almost musical quality to them. The language flows, whether it is street talk or high-finance legalese. Bogosian is a physical as well as verbal performer. He paces and prowls the small, spare stage. In his swagger, struts, shuffles and pacings you get a sense of the fierce energy these characters invest in pursuing both pleasure and pain. The evening goes on a little too long and might work better if there were an intermission. ``Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll'' is such a densely packed work that by the time it's over, the audience is exhausted _ from both laughing at, and worrying about, the memorable people Bogosian has put on stage.

A judge said he may reverse himself and permit Joseph Hazelwood's defense to allege that government negligence _ not recklessness by the Exxon Valdez captain _ caused the nation's worst oil spill. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone reopened the question after he had ruled Thursday that such a theory could not be advanced by the defense. Defense attorney Dick Madson said in his opening statement that the U.S. Coast Guard monitors weren't watching their radar screen and failed in their duty to notify Hazelwood that his 987-foot tanker was heading for disaster at Bligh Reef. A Coast Guard traffic monitor, civilian employee Gregory Taylor, testified Thursday that part of his job was to watch the radar screen for trouble and communicate with tankers if a problem was imminent. He also said he was to ``let people know what was going on to make things easier.''

U.S. and Latin officials are close to agreement on a communique for next week's drug summit pledging U.S. help to revamp the drug-dependent economies of Peru, Bolivia and Colombia, sources say. The communique to be signed at the four-nation meeting also would commit President Bush to press other Western nations to provide economic aid to the Andean nations, said a South American diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The document is being prepared for the signature of Bush and the presidents of the three Andean countries who will meet Feb. 15 for a drug summit in Cartagena, Colombia. U.S. military assistance to the Andean countries is not spelled out in the document, but the Latins have insisted it be restricted to equipment and training rather than direct U.S. military involvement in interdiction, said the South American diplomat.

AIDS spread at its slowest rate in the United States last year as fewer homosexual and bisexual men developed the disease and drugs delayed symptoms in people already infected, federal officials said. But AIDS is spreading faster among heterosexuals, newborn babies, women and Southerners, the federal Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The CDC reported 35,238 new cases of AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, in 1989, compared with 32,196 in 1988. That 9 percent increase is easily the slowest since the AIDS spread began in early 1981. For example, AIDS was up 34 percent in 1988 and 60 percentn 1987.

Researchers have found the first gene able to suppress formation of prmors, one of the most common cancers among men, according to a study published today. The gene, called thegene, or RB, was found in earlier studies to block the formation of a rare cancer of the eye. In a Sciencee study published today, scientists at the University of California-San Diego say they have shown that a normag RB gene inserted into human prostate cancer cells is able to ppress formation of tumors. The RB gene is ng, mutated or not functioning in such tumors.
