DOC.HEAD: Norwegians Convinced They Are Overrun by Thugs and Hooligans
DOC.TEXT: Criminologists and other experts tell them otherwise, but many Norwegians are convinced their country is overrun by thugs, hooligans and ``the mob.'' The experts say the public concern verges on ``national hysteria.'' They argue that Norway still has one of the world's lowest crime rates, and is nowhere near being in a league with the United States or other countries with serious crime problems. ``Our biggest crime problem is the unfounded anxiety people feel about it,'' said Nils Christie, a University of Oslo criminology professor. Muggings are rare and city parks generally are safe. Some cafeterias leave it up to the customers to leave what they owe in a till and even make their own change. Few of Norway's 4.2 million people have actually witnessed criminal violence, according to an informal poll by one newspaper. Police, who usually are unarmed, used or threatened to use weapons just 28 times last year, according to Justice Ministry figures. ``Norway is at the bottom of the list of violent crimes per capita,'' said Christie. The risk of being murdered in the United States is nine times greater than in Norway, according to a local study. Sociologist Cecilie Hoigaard listed Norway's murder rate in 1988 as 0.9 killings per 100,000 residents, compared to 1.4 in Sweden and 5.1 in France. The World Almanac said the U.S. figure was 8.3 the same year. Yet crime in Norway has increased by about 15 percent a year since 1986, according to official figures, and that's what has brought all the repercussions. ``We aren't interested in comparing ourselves to other countries,'' said Tor Aksel Busch, deputy director general of public prosecutions. ``We must compare ourselves to the way things were. It is the increase that is disturbing.'' Crimes for monetary or material gain, such as theft and fraud, represent 81 percent of the offenses. ``There is simply much more to steal because Norway's standard of living has increased enormously,'' criminologist Christie said. Norway had an economic boom when it discovered oil off its coast. From 1986 to 1988, drug arrests doubled and violent crime rose 29 percent, partly because alcohol is more accepted by ``traditionally reserved and pious Norwegians,'' Christie said. ``We Norwegians are very worried about crime,'' said Kjell Solem of the Justice Ministry. ``It is a frequent topic of debate. We started with very little and don't like the increase,'' ``Norway has an old-fashioned crime rate,'' he added. ``You have to go back 25 years to find such a low rate in Sweden. It is safe almost anywhere, any time in Norway.'' In December, robbers rammed a large truck into an armored car and escaped with about $1 million, leaving a trail of burning getaway cars. Norwegians could perhaps understand the greed but were appalled that the thieves were prepared to harm the security guards by ramming the armored car with the truck. ``People speak of moral decay, the fraying of society's fabric,'' Solem said. Crime was a major issue in last autumn's national election; everything from drugs and alcohol to video tapes and foreigners came in for the blame. The right-wing Party of Progress increased its standing in Parliament tenfold, partly on the basis of a law-and-order campaign. ``Crime has become a matter of national hysterics,'' said sociologist Thomas Mathiesen. ``There is a much greater fear of crime than there is any grounds for.'' Many Norwegians are responding by fortifying their homes. Lock sales soared 60 percent from 1987 to 1989 and burglar alarm sales are said to be on the rise. Mathiesen said fear was being spread unwittingly by the news media, politicians and even police who seek larger budgets. Tabloid newspapers routinely brand any group of criminals ``the Mafia.'' They devote sensational and lengthy coverage to murders and pursue the cases for weeks. The respected Aftenposten newspaper, in a review of the 1980s, said more crime produced more crime reporting. In the 1970s, ``trivial crimes were reported,'' it wrote. ``Now it's hard to find space for all the corruption, theft and violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Radio Free Europe Still Has Job to Do in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: An original goal of Radio Free Europe, born in the Cold War to penetrate the Iron Curtain, was to close when Eastern Europe opened up and the news flowed freely. But the Western network is staying on the air with a new mission _ to spread word on how democracy works. ``Yes, we are going to stay in business,'' said William W. Marsh, executive vice president of Radio Free Europe and its sister station Radio Liberty, which broadcasts into the Soviet Union. ``Our job is not done.'' Radio Free Europe, founded in 1949 and Radio Liberty, established two years later, are based in Munich but controlled by the Washington-based Bureau of International Broadcasting and funded by the U.S. Congress. It is popularly known as RFE-RL. RFE-RL was distinct from the Voice of America, the British Broadcasting Corp. and other Western radios, because it was ``a surrogate for free media that did not exist'' in Eastern Europe, said Robert E. Gillette, the deputy director. RFE broadcasts to Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Romania, as well as the Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Radio Liberty broadcasts to the Soviet Union in 12 languages. Gillette and A. Ross Johnson, a director, say they believe RFE was a powerful catalyst in the revolutions that have swept Eastern Europe. It not only broadcast international news but news from inside the countries to which it beamed its programs _ people got news of home from abroad. But now, after the revolutions, RFE-RL is hearing increasingly from people who ask for practical advice on democracy and the free-market economy, the radio's officials say. Setting an example of Western journalistic ethics is another role RFE sees as vital in the establishment of democracy in Eastern Europe. ``It won't be a short or easy process to have a pluralistic media,'' Johnson said. ``It is relatively easy to close down the censor's office and get the Communist Party out of the media, but it is not so easy to change a generation of habits.'' ``The best way to teach Western journalistic ethics is by example, but it will take some years,'' said Gillette, a former correspondent for The Los Angeles Times. But the broader role is to answer the countless questions people have about democracy and Western economics. ``They don't know much about democratic institutions, how to go about establishing them,'' Marsh said. ``They are trying to learn about the democratic process.'' ``We get specific requests on the practice of democracy,'' Johnson said. People want to know how parliaments and courts work in the West, how political parties are financed, what entrepreneurs do, even how to clean up the environment. ``We are trying to provide that kind of practical information,'' Johnson said. ``In a sense, lessons in democracy.'' What happens when that job is done? ``In an ideal world if there were no need for us, we would be very happy to close our doors,'' Marsh said. ``But that doesn't exist yet.'' Said Gillette: ``History has been on fast-forward, but that doesn't mean there can't be a reversal. There are lots of alternatives to democracy. It's not done yet.''

DOC.HEAD: Live Radio Show Hits Its Stride
LaserPhoto CN1 of Feb. 7.
DOC.TEXT: ``Mountain Stage,'' Appalachia's radio answer to ``A Prairie Home Companion,'' is hitting its stride as a showcase for new and avant-garde folk, blues, bluegrass, country and even rock music. ``Now we're to the point in the world of music that a lot of people know about us. I don't think we're in our prime yet,'' said Larry Groce, host and co-producer. The two-hour weekly show, broadcast on nearly 150 American Public Radio stations, brings eager artists before appreciative crowds in a historic downtown theater every Sunday afternoon. Between them stand live microphones. ``There's a lot of uncertainty in this thing,'' Groce said. ``Every show is like writing a song. It's not art without uncertainty.'' Co-producer Andy Ridenour saw a dearth of live radio shows when he created ``Mountain Stage'' for West Virginia Public Radio in 1981. ``The idea is not a novel one,'' he said. ``The contemporary presentation is unique. There's no one else doing what we're doing.'' ``Mountain Stage'' went into regular production in 1984 and was first distributed nationally by National Public Radio in 1986. The show switched to APR last October. It is often compared to ``A Prairie Home Companion,'' Garrison Keillor's celebrated live public radio variety show. ``Mountain Stage'' producers say they admire Keillor's show, but emphasize they didn't jump on the Minnesota show's bandwagon. For one thing, they say, ``Mountain Stage'' emphasizes music over talk and moves quickly between acts. A typical show, broadcast live in West Virginia and rebroadcast on a tape delay elsewhere, usually offers three acts and the ever-present Groce, backed by the house band and ``The Fabulous Twister Sisters.'' Groce, 41, is a singer and songwriter from Dallas whose ``Junk Food Junkie'' was a 1976 hit. His smooth tones and gentle manner now probably come across best when he sings a traditional hymn on every ``Mountain Stage.'' The band, which includes Twister Sisters Deni Bonett and Julie Adams on fiddle and guitar, is making its own name as Stark Raven. ``Mountain Stage'' often features regional acts from Texas and Cajun country, and such international acts as Latin American, African and Irish folk singers. Ridenour, 40, a former radio newsman, was not met with enthusiasm when he created the show. Groce said even NPR pooh-poohed the show. ``People spent a lot of time telling us what we couldn't do,'' Ridenour said. ``We were told ... the show would never work, that we couldn't do a show like this in Charleston, W.Va. NPR said there was a maximum of 60 stations that would ever use `Mountain Stage.' '' Funding for the show hasn't grown as rapidly as its popularity. The producers manage up to 40 broadcasts on about $500,000 a year, about one-third the amount similar radio shows receive. Ridenour said the money buys a small staff and musicians, stipends for the artists, rental of the auditorium and a little promotion. Stations now get the show through their APR fees, but West Virginia Public Radio will be paid directly beginning in July, Ridenour said. ``A la carte'' public radio is becoming a trend as funding becomes more difficult and stations pick and choose which shows they want, Groce said. ``The reality is that it costs money to make this programming, and if you're going to take it, you're going to have to start paying money,'' he said. ``Mountain Stage'' is fast becoming a key stop for rising musicians as agents and record companies realize the show's popularity. Artists, too, are enthusiastic and show their appreciation by signing the walls in the basement of the Capitol Plaza Music Hall downtown. ``I was West Virginia when West Virginia wasn't cool,'' wrote country singer Kathy Mattea, a Charleston-area native who performed in December after being named the Country Music Association's Female Vocalist of the Year. Pop songwriter Livingston Taylor, younger brother of the singer James Taylor, was recently greeted like an old friend. ``I've been here lots of times,'' he said. ``They're a really comfortable crew to work with.'' Taylor's enthusiasm came through when he modified the final stanza of ``You Are My Sunshine'' in the finale, singing, ``On Super Sunday, I flew to Charleston, my loneliness to assuage. At long last, I have contentment, with my `pards' on `Mountain Stage.' '' Robin Williams _ the traditional folk musician, not the comedian _ said he's been on ``Mountain Stage'' four times to work with ``great musicians in a great atmosphere.'' He also likes the exposure and the chance to do new songs instead of old hits.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Mon Feb. 12

DOC.HEAD: Burgess's Banned Film Finds a Home on Stage
LaserPhoto LON1 of Feb. 7.
DOC.TEXT: Eighteen years after it was made, ``A Clockwork Orange'' still cannot be seen on British screens. But it is about to find a new home on stage. Set in the next century and featuring music by members of the U2 rock band, the Royal Shakespeare Company's version extensively reworks a script by Anthony Burgess, author of the 1962 novel. ``A Clockwork Orange'' remains best-known for Stanley Kubrick's controversial 1971 film, starring Malcolm McDowell as the marauding Alex, a 15-year-old Briton drunk on the joys of violence. The film was nominated for several top Academy Awards but was also denounced for supposedly extending the frontiers of screen violence. In 1972, Kubrick withdrew it from British circulation because he was receiving death threats. Written in ``nadsat,'' an Anglo-Russian slang invented by Burgess, the novel and film were about Alex's love of violence and Beethoven, and the doctors who destroy both passions by meddling with his brain. Burgess wrote the stage script simply to deter others from doing it, but lately he has taken to deriding his most famous novel. ``It's a terrible book in some ways. I'm not prepared to defend it,'' Burgess told the Independent newspaper. But the play's director, Ron Daniels, disagrees. He calls the novel ``a brilliant piece of work,'' and he believes the stage show will be ``complex and interesting and vivid and at times funny.'' ``A Clockwork Orange: 2004,'' as the play-with-music is now called, opened Feb. 6 at the RSC's Barbican Theater in London, running in repertory through March 13. ``It's very much a morality play for the '90s,'' Daniels said during a rare afternoon off from rehearsals, as many of his cast are appearing in his concurrent RSC ``Hamlet.'' ``Nowadays, after pictures of Vietnam, after punk, after video nasties, after all those appalling images of violence, the way I hope we will assess the novella will be not so much as a play about violence, but as a play about right and wrong,'' he said. Alex, leader of the so-called ``droogs'' who get their kicks beating and raping others, is ``the malefactor as hero, a modern-day Richard III,'' Daniels said. ``It's amazing how attractive the character is,'' Daniels said. ``He's someone free from all sense of guilt. ... He says, `I'm celebrating myself.''' The stage version restores the original ending of Burgess' novel which was excised in both the American edition of the novel and in Kubrick's film. ``What happens is Alex goes back into the wide world; now he's 18, but he's no longer enjoying the ultraviolence, no longer enjoying the gang society,'' Daniels said. ``He's becoming a much more stable citizen, but at the same time we miss his creative energy. He's the brightest and the best.'' Burgess' script includes musical numbers to Beethoven melodies. Phil Daniels, a 31-year-old Londoner and no relation of the director, plays Alex. The show features some Beethoven, while adding a contemporary sound provided by Bono and The Edge, two members of U2. ``I phoned up their manager and said, `I'm going to be doing this; would they be at all interested?''' Ron Daniels recalled. ``Ironically, they had just been in Los Angeles where they were struck by the gang identity and violence. ``Had I wanted abrasive music, I would have gone to a hard rock group. This music is immensely evocative and haunting; other moments have a very here and now sound.'' While ``A Clockwork Orange'' is not, Daniels emphasizes, a musical, its choreography by Arlene Phillips (``Starlight Express'') involves knives and chains, not high-stepping chorus lines. ``The fact is we have a boy who is enjoying evil,'' he said. He added that the play has ``a moral and a social context. It's about people who have no stake in society _ the discarded, the marginals.'' To those who wonder whether it's a suitable project for the Royal Shakespeare Company, Daniels replies: ``This is precisely the sort of front-line theater the RSC needs to be doing. ... It does what I think theater must do: It disturbs, it unsettles, it makes you think new thoughts.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Wed Feb. 14

DOC.HEAD: PBS Special Profiles Black Astronauts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in 12th graf, ``In the mail...'' In 13th graf, the name Nichelle Nichols is correct.
DOC.TEXT: Early in ``Black Stars in Orbit'' on PBS tonight, a former Air Force pilot, nominated in 1963 to be the first black astronaut, discusses what he says was the racial prejudice that kept him from that achievement. President John F. Kennedy had prodded him to apply for the space program, says Edward J. Dwight Jr., and there were rumors that ``he had this dream of having a black or ... an Oriental'' on the nation's first mission to the moon. Dwight never became an astronaut. The reason, he says _ his bitterness muted but still there _ was racial prejudice, particularly by a white senior officer at the Air Force test pilot school to which Dwight had been assigned. You'll wish that this otherwise excellent ``Orbit'' had done more in the segment _ had identified the officer Dwight doesn't name and listened to his side of the story. It might have shown that even with Dwight's accusations of bigotry, perhaps a bit more was involved. The program, produced by filmmaker William Miles, should at least have raised more questions. But this one-hour documentary about America's black astronauts and the blacks who worked behind the scenes in the nation's space program, still is well worth viewing. It lets them tell of their dreams and the obstacles they faced and amply shows their determination to succeed in what for years had been an all-white, all-male preserve. The program profiles six black astronauts, including the late Dr. Ronald E. McNair, one of the Challenger crew members killed when the spacecraft exploded in January 1986. Others on the program include Dr. Mae C. Jemison, who will make her first space flight next year, and Air Force Col. Guinon S. Bluford, who in 1983 became the first black to travel in space. ``Orbit'' also shows, sparingly, the outright racism that existed, the ugliest example a letter once sent the widow of Air Force Maj. Robert H. Lawrence Jr., the first black pilot selected for astronaut duty. Sympathy cards poured in, she says, after he was killed in the mid-'60s when the ejection seat of his F-104 fighter malfunctioned just before the plane crashed. But the mail also brought hate. One writer, she recalls, said he was glad her husband was killed ``because now there would be no coons on the moon.'' In a long but interesting segment, actress Nichelle Nichols, Lt. Uhura of ``Star Trek,'' speaks about how she agreed to use her TV fame to help the nation's space program recruit minorities and women. But perhaps the program's best moments come when individuals simply are allowed to talk about what they do, or about their experiences in space if they've been there, without a big deal being made about what ``first'' they accomplished. It's good that viewers, particularly young ones, know what blacks have faced in the space program, and prior to that _ such as their struggle to fly combat missions in the racially segregated military of World War II. But sometimes it's just as helpful to just listen to someone like Marine Col. Charles F. Bolden Jr., who flew the space shuttle Columbia in 1986, talk about the space program or his memories of McNair. He's articulate and obviously loves his work. He shows that today's Right Stuff cadre has no color, only desire, courage, education and ability.

Elsewhere in television... TEAM OF FRANK & ELLERBEE REUNITED: Former NBC News President Reuven Frank is joining Lucky Duck Productions, the show-making company of former NBC News anchor Linda Ellerbee. Frank, who will be a ``consulting producer,'' once was executive producer of NBC's acclaimed ``Weekend'' series for which Ellerbee and Lloyd Dobyns were co-anchors.

DOC.HEAD: Grocery Stores: Here Come The Japanese
DOC.TEXT: Americans have seen how efficiently the Japanese make and deliver cameras, television sets, electronic accessories and automobiles. Soon they may witness that same efficiency in the grocery store. Already the Japanese have perfected their techniques at home; now they are preparing to move into the American market. ``Acquisition and aggressive market entry is only a matter of time,'' says Bill Best of A.T. Kearney, a consulting firm that has just completed two studies of what is likely to become a controversial situation. Already, says Best, who heads the company's Tokyo office, many Japanese food companies have set up at least an outpost in the United States, and he predicts the matter ``will become a major issue in the next five years.'' The battle could be bitter, and controversial too, because the Japanese have developed advantages over American counterparts in the efficiency of food delivery, a critical factor in the highly competitive food business. Even now, competition for space in foodstores is intense. With some outlets earning less than a penny a dollar, stores cannot afford empty shelf space, and even brand-name products can be removed because of tardy deliveries. In Japan, says Best, it takes Japanese food manufacturers less than a day to deliver to their customers, while a similar study in the United States showed food producers took 7.7 days from processing to delivery. While travel time conceivably could be a factor in the Japanese advantage, other factors seemingly play a far greater role. Among them, Best cites three: 1. Japanese manufacturers focus entirely on service, coordinating closely with customers to meet their day-to-day needs. 2. Point-of-sale data systems are much more accurate than U.S. systems. 3. The Japanese have more flexibile delivery conditions for small lots, often using `window' distributors, or third-party contractors, for actual delivery. While the Japanese view the American market as an opportunity, domestic factors also influence their attitudes. Market growth in Japan has slowed, says Best, because calorie intake has leveled off and population growth is slow. While this situation has existed for a while, Japanese food companies feared entering the U.S. market, says Best, because they were unsure of ability to adapt to American tastes. He says that fear is receding, as Japanese companies acquire interests in U.S. companies, such as Del Monte. Already active in the United States are scores of brand-name firms, such as Nissin (noodles), House (spices) Asahi (beer), Ajinomoto, the biggest food company in Japan and Kikkoman (soy sauce). The efficiency of the Japanese could present a critical challenge to American food manufacturers, especially if retailers seek to lower inventories, historically a large expense, in favor of just-in-time delivery. It wouldn't be a first. Accustomed to warehousing large inventories of components, American automakers quickly shifted to just-in-time deliveries when they discovered them to be a major factor in Japanese price competition. Best lists these implications for the U.S. marketplace: 1. American grocery products companies will need to respond to customers with faster, more reliable service. 2. Distribution strategy will become more important in customer relations. 3. Reliable, current market information _ data on sales and inventories, for example _ will be essential to providing better service with less inventory.

DOC.HEAD: With Wall Street in Decline, Brokerage Stocks Suffer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic in AP Access under TICKERTALK
DOC.TEXT: Stocks of Wall Street's big brokerages are dancing the limbo. The question is: How low can they go? Not much lower, say securities analysts, who think brokerage stocks already may have bumped the bar with their bellies, bottoming out after a pathetic showing in 1989. One sign of apathy was troubled Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s decision last month to scrap a sale of 20 million shares of common stock. Shearson's own brokers were said to balk at selling the issue. In a typically gloomy assessment, analyst Lawrence Eckenfelder of Prudential Bache Securities Inc. said the securities business remains sluggish and investors pessimistic about brokerage firms' performance in 1990. Eckenfelder said it will take at least six to 12 months to evaluate securities stock buys made at current depressed levels, ``because the market seems poised to take a wait-and-see attitude, and earnings for the March quarter are not expected to improve significantly.'' While a revival isn't imminent, that doesn't mean stocks of major firms will fall further. Shearson brokerage analyst Dean Eberling said stocks of full-line investment firms fell 21 percent in 1989, compared with a 10.6 percent rise in the Standard & Poor's 500 index and 27 percent jump in the Dow Jones industrial average. ``This may mark the bottom of the cycle,'' Eberling said. ``I can't say it's going to turn around tomorrow night,'' but securities stocks may improve over the long term, he said. Just how long that term will be no one knows. Unless crucial Wall Street businesses such as investment banking and retail brokerage _ both in the doldrums _ pick up, the consensus is at least a year. How bad has it been? Shares of Shearson, beset by internal management turmoil, hit an all-time low of $10.12{ late last month, down 44 percent from the start of 1989 and more than 70 percent from its public offering in 1987. Stock in the nation's largest brokerage, Merrill Lynch & Co., has lost more than 25 percent in the last year. Salomon Inc. is off about 20 percent, even though it reported a 1989 profit of $470 million, the best on Wall Street (though much of that came from the firm's oil-refining and trading businesses). Wall Street firms have been grumpy since the October 1987 market crash washed away the giddy prosperity of mega-mergers and buoyant stock market activity. After tanking in the crash, brokerage stocks idled through 1988. Individual investors cautiously returned to the market in mid-1989, investment firms turned in strong second- and third-quarter profits and their stocks responded. But hopes of a lasting revival were wiped out when the Dow average plunged 190 points on Oct. 13. Brokerage commissions are down and investment banking activity has all but dried up along with the junk-bond financing market _ a double whammy for Wall Street firms. ``Now we have a soft retail environment and a very weak investment banking environment,'' Eberling said. ``Those two have come together to create a very tough operating environment.'' Not all firms have performed badly. Analysts recommend stocks such as the St. Louis-based retail brokerage A.G. Edwards Inc., whose shares have risen since the start of 1989. Discount brokerage Charles Schwab & Co. has more than doubled in the same period. Analysts point to low overhead and well-managed costs at those firms. Of the large publicly traded firms, only Morgan Stanley & Co. and Bear, Stearns & Co. are getting high marks, for similar reasons: specialization and controlled costs. Analysts laud Morgan's domestic and international investment banking business. The company also is buying back its own stock _ a good sign for investors, analysts said. Bear Stearns wins for consistent earnings and a successful stock clearing-house operation. Regional brokerages could do better because of less susceptibility to the junk-bond market mess that has crippled big takeover deals, industry executives said. ``The middle-market deals, those of $250 million and less, are continuing to get done because they are much less dependent on public offerings of subordinated debt _ that is, on junk bonds,'' Lloyd Greif, vice chairman of the San Francisco-based investment firm Sutro & Co., said at a conference of regional brokerages earlier this month. But securities industry analysts caution that investors shouldn't expect instant profits from brokerage firms. Wall Street is in a recession, and there are no indications it will end soon. The message: Beware of bulls. ``The brokerage industry is characterized by its optimism and enthusiasm,'' said analyst John Keefe of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``There's a tendency on the part of management to think the next market turn is just around the corner.''

DOC.HEAD: Bigger Than Defense Budget, Business Entertainment Grows in Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: A minor executive of an immensely powerful Japanese bank invites you for a nightcap at ``his bar,'' where pretty young women in leather miniskirts pour your whiskey. Three hours later the banker takes care of the $620 tab by handing the cashier a business card. As you walk into the neon glare of Tokyo's Ginza, you wonder how the home office will react when you try to return the hospitality. Welcome to the moderate end of business entertainment in Japan. Dinner for four at a swank ``ryotei'' restaurant _ where geisha entertain with mournful ballads and witty stories while diners feast on prawns so fresh they wriggle on the plate _ can cost $6,900. Yet many Japanese companies expect their executives to entertain clients several nights a week at such restaurants and hostess bars. In 1989, the cost of entertaining climbed 8.7 percent to a record $31 billion, says the National Tax Administration, surpassing the $29 billion budgeted for Japan's defense. The rise occurred despite a call from the Keidanren, a leading business group, for restraint in the aftermath of the notorious Recruit affair, a scandal over alleged bribery of numerous politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen. The money is spent not so much on closing deals as on building close relationships. ``Without liquor Japanese can't be frank,'' said Kazutaka Nakamura, an accountant who has crunched the numbers on expense accounts. ``It's a national characteristic.'' For small companies, entertainment expenses can make up 20 percent to 30 percent of project costs, he said. The practice can hobble a foreign enterprise in Japan. Robert J. Collins, president of the American Club in Japan and author of the satiric novel ``Max Danger, The Adventures of an Ex-Pat in Tokyo,'' cites golf as evidence. ``If a guy is really laying it on ... golf can easily run to half a million yen ($3,500).'' Laying it on may include sending a limousine or even a helicopter for the guest and providing luxury accommodations by the green, he said. Even a ``no-frills golf excursion during the weekdays'' costs about $1,000, said Collins, who has been an insurance executive and head hunter during his 12 years in Japan. Expense is not the only burden. With traffic jams snarling Tokyo highways every weekend, ``You go out there the night before, stay up late drinking, get up at dawn and go out in the rain and play all day long. ``Then you drive four hours back to Tokyo and never once has anyone said a word about business.'' Collins said the object is to endure an ordeal together. Afterwards, he said, ``I can get on the phone to a company chairman and he'll come out of a meeting to talk to his golfing buddy.'' After-hours entertainment follows tediously predictable patterns, Collins said: ``Mutual appreciation over dinner, then some gossip. Then you move onto ... a hostess bar. There's a `karaoke' (sing-along) machine and four or five girls.'' For hours, ``You sing and drink. Names get shortened.'' Finally, he said, ``You go home sick and show up the next day at work complaining, `God, I had to stay out 'til three in the morning.''' The effort can create ``a bond stronger than any contract,'' though a company may have to absorb losses for a few years in hopes of long-term profits. Spending into the red on entertainment is hard to explain to management or shareholders overseas, but it is a way to enter Japan's tightly knit business circles and help find a market for an import. As wives are never included in such activities, the family life of Western businessmen suffers. For women inside Japan's corporate world, business entertainment often means pouring tea during the day and whiskey after hours. Anastasia Morgan, 23, of Seattle, left a Japanese advertising firm recently after finding her position as an assistant account executive was short on substance and long on entertainment. She accepted serving tea to visitors as part of the job but found that accompanying guests to hostess bars galled her. While young hostesses flirted with the men, Ms. Morgan was expected to make pleasant conversation. ``There was a little bit of hanky-panky involved,'' she said. ``It was done in good taste, but you could sense the lust around you. As a woman, I didn't want to see that.'' She went along with it for a year and a half because, ``I came to learn from Japan, not to change it.'' Pausing, she added, ``I learned to deal with leches.'' Sometimes the lechery becomes a commercial transaction. One Japanese businessman, speaking on condition of anonymity, admitted he had been offered sex with a prostitute as a business gift. Tapping his wedding ring, he said ``It happens, but we don't talk about it.'' For most businessmen, however, entertainment means a numbing cycle of meals, drinks and golf. Takehiko Yamaguchi, formerly an executive of Marubeni Corp., says that while in the trading house's steel export division, he ``found it a bit tough'' to entertain two or three times a week. Yamaguchi, now a senior analyst at the Japan Institute for Social and Economic Affairs, added: ``Japanese businessmen are not so very pleased to entertain every night, but (it) is traditional. It will not change in the near future.''

DOC.HEAD: Salmon Farmers Plow Into Profits of Northwest Fishermen
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The history of salmon-fishing in the stormy North Pacific is filled with tales of brave fishermen riding the wild seas, but its future is being shaped in calmer waters. Thousands of salmon in this sheltered arm of Puget Sound are captives in sunken pens the size of basketball courts. Crowded fin to fin, they swim endless laps, gobbling feed pellets and being fattened toward the day they'll be scooped up and whisked to market. Yet while the crenulated coastline and pristine waters that stretch from Washington's Puget Sound to southeastern Alaska might be ideal for fish farming, the political climate is not so welcoming. In Alaska, where commercial fishermen are a powerful lobby, bumper stickers in fishing towns proclaim ``Real Fish Don't Eat Pellets,'' and the Legislature is considering a permanent ban on fish farms when a two-year moratorium expires in July. In Washington state, salmon farmers have the official blessing of the Legislature, but that has helped little in the face of challenges from fishermen and environmental groups, which have defeated several proposed farms. The fish waste produced by a two-acre salmon farm is equivalent to the sewage produced by a town of 5,000 people, claims a Washington citizens group called the Marine Environmental Consortium. Environmentalists also fear introduced species such as Atlantic salmon _ favored because they fetch a higher price and are more docile than Pacific salmon _ will corrupt the local gene pool and spread disease. Wealthy owners of shoreside homes, meanwhile, don't want fish farms spoiling their views. Promoters call fish farming an efficient way to help meet the world's growing appetite for fish. Not only does it provide a year-round supply of fresh salmon to supplement the seasonal wild catch, they say, it also creates jobs free of the hazards of commercial fishing, one of the nation's most dangerous occupations. They also contend salmon-farming provides an economic incentive to preserve clean water. ``We're the best environmentalists of all, because we're dependent on it,'' said Jerry Polley, site manager for Global Aqua, the nation's largest salmon farm. ``If something's wrong with the water quality, we're going to be the first to complain.'' Production of farmed salmon, here and abroad, has boomed in five years, flooding markets traditionally held by wild salmon and driving down prices. ``For the first couple of years, as more salmon was around on a year-round basis, the farmed fish seemed to help the wild market,'' said commercial fisherman Randy Babich. ``Now it's a battle at the retail counter.'' Fish farming, or aquaculture, is hardly a new concept. For years, farmers have raised oysters in the Northwest, rainbow trout in Idaho and catfish in the Southeast. But techniques have developed more slowly in domesticating salmon, the mainstay of fisheries off Oregon, Washington, British Columbia and Alaska. For years, it was practiced only by the Norwegians, forced into salmon farming by their declining wild fish populations. But interest has spread quickly since 1985, after Norway refined methods to raise salmon cheaply enough to compete with the wild catch. In 1983, world production of farmed salmon was 23,500 metric tons, just 3 percent of the 670,000-ton wild salmon catch. By last year, farmed salmon production had soared to an estimated 202,000 tons, or 30 percent of the relatively constant wild catch. Norway still leads the pack, producing about 75 percent of the world's farmed salmon, but other places, including Scotland, Chile, Canada and Iceland, are catching up. The United States, with 50 fish farms in Washington state and Maine, lags far behind, producing 1 percent of the total. Many of the U.S. salmon farms are run by Norwegian companies, including Global Aqua's four-acre operation in Rich Passage, 10 miles west of Seattle. Global Aqua's farm is fairly typical: a huge raft anchored offshore holds 40 pens, each lined with a net holding up to 15 tons of fish, which range from finger-size smolts to fat-bellied salmon 2 feet long. A half-dozen workers tend the pens from metal walkways, filling automatic feeders and mending nets. At harvest, workers herd fish into one end of the pens, scoop them out with an oversize dipnet and load them onto a boat. The salmon are still kicking when they reach a Seattle processing plant 30 minutes away. In the three years it takes to raise salmon to harvest, farmers contend with prowling otters, hungry sea lions and diseases that can wipe out whole farms if left unchecked. Aquaculturists say their operations will never be a major blot on the coastline. ``It would take just 40 acres of farms to produce all of the salmon that was imported into the United States in 1988,'' said Chris Gibson of Sea Farm Washington in Port Angeles. ``The industry does not need a lot of space.'' It may need even less space in coming months. Worldwide growth of salmon farming and recent overproduction in Norway have glutted the market with fish. Prices have plunged, and many farms are selling below cost just to keep cash flowing. In British Columbia, lax regulation and a surge of Norwegian investment capital helped the number of fish farms soar from five to 135 in the last six years. But now many are in trouble. Nineteen have filed for receivership in the past year, and small businesses are being bought out by large investors better able to outlast the lull in prices. Aquaculture boosters profess confidence in their long-term place in the salmon trade. Declining stocks of wild salmon already have forced Northwest fishermen to rely more heavily on fish that are started in shoreside hatcheries and released to sea. About 23 percent of Alaska's ``wild'' catch now comes from hatcheries, while some salmon populations off Washington's coast are 60 percent hatchery-reared. ``We're not going to re-establish the wild resource. You just don't have the habitat for them to come back to,'' said John Pitts, who promotes aquaculture for the Washington Department of Agriculture. ``Future generations will become more dependent on aquaculture.'' Perhaps, but as long as any wild salmon remain, some independent-minded fishermen will take their chances on the high seas rather than turn in their rain slickers for bags of fish chow. ``It's the Cro-Magnon in us,'' said Randy Babich. ``Fishing is one of the last hunting-gathering professions in the world. Tossing feed into a pond just doesn't provide the same adventure.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: David Foster is the AP Northwest regional reporter, based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: One Expert's Views on How It Happened
LaserPhoto WX14 of Feb. 9
DOC.TEXT: Carl Gershman, whose job is fostering the spread of democracy around the world, has it easy these days. Democracy is fostering itself. When Gershman wrote the annual report of the organization he heads, the National Endowment for Democracy, he warned of democracy's vulnerabilities and of setbacks here and there. But nothing could hide one triumphant fact. The ``central reality'' of these times, he wrote, is that ``throughout the world millions of people are striving to establish and secure democratic systems based upon peaceful political competition, the rule of law, a free market economy and respect for basic human rights.'' The endowment, created by Congress in 1983 at Ronald Reagan's suggestion, draws its money from the government but is administered privately. It receives less than $20 million a year, small change in Washington. It doles out grants _ as little as a few thousand dollars, as much as $1 million to Solidarity in Poland in 1988 _ to bolster democracy where it is tender or to support independent groups in closed societies. In an interview, in his year-end report and in an essay, Gershman offered one expert's view of how the worldwide assertion of the democratic spirit happened to occur at this time. He thinks he can pinpoint the crucial place and moment: Portugal in the mid-1970s. At that moment, Gershman said, democracy seemed to be in retreat. America, democracy's bastion, was experiencing self-doubt, the Vietnam malaise. Intellectuals argued over whether the United States should support right-wing authoritarian regimes if they were opposed to left-wing totalitarian regimes, ``a debate which was based upon the assumption that the best we could hope for was the lesser evil,'' said Gershman. Then, in Portugal, the poorest country in Western Europe, bloodied by the loss of its overseas colonies, a military coup overthrew a dicatorship. In the confusion, communists attempted to seize power. But the people injected themselves into the streets _ much as they would do in 1989 in Eastern Europe _ and popular government prevailed. A republic was proclaimed and a constitution adopted. Next door, Spain's dictator, Francisco Franco, a remnant of pre-war fascism, died. A similiar struggle resulted in a parliamentary monarchy. Greece, too, underwent a transition toward democracy. From there, the wind swept through Latin America. Ninety percent of the region's people lived under authoritarian rule at the start of the 1980s; now every country in the hemisphere except Haiti and Cuba has some form of democratic government or is planning elections. Next, of course, the democratic bug descended on Europe: Poland, Hungary, East Germany, Czechoslvakia, Romania and within the Soviet borders themselves. In Asia, the uprisings were less successful, brutally suppressed in China and Burma, but their occurrence, Gershman said, ``should erase any remaining doubts about the appeal of the democratic idea in the non-Western world.'' While Gershman does not claim that these events are linked _ that the overthrow of the 18-year rule of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner in Paraguay last year somehow precipitated the street uprisings of Eastern Europe _ he does conclude that they did not occur in isolation, either. ``Events have a momentum of their own and no country can be shielded from the sweep of historical forces,'' he said. Several historical forces coincided to drive democracy forward on a global scale, he said, among them: _The scientific and technological revolution, which rigid political systems could not assimilate. _The communications revolution, which makes for rising expectations. _The tendency toward a world economy, which subjects governments to the discipline of the market. _The human rights revolution of the 1970s, which ``spread the view that all individuals have rights that governments must respect.'' With that idea fixed, ``you need to find a way in which people can live together in peace, to negotiate differences without violence,'' Gershman said. ``The alternative to democracy is simply the imposition of tyrannical force, and that doesn't work very well. It produces a lot of deaths, it doesn't produce economic growth, it means one group ruling over another and the other resorting to violence because they've been excluded.''

DOC.TEXT: A rundown from the annual report of the National Endowment for Democracy on the events that were part of the ``resurgence of democracy'' in 1989: _``Mass demonstrations in China and the erection of the Goddess of Democracy statue in Tiananmen Square.'' _``An election in Poland swept by Solidarity and eventuating in the Soviet bloc's first non-Communist government.'' _``A hero's burial for Imre Nagy, the executed leader of the 1956 Hungarian Revolution.'' _``Millions linking hands across the Baltics on the 50th anniversary of the Hitler-Stalin Pact.'' _``Throngs rejoicing atop the Berlin Wall after the East German government effectively abolished that notorious symbol of Communist oppression.'' _``The resignation of the Stalinist regime in Czechoslovakia under pressure from hundreds of thousands of demonstrators demanding the restoration of democracy.'' _``The overthrow of the Stroessner dictatorship in Paraguay, the Ceausescu dictatorship in Romania and the Noriega dictatorship in Panama.'' _``The most open election in the history of the Soviet Union.'' _``The peaceful demise of the Pinochet dictatorship in Chile.'' _``Free elections in Namibia.'' _``A legal opposition contesting elections for the first time in Taiwan.'' _``The peaceful transfer of power following sharply contested elections in India and Brazil, the Third World's two largest democracies.''

And these were some of the setbacks: _``The bloody suppression of the democracy movement in China.'' _``The use of poison gas against peaceful demonstrators in Soviet Georgia.'' _``Violent uprisings against democratically elected governments in El Salvador and the Philippines.'' _``The violent disruption of opposition election rallies in Nicaragua.'' _``The bloody suppression of demonstrations in Romania.'' _``And in El Salvador, Colombia, Peru and elsewhere the murder of priests, journalists, politicians and peasants by terrorists and death squads.''
