DOC.HEAD: Australian Tycoon Loses Court Fight Over Brewing
DOC.TEXT: Alan Bond lost a month-long court battle to save his lucrative brewing interests from receivership, dealing a further blow to the embattled Australian tycoon's crumbling empire. The Supreme Court of the state of Victoria said Friday that Bond Brewing Holdings had made a deliberate decision to keep people with any knowledge of the affairs of the Bond group away from the court. The court also found it extraordinary that the company had deliberately excluded relevant material from the case. On Dec. 29, the court appointed receivers and managers to several of Bond Corp.'s brewing interests at the request of the National Australia Bank Ltd., which was acting as agent for a syndicate of banks that is owed about $660 million by the Bond group. The court said the banking syndicate was entirely justified in seeking receivers for Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd., Bond Brewing Investments Pty. Ltd., Swan Brewery Co., Castlemaine Perkins Ltd., Tooheys Ltd. and BBH Securities Pty. Ltd. The banks had claimed that Bond Brewing Holdings had broken several convenants of a loan agreement. The court said evidence heard in January's month-long court battle reinforced its original decision. Bond, whose interests also span media, property and natural resources, is estimated to have debts of more than $6 billion.

Prices in the credit markets rose sharply despite weak demand for 30-year bonds in the long-awaited final leg of the government's quarterly refunding auction. The Treasury Department on Thursday received just $18.4 billion in bids for $10 billion of bonds, in what had been termed a critical auction because of fears that foreign institutions would not play their normal active role. The average yield on the 30-year bonds was 8.50 percent, up from 7.87 percent at the last comparable auction on Nov. 14. It was the highest rate since 30-year bonds averaged 9.11 percent on May 11.

Americans took out $4.91 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in December, pushing total consumer debt up 6 percent for the year, the Federal Reserve said. The Fed said Thursday that consumer credit in December advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.3 percent, up from November's revised 7.8 percent increase.

OMAHA, Neb. _ President Bush told a corn-country audience that he hopes a trade agreement with the Soviet Union can be negotiated by the time of his summer summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, ``expanding markets for American exports'' and helping the Soviet Union. Bush talked Thursday of his hopes for a trade agreement, a goal he and Gorbachev set in their meeting at Malta last December, in a state keenly interested in selling grain to the Soviets.

IBM is expected to roll out a new line of computer workstations next week aimed at claiming a stake in one of the industry's fastest-growing markets, a segment where the computer giant never has shined. Industry analysts said Thursday they are impressed by details of the new line that have appeared in trade journals. ``It will be as good as if not superior to anything on the market,'' said Stephen Cohen, research director for SoundView Finanical Group Inc., a high-tech research firm in Stamford, Conn.

A federal judge handed Georgia-Pacific Corp. a victory in its bid to buy Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., ruling that it will take just a two-thirds vote by Great Northern shareholders to oust the paper company's directors. Great Northern's bylaws called for a three-fourths vote, but U.S. District Judge Gene Carter agreed Thursday with Georgia-Pacific that the higher number ran afoul of Maine corporate law. The judge also struck down two other portions of Great Northern's bylaws, which allowed outgoing directors to name a new board and called for a 90-day nomination period for new directors.

Mazda Motor Corp. introduced a two-door, four-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle made by Ford Motor Co. as other automakers enter the popular market segment with four-door versions. The popularity of the four-door versions has zoomed recently, with each of the Big Three and some Japanese competitors getting into the market.

Rather than calming fears of economic collapse in East Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's advocacy of one currency for East and West Germany has created worries about continued prosperity at home. Economists and investors have reacted negatively to Kohl's proposal for swift introduction of the West German mark in East Germany. Some accuse him of trying to boost his chances in the December elections. Fear that taking over the East's nearly bankrupt system would endanger the West German economy drove bond prices down Thursday for the third straight day. The mark has dropped two pfennigs against the weak U.S. dollar in two days.

Japanese banks may have a lion's share of the international banking business, but they now must come to grips with the same problems that hammered many big U.S. banks in the last decade: bad Third World loans, rising interest rates and a potential downturn in their domestic real estate market. ``It's clear the Japanese banks will be pressured to take on a more philanthropic role,'' Simon Smithson, an analyst with Kleinwort Benson Securities, said Thursday of Japan's Third World debt exposure.

The sanctions Congress imposed against South Africa in 1986 took a stiff economic and psychological toll on the white government and helped encourage reforms, a wide spectrum of experts say. ``International trade sanctions alone have probably resulted in a $2 billion loss annually to the South African economy,'' Stephen R. Lewis Jr., author of ``The Economics of Apartheid,'' said Thursday. Fewer than 1 percent of all South Africans are employed by U.S. companies.

Blue-chip stocks posted some small gains Thursday, but prices finished narrowly mixed in the broader market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 4.28 points to close at 2,644.37. The dollar ended mostly higher as the soaring West German mark ran out of steam. Gold prices rose slightly after falling overseas. Bond prices rose sharply. Coffee futures prices rose; oil futures were mixed; precious metals advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Murdoch Magazines Plans Video Program for Beauty Salons
DOC.TEXT: Murdoch Magazines, a division of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. Ltd., plans to make available commercially sponsored programming for use in beauty salons starting in June. It would be the first regularly scheduled video program from Murdoch Magazines, and the first video entertainment program aimed at reaching clients of beauty salons, the company said Thursday. Phillip Cassidy, director of special projects at Murdoch Magazines, said his company hopes to sign up at least 3,000 beauty salons reaching 2 to 2.5 million women for the launch of the service. But while creating television programs for people getting their hair done may be new, the concept of trying to reach people in unusual settings is not. A number of media companies have come up with magazines, sponsored posters and video programs designed to reach patients in waiting rooms, pet owners at the veterinarians and students at school. In what may be the most controversial commercial video project to date, Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn., plans to launch its Channel One daily news show with commercials next month in more than 1,000 classrooms across the country. The service has been vilified as an unjustified intrusion on the rights of students who are required by law to be in school. The Murdoch Magazines project is not likely to cause any such uproar. Cassidy said the service, called Salon Network, would consist of a bi-monthly program of 30 to 40 minutes drawing on health, fashion, beauty and other stories that appear in its Mirabella, New Woman, Seventeen, Premiere and European Travel & Life magazines. He said the programs would be distributed on two-hour videocassettes to beauty shops that already have their own videocasette recorders and television monitors. The salons would be expected to air the tapes for four hours a day. A new program would be made available every other month. Each program would contain 7{ to 10 minutes of commercials, 5 minutes of which would be sold to advertisers and the remaining time used to promote services available at particular salons. Murdoch said its production partner in the venture is TeleTime Inc., a privately-owned production company based in Great Neck, N.Y., that has previously created programs in beauty shops for individual sponsors. Cassidy said he has been presenting the plan to advertisers for about a week and plans to begin showing it to beauty salon operators next month. No clients have been signed yet, he said. The advertising rates will be $20,000 for a 30-second commercial. The promotions will be run for free. Cassidy said that if the program proves successful, Murdoch Magazines would probably begin offering advertisers the chance to buy packages that include ad space in magazines and commercial time on Salon Network starting next year.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda Moves into Sport-Utility Market
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Corp. has entered the already crowded four-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle market with a two-door version at a time when other automakers are shifting to four-door models. Mazda officials said Thursday that dealers will begin selling the Navajo sport-utility vehicle this fall. It will compete against a swelling number of entries from companies hoping to grab part of one of the few market segments forecast to grow in the early 1990s. Unlike other companies, Mazda, which calls itself a ``targeted niche marketer,'' will sell only a two-door vehicle, made by Ford Motor Co. beside its new Explorer. ``We simply can't afford not to be in this market,'' said Clark Vitulli, general manager of Mazda's U.S. marketing arm. The popularity of the four-door vehicles has zoomed recently, with each of the Big Three and some Japanese competitors getting into the market. Most of the four-door buyers rarely, if ever, take the vehicles off the road, an original selling point for Jeeps and others. Generally, four-door sport-utility vehicles are seen as appealing to families while two-door versions are more likely to be used in the back country. Mazda's Navajo, the Japanese company's first sport-utility vehicle for U.S. dealers, will be built at Ford's light-truck assembly plant in Louisville, Ky. Ford began building its Explorer there Monday. Ford officials said about 70 percent of the 200,000 or so Explorers it intends to sell annually will have four doors. Mazda, which plans to sell less than 20,000 Navajos a year, is banking that families shopping for four-wheel-drive vehicles will head to its minivan, called the MPV. ``We concluded the MPV is a better way to serve this customer,'' Vitulli said. Sport-utility vehicles made up 14.5 percent of the light truck segment last year, up tremendously from 1982 when they had just 1.5 percent. Manufacturers and analysts expect sport-utility vehicles and minivans will gain in popularity while other parts of the total vehicle market shrink. Vitulli projected the sport-utility vehicle segment alone will grow by 24 percent by 1992. Over the past few months, Ford, General Motors Corp., Toyota Motor Corp. and Nissan Motor Co. Ltd. have introduced four-door vehicles to compete with four-door Jeeps, the market leader made by Chrysler Corp. There will be only slight differences between the Navajo and the Explorer, mostly in some interior and exterior styling and larger bumpers on Mazda's version. Prices have not been set for either vehicle. The sport-utility project is the second U.S. vehicle manufacturing agreement between Ford and Mazda. Ford gets its Probe cars from Mazda's plant in Flat Rock, Mich. Mazda's introduction came during a media preview of the Chicago Auto Show, which opens Saturday. Also on Thursday: _Ford introduced its 1991 Escort GT and Mercury Tracer cars. They are the products of an engineering cooperation between Mazda and Ford. Ford said it wants to sell more than 400,000 Escorts and Tracers in 1991. Escorts will be made in Wayne, Mich., and Tracers will be assembled in Hermosillo, Mexico. The government will classify Tracers as domestic vehicles because more than 75 percent of each car is made in the United States. _Robert Rewey, Ford's vice president for North American sales, said the company had reduced its new-car inventories into the 60-to 70-day range, about normal for this time of year. GM and Chrysler plan indefinite plant shutdowns during the next seven weeks, which will result in thousands of auto workers being laid off. Each of the nation's Big Three automakers shut down assembly plants in January for a week or more at a time. ``I believe that the inventory correction that we planned was essentially completed at the end of January,'' Rewey said.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Group to Mount Avon Proxy Fight
DOC.TEXT: A group of powerful investors including the owners of Mary Kay Cosmetics and a Getty family trust says it plans to launch a proxy fight to win four seats on the board of Avon Products Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday, Chartwell Associates, a limited partnership, also disclosed it had increased its stake in Avon, a New York-based cosmetics company, to 9.1 percent. Chartwell said it favored a sale of Avon but ruled out any intention to seek a merger of Avon and Mary Kay Cosmetics. John Cox, a spokesman for Avon, which twice rejected unsought takeover bids last year, said the company had no comment. Partners in Chartwell Associates include the Fisher real estate family of New York as well as the family trust of oil heir Gordon P. Getty and a subsidiary of Dallas-based Mary Kay Corp., the parent of Mary Kay Cosmetics. In its filing, Chartwell said it plans to solicit proxies from Avon shareholders to nominate four persons for the 11-member Avon board. A proxy battle is an attempt by a person or group to take over a company or oust its management by obtaining enough proxies _ the legal right to exercise a shareholder's vote _ to influence a corporate election. In this case the battle is over Chartwell's belief that Avon shareholders ``would best be served by a sale of the company,'' a view Chartwell said was not shared by Avon's board. The Chartwell filing continued that the partnership ``may submit a proposal for a merger or similar transaction'' between Avon and one of the entities of Chartwell Associates or an affiliate _ other than Mary Kay. ``In no event, however, will Mary Kay or Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. merge with the company (Avon) nor will the sales forces of the company and MKCI be integrated or combined with each other in any manner whatsoever,'' the filing said. The document said Chartwell has purchased 5.16 million shares of Avon for a total of $173.4 million since November.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Apparently Borrows more than $700 Million
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp.'s cash crisis apparently hasn't abated despite the recent sale of more than $1.1 billion in assets, an analyst says. The Federal Reserve Bank of Boston, considered the lender of last resort for banks, reported Thursday that it loaned an unusually high amount of $723 million to member banks this week. Marcia Ryan, a Bank of New England spokeswoman, confirmed that the bank borrowed money from the Federal Reserve. She declined to give the amount, except to say it was ``slightly above last week.'' ``Our borrowing was as we expected it to be,'' she said. Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc., said Bank of New England likely was the prime borrower, and he said the numbers were particularly troubling because until this week the bank appeared to have gained more control over its problems. Two weeks ago, the Boston Fed loaned $478 million, and last week the figure dropped to $440 million. At the same time, Bank of New England has completed asset sales of more than $1.1 billion. ``It means the situation is still bleeding,'' Cassidy said. Bank of New England reported last month that its 1989 losses should exceed $1 billion, largely because of bad real estate loans. The bank has been trying to sell $6 billion of assets to raise cash, after watching depositors withdraw millions of dollars. Ryan noted that the bank has not received all the proceeds from its recent asset sales, though she could not say specifically how much money the bank has collected. In comparison with recent Boston Fed lending totals, the weekly figures from mid-December to mid-January ranged from $1 million to $5 million, said Herb Wass, a Federal Reserve spokesman. The Federal Reserve does not identify the institutions borrowing the money. Wass stressed that the loans normally are repaid within a day and do not accumulate. Earlier in the day, it was announced that The Bank of Tokyo had restructured a deal to buy part of Bank of New England's leasing business after the Japanese company became concerned about the bank's troubles. Under the new agreement, Bank of New England will sell Bank of Tokyo its BancNewEngland Leasing Group operations and $500 million of its lease portfolio, and record a profit of $92.5 million. The original terms of the agreement announced last November would have given Bank of New England a $110 million gain. ``Bank of Tokyo expressed concern about Bank of New England, given the publicity the last few weeks,'' said Tom Lavelle, a bank spokesman. ``There's been some give and take on both sides.'' Lavelle noted that under the new agreement, Bank of Tokyo will cut by 20 percent the cost to service a $1 billion leasing portfolio retained by Bank of New England. ``The revised terms of the sale do not change the advantages to us of the previously announced transaction,'' H. Ridgely Bullock, the bank's interim chairman, said in a statement. ``The transaction will help improve our capital ratios and will raise in excess of $500 million in cash.'' Bullock said he hoped to complete the transaction ``within the next several weeks.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Makes It Easier For Georgia-Pacific To Oust Great Northern Board
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge's ruling that just a two-thirds vote by shareholders can oust Great Northern Nekoosa Corp.'s directors was hailed by Georgia-Pacific Corp. as a major victory in its $3.8 billion takeover attempt. ``We are delighted with the court's decision,'' said Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. ``This is one more important advance in bringing Georgia-Pacific closer to completing this acquisition, which we believe is best for Great Northern shareholders, employees and communities in which they operate.'' A Great Northern spokesman declined to predict whether directors will be able to survive a March 2 proxy vote in light of U.S. District Judge Gene Carter's decision, which lowered the percentage of votes needed to oust the board from three-fourths to two-thirds. ``We're disappointed, and we certainly are going to study what he had to say, and then we'll decide how to react to it,'' Great Northern spokesman Stephen M. Hill said from his office in Norwalk, Conn. Carter agreed with Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific that the three-fourths requirement in Great Northern's bylaws ran afoul of Maine corporate law. The judge also struck down two more portions of the company's bylaws that allowed outgoing directors to name a new board and called for a 90-day nomination period for new directors. Great Northern's board has been fighting the takeover attempt, but Georgia-Pacific succeeded in forcing next month's special shareholders meeting in Portland. Georgia-Pacific contends that Great Northern's directors are resisting the takeover offer so they can hold onto their own high-paying jobs at the expense of shareholders. Despite Thursday's setback, Great Northern still hopes to persuade the judge to block Georgia-Pacific's effort to oust its board. The judge plans to hear oral arguments Monday on that motion. Great Northern also hopes to block the hostile tender offer on grounds including allegations that Georgia-Pacific has violated federal securities laws by covering up plans to sell Maine assets should the deal go through.

DOC.HEAD: Fun With Food
DOC.TEXT: An advertising company that uses all the tricks of the trade to boost consumer appetites for raw agricultural products believes in a fun food fight. Ketchum Communications Inc. leads a growing number of firms battling old images to give people a new and, at times, humorous, way of thinking about food staples. Prunes, for example. They shouldn't remind you of something you'd most likely find at grandma's house. Ketchum touted them as ``high fiber fruit.'' Or raisins. Instead of gobbling them straight from the box, Ketchum advises adding them to citrus juice and dabbing the mixture on a slice of salmon for a ``pink lady.'' Ketchum's campaign pushing beef as ``real food for real people'' is probably its best known one. It used Hollywood stars to tell consumers that meat can be low calorie and packed with protein. Pittsburgh-based Ketchum, with offices in San Francisco and several other major cities, claims the largest client list of commodity boards of any advertising and public relations company in the United States. The agency believes says food producers need new strategies to get their goods into the modern kitchen, where the microwave is king and old-fashioned cooking techniques are becoming obsolete. ``American home life has taken to the fast lane,'' Ketchum spokesman Phil Siegel says. ``With a growing need to do everything quickly, longstanding traditions, like baking, are being lost. And the marketers of certain food staples are now forced to rethink strategies and inspire consumers to use traditional products in non-traditional ways. After all, how can baking ingredients, like walnuts and raisins, be sold to a country of non-bakers?'' The nation's more than 200 commodity boards consist of farmers, shippers and distributors of food products _ from salmon to wild rice _ that unite to market their products. Dianne Snedaker, president of Ketchum's San Francisco ad division, said the firm's commodity business has tripled in the last five years and accounted for nearly $200 million of its $750 million in billings last year. The Beef Industry Council, Ketchum's largest commodity client, has increased its marketing budget eightfold since 1981 to $35 million, for example. The growth should slow because the number of boards is limited and Ketchum's contracts with some, like the beef council, prohibit the firm from accepting rival clients, like the chicken or pork boards. Still, Snedaker predicts further growth in billings this decade. ``I have always considered them the premiere public relations agency for food in the United States,'' said Robert Phinney, director of the California Raisin Advisory Board. His group became a household word overnight after its advertising agency _ Foote, Cone & Belding _ created the California Dancing Raisins in 1985. Ketchum later created human models for the characters that toured the nation, even getting invited to President Bush's inaugural parade. ``Ketchum made a concerted effort 20 years ago to be pioneers by taking the (marketing) expertise from the rest of the food industry and bringing it to commodity groups,'' said Phinney, whose board was Ketchum's first commodity client in 1971. Ketchum's clients list also includes the California Strawberry Advisory Board, California Prune Board, the Peanut Advisory Board, the Wisconsin Milk Marketing board, Norway Sardines, the American Egg Board and the National Mushroom Growers Association. The key to finding a new image for food staples is keeping track of how people eat. Snedaker says company research shows that a remarkable number of people eat while standing up. Allen Miller, executive vice president of Ketchum's public relations division, says food marketers find many people have grown up with little cooking experience because of the advent of the microwaves and fast foods. ``You've got to show these people how to quickly and easily make a meal out of something you don't necessarily take out of a package,'' Miller said. Take potatoes. Ketchum has been trying to boost sales for the $2 billion American potato crop by calling them the ideal fast-food in the age of the microwave. Magazine advertisements tout the vegetable's ``smooth skin'' and ``luscious curves.'' ``Aerodynamically designed for speed,'' it is the perfect alternative to food like pasta, one ad stresses. Ketchum has sponsored food preparation demonstrations by cooking experts in stores and on television shows to show how to prepare potatoes and other food staples in the microwave, other than just baking. Ketchum also runs a food research center, where it experiments with new ways for producers to capture greater slices of the $220 billion annual food service industry. The center worked on walnuts, finely grinding them to invent a creamy walnut smear for bakery use. It also formulated chocolate-covered walnuts that withstand freezing and created a walnut additive for ice cream. By creating American versions of traditional Japanese recipes, Ketchum was able to help increase sales of Kikkoman soy sauce by 25 percent during the first year of a marketing program, according to Kaz Takei, a Kikkoman International Inc. vice president.

DOC.HEAD: Loans Totaling $700 Million Expected to Get Judge's Approval
DOC.TEXT: A federal bankruptcy judge indicated that Federated Department Stores Inc. would get approval for a $400 million loan before a ``drop dead'' bank deadline, enabling the retailer to keep its shelves stocked. After more than eight hours of testimony Thursday and a last-minute compromise proposed by Federated's unsecured creditors, U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. said he would review the agreement and sign it today. A similar proposal by Federated's sister retailer, Allied Stores Corp., to borrow $300 million from Chemical Bank of New York was expected to face no opposition at a hearing today, attorneys for Federated told Aug. The $400 million debtor-in-possession loan from a 90-bank syndicate led by Citibank would be in addition to a $1 billion financing package allowing Federated to sell credit card receipts to a subsidiary, Federated Credit Corp. The credit division wasn't among those that filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors Jan. 15 with Federated and Allied. ``There was a great deal of testimony today that provided the committee with information that had not been available previously,'' said Lewis Rosenbloom, a lawyer for the committee of unsecured creditors. ``It permitted the committee to better understand the consequences involved, and we also were able to make some changes in debtor's proposal to give the creditors greater assurances,'' he said. The committee also withdrew its opposition to the $1 billion receivables. In return, Federated gave the unsecured creditors ``substantial protections,'' Rosenbloom said, including guarantees that all inventory _ which the committee considered excess _ will remain in the estate. Federated also will provide a monthly accounting of all its operating units, he said. Federated and Allied, the U.S. retail division of Toronto-based Campeau Corp., listed $7.7 billion in debt when they filed for Chapter 11 protection. The two divisions employ about 100,000 people and operate 260 stores within nine chains _ Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati, Rich's of Atlanta in the Federated group; and The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa, and Stern's of Paramus, N.J., in the Allied group. Federated treasurer Mark Kennedy testified at the hearing that Federated could not survive more than a month without the infusion of money. He said the retailer had been turned down by other lenders, and that vendors would lose all confidence in Federated if Aug refused to approve the loan. Quick approval was needed to beat Citibank's Feb. 14 deadline. The creditors' committee had opposed the loan, contending that Federated does not need the money and had pledged the creditors' only collateral _ its inventory _ to get the loan. But Kennedy testified that Federated had no contingency plan if approval were denied, and that Federated wouldn't survive the two months it would take to negotiate another loan, providing a lender could be found. ``The company doesn't have 60 days _ 30 days maybe,'' Kennedy said. ``The existence of the loan is mandatory to re-establish our credibility in the eyes of our creditors ... A headline which says `Federated DIP Rejected' would have a disastrous effect.'' Kennedy said failure to get the loan would put Federated in default of the $1 billion receivables arrangement. Creditors had objected to Federated putting its profitable store chains under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Kennedy testified that three of the profitable ones _ Bloomingdale's, Burdines and Rich's _ were worth more than $1 billion each and probably could be liquidated to pay creditors full value for their goods. But he said although Federated has $858 million in inventory and $250 million cash on hand, forcing Federated to spend all its cash to buy merchandise would ensure its demise. ``The biggest losers would be the creditors of this company,'' Kennedy said. One of the provisions of the loan is that Federated cannot borrow more than 40 percent of the wholesale value of its inventory, meaning that Federated could borrow the full $400 million only if it had $1 billion in inventory.

DOC.HEAD: S&P Lowers Sears Bond Rating
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. says Sears, Roebuck and Co. deserves a lower debt rating because of the weak performance of its retailing business. S&P said Thursday it was lowering its ratings of Sears' long-term bonds and commercial paper. The downgrade implies lowered confidence in the company's ability to repay its debts. It is S&P's second downgrade of Sears debt instruments since the retailing giant announced a new merchandising strategy in October 1988. At least two other bond-rating companies, Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Duff & Phelps Inc., also have downgraded Sears debt ratings since the switch to ``everyday low pricing'' was announced. Sears spokesman Douglas Fairweather declined comment on the downgrade. On Monday, Chicago-based Sears released fourth-quarter and annual results that were slightly better than expected but still showed a decline in merchandise-group earnings after extraordinary items were excluded. Sears has been battling a decade-long slide in its share of the retail market. The company has pinned its hopes on the switch to everyday low pricing, with competitive prices year-round and fewer sales. ``The downgrade reflects a slower-than-expected recovery in Sears' retailing operations, despite the implementation of a costly and comprehensive strategy to arrest a steady deterioration in that core business,'' S&P said in a statement. The rating firm said Sears' overall financial condition was strong and its financial-services businesses _ Dean Witter brokerage services, Allstate insurance and Coldwell Banker real estate _ added diversity and strength. Nevertheless, S&P said its new rating of Sears' debt instruments ``anticipates continued sub-par performance for the next couple of years.'' S&P downgraded Sears' senior long-term debt rating by one notch to A-plus from AA-minus, and lowered its commercial-paper rating one notch to A-1 from A-1-plus. S&P also lowered its debt ratings of the following Sears' subsidiaries: Discover Credit Corp., Sears Overseas Finance N.V. and Sears Roebuck Acceptance Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Former GAO Official Top Choice for Thrift Regulatory Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The former No. 2 official at the General Accounting Office is emerging as the top candidate to replace thrift regulator M. Danny Wall, according to administration, congressional and industry sources. Frederick D. Wolf is known for offering a blunt assessment of the savings and loan industry during 1988, when Wall was offering a more optimistic evaluation. He is backed by Treasury Department officials who worked with him while fashioning President Bush's S&L bailout last year and by senior aides to the Senate Banking Committee, which would have to vote on his confirmation. Wolf has been lobbying for support from members of Congress, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity Thursday. But Wolf's independence and popularity with congressional Democrats may hurt his candidacy, according to two industry officials. The administration must already cope with Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman, who often differs with Treasury officials on regulatory issues. The bailout legislation made Wall's agency, the Office of Thrift Supervision, a wing of the Treasury Department. Also, the thrift office director would sit on Seidman's five-member board, which handles the deposit insurance funds for the S&L and banking industries and governs the Resolution Trust Corp., the S&L bailout agency. ``Wolf's enormously able, outspoken, blunt and understands the issues,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``But, he's an independent force and there's some concern in Treasury about bringing in an independent force.'' However, another industry official said, ``When all is said and done, I don't think they have another choice.'' Wolf did not return a telephone call seeking comment Thursday. About a dozen names of possible successors have circulated, but most have ruled themselves out. Provisions in the S&L bill applying to the RTC would prevent the thrift office director from working for or representing an insured financial institution until two years after leaving office. William Taylor, director of bank supervision for the Federal Reserve System, was asked to consider the thrift office post but opted to stay at his current job, which pays a higher salary and is independent of the administration, according to congressional sources. Another possible candidate is William T. Graham, banking commissioner in North Carolina. A former judge, he was active in Bush's 1980 and 1988 presidential campaigns. According to a government source, Graham was interviewed in Washington for the job. Meanwhile, the administration is coming under increasing pressure to decide on a thrift director soon. The U.S. League of Savings Institutions, and House Banking Committee Chairman Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, have written to Bush urging action. ``I have applauded your `never again' statements about the savings and loan crisis,'' Gonzalez wrote the president earlier this month. ``I am very disappointed that this affirmation has been diminished by allowing regulators _ who share responsibility for the disaster _ to remain in office.'' Wall, who announced his resignation Dec. 4 after harsh criticism from Congress for his handling of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, is anxious to move on, according to his aides. An administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the administration intended to decide on Wall's successor ``in the near future'' and called Wolf ``an extremely capable, experienced person.'' But even if Wolf is selected soon, the clearance process, including FBI checks, could take several months. Before joining the GAO, Wolf, 49, spent 22 years with Arthur Andersen & Co., an accounting firm. He recently left the GAO after six years, including nine months as assistant comptroller general, to become a partner at the Price Waterhouse & Co. accounting firm. The American Banker, a trade publication, first reported Wolf's emergence as the leading candidate for thrift office director earlier this week.

DOC.HEAD: Spill Prompts Demands for Double Hulls, Tough Regulations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The oil slick spreading from the tanker American Trader spilled into politics as officials and environmentalists demanded stronger controls on oil industry operations in coastal waters. ``We need to do something to make sure this doesn't happen again,'' Attorney General John Van de Kamp, a Democratic candidate for governor, told a news conference in Huntington Beach on Thursday. Controller Gray Davis, a member of the California Lands Commission, pledged a state investigation into the 295,000-gallon spill and said his panel would urge Congress to require tankers to be fitted with double hulls. The commission, which regulates oil development in state lands and waters, has declared previously unprotected tracts in state waters off-limits to new drilling. The spill off Huntington Beach renewed debate about requiring a double hull and double bottom on tankers, a move opposed by many oil industry executives because of the higher cost and arguable safety advantages. ``This oil spill is another warning that our legislators are dragging their feet on double-hulled tankers, at great peril to our environment,'' said Dorothy Green, head of Heal the Bay, a local environmental group. A number of officials speculated that a large swell plopped the American Trader onto its own anchor Wednesday, punching a 3-foot hole into the single-hulled ship's bottom as it maneuvered toward an offshore mooring. ``If the information is born out that this tanker lifted up and came down on its own anchor, double-hulling the vessel may well have prevented the spill,'' said Peter Douglas, executive director of the state Coastal Commission. ``The double hull, in this case, could have avoided the spill,'' said Jerry Aspland, president of Arco Marine Inc. and a former ship captain experienced in offshore moorings. But he stressed other factors, including human error, may have played a more significant role in the spill. In Washington, Democratic Rep. George Miller said British Petroleum Oil Shipping Co. USA, which leased the American Trader, has led lobbying against comprehensive oil spill liability legislation pending in Congress. A conference committee is working on differing House and Senate bills to produce a measure both chambers can approve by the March 24 anniversary of the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska's Prince William Sound. The main sticking point concerns double bottoms and double hulls. The House wants them on all tankers calling at U.S. ports with oil or hazardous materials within seven and 15 years, respectively. The Senate bill calls for further study, a position backed by the oil industry. Miller told a news conference that British Petroleum was leading efforts to ``gut the oil spill liability bill.'' That drew a response from Bill Rountree, vice president for federal government affairs with British Petroleum. ``BP America has supported enactment of comprehensive oil spill legislation for close to a decade,'' Rountree said by telephone. ``We support a $1 billion federal fund and increasing liability limits on ship owners.'' Using the American Trader as a backdrop at a beachside news conference, Davis and Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy called on the state Assembly to pass the Oil Spill Prevention and Cleanup Act, which would establish a $500 million reserve, funded by the oil industry, for spill cleanup. Davis said the oil companies to date have indicated they are willing to contribute a total of $10 million to such a fund. The bill would require tankers operating in state waters to be equipped with booms and other cleanup equipment, and require tanker companies to have $400 million in insurance to meet legal costs, said Ed Manning, a McCarthy aide who authored the legislation. Davis said Thursday that had the bill been in effect, British Petroleum could have been required to pay an estimated $25 million penalty to the state. The cleanup and prevention act will be heard Feb. 26 by the state Assembly's Natural Resources Commission, Manning said. Some activists said the spill should remind the nation about the hazards of reliance on oil as an energy source. ``The whole issue is that every gallon of oil we save is one less gallon of oil that must be pumped and transported and one less gallon that can spill,'' said Bob Hattoy, regional director of the Sierra Club of Southern California.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Criticize Democratic Clean Air Negotiators
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists claim Democratic Senate leaders are buckling under to White House pressure and agreeing to too many weakening amendments during closed-door talks on clean air legislation. ``The public health is being negotiated away,'' argued Dan Weiss, who has been following the clean air debate in the Senate for the Sierra Club. Senate leaders and Bush administration officials have been negotiating for more than a week in an attempt to work out a compromise air pollution control bill and avoid a floor fight. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Thursday that he expected the criticism, but said the critics ``should evaluate the final product against current law'' which he said would be greatly strengthened. Mitchell and Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, said that although progress was being made, further discussions are being delayed until after Congress returns from a week-long recess Feb. 20. While tentative agreement has been reached some areas such as curbing toxic and smog-causing pollution by industry, major differences remain over how to reduce urban smog caused by pollution from automobiles. The Senate bill calls for tough second-stage tailpipe controls, while the administration says those provisions are too expensive and favors a phase-in of alternative fuel cars in regions with the dirtiest air. ``We are making progress,'' said Dole, R-Kan., who along with senior White House and Environmental Protection Agency officials has been pushing for the changes sought by President Bush in the closed-door meetings. But various environmental groups argued Thursday that too many strong provisions in the original Senate bill were being negotiated away under White House pressure. ``They're not talking about any strengthening amendments, only weakening ones,'' said Richard Ayres, executive director of the Clean Air Coalition, which is made up of various environmental organizations. ``The longer these negotiations go on, the weaker the bill gets,'' charged Casey Padgett, legislative director for Environmental Action. Both the Senate bill and the administration proposal call for tougher controls on auto pollution and releases of toxic and smog-causing pollution from industrial sources, as well as a 10 million-ton reduction of acid rain pollutants, primarily from electric power plants. The environmentalists criticized a compromise allowing the Environmental Protection Agency to issue a waiver of federal air quality standards for certain areas if the cost of doing so exceeds $5,000 per ton of pollution. Other provisions already agreed upon by the negotiators would no longer automatically require the EPA to impose a clean air plan if local officials were unable or unwilling to do so. Administration officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, called the environmentalists' criticisms groundless. They said the EPA still could disapprove any waiver and that the federal government has never imposed a cleanup program on a community anyway. The officials argued that under the proposal, urban areas still would have to improve their air quality by specific yearly increments, something not now required.

DOC.HEAD: Turf Battle Between Dogs as New York Franks Invade Chicago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: On the baseball diamond, it's Mets versus Cubs. For architects, it's Sears Tower vs. World Trade Center. Now, Nathan's Famous of New York has thrown some fat and other byproducts on the fire of the Chicago-New York rivalry. They're calling it th war of the dogs. Relish the thought: New York-style frankfurters girded against Chi Dogs. It's still too early to tell which wiener can cut the mustard. Nathan's of Westbury, N.Y. _ dating back to 1916 and famous for its hot dog stands on Coney Island's boardwalk and 42nd Street in the Big Apple _ decided last year to open a place in the Windy City, home to 3,000 hot dog stands. It looked like a tough market to crack for the New Yorkers, who say frank when they mean hot dog. But Nathan's marketing research showed that many Chicagoans were familiar with the company's name and would pay extra for a gourmet frank that cost $1.59. ``We figured if we could make it there (Chicago), we could make it anywhere,'' said Larry Feierstein, a vice-president of Nathan's in New York, New York. Frankly, not everyone was throwing out the welcome mat. ``Does Newcastle need coal? Does Alaska need salmon? Does Idaho need potatoes? More than 3,000 hot dog stands in greater, grander metropolitan Chicagoland _ and these people come bearing frankfurters?'' said a tongue-in-cheek editorial from the Chicago Tribune last week. Nevertheless, around Thanksgiving Day, Nathan's Famous opened up shop where Rush Street meets State Street in the heart of this city's glitzy entertainment district. ``I like this place. It's clean, it's bright and it's different,'' said Patrick A. Connolly, 67, a Chicago financier who was smoking a foot-long cigar but carrying a couple of Nathan's regular-sized franks on Wednesday night. ``The taste is out of this world.'' Connolly said he can afford the posh eateries in the neighborhood, but prefers the dogs at Nathan's. Barry Potekin, co-owner of downtown's Gold Coast Dog, has challenged Nathan's to a hot dog taste test. ``They called themselves the Gucci of hot dogs. That ticked us off. What is this, perfume?'' he asked. Bob Hardison is caught between the dog soldiers of each side. He's a Chicagoan, but manages the city's first Nathan's. ``I like both styles,'' he insisted diplomatically. The New York style, he explained, is with mustard and sauerkraut, while Chicago style is with mustard, relish, onions, tomatoes, peppers and just about anything else that will fit on the bun. Not wanting to choose sides, Nathan's has a condiment bar for customers to choose their own fixings. There's also a difference in the way the two dogs are cooked. Nathan's frank is prepared on a griddle, while Chicago's dogs are usually boiled in water. Nathan's dogs are ``more intense and spicier, but not altogether more pleasant'' than Chicago's dogs, said Tribune food critic Phil Vettel. But Wednesday night, a 50-year-old man remembered bygone dogs and said that neither city's product was, frankly, worth sniffing at. ``The best hotdog place was Dave's at Homan and Roosevelt when I was 8,'' said Harvey Shapiro, a messenger service employee. ``It was 20 cents for a hotdog and an Orange Crush!''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Softer
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell against most major currencies in European trading today. Gold was quoted nominally softer. The dollar lost ground against the yen in Tokyo today, closing at 144.72 yen, down 0.78 yen from Thursday's close of 145.50 yen. Later in London, the dollar traded at 145.15 yen. Traders sold the West German mark for the yen throughout the day to take profits on overbought mark positions, dealers said. Concerns about the implications of a proposal to unify the two German monetary systems, along with profit-taking, helped push the mark lower, traders said. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Thursday's prices, included: 1.6665 West German marks, down from 1.6872; 1.4890 Swiss francs, down from 1.4905; 5.6710 French francs, down from 5.6725; 1.8840 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8810; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,241.50; and 1.1940 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1970. The British pound traded at $1.6910, compared with $1.6885 late Thursday. London's major gold dealers fixed a recommended price of $418.50 at midmorning, up from $417.75 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the bid price was $418.75, up from $417.75 bid late Thursday. Gold in Hong Kong rose 96 cents an ounce today, to close at $417.42. Silver traded at a bid price of $5.34 a troy ounce, up from Thursday's $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: GE American Communications to Launch New Satellite Service
DOC.TEXT: GE American Communications Inc. has signed a $100 million deal with nine large cable operators to deliver television programming to homes via satellite, officials say. ``This new service will come directly to a satellite dish at your house that's about the same size as a garbage can cover,'' said Bill Fredell, a spokesman for the company, which is also known as GE Americom. Fredell said Thursday the service would be a boon to people living in rural areas who have no access to cable service. Cable operators will pay GE Americom $100 million to lease 10 transponders on a satellite, Fredell said. The deal expires in 1996, when the satellite reaches the end of its life. GE Americom is one of the 10 partners involved in the deal. The others are all cable companies, including American Television and Communications Corp., Comcast Corp., Cox Cable Communications, Continental Cablevision Inc., Newhouse Broadcasting, Telecommunications Inc., United Artists Entertainment Co, Viacom and Warner Cable Communications. The 10-channel service will include a set of superstation signals as well as pay-per-view services. Fredell said the package could one day offer direct broadcast programming, including High Definition Television or HDTV.

DOC.HEAD: Company Denies Plans to Disband Development Arm
DOC.TEXT: The Campeau Corp. says it has no plans to dismantle a Cincinnati-based development subsidiary of Campeau's Federated and Allied department store chains, which are under bankruptcy court protection. Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger said earlier this week that the company planned to dismantle Campeau Development Corp. in three to six months. The company was set up in 1988. ``At this time, Campeau Development Corporation is not being dismantled. It remains a legal, operating entity,'' Campeau spokesman Dick Wertheim said Thursday in a statement from Toronto, where Campeau is headquartered. Wertheim said Campeau is reviewing the future of the development company in light of the financial condition of Cincinnati-based Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., which sought protection from their creditors Jan. 15 under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. ``While CDC is not directly affected by the bankruptcy filings of the retailing operations, it is indirectly impacted since in most, if not all, cases, Allied or Federated stores were expected to be anchors or key tenants in the developments,'' Wertheim said. He said the bankruptcy court proceedings would delay Campeau's involvement in planned projects such as Boston Crossing.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Aerospace Laying Off 40 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Aerospace and Electronics said it would lay off about 40 employees from its Oak Ridge, Tenn. plant because of uncertainty about the defense budget and the future of missile production at the facility. In Seattle, 32 of 105 employees also working on the expansion of the Oak Ridge plant's missile-making capacity will be reassigned within the company, Boeing said in a press release Thursday. ``In the light of recent production schedule slides and reconsiderations of other Defense Department programs, it is prudent for us to reassess the need for this Advanced Production Facility,'' said Randy Mitchell, Boeing Aerospace and Electronics vice president of operations. Boeing will decide by the end of the year whether it will proceed with the project, Mitchell said. The facility was to produce the Short Range Attack Missile II and T versions for the U.S. Air Force; the Sea Lance anti-submarine missile for the U.S. Navy; and the air-to-surface Advanced Interdiction Weapon System missile, also for the Navy. Earl Bowden, president of Boeing Aerospace and Electronics, Oak Ridge, said about half the expansion facility's $200 million cost has already been invested. Boeing has about 640 workers at Oak Ridge. About 90 percent of the work done there involves commercial jetliner subassemblies.

The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose more than 4 points on Thursday, added another 6.53 to 2,650.90 after 30 minutes of trading. The bond sale received a less enthusiastic reception than the sales of $10 billion in three-year notes and a like amount of 10-year notes earlier in the week. But some analysts said the fact that the auctions are over should take some pressure off interest rates anyway. DOC.HEAD: Government Enters New Business _ Peddling Junk Bonds
DOC.TEXT: As if the federal government didn't play a big enough role in the credit markets, it's taken on a big new position _ in junk bonds. The nation's biggest and most creditworthy issuer of IOU's will be looking to unload a bundle of some of the riskiest paper around following the recent federal seizure of CenTrust Bank, Florida's largest thrift. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision ordered the seizure on Feb. 2, saying CenTrust was unsound largely because of ``large and mounting losses'' on its securities portfolio. That included $922 million of junk bonds at the end of last September, the most recent figures available, said Kenneth H. Thomas, who runs a Miami-based bank and thrift consultancy. It wasn't the first junk pill swallowed by the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency responsible for selling assets of failed thrifts, but it was easily the biggest. City Federal Savings of Elizabeth, N.J., had junk holdings of $715 million last September and Lincoln Savings and Loan of Los Angeles had $339 million, Thomas says. Both institutions were seized by the government late last year. All told, Thomas said, thrifts now in federal hands owned $2.3 billion in junk bonds as of last September. How and when the RTC peddles its junk holdings could add more angst to the $200 billion junk market, reeling lately from steady bad news: the bankruptcy filings of Campeau Corp.'s department store groups, a low credit rating for an RJR Nabisco issue and heavy selling by speculators. ``Anytime you put $2 billion of paper in the market, it's just one more adverse factor on the supply side,'' said Martin Fridson, managing director in charge of high-yield bond research at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. But RTC spokesman Steve Katsanos said the agency isn't interested in a fire sale that could only cost taxpayers more money and unsettle the market. ``Everything we have is for sale,'' he said. ``It's not for sale at any price.'' The prospect of selling by thrifts isn't new for the junk market. The Congressional bailout bill for thrifts enacted last August requires S&Ls to sell their junk holdings _ which totaled $13.2 billion in September _ by 1994. It's unclear whether the federally controlled thrifts have dumped some of their junk holdings since September. Katsanos said he couldn't provide a current figure for the RTC's holdings. Nevertheless, Thomas said the CenTrust debacle presents the federal agency with a new problem. Although other failed thrifts owned junk bonds, their failures stemmed primarily from sour real estate loans or fraud, he said. Not so with CenTrust. ``This is the first thrift that definitely failed, without a doubt, because of junk bonds,'' he said. CenTrust owned some of the riskiest junk paper of any thrift, Thomas contended, including those financing operations of Eastern Airlines, Braniff, Integrated Resources and Hillsborough Holdings, which have either filed for bankruptcy protection or defaulted on their debts. Anyone thinking of giving the government a bid for some of CenTrust's bonds must carefully research what the holdings are and if they can be traded, said Alan Schlesinger, head of junk bond trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Warren Greene, who runs a $12 million high-yield portfolio at his American Investors Income Fund Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., said he doesn't think it's likely anyone will bid for CenTrust's entire junk portfolio because the market is so weak. Still, he said that weakness presents the government with other possible buyers _ the companies who issued the junk bonds. While some highly publicized junk issuers are in default, many are viable companies that can book big profits and eliminate interest payments by buying back their debt at steep discounts, Greene said. Some bond brokerages also could try to repackage some of CenTrust's holdings into new types of debt securities that carry less risk, said Fridson of Merrill Lynch. ``I think a lot of people are talking to them (the RTC) and suggesting ideas,'' he said. Whatever the RTC decides, junk marketers agree on one piece of advice: don't panic. Fridson said if the S&L industry shedded its junk portfolio gradually over the next four years, the amount it would have to sell each year would equal just 7 percent of the average new issue volume in each of the past three years. ``It's not an amount that's unmanageable,'' he said. Added Schlesinger: ``Sell them when you can, not when you have to.''

DOC.HEAD: L.J. Hooker Unit Files Under Chapter 11 to Ease Sale
DOC.TEXT: The commercial real estate brokerage and property management division of L.J. Hooker Corp. is shutting its doors. L.J. Hooker International will file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy to ease the sale of nine offices _ including its Atlanta headquarters _ to Lambert Smith Hampton, a European real estate firm, the Atlanta-based parent company said Thursday. The company said the subsidiary's other 10 offices will be sold separately or closed. On Aug. 9, L.J. Hooker and several of its subsidiaries filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Act. L.J. Hooker International was not part of that filing. Various retail properties were included in the original bankruptcy filing, among them the B. Altman & Co. and Bonwit Teller department stores. Efforts to find a buyer for Altman's failed and on Nov. 17 L.J. Hooker announed six of the seven stores in the chain would close. The company still is seeking offers for Bonwit Teller. In a statement Thursday, Hooker said Lambert Smith Hampton is to acquire ``certain of the assets'' of Hooker International offices in Atlanta; Beverly Hills, Calif.; Dallas; New York; Orlando, Fla.; Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz.; San Diego, and Tampa, Fla. The Atlanta office includes Hooker International's corporate headquarters. If the U.S. Bankruptcy Court approves the sale of the offices, the deal is to be completed by the end of March, Hooker said. According to the statement, Lambert Smith Hampton officials said the transfer of the offices will give the company 31 offices and 1,000 employees, making it the largest United States-European real estate operation. Ralph G. Edwards Jr., president of Hooker International, said senior managers as well as client portfolios will shift to Lambert Smith Hampton with the sale. L.J. Hooker, which is the U.S. arm of Australia's Hooker Corp., got into the brokerage business in December 1986 with the purchase of Merrill Lynch & Co.'s commercial real estate division. The Sydney-based parent company last autumn revealed severe cash flow problems due to high interest rates and a sagging real estate market in Australia. The company now is being liquidated.

DOC.HEAD: Gibraltar Financial Corp. Files For Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: Gibraltar Financial Corp., whose savings and loan subsidiaries were seized by the federal government two years ago, said it has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. James N. Thayer, the corporation's chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement Thursday the move was necessary to dissolve a writ of attachment, or claim against its assets, obtained by Bank of America. Thayer also said the move was prompted in part by the government's seizure of two of the corporation's savings and loan subsidiaries, Gibraltar Savings and Gibraltar Savings Bank, F.A., in March 1989. Gibraltar's thrifts, which together ranked as the nation's ninth-largest, had operations in California, Washington state and Florida. They were seized on March 31, 1989 by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which declared the institution unsound. Gibraltar Financial, a holding company whose stock is publicly traded and which hasn't any significant assets other than two Gibraltar Savings units in California and Washington state, was not included in the seizure of its thrifts. Gibraltar Financial lost $100.5 million in 1988 and $146.5 million in 1987. In 1986, it had a $43.9 million profit.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Soar 1.8 Percent in January
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs graf 6, The so-called, to CORRECT April to July.
DOC.TEXT: A double wallop delivered to energy and food prices by the holiday cold snap sent wholesale inflation soaring 1.8 percent in January, the steepest one-month rise in more than 15 years, the government said today. The spurt in the Labor Department's Producer Price Index was nearly triple the already brisk 0.6 percent gain in December. If wholesale inflation persisted at the January pace, it would produce an annual price rise of 24.1 percent. The last monthly increase of greater magnitude was recorded in November 1974 during the OPEC oil embargo, when prices shot up 2 percent in one month. Last month's gain was even steeper than the 1.2 percent jump predicted by most analysts. Economists, however, were not overly concerned. January inflation one stop short of the retail level was attributed almost entirely to sharp but temporary increases in the price of fuel oil and vegetables. The so-called core rate of inflation _ prices excluding the volatile food and energy sectors _ rose a slight 0.1 percent in January, the mildest rise since July. Financial markets, which usually react badly to scary inflation numbers, started the morning with a rally. The Dow Jones average of industrial stocks rose 6.53 points to 2,650.90. ``Without food and energy, commodity price inflation was very low,'' said economimst Allen Sinai of the Boston Co. ``The bad news is the (overall) January number was incredibly high and consumers will pay higher prices for food and energy for a while longer. The good news is the report suggests much of the activity was weather-related and will diminish in coming months.'' Energy prices in January rose 13.6 percent, the biggest increase since the Labor Department began compiling that index in 1974. Fuel oil prices were up a startling 25.3 percent, also the biggest jump on record. As refineries switched production to fuel oil, supplies of gasoline grew short, sending those prices up 16.7 percent. Natural gas costs rose a brisk 3.2 percent. Food costs, meanwhile, shot up 2.1 percent, the sharpest rise in six years. The price of fresh and dried vegetable rose 58 percent for the month, the largest seasonally adjusted gain recorded since the department began tracking that category in 1967. Egg prices climbed 12.5 percent on top of a 9.1 percent rise in December. Over the past 12 months, egg costs have risen 45.2 percent. Fruit was up 3.9 percent and fish rose 6.3 percent. The increases were partly offset by substantial declines for other items. Rice dropped 1.1 percent; pasta, 5.8 percent; chickens, 2.8 percent, and turkeys, 11.9 percent. In other categories, prices rose 2.9 percent for children's clothing, 0.8 percent for men's and women's clothing, and 0.9 percent for home electronic equipment. That was mostly counterbalanced by drops of 1.3 percent for tobacco, which had risen 2.2 percent in December; 0.7 percent for automobiles, the result of a new round of discounting at auto dealerships, and 0.7 percent for tires. The various changes put the Producer Price Index at 117.5 in January. This meant that a hypothetical marketbasket of goods, which cost $100 in 1982, cost $117.50 last month, up from $111.10 a year earlier. Soaring energy costs also drove up inflation in earlier stages of the production process. The price of intermediate goods rose 1.2 percent overall, but only 0.1 percent excluding food and energy. The price of crude goods was up 2.4 percent overall and 0.2 percent minus food and energy. An example of the three stages would be bread for finished goods, flour for intermediate and wheat for crude. Despite the big January increase, many economists were expecting wholesale inflation to moderate this year compared with the 4.8 percent rate last year. The Bush administration last week predicted inflation of about 4 percent, in line with most private forecasts. ``The U.S. economy is on the weakish side ... and the pressures of slowing demand will continue to keep inflation at least stable and possibly lower over the next year,'' said economist Samuel D. Kahan of Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago. ``You might not see a collapse in the inflation rate, but certainly an acceleration seems unlikely.'' Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan strengthened that impression last week when he told Congress the risk of recession receded from last spring and inflation, although stable, was unacceptably high. That was taken by financial markets as a sign the Fed would not be lowering interest rates anytime soon. In recent years, the Fed has kept interest rates high in order to fight inflation by slowing economic growth. It has cut rates only when the economy seemed in danger of lapsing into a recession. Monetary policy-makers met earlier this week and most analysts believe they decided to leave interest rates unchanged for now.

But some analysts said the fact that the auctions are over should take some pressure off interest rates anyway. Rising interest rates make yields on fixed-income securities more competitive with those on stocks, reduce chances for corporate earnings growth and make it more expensive to borrow money to buy stocks. Before the market opened today, the government reported a steep 1.8 percent rise in its producer price index in January, after a 0.6 percent gain in December and the biggest one-month increase in more than 15 years. DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Gain On China Wheat Offer
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures opened with a pop today on the Chicago Board of Trade after the Agriculture Department USDA announced it had targeted China for sales of 1 million metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices. Soybean futures also opened higher while corn and oats were mixed in early trading. Susan Leighty, a grain-market analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said the timing of the USDA announcement was somewhat surprising although rumors of an upcoming export bonus offer of wheat to China had swept through the markets about a month ago. ``It's not like we didn't have an inkling it was coming,'' she said. Traders guessed the Chinese will buy a combination of old-crop and new-crop wheat. The USDA announcement, which came after the close of trading Thursday, stirred speculation that wheat will also be offered to the Soviet Union, Ms. Leighty said. In early trading, wheat futures prices were 1\ cents to 4{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.87 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent lower to { cent higher with March at $2.39 a bushel; oat futures were \ cent lower to { cent higher with March at $1.37 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2\ cents higher with March at $5.67 a bushel. Cattle futures retreated in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Pork futures were narrowly mixed. Live cattle futures were .10 cent to .22 cent lower with February at 79.45 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent to .25 cent lower with March at 82.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent lower to .10 cent higher with February at 49.15 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .12 cent higher with February at 50.65 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled mostly lower on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Appliance Maker Closing Kentucky Dishwasher Plant
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. will close its Mount Sterling, Ky., dishwasher plant by March 1991 and lay off most of the factory's 650 workers, the appliance company said today. After a plant capacity study by Whirlpool's KitchenAid Appliance Group, dishwasher production will be moved from the Mount Sterling plant to Whirlpool's Findlay Division plant in Findlay, Ohio, which already makes Whirlpool, Roper and Kenmore dishwashers and Whirlpool cooking ranges. Production of built-in cooking appliances will be moved from Findlay to Whirlpool's Oxford, Miss., plant, which makes built-in cooking products as well as components for Whirlpool and KitchenAid. Whirlpool also said it will sell its Danville, Ky., plant, which employs 1,000 people and makes Kenmore canister, upright and central vacuum cleaners for sale to Sears, Roebuck and Co. William D. Marohn, executive vice president of Whirlpool's North American Appliance Group, said the moves would improve manufacturing efficiency and focus on the company's major appliance businesses. ``Clearly these were not easy decisions to make since they affect a number of our people,'' Marohn said. ``We believe they are the right ones for the company's North American business long term.'' The moves will cost 650 jobs at Mount Sterling, but add about 300 jobs at Findlay and another 135 jobs at Oxford, the company said. The Mount Sterling plant will operate at least through the fourth quarter of 1990, and close by the end of the first quarter of 1991, Whirlpool spokeswoman Carol Sizer said. Some management jobs may be transferred to other Whirlpool facilities but most employees will be dismissed, Sizer said. The company will schedule meetings with United Auto Workers Local 1562, representing the Mount Sterling employees, to negotiate the dismissal procedures, she said. Whirlpool will seek buyers and hopes to complete the sale of the Danville facility in the first half of this year, Sizer said. ``We will do everything we can to assure that we find the right buyer to provide Sears with a continuing supply of superior products,'' said Whirlpool Vice President H.W. Bowman.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Finishes Health Assertions Revisions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to update with announcement today
DOC.TEXT: The government today announced plans to toughen rules on the health claims that food marketers can make about their products. The new policy, to be published in the Federal Register next week, is a ``mid-course correction'' of regulations that have allowed food sellers to make health claims since 1987, said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. ``Only with such a consistent set of standards can Americans be sure of the meaning of health information on food labels,'' he said in a statement announcing the Food and Drug Administration's proposed rules. The FDA's proposal would let companies make specific health claims if they fall within a narrow range of messages concerning the relationship between diet and health benefits detailed in recent studies by the U.S. surgeon general and the National Academy of Sciences. Claims outside this narrow range would be allowed only in certain circumstances. ``As science finds additional links between diet and health, these could also be included in our health messages policy,'' Sullivan said. The FDA used to prohibit health-related messages on food products, but in 1987 the agency proposed a set of liberal regulations that allowed health claims. It was criticized as being too broad and permissive. The new proposal supersedes the 1987 proposed rule. The Office of Management and Budget, which reviews draft regulations of all executive branch agencies, approved the new policy on Wednesday without substantial changes, an FDA official said. The new policy will allow health claims only about fiber and colon cancer, fiber and heart disease, fats and cancer, fats and heart disease, sodium and high blood pressure, and calcium and osteoporosis, a softening of the bones sometimes found in the elderly. Many scientists believe that in some circumstances, fiber might reduce colon cancer and heart disease; fats might increase cancer and heart disease; high concentrations of sodium increase blood pressure; and calcium can help prevent osteoporosis. The new policy could take a year to be completely implemented. Until then, claims will be considered on a case-by-case basis. Among the FDA considerations will be whether ``the good outweighs the bad'' in following the seller's advice, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. This might, for example, rule out health claims for low-cholesterol food that is high in saturated fats, since scientists believe saturated fats in the diet are more important in forming cholesterol in the blood than diet cholesterol itself. The official declined to give examples of current claims the agency could act against under the new policy. However, the agency has said it has serious concerns about cereals with husks of psyllium, which contain soluble fiber. The FDA also has criticized the American Heart Association's new ``Heartguide'' program to label brands it approves as ``heart healthy'' with a prominent mark. The official said the new policy did not directly bear on the heart group's action. The association had said it would review the program plans when the new policy was published.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner Launches New Weekly
DOC.TEXT: If Entertainment Weekly flops, don't blame the marketers. The first major weekly magazine from the Time Inc. Magazine Co. since the expensive failure of TV-Cable Week seven years ago debuts Monday after a marketing blitz that smaller magazine operations can only envy. Television commercials late at night have invited viewers to subscribe by phone. New members of the Book-of-the-Month Club got offers of free issues. But the crowning stroke may have been during the two weeks preceding the magazine's premiere. That was when Entertainment Weekly tucked a 12-page supplement in its sister publications _ Time, People, Sports Illustrated, Fortune and Money _ and gave an estimated 61 million readers a sneak preview. The supplement had a cover photo of a gun-toting Warren Beatty dressed like Dick Tracy in a broad-brimmed hat and bright yellow coat. But the best thing about the exposure was that it was free because the magazines are published within the same company. The only thing Entertainment Weekly had to pay for was production. Publisher Michael J. Klingensmith estimated it would have cost an outsider at least $5 million for the same exposure. The magazine is the dream child of two aging, busy yuppies who wished they had a single source of information on what to watch, read or listen to on any given night. They hope a million or more active, relatively affluent baby-boomers like themselves would like to find the magazine in the mailbox every week. ``These people have plenty of money; what they don't have is a lot of time. The bigger loss for them is a lost evening rather than a lost $30,'' said Klingensmith, 37. Managing Editor Jeff Jarvis, 35, the former TV critic for People magazine, said two-thirds of each issue will be reviews of movies, records, books, magazines, television programs and videos. The critics will give grades A to F. The other third will have features about entertainment products _ where can you go to create a customized music cassette, how do authors go about gathering material and how has the threat of censorship affected the television business. What you won't find is gossip about celebrities' personal lives. ``If you want to find out about a star's wedding or divorce, go to People. We'll tell you about their movie,'' Jarvis said. Magazine consultant Martin S. Walker wonders whether Entertainment Weekly can survive by sticking to that premise. ``The real question I have is can you come out with a news-oriented weekly that is not gossip-and-celebrity-oriented and find the audience,'' he said. Klingensmith and Jarvis say you can. They have spent years making the case. The two men independently proposed a magazine like Entertainment Weekly in 1984. The company, still in shock over the $47 million loss it took on the failed TV Cable Week a year earlier, failed to act on the ideas. About 2{ years ago, Klingensmith revived his proposal, noting the growing popularity of cable and pay television, portable tape players and videocassette recorders. The appetite for entertainment products, he argued, was enormous. A Time executive took note of the suggestion and recalled that Jarvis had made a similar proposal. He suggested the two men team up. They did, and the brass liked what they heard. A direct mailing of a prototype issue received a ``very strong response,'' Klingensmith said, and the company gave the go-ahead. The magazine plans were announced last summer. Klingensmith expects to surpass plans for average circulation of 600,000 during the first year. The magazine will rely mainly on subscriptions. The price is $51.48 a year or $1.95 a copy at newstands. Despite a sluggish advertising environment, he said demand for space in the magazine has exceeded expectations with more than 100 companies signing up. Klingensmith knows how badly Time executives want a winner this time out. This is the company's first magazine launch since parent Time Inc. bought Warner Communications Inc. last year, saddling itself with debt and changing its name to Time Warner Inc. Time Warner President Nicholas J. Nicholas told a Columbia University audience last fall that the company was prepared to invest $150 million in the magazine; Klingensmith said the out-of-pocket cash costs will be much smaller, on the order of $30 million until it breaks even within five years. Media critics will be watching to see if the magazine plays favorites with sister company products such as Warner Bros. movies or pans offerings from rival companies. Klingensmith and Jarvis insist that won't happen. ``It is one of the most exciting new concepts to come along in recent years,'' said Rich Hamilton, media director for the advertsing agency D'Arcy Masius, Benton & Bowles. ``But the reader will tell us if it succeeds.''
