DOC.HEAD: NYSE Phone Lines To Aid Program Trading Crackdown
DOC.TEXT: Money managers say a move by the New York Stock Exchange to persuade big investors to report suspected program trading abuses by their brokers is no solution to curbing volatile price swings that sometimes afflict the market. The Big Board in recent months has sent letters to 100 top institutional investors providing two telephone numbers they can call with suspicions about big-block computerized trades by brokers that may run afoul of exchange regulations. The NYSE and two futures exchanges have been investigating suspected market manipulation involving stocks and stock-index futures since the mini-crash last October renewed complaints that program trading was causing trading turmoil. The main target of the probe is said to be a technique known as front-running, in which traders profit on the knowledge of orders placed with them by buying or selling stocks or stock-index futures or options before placing the orders. ``There's no way in the world you're going to know it's being done in front of you,'' Donald Dreman, managing partner of Dreman Value Management, which handles about $4 billion in investor funds, said today. By calling the exchange to effectively squeal on their own broker, institutional investors who hire brokerage firms to conduct program trading _ estimated at less than 100 nationwide _ would risk losing face, not to mention business. ``You're going to endanger your relationship, and if there's nothing there you look quite silly,'' said Dreman, who opposes program trading. ``It may be a propaganda ploy to say (the exchange is) doing things.'' In a statement, the NYSE said Thursday that the probe of several volatile trading days was continuing in conjunction with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade. ``If trading abuses are found to have taken place, the NYSE will take appropriate enforcement action with respect to parties within our jurisdiction,'' the statement said. Program traders use computer models to buy and sell large blocks of stocks with opposite purchases of stock-index futures or options to capitalize on brief and small price differences. Investigators are said to be examining volatile trading Oct. 13 _ when the Dow Jones industrial average sank 190 points _ and the following trading day, when it regained 80 points during the course of the day. Also under scrutiny is Oct. 24, when the market see-sawed in wild trading. Exchange officials declined further comment on the issue, including details on the letters to institutional investors proferring the direct-access telephone numbers, dubbed a ``hot line'' by The Wall Street Journal. The NYSE refused to say whether the lines were set up exclusively for the institutions. Fund managers calling the numbers would reach the NYSE's market surveillance department, which would analyze specific transactions suspected of fishy trading. Program trading critics said the telephone lines were insignificant in regulating abuses and some criticized self-policing by the exchanges as inadequate to ferret out trading irregularities. Some Wall Street professionals said the federal government should unify regulation of the nation's stock and futures markets. The Securities and Exchange Commission now regulates the stock markets while the Commodity Futures Trading Commission handles futures trading. ``That's what we need, not action line,'' said James J. Cramer, president of Cramer & Co., a small New York money management firm. ``It's up to the institutions to get together and say something about it,'' said Neil Weisman, a general partner with the money management firm Chilmark Capital Partners. ``Unless the institutions decide not to deal with anyone doing program trading it's not going to stop.'' Many fund managers have complained that abuses of program trading _ not the tactic itself _ are responsible for market volatility and have called for a specific attack on improprieties. Specialists who set opening prices and manage the flow of trading on the stock exchange floor also are said to have called on NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. in recent months to take stronger action to curb program trading abuses.

DOC.HEAD: Sematech Funds Chip-Making Project
DOC.TEXT: Sematech, the computer industry consortium, says it plans to fund an innovative project aimed at boosting the expertise of U.S. companies in ion implant technology, a key part of the computer chip-making process. The Austin consortium, which over the past year has spent millions of dollars on joint development contracts with U.S. semiconductor equipment companies, said the program involves Ion Implant Services of Sunnyvale, Calif., and Genus Inc., an equipment manufacturing firm in Mountain View, Calif. Under the deal, announced Thursday, Sematech bought a $2.4 million ion implanting machine from Genus and plans to lease it to Ion Implant Services for two years. In turn, the Sunnyvale company will house and service the machine at its headquarters and make it available to any other U.S. high-tech company. The companies, particularly chip makers and semiconductor equipment manufacturers, will use the machine as a test site for high-energy implantation, and Sematech will pass on the information gleaned from the process to its dues-paying member companies, the consortium said. Ion implantation is used to alter the quality of silicon used in computer chips.

DOC.HEAD: Sock Retailer Posts Loss of $4.9 Million
DOC.TEXT: Sock Shop International PLC on Friday reported a loss of 2.9 million pounds, or $4.9 million, for the first six months of its fiscal year, blaming London's 14 weeks of transportation strikes last summer. Thirty of the retailer's stores are in or near London's subway stations, and the company was forced to close them during the walkouts. Sock Shop also cited mild weather in Britain, which dampened demand for warm socks and tights, and high interest rates, which discouraged consumer spending and raised the company's borrowing costs. It said it also expects to post a loss for the year ended Feb. 28. A Sock Shop spokesman, who wasn't identified in keeping with British practice, said the company would hold a special shareholders meeting shortly to discuss the situation. The directors already were engaged in active negotiations on possible refinancing, the outcome of which would be notified to shareholders as soon as possible, he said. In December, Sock Shop closed its 17 U.S. stores, most of which are in New York City. It cited disappointing sales coupled with high rents and security costs. The company said it is holding talks with a U.S.-based potential investor to revive its American business. It operates another 109 outlets in Britain and 16 elsewhere in Europe. The after-tax loss for the six months ended Aug. 31 compared with an after-tax profit of 400,000 pounds, or $676,000, in the same period a year earlier. On a per share basis, the prior year's profit came to 1.8 pence, or 3 cents. Sales rose 38 percent to 15.3 million pounds, or $26 million, from 11.1 million pounds, or $19 million the year before. The company said there would be no half-year dividend and no likelihood of a final dividend at the end of the financial year.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Crude Begins Washing Ashore in Southern California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with new figures on amount of oil spilled, giving range sted exact number; slightly revised figure on dead birds; oil being transferred to barge, other details; pick up 12th graf pvs. `John Richards ...'. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphotos LA3, LA4
DOC.TEXT: Floating black globs of crude oil and brown foam splashed ashore today as winds drove strips of a quarter-million-gallon spill onto golden beaches beloved by surfers and sun worshipers. About 2,000 residents called city hall to volunteer to help 300 professionals start cleaning up the mess, Mayor Thomas J. Mays said. ``We were on our knees scooping up the oil and putting it into bags,'' said Steve Brick, one of the volunteers who showed up before dawn today. ``The oil was seeping down into the sand; our hands were just black when we finished.'' The 811-foot tanker American Trader carried 21 million gallons when its single-wall hull was punctured, apparently by an anchor, as it approached an oil pipeline mooring about 1{ miles offshore Wednesday night. The tanker lost between 250,000 and 300,000 gallons of oil from a forward compartment that held 1,386,000 gallons, Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Mark Kennedy said. When the leak stopped Thursday night, the Coast Guard began pumping the remaining oil and water from the compartment onto a barge. By 6 a.m. today about 26,000 gallons had been transferred, said Lt. Cmdr. Alan Carver. Ten skimming boats worked on the slick, which covered water over an area roughly measuring 6 miles by 4 miles. Seas were calm and winds light. ``The weather has cooperated,'' Kennedy said. Offshore winds Thursday had kept the slick away from beaches until afternoon, when they reversed direction and began nudging the mess onto shore. Pockets of crude oil began washing ashore Thursday night. A 4-mile stretch was fouled in Newport Beach, an affluent community that boasts some of Southern California's most expensive beachfront property. The oily goop washed ashore along a mile-long expanse north of Huntington Pier on Bolsa Chica State Beach, which borders a sensitive estuary habitat, officials said. More oil hit along a quarter-mile-long stretch of beach south of the pier, renowned from references in Beach Boys surf songs and its use in films as a surfing set. At least eight oil-coated sea birds were found in the fouled surf early today, said Newport Beach lifeguard Eric Bauer. Altogether, about 50 oiled seabirds have been found, and about half that number had died as of this morning, Kennedy said. At least one California brown pelican was among the dead birds. John Richards of Newport Beach and his fiancee found one of the birds. ``He was floating in the surf area and he washed up, and then he tried to fly away and he just flopped over,'' Richards said. Coast Guard Commandant Adm. Paul Yost said American Trader's hull apparently was punctured when it hit something on the bottom as the crew prepared to hook up to an underwater pipeline that carries crude oil to shore. It was unclear if the tanker hit one of its own anchors or a buoy anchor, he said. The ship had been chartered by British Petroleum Oil Shipping Co. USA to deliver Alaskan North Slope crude oil to the Golden West Refinery in Santa Fe Springs. The ship, owned and operated by American Trading Transportation Co. Inc. of New York, was maneuvering to a mooring before pumping its load ashore via the refinery pipeline, said company president Sanford Schmidt. The seas and weather were calm at the time of the accident. Federally mandated alcohol tests given to the ship's captain, Robert La Ware, the pilot, the first mate and the second mate all came back negative, the Coast Guard said. Drug test results were not complete. Yost described the spill as major. ``The Coast Guard is taking this very seriously as are the people of this region, and we're going to see you get a good cleanup here,'' Yost said. Mays said the Huntington Beach cleanup largely would be done with shovels, rakes and garbage bags. In Newport Beach about a dozen employees of a private cleanup company stood at water's edge overnight, using a spongy material to mop up the oil globules floating in on the waves. The tanker, still about 1{ miles off the coast, was surrounded by an oil containment boom. Six oil-recovery boats worked to mop up the slick in calm seas Thursday and eight more were scheduled to start work today. An estimated 5 percent of the slick had been skimmed by late Thursday, Coast Guard Lt. Vincent Campos said. Use of chemical dispersants ``was under discussion,'' Campos said, as officials weighed possible environmental damage from the chemicals against harm from the oil. Workers laid booms to protect fragile estuaries at the Santa Ana River mouth, Anaheim Bay, Bolsa Chica Wetlands and upper Newport Bay _ all scenic wildlife havens. The Seal Beach National Wildlife Refuge, which is farther north along the coast, was being monitored. John Turner, director of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, said the oil posed a hazard to such endangered creatures as the peregrine falcon, brown pelican and light-footed clapper rail. The cleanup will be paid for by American Trading or its insurance company, said British Petroleum spokesman Chuck Webster. Huntington Beach is a city of 180,000 about 35 miles southeast of Los Angeles. Newport Beach, about five miles down the coast, has about 70,000 residents.

Foreign exchange dealers said dollar trading was secondary to activity in marks, pounds and Japanese yen. Mark Sexton, senior dealer at the bank of Montreal, said that as the pound gained on the mark the British currency looked the ``safest to be in right now,'' with Britain's high 15 percent bank base lending rate seeming likely to continue for some time. Traders said there had been euphoria over the mark because of the upheavals in Eastern Europe but more realism had now set in amid confusion over the possible merging of the currencies of the two Germanys. The markets could not decide whether an unexpectedly sharp rise of 1.8 percent in U.S. producer prices in Janaury would result in an increase in U.S. interest rates. DOC.HEAD: Jaws V, Man's Revenge: Consumers Stalking Sharks
DOC.TEXT: Silently the hunter banked left and spotted her prey. She moved closer and struck. ``Could I have a one-pound fillet of shark?'' Maria Suarez asked the seafood clerk at a Miami market. ``And do you have any lemons?'' Sharks, feared kings of the ocean food chain, are increasingly ending up as dinner meat in your local supermarket chain. They've become a main course for Americans who have discovered the fish to be inexpensive but tasty. In addition, the expansion of trade with China since the mid-1980s dramatically boosted demand for Atlantic and Gulf shark fins, used for a soup considered an Asian delicacy. But a nearly six-fold increase in shark catches since 1985 has alarmed environmentalists, who fear populations are dwindling to dangerously low levels off the Southeast coast. Despite their ferocious image, many sharks perform a useful function, cleaning the sea floor and controlling other fish populations. Federal officials are drafting a proposal that would limit catches and could temporarily ban shark fishing. Unlike other fish, sharks reproduce slowly and may take up to 15 years to mature. In areas of intensive fishing, it could require up to 30 years for the shark population to recover, said Jose Castro, a shark specialist at the National Marine Fisheries Service in Miami. The proposed regulations, which may take effect this summer, would limit the U.S. commercial harvest to the 1988 level of about 12.76 million pounds, up from 2.13 million pounds in 1985. The draft proposal also seeks to outlaw the practice of capturing sharks only for their fins. Florida and Alabama account for about 80 percent of the nation's commercial shark catch. The catch limit will probably already be reached if the regulations take effect in late July or August, said Lt. Eric Hawk, an official at National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration who is helping draft the final plan. ``Whether you call it retroactive to January or an all-out ban, commercial shark fishing will probably close the day the rules go into effect,'' said Hawk. Meanwhile, federal officials will study shark populations and revise the regulations for the summer of 1991, he said. ``They are beautifully adapated in their environment,'' said Castro. ``But they haven't had time to adapt to this new predator in the sea, which is man.'' Most are caught on baited hooks connected to cables stretching for miles behind fishing boats. The most prized species for meat include the sand bar, mako and thresher sharks, said Wayne Swingle, executive director of the Tampa-based Gulf of Mexico Fishery Management Council. Some species, such as hammerheads, often have bloody, unappetizing meat and may be used only for their fins, he said. ``We were promoting shark back in the early '80s when it was something real unusual,'' said Donna Florio, seafood marketing director at the South Carolina Wildlife & Marine Resources Department. ``Now, we don't have to do too much. People are learning about shark and are not afraid to eat it. Cost is a big factor.'' Shark meat brings fishermen about 65 cents a pound and shark fins about $10 a pound, said fisherman John Bonnell of Madeira Beach, the hub of Florida's Gulf Coast shark fleet. But Bonnell said he believes the proposed regulations could drive shark fishermen out of business and force U.S. seafood retailers to turn to Mexico, and perhaps Cuba, as main suppliers. ``Why would they come to us if we can only fish for half the year when Mexico can provide them all the shark they want all year round?'' said Bonnell, a former grouper fishermen who refitted his boats for shark years ago. Bonnell and other shark fishermen are calling for officials to wait at least a year before making regulation proposals. ``We're not totally against regulation, but so little is known about the effects on the sharks that we should wait until better data is collected,'' said Bonnell. ``We would be the first to recognize a collapse in the shark population and we've seen no decrease in the number or size of our catch.'' In the shark-fin market, high-flying profits have dipped since Chinese-U.S. relations cooled because of Beijing's violent suppression of a pro-democracy movement in June, but Gulf shark fins remain the most prized in the world, said Sonya Girard, a shark fin dealer in Golden Meadow, La. The U.S. fins are sought because of the high content of a noodle-like substance in species such as lemons and blues, whose fins can retail for more than $20 a pound dried. ``The noodles are like pasta and come in all different sizes, from thick like linguine to angel hair,'' said Ms. Girard, who once received $300 worth of shark fins in the mail from a fisherman. Ms. Girard noted sharks have non-culinary uses ranging from cancer research to an aphrodisiac made from ground backbone cartilage favored by Japanese geishas. In the 1940s, shark livers provided a high source of vitamin A, which now can be made synthetically. Like many in the shark trade, Ms. Girard doubts the practice of ``finning'' is as common as portrayed during public hearings on the proposed federal regulations last year. ``It's an emotional issue,'' she said. ``I don't think too many fishermen are going to cut off the fins and dump $800 worth of meat back into the sea.'' Sid Preskitt at Trans Ocean Inc. shark fin dealers in Port Orange, Fla., attributed the growing popularity of shark meat to better knowledge by fishermen on how to process the fish. To be edible, sharks must be caught alive and the tail and head severed immediately to allow drainage of blood, which contains a high urea content and turns to ammonia quickly after the shark dies. The carcass is then submerged in a cold brine solution that leaches out more blood. ``Shark is something a little different to eat and it's cheap,'' said Ms. Girard. ``It's become a real yuppie food.''

DOC.HEAD: Skating Ninja Turtles, Barbie Summit Show Toy Touting is Serious Business
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Turtles-on-Ice may sound like tempting delicacies to adventurous food fanatics but these reptiles are inedible. A band of skating, human-sized Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles will stage an ice show Sunday on a rink in New York's Central Park. The show featuring costumed professionals on loan from the Ice Capades is one of the gimmicks planned for this year's Toy Fair, an annual outpouring of hyperbole to stoke enthusiasm for new creations and old favorites. Toymakers spare no expense or imagination in dreaming up attention-grabbing stunts for the annual 10-day event in New York. ``This is show biz. This is a fun industry and this sets a tone of fun, excitement and adventure,'' said Frank Reysen Jr., editor of Playthings magazine, a trade publication. Publicity also is serious business for a multibillion-dollar industry in which companies rely on the capricious tastes of children. At the trade exhibition, manufacturers try to hook buyers from all over the country scouting for inventory that will move off store shelves quickly. Toy Fair visitors _ who must be members of the trade or media and at least 18 years old _ typically encounter clowns, actors dressed as cartoon characters, real movie stars, sports celebrities and outlandish creatures. This year a fierce but environmentally friendly intergalactic ninja named Zen will debut, as will a 12-foot ``BRIKasaurus Tex,'' a dinosaur replica built from BRIK Toy Co. blocks. Another company plans to assemble the world's biggest crossword puzzle with the help of 50 schoolchildren. Hasbro Inc. will have on hand the New Kids on the Block to pitch a new doll line modeled on the singing fivesome. Super models Christie Brinkley, Beverly Johnson and Cheryl Tiegs will show up to plug high-fashion dolls from Matchbox Toys (USA) Ltd. Anniversaries are planned for some old-timers in toyland. Etch A Sketch will be feted for turning 30 by Ohio Art Co. while Tonka Corp. will pay tribute as its Mighty Tonka Truck line rumbles into year 25. Barbie, who celebrated her 30th birthday last year with much fanfare, will add a new career in 1990. At a black-tie gala Monday night, Mattel Inc. will announce that the darling of the doll world will become an ambassador of international goodwill. Mattel will outline plans to sponsor the ``Barbie Summit,'' designed to bring children together from different countries to talk about world issues. To add drama, the company has flown to New York a 6-year-old East German girl, Anika Polzin, who had been photographed clutching a new Barbie on her first visit recently to West Germany. The most tongue-in-cheek publicity pitch may be delivered by the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles courtesy of Playmates Toys Inc. The figures are based on a comic about four pet turtles endowed with human proportions after they were doused by a mutagen chemical in a sewer. They learned Ninja ways from a martial arts master mutated into a giant rat. The turtles, fighting for life, liberty and the pursuit of pizza, their favorite food, will appear around New York. The skating show, an Easter Seal benefit, will be followed by a Meet the Mutants autograph session. Industry gimmicks concocted to beseech the press for publicity reached new levels this year. An actor in a turtle costume peddling free pizza was dispatched Friday to woo reporters who will be covering Toy Fair. A small party of the turtles and their foes were to troop around the streets of Manhattan on Monday. A local radio station plans to interview Wall Street brokers for reaction to New York's first mutant parade. Playmates, a subsidiary of Hong Kong-based Playmates Holdings Ltd., also is aggressively promoting its line spun off from the upcoming Dick Tracy movie. The film, starring Warren Beatty and Madonna, opens June 15. One hundred pairs of personalized handcuffs were sent to members of the media. To get the keys, reporters must show up at the Playmates showroom during the fair. About 350 reporters received ``talking'' invitations to see the Dick Tracy stuff. Cards of walkie-talkie wrist telephones, costing $8.50 a pop, contained sophisticated circuitry that summoned individual reporters by name to the Playmates showroom. Why go to such trouble? ``This is really the only chance of impressing and reaching the toy buyers about your product line,'' said Timothy Unger, a public relations executive handling the Playmates account. With hundreds of exhibitors at Toy Fair, he said. ``it's very important that you add as much pizazz as possible to your program.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Fall
DOC.TEXT: Stocks fell in nervous trading on London's Stock Exchange Friday, as investors worried over the prospect of rising inflation in Europe. With the threat of an interest rate hike in West Germany to cool inflation, London equities became unsettled. Equity analysts said the London market's recent stability has been based on the assumption that British interest rates would not rise any further. But if the West German Bundesbank hiked it interest rates, Britain likely would too. ``Caution has become the watchword,'' said a director at a brokerage firm. ``When you get the possibility that the cornerstone of Western Europe might shove its interest rates higher in what could be a destabilizing move, it's right that people take cover.'' At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 17.4 points, or 0.7 percent, at 2,313.6, compared with a session high of 2,323.9 and an early afternoon low of 2,308.5. The Financial Times 30-share index was down 14.6 points at 1,830.7 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 8.54 points to close at 1,260.56. Volume totaled 521.4 million shares, compared with 458.0 million shares Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of European, African and Middle Eastern Operations Named
DOC.TEXT: Apple Computer Inc. promoted a regional manager to head its European, African and Middle Eastern operations, the company announced Friday. Soren Olsson, 44, was named president of Apple Computer Europe, replacing Michael H. Spindler, who last week was named chief operating officer and executive vice president of Apple. Olsson had directed Apple's Scandinavian operation since 1984. He assumed the position of managing director of Sweden and Northern Europe in 1988, overseeing operations in Norway, Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Germany, Austria and several Eastern European countries. ``Soren has the vision and the drive needed to ensure Apple Europe's success in a global marketplace,'' said Spindler in announcing the promotion.

DOC.HEAD: Braniff Seeking to Sell Three Gates in Orlando
DOC.TEXT: Braniff Inc. is asking a federal bankruptcy court for permission to sell its three passenger gates at Orlando International Airport to Midway Airlines for $2.25 million. Braniff, based in Orlando, has been trying to raise cash by selling assets since Sept. 28, when it filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code. Part of the money from the gate sale would be set aside to pay some $400,000 which Braniff owes the Greater Orlando Aviation Authority, officials said. Braniff, which has stopped flying and laid off nearly all of its 4,800 employees, has survived on court-approved cash infusions from a dwindling bank account and the sale of aircraft parts, landing slots and passenger gates at other airports. Rodney May, a lawyer for the aviation authority, said he believes the sale of the three gates to Chicago-based Midway will be approved. ``They've done the deal. The aviation authority is going to get an airline in those gates and is getting paid. That's the result we wanted to achieve,'' May said Thursday. Midway now subleases two gates at the Orlando airport from Trans World Airlines. Midway has operated between Orlando and Chicago since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Rise on China Wheat Offer
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported by the Agriculture Department's offer to subsidize sales of 1 million metric tons of wheat to China. The USDA announcement, which came after the close of trading Thursday, stirred speculation that subsidized wheat also will be offered to the Soviet Union, said Susan Leighty, a grain-market analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. She said rumors of upcoming export bonus offers to both nations had circulated in the markets in the past month. Under a program designed to increase export sales of U.S. grain, the USDA provides grain or grain credits to exporters who sell grain to targeted nations. The near-month wheat contract, for delivery in March, rallied most strongly amid speculation that the Chinese would take some old-crop wheat in addition to new-crop, analysts said. At the close, wheat futures were \ cent lower to 4{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.87 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to } cent higher with March at $2.39} a bushel; oats were { cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.38 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3 cents higher with March at $5.66} a bushel.

The stock market posted some modest gains this afternoon in sluggish dealings as interest rates slipped and investors took a favorable view of an inflation report. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose more than 4.28 points on Thursday, was up 3.38 at 2,647.75 with one hour left in the session. Advancing issues outpaced declines by a margin of 8 to 7 among issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with 781 up, 663 down and 494 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 119.11 million shares as of 3 p.m. EST compared with 151.31 million shares at the same point in Thursday's session. The market opened higher, but then pulled back even as bonds advanced. Prices rallied again in the afternoon. Some analysts say the completion of the Treasury's $30 billion auction of new securities on Thursday should take some of the pressure off stocks. The auction ended with the sale of $10 billion in 30-year bonds, which received a less enthusiastic reception than the sales of $10 billion in three-year notes and a like amount of 10-year notes earlier in the week. But some analysts said the fact that the auctions are over should take some pressure off interest rates anyway. Rising interest rates make yields on fixed-income securities more competitive with those on stocks, reduce chances for corporate earnings growth and make it more expensive to borrow money to buy stocks. Before the market opened today, the government reported a steep 1.8 percent rise in its producer price index in January, the biggest one-month increase in more than 15 years. But analysts had been expecting a sharp rise, as the holiday cold snap sent energy and food prices soaring. Bond prices were up as much as $8 for every $1,000 in face value in the credit markets today and short-term interest rates fell. Among the blue-chip issues, American Telephone & Telegraph was down \ at 40, IBM was off \ at 102{ and General Electric was up { at 63{. The NYSE's composite index was up 0.30 at 184.39. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 2.79 at 360.47.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Switched Surveillance to New York After Bomb Scare
DOC.TEXT: Surveillance responsibilities for the national over-the-counter stock market were switched to New York briefly on Friday after the National Association of Securities Dealers headquarters were evacuated following a bomb threat. The NASD, which oversees the OTC market and maintains a national price quotation system for over-the-counter stocks, evacuated its office buildings in downtown Washington and Rockville, Md., spokesman Robert Ferri said. The Washington-area operations are responsible for market surveillance, including monitoring of trading for signs of improper activity. Surveillance was conducted from the association's New York offices during the hour the buildings were evacuated. Ferri said trading on NASD's automated quotation system, known as NASDAQ, was unaffected by the incident and workers in Washington and Rockville returned to their desks at 12:30 p.m. about an hour after the evacuation. Ferri said an unidentified male caller said there was a bomb in the building, although no direct threat was made against the NASD. No device was found at either location. Ferri said both buildings were evacuated because the call was received at a switchboard in Rockville that also serves the Washington office. A spokesman for the Montgomery County Police, Sgt. Harry Geehreng, said officers using a bomb sniffing dog searched the building in Rockville. Stocks traded over-the-counter generally represent smaller companies or newer, startup businesses without a substantial financial history.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed By Source For Release AMs Monday Feb. 12
Underwriting Decline Reflects Wall Street Woes
DOC.TEXT: More dismal news from Wall Street: The nation's leading brokerages made 21 percent less money underwriting stocks and bonds in 1989 than the year before, figures released Monday show. The total dollar volume and number of underwritings also fell sharply last year, and analysts expect firms to slash underwriting staffs to cope with the 1990s climate of conservatism following the 1980s boom. ``With lower levels of revenue and outlook for smaller dollar volume of business, chances are you could see departments trim back 10 to 15 percent (in 1990),'' said veteran industry analyst Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services. Wall Street already has begun retrenching in other areas of the securities business, with a number of major firms laying off thousands of workers across the board in recent months. In underwriting, investment firms acquire new stocks and bonds issued by corporations that are seeking to raise money and sell them to the investing public. The firms charge companies a percentage of the offer price, in the range of 6 percent on stocks and less than 1 percent on bonds. In an apparent attempt to stanch some of the underwriting business decline and to compete in a weak market, Wall Street firms last year cut back the average fee they charged to issue stocks and bonds for corporate clients, according to data compiled by IDD Information Services. But even that didn't help drum up much new business. For the full year, total underwriting fee revenue declined $811 million, or 20.9 percent, to $3.07 billion from $3.88 billion in 1988, IDD reported. The average fee as a percentage of dollar volume shrank to 1.59 percent from 1.71 percent. Fees from debt issues fell by 16 percent in 1989 and from all common stock issues by about 30 percent, IDD said. The biggest declines last year were in the area of initial public stock offerings by companies, with fees plummeting about 43 percent to $889 million from $1.56 billion in 1988. A slowdown in stock market activity was the primary reason for the drop. ``It's an expensive proposition to float new equity,'' Long said. ``Obviously you didn't have many new IPOs because the market wasn't doing anything.'' Money made from selling new issues of high-yield, low-grade junk bonds shrank about 14 percent to $795 million from $923 million, IDD said. Analysts attributed that drop to the virtual collapse in the junk bond market in the second half of 1989, when several companies scrapped large planned debt offers. Merrill Lynch Capital Markets was the overall leader in underwriting fees, reaping $448 million, or 14.6 percent of the market. In second place was Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which made nearly all of its $378 million in fees from junk-bond offers. IDD did not compare the fee rankings to 1988. Drexel has shrunk to nearly half its size since it pleaded guilty to felony crimes and paid $650 million to settle government insider trading charges. The firm's share of the junk bond market, while still commanding, is decreasing. For the full year, total stock and bond underwriting volume declined by about 15 percent to $193.6 billion from $227.4 billion in 1988. IPOs dived by 42 percent to $13.7 billion from $23.5 billion and junk bond issues fell 4.8 percent to $28.05 billion from $29.47 billion. The total number of debt and equity issues also declined sharply, to 1,452 in 1989 from 1,759 the previous year. There were 184 initial public offerings last year, down from 202 in 1988, and 125 junk-bond issues, down from 151. Merrill Lynch & Co. retained its No. 1 ranking, handling a total of $46 billion as lead underwriter. Goldman, Sachs & Co. remained second, while First Boston Corp. moved up to third, swapping places with Salomon Brothers Inc. Drexel's share of the junk-bond underwriting market slipped to 38.7 percent from 42.8 percent in 1988. But the firm remained by far the industry leader, with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. moving up to second place from 12th, but with just 9.4 percent of the market.

DOC.HEAD: Reader's Digest Completes Purchase of American Health
DOC.TEXT: Reader's Digest Association announced Friday that it has completed its purchase of American Health magazine for $29.1 million. The sale was completed after American Health Partners, which publishes the health and fitness magazine, met certain conditions set by Reader's Digest, said Bruce Trachtenberg, a spokesman for Reader's Digest. He declined to disclose the conditions. Reader's Digest, a privately held publishing company based in Pleasantville, N.Y., announced last month that it agreed to pay $29.1 million for American Health, provided that the conditions were met by Jan. 31. When that deadline passed, the contract was not terminated. Reader's Digest set no new deadline for completing the deal. Reader's Digest will focus primarily on integrating the American Health employees into its structure and working with advertisers, Trachtenberg said in a telephone interview. American Health Partners, a partnership based in New York, owns and publishes several other magazines, including Psychology Today and Mother Earth News.

DOC.HEAD: New Source of Anxiety on Interest Rates: Swiss-Cheese Berlin Wall
DOC.TEXT: Many investors who are worried about rising interest rates have focused their angst on mixed results from the latest Treasury Department auction of new U.S. debt. But another source of interest-rate paranoia emerged this past week, and it came streaming through the holes in the Berlin Wall. East and West Germany, which have been stunning the world with speedy moves toward reunification, dropped another big surprise: The West German mark soon could become the national currency of both countries. Monetary union had been considered the theoretical final phase of reunification. But East Germany's economy is so weak and its currency so worthless that the West proposed financial melding much sooner. This proposal was aimed largely at persuading East Germans to stay on their side of the border. Otherwise, West Germans feared, their cousins would migrate en masse, swamping West Germany's already overburdened social welfare system and turning East Germany's state-run economy into a rusty abandoned hulk. But the monetary union proposal could carry an enormous price, reaching far beyond Germany and across the Atlantic. In an indirect way, it could force interest rates to rise in this country. The reason, some economists argue, is that monetary union will acutely strain West Germany's economy, the most powerful in Europe, by forcing the West German government to print billions of new marks and borrow large sums of money by selling bonds. To control inflation and attract buyers for the bonds, the West Germans will have to offer higher interest rates. That will force the United States Treasury to raise the rates offered on its debt securities to keep them competitive to buyers looking for the best returns. The new fear about the impact of monetary union injected new uncertainty into the U.S. bond market, which had been preoccupied with the mixed results of the latest Treasury refunding auction. The auctions have an enormous influence in determining U.S. interest rates, depending on the yields the Treasury must offer to persuade investors to buy the new debt. Some economists say the U.S. bond market's behavior this past week shows how in many respects it has become a hostage to foreign events beyond America's control. One reason is the large U.S. budget deficit, which forces the Treasury to sell large amounts of government-backed IOUs to foreigners. But another is the ease with which investors transcend borders and move money anywhere they can earn the most profit. For many, Germany already looks increasingly attractive. At current yields, for example, a 10-year U.S. Treasury earns about 8.31 percent, and a comparable 10-year West German government bond earns about 8.28 percent. But when the higher U.S. inflation rate is factored in, the West German bond earns more. ``When I started trading bonds 20 years ago, the last thing in the world we cared about were what interest rates were doing in Germany,'' said William Veronda, a fixed-income strategist at Financial Group, a Denver investment firm. ``But with a more volatile flow of funds throughout the world now, many investors stop and say, `Gee, the real return is much better there.''' In other business and economic news this past week: _The government said record price increases for vegetables and fuel oil combined in January to produce a 1.8 percent rise in wholesale inflation, the highest monthly rate in 15 years. But economists were quick to characterize the rise as a temporary spurt due to the holiday cold snap. _More signs emerged of trouble in the airline business. The government said the on-time performance of major carriers was the worst ever in December and a record number of bags were lost. Texas Air Corp. reported a record annual loss of $885.6 million, moneylosing Pan Am Corp. dropped hints it still was seeking a merger partner, and Trans World Airlines pilots snubbed owner Carl Icahn's efforts to cut the carrier's losses with wage concessions. _Georgia was on the minds of woodcutters and federal securities officials. A federal judge's ruling made it much easier for Georgia Pacific Corp. in its $3.5 billion hostile attempt to buy Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. Takeover investor Harold Simmons said the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating his stock purchases in target Georgia Gulf Corp.

DOC.HEAD: For Weekend Editions Feb 10-11
Market Outlook Shaky Despite Passage of Refunding Auction
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury auction monkey is off the stock market's back, but many observers say Wall Street still faces some rocky moments as it tries to sustain a recovery from its January lows. They warn of potential corporate earnings shocks. Rising interest rates overseas may continue to make home-grown investments more attractive to foreigners. And weakness in the dollar could cut foreign demand here as well. On the plus side, they say inflation appears to be under control despite a strong increase in wholesale prices in January. The increase was blamed in large part on spikes in food and energy prices due to unusually cold weather. And they say that the slowing economy may soon inspire declines in interest rates that will make stocks more attractive. In a word, analysts on both sides of the fence say the next few weeks will be _ bumpy. ``Getting the refunding behind us is positive for the market. It takes away one of the negatives overhanging the market,'' said Thomas Czech, chairman of the investment committee at Blunt Ellis & Loewi in Milwaukee. The refunding auction, which involved sales of $30 billion in new Treasury notes and bonds, had been nervously awaited by the stock market. Traders feared that rising rates in Japan and other countries would diminish the foreign appetite for Treasury issues, forcing the government to offer even higher interest rates to sell all of the new issues. But demand was strong for the three-year and 10-year notes, and even a lukewarm reception for the 30-year bonds didn't spoil the impression that the refunding had gone fairly well. Nonetheless, having the refunding out of the way does now guarantee smooth sailing for either the stock or bond markets. ``We have some other clouds to clear up here,'' Czech said. He said the weak dollar has been ``bothering the stock market'' and has given no signs of bottoming out. In addition, he said ``disappointing earnings will be with us for a while,'' hurting stock prices. He expects the market to move in spurts in a trendless pattern over the next few weeks until ``we get a clear sign that inflation is receding.'' ``We are still facing a market that was wounded in January,'' said Bill Raftery, a technical researcher for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. He referred to a move that took the Dow Jones industrial average to a record high of 2,810.15 on Jan. 2 and then sent it careening to a low of 2,543.24 on Jan. 30. The market has retraced about a third of the loss through Friday's close, but Raftery noted, ``It takes a long time to heal the wounds.'' Rao Chalasani, market strategist for Prescott, Ball & Turben in Cleveland, expects rates to continue rising in West Germany and Japan as monetary officials there respond to signs of inflation. In addition, he said the first-quarter corporate earnings reports will be worse than the market anticipates. He said the Dow Jones industrial average could fall to the 2,400 level in the spring before declining interest rates spark an economic pickup and provide a lift for stocks later in the year. This past week, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials showed a net gain of 45.50 to finish at 2,648.20 by Friday's close. It was the second consecutive weekly advance as the Dow Jones average rose 43.47 the previous week. Other readings for the week showed the New York Stock Exchange composite index gained 1.64 to 184.39; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market was up 6.63 at 428.84; and the American Stock Exchange market value index rose 7.23 to 360.79, its strongest gain since rising 7.38 for the week ended Sept. 29, 1989. Big Board volume averaged 154.98 million shares a day, down from 169.09 million the previous week. Investment newsletter writers are in their most pessimistic mood about the market's prospects since June 1982, according to a survey by Investors Intelligence, which studies about 130 newsletters a week in New Rochelle, N.Y. Editor Michael Burke said his latest report, which covered the week ended last Friday, found that 57.3 percent of the nearly 130 newsletters studied were bearish on prospects for the stock market, the highest since 57.6 percent were bearish in June 1982. The report found 29.9 percent of the newsletters were bullish, down from 56.0 percent in the week of Dec. 15. Of course, some analysts view such reports as a contrarian signal that the market may be about to reverse direction. ``When they get nervous, people say `Sell' very quickly. They are pulling the trigger very quickly here,'' Burke said.
