DOC.HEAD: AT&T Maintenance Glitch Leaves Some ``800'' Numbers Dead for 1{ Hours
DOC.TEXT: As many as 200 AT&T customers with toll-free 800 numbers were left without service for nearly 1{ hours Friday, the second time in a month the phone company has experienced a major service problem. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. blamed the latest problem on a maintenance error. Customers with 800 numbers followed by the digits 424 could not receive calls from 12:40 p.m. EST and 2 p.m., said AT&T spokesman Gary Morgenstern. He said as many as 200 business and agencies may have been affected, but added that a precise figure was not available and that the number may have been smaller. An 800 number is one which callers may call without incurring any charges. One of the customers affected, the federal Internal Revenue Service, reported its toll-free number, 1-800-424-1040, was down in about half the the nation. ``The entire eastern half of the country was involved as far as that toll-free situation,'' said IRS spokeswoman Phyllis Goodwin in Newark. ``I understand it has been taken care of.'' She could not estimate the number of taxpayers seeking information that were unable to get through. The outage occurred because of an ``error in a routine maintenance procedure,'' Morgenstern said. ``Someone failed to follow standard procedure'' while technicians were relocating some 800 numbers from one network control point to another. ``These routing changes were inadvertently omitted from one of the systems which guide network traffic,'' he said. He did not know where the technicians were working. On Jan. 15, much of AT&T's long-distance network was down nationwide for nine hours due to a computer programming error in the network's call switching system. The company has scheduled a special discount day Feb. 14 to make it up to long distance customers inconvenienced by the outage. Discounts of 33 percent off the regular daytime rate will be in effect between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. that day, Morgenstern said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON BC
Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed against other major currencies Friday in light pre-weekend trading and the soaring West German mark lost a little altitude. Gold prices fell in domestic and overseas dealing. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $416.10 a troy ounce, down $2.60 from Thursday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a troy ounce of gold at $415.75 as of 4 p.m. EST, compared to Thursday's late bid of $418.70. Currency dealers said the dollar stayed within a narrow range for most of the session as the markets wound down activity ahead of the weekend. ``The dollar was basically range-bound,'' said Richard Alford, a vice president of the Continental Bank of Chicago. The foreign exchange markets managed to take in stride a large 1.8 percent increase in the Producer Price Index during January. Economists noted the wholesale inflation reading was boosted by the severe cold snap in December; excluding food and energy the PPI went up a barely perceptible 0.1 percent. Enthusiasm to invest heavily in marks was tempered by news that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl favors uniting the two Germanys with a common currency. Dealers, who had been buying marks aggressively on the assumption that the West German economy would benefit from the reforms in Eastern Europe, adopted a more cautious approach. There was uncertainty about what a possible merging of East and West Germany's currencies would mean. Regardless, dollar trading continued to be secondary to activity in marks, British pounds, Japanese yen and Swiss francs on world markets Friday. The dollar traded at 1.6680 marks late in New York, up from 1.6665 Thursday and also above the level of 1.6750 marks at the close of European trading. In London, one British pound cost $1.6930 late Friday, more expensive than Thursday's late $1.6885. Sterling also strengthened in New York, where a pound was quoted at $1.6955 late in the day compared with $1.69435 on Thursday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar began its trading day by falling to 144.72 yen from 145.50 late Thursday. Later, in London, the dollar traded higher at 145.20 yen but it ran out of upward momentum in New York and closed at 144.725 yen, down from 145.315 yen Thursday. Other late dollar rates in New York compared with Thursday's late quotes, included: 1.4915 Swiss francs, up from 1.4890; 5.672 French francs, up from 5.6660; 1,241.25 Italian lire, up from 1,240.25; and 1.20025 Canadian dollars, up from 1.19465. Late rates for the dollar in Europe Friday compared with Thursday's late levels were: 1.6750 West German marks, down from 1.6872; 1.4935 Swiss francs, up from 1.4905; 5.6765 French francs, up from 5.6725; 1.8835 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8810; 1,242.25 Italian lire, up from 1,241.50; and 1.1987 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1970. Meanwhile, in the precious metals markets gold prices posted slight declines. Gold in London traded late at a bid price of $415.75 a troy ounce, down from $417.75. The Zurich late bid was $416, also down from $417.75. In Hong Kong, gold closed at a bid of $419.15, up from $418.15. Silver prices moved lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.254 a troy ounce compared with $5.324 on Thursday. Silver bullion traded late in London at $5.25 a troy ounce, down from Thursday's late bid of $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Post Small Gains, Up for Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market posted a small gain Friday, drawing some mild encouragement from an inflation report and a decline in interest rates. Trading activity was sluggish. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 4.28 points on Thursday, added another 3.83 points to close at 2,648.20, extending its gain for the week to 45.50 points. Advancing issues outnumbered losers by about 8 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 826 up, 667 down and 478 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 146.91 million shares, down from 176.24 million in the previous session. Volume for the week averaged 154.98 million shares, down from 169.09 million the previous week. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 179.22 million shares. The market traded in a narrow range for most of the day, opening higher, fading at midmorning, rallying again in the afternoon and fading at the close. Before the market opened, the government reported a steep 1.8 percent rise in its producer price index in January, the biggest one-month increase in more than 15 years. But analysts had been expecting a sharp rise, as the holiday cold snap sent energy and food prices soaring. Discounting the food and energy increases, inflation was lower than had been expected. The report was viewed positively in the credit markets, where bond prices rose as much as $10 for every $1,000 in face value and short-term interest rates fell by 6 to 7 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Some analysts say the completion of the Treasury's $30 billion auction of new securities on Thursday should take some of the pressure off stocks. The auction ended with the sale of $10 billion in 30-year bonds, which received a less enthusiastic reception than the sales of $10 billion in three-year notes and a like amount of 10-year notes earlier in the week. But the analysts said the refunding as a whole went well, avoiding the big spikes in rates that some traders had expected. Rising interest rates make yields on fixed-income securities more competitive with those on stocks, reduce chances for corporate earnings growth and make it more expensive to borrow money to buy stocks. Amax was the most active stock on the NYSE, finishing unchanged at 23[. Scudder New Europe Fund, a mutual fund, was the second most active, closing at 13] compared with an initial offering price of 12{ earlier in the day. Among other active issues on the NYSE, Philip Morris fell [ to 39\, Chase Manhattan was down } at 28 and Bank of New England fell \ to 5. Among the blue-chip issues, American Telephone & Telegraph lost ] to 39~, IBM fell \ to 102{ and General Electric rose \ at 63\. Great Northern Nekoosa climbed 2| to 61]. A federal judge's ruling that just a two-thirds vote by shareholders can oust Great Northern's directors was hailed by Georgia-Pacific Corp. as a victory in its $3.8 billion takeover attempt. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $7.02 billion, or 0.22 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.30 to 184.39. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 0.58 to 385.57, and S&P's 500-stock composite index rose 0.66 to 333.62. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 1.52 to 428.84. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.79, up 3.11.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Chrysler Refuse to Rule Out Further Plant Closings
DOC.TEXT: Top executives of General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. declined Friday to rule out further plant closings this year, but said temporary shutdowns had whittled new-car inventories to reasonable levels. GM Chairman Roger Smith and Chrysler Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald, meeting separately with reporters previewing the Chicago Auto Show, said changes in the fickle U.S. car and truck market could result in more plant shutdowns this year. Separately, Smith said he expected GM to report company-record sales of $125 billion for 1989 next week, up by about $1.4 billion from the previous year. Ford and Chrysler also report their earnings next week. Slow sales and rising inventories prompted temporary plant shutdowns last month, which put thousands of auto workers on layoff but significantly reduced new-car inventory levels Inventories of unsold cars now are at between 60 days and 70 days supply, considered normal for this time of year, compared with between 90 and 100 days at the end of December based on the current selling rate. In January the automakers, particularly Chrysler, trimmed production and experienced higher-than-anticipated sales as the full effect of buyer incentive programs announced the month before became apparent. Executives at each of the Big Three automakers have said their inventories are in line with production now, although it may not stay that way for GM and Chrysler. ``We're going to have to see how the market evolves,'' Greenwald said Friday. Later, Smith said he didn't see any need to close a plant in the near future, but added, ``These are things you have to stay loose and roll with.'' On Thursday, Ford North American sales Vice President Robert Rewey had said ``I believe that the inventory correction that we planned was essentially completed at the end of January.'' Ford is the only one of the Big Three that has not announced a plant shutdown or large-scale indefinite layoffs for 1990. Chrysler shut down its Detroit subcompact car plant a week ago and plans to close its car plant in St. Louis on Sept. 21. GM will close its Lakewood car assembly plant in Atlanta in mid-March. GM and Chrysler also will be removing shifts and slowing production rates at other plants, resulting in indefinite layoffs. Also Friday: _Greenwald said some bids had been received for its Chrysler Technologies Corp. subsidiary, and indicated that talks about selling the company, which includes Gulfstream Aerospace Inc., were in late stages. However, he declined to discuss any details with reporters and said negotiations were at their most delicate stage. _Toyota Motor Corp. introduced its new minivan, the Previa. Its 2.4-liter, four-cylinder engine is mounted under the front seats, behind the front axle. Base price for the imported vehicle, which will arrive in showrooms in limited numbers next week, will be $13,998, said Bob McCurry, executive vice president for Toyota's U.S. marketing organization. McCurry said the company expected to import a relatively modest 40,000 of the Japanese-built vehicles during 1990. _Smith said a decision would be made within 90 days of how to proceed, if at all, with an electric-powered vehicle. GM first showed its Impact electric car last month in Los Angeles. He said the company's options included production of the Impact, transferring the Impact's technology to an existing car, such as the Geo Storm made for GM by Isuzu Motors Corp., or delaying a production decision altogether.

DOC.HEAD: Coffee Futures Hit 5-Month High On Supply Concerns
DOC.TEXT: Coffee futures prices surged to their highest levels in five months Friday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, fueled by rumors of cancelled Mexican coffee shipments and other supply concerns. On other commodity markets, near-month oil futures fell sharply; orange juice futures fell ahead of a bearishly construed crop report; precious metals slipped; grains and soybeans were higher; and livestock and meat futures retreated. Coffee futures settled 2.85 cents to 3.24 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March up 2.97 cents at 85.06 cents a pound, the highest settlement of the March contract since Sept. 21 and the highest for a near-month contract since Sept. 11, when the September contract settled at 88.08 cents. The main influence in the coffee market was unconfirmed talk that Mexico had cancelled export shipments of 350,000 to 400,000 132-pound bags of coffee, said Celeste Georkakis, a market analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. The rumors were supported by estimates that a Christmastime freeze damaged about 10 percent of the coffee crop in Mexico, the world's fourth-largest producer. ``Mexico has been withdrawing from market since the freeze and is probably evaluating the situation overall,'' Ms. Georkakis said. Other constructive factors in the coffee market included a threatened strike by dockworkers in Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, and perceptions that President Bush's trip next week to Colombia will include discussions about possible reinstatement of coffee export quotas to support prices. Prices for March deliveries of crude oil, heating oil and gasoline tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange, possibly reflecting expectations for a drop in demand for crude oil over the next two months as U.S. refineries partially shut down for annual maintenance. During the shutdowns, known as ``turnarounds,'' refiners retool to produce more gasoline and less fuel oil to meet the demands of the summer driving season. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures finished 35 cents lower to 55 cents higher with March at $21.74 a barrel; heating oil was .24 cent lower to .61 cent higher with March at 55.08 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .25 cent to 1.61 cents lower with March at 59.56 cents a gallon. Orange juice futures fell on the New York Cotton Exchange as traders positioned for an Agriculture Department report released after the close that contained a higher-than-expected Florida orange crop projection. In its second monthly crop estimate since the December freeze, the USDA pegged the 1989-90 Florida orange crop at 100 million 90-pound boxes compared with the January estimate of 92 million, the pre-freeze estimate of 130 million and last year's harvest of 147 million. The projected yield was reduced to 1.29 gallons per box from 1.3 gallons. Frozen concentrated orange juice futures settled .75 cent to 1.75 cents lower with March at $1.9775 a pound. Gold and silver futures sank on New York's Commodity Exchange, partly in reaction to the stock market's strength. Gold settled $2.60 to $3.30 lower with February at $416.10 a troy ounce; silver was 7 cents to 7.8 cents lower with March at $5.273 a troy ounce. Most grain and soybean futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade, supported by the Agriculture Department's offer to subsidize sales of 1 million metric tons of wheat to China. After the close, the USDA released a supply-and-demand report containing lower estimates for 1989-90 ending stocks of U.S. corn and wheat, prompting predictions of higher corn futures when trading resumes Monday. Wheat settled { cent lower to 4\ cents higher with March at $3.86} a bushel; corn was \ cent to { cent higher with March at $2.39{ a bushel; oats were } cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $1.38 a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 3 cents higher with March at $5.66} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, pressured by falling beef prices and a large hog slaughter on Thursday. Live cattle futures were .30 cent to .47 cent lower with February at 79.22 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .80 cent lower with March at 81.77 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .25 cent lower with February at 49.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .70 cent to 1 cent lower with February at 49.70 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: FOMC Voted To Ease Credit At December Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve policy-makers decided at their December meeting to further ease their high interest rate policies due to the sluggish economy, according to minutes released Friday. Two days after the Dec. 18-19 meeting, the federal funds rate dropped from 8.5 percent to 8.25 percent, the sixth quarter of a percentage point decline since the rate peaked at 9.75 percent in June. Federal funds _ the interest banks charge each other for overnight loans _ is the primary lever the Fed uses to control short-term interest rates. It has not been adjusted since Dec. 21. The central bank has kept interest rates relatively high for more than a year as it sought to decrease inflation by slowing the economy. The gross national product, the total output of goods and services, declined from third-quarter growth of 3 percent to just 0.5 percent in the last three months of 1989. Some government officials and business leaders have urged the Fed to loosen its grip further to stimulate economic activity. The Federal Open Market Committee, as the policy-making body is called, met again Tuesday and Wednesday to review monetary policy, but minutes of that meeting will not be released until next month. The committee holds closed meetings eight times a year to formulate monetary policy and confers by telephone as needed. It is made up of the seven Federal Reserve Board members and five of the 12 presidents of the Fed district banks. ``A majority indicated that on balance they viewed the risks of a shortfall in economic activity as sufficiently high to justify an immediate move to slightly easier reserve conditions, and one member expressed a preference for somewhat greater easing,'' the minutes of the December meeting said. ``Members who supported an unchanged policy ... were concerned that further easing might overcompensate for current weaknesses in the economy at the cost of delaying progress toward price stability,'' the minutes stated. In the end, the vote to ease was 9-2. Dissenting were Govs. Wayne D. Angell and Thomas C. Melzer. One board governorship is vacant. In arriving at their decision, committee members reviewed information suggesting that economic activity was expanding slowly in the fourth quarter with sluggishness ``especially evident in the manufacturing sector,'' the minutes read. ``By contrast, growth of the service sector appeared to be well sustained and overall construciton activity seemed relatively firm,'' they continued. However, a Fed staff projection suggested the economy would continue to slow over the next several quarters, although it would rebound in the first quarter from the effects of fourth-quarter strikes and natural disasters. As it has in the past, the committee agreed that its decision would be subject to further adjustment depending on subsequent economic developments.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Prices Finish Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished mixed Friday, with near-month contracts posting losses amid concern that petroleum supplies will exceed demand in the short term. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of crude oil, fell 35 cents to $21.74 per 42-gallon barrel. The contract finished the week with a net loss of $1.28 a barrel. Crude oil for April lost 9 cents to $21.56 a barrel, while contracts for later delivery posted gains. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale unleaded gasoline for March delivery fell 1.61 cents to 59.56 cents a gallon, for a net weekly loss of 4.66 cents. April closed 1.50 lower at 60.25 cents a gallon, May was off 1.15 cents to 64.25 cents and other contracts had narrower declines. March heating oil, which lost 0.57 cent on Thursday, remained under pressure from warm weather in the Northeast, traders said. The contract closed down 0.24 cent at 55.08 cents a gallon. Later contracts finished higher. April ended at 54.62 cents, up 0.21 cent, and May rose 0.61 cent to 54.06 cents a gallon. Analysts said prices came under pressure from industry and government reports this week that showed an increase in crude and product supplies in the nation's storage tanks. The higher stocks coincide with lower seasonal demand. Crude prices also weakened on word that many big refineries would slow operations for their spring overhaul in the next few months, which suggests a decline in demand for raw oil by refiners. Although this week's reports by the American Petroleum Institute and Department of Energy showed that gasoline supplies were higher week-to-week but lower than last year, analysts said there was no immediate cause to worry about possible supply tightness. Jack Baker, energy analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. called ``outlandish'' a news report Friday that suggested a possible squeeze in motor fuel supplies this spring. ``We have less inventories than last year but more than we had last April 1 and we're making more,'' said Baker. Moreover, annual maintenance turnarounds at refineries are being done in March and April, earlier than last year and well ahead of the peak gasoline season, analysts said. Refineries, therefore, are expected to be pumping plenty of gasoline in time to meet spring demand and environmental standards requiring lower-polluting motor fuel, analysts said.

DOC.HEAD: Gibraltar Financial Corp. Files For Bankruptcy Protection
DOC.TEXT: Gibraltar Financial Corp. has filed for protection from its creditors under federal bankruptcy law, nearly a year after regulators seized its main unit, Gibraltar Savings. Gibraltar Chairman James N. Thayer said the thrift holding company was forced to make the filing Thursday to dissolve a claim against its assets by Bank of America, the trustee for the holders of $99.5 million in unsecured Gibraltar bonds. Thayer also said the move was prompted in part by the government's seizure of two of the corporation's savings and loan subsidiaries, Gibraltar Savings and Gibraltar Savings Bank, F.A., in March 1989. The filing, which had been expected, was made under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. It gives Gibraltar freedom from the threat of creditors' lawsuits while trying to reorganize its business. Bank of America obtained a writ of attachment against Gibraltar's assets in November. Gibraltar was unable to make interest payments because federal regulators seized Simi Valley-based Gibraltar Savings March 31, declaring it insolvent. The unit then didn't pay interest on debt it owed the parent company. ``The company intends to continue its legal remedies against Gibraltar Savings and the federal regulators during the course of the Chapter 11 case for the benefit of our creditors and stockholders,'' Thayer said in a statement. Gibraltar Savings had 83 branches and the sister thrift had six branches in Washington and 18 in Florida. Together, they had $8.8 billion in deposits when seized. Gibraltar Financial sued regulators last June, demanding that Gibraltar Savings return about $11 million that the one-time parent company claims it is owed. Thayer, who has been highly critical of the regulators, continued his attack on them in his statement, saying the bankruptcy filing would not have been necessary if Gibraltar Financial still ran the thrift. ``While the writ of attachment was the proximate cause of today's action, the Chapter 11 filing also resulted from the federal regulators' action in seizing Gibraltar Savings and Gibraltar Savings Bank ... and the regulators' failure to date to cause Gibraltar Savings to pay its debts to the company,'' Thayer said. Gibraltar Financial lost $100.5 million in 1988 and $146.5 million in 1987. In 1986, it had a $43.9 million profit. The holding company, whose stock is publicly traded, has no significant assets other than its units in California and Washington state.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Shoot Up After Auction
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose sharply Friday, rallying after the successful completion of the Treasury Department's $30 billion quarterly refunding auction. The newly issued 30-year government bond surged 1 25-32 points, or $17.81 per $1,000 in face amount, from its level at Thursday's auction. Its yield tumbled to 8.33 percent from 8.50 percent. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions. The jump in the price of the long bond, the most widely watched of government securities, was the largest since last Oct. 13, when it rose 2 9-16 points in response to a sharp sell-off in the stock market. Credit market strategists attributed Friday's large increase to two factors: relief over the completion of the Treasury's three-day auction this week and a government report indicating that wholesale inflation in January was low, excluding volatile food and energy prices. The government sold $10 billion each of three-year notes, 10-year notes and 30-year bonds on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. The market had viewed the auctions with concern that low foreign buying would push yields up and prices down to stimulate interest. The United States has come to depend on foreign investors, particularly the Japanese, to help finance the federal deficit and pay interest on the total public debt. Instead, the auction was completed successfully, with adequate foreign interest propped up by strong domestic buying. Demand slackened only in the final leg, the 30-year bond. ``There's a lot of relief the refunding is over and the auctions by and large went well _ at least better than expected at the beginning of the week,'' said Steven A. Wood, money market economist with BankAmerica Capital Markets Group in San Francisco. In addition, the credit markets were pleased with an increase of just 0.1 percent in wholesale inflation for January excluding a spurt in food and energy prices due to severe cold around the country. Overall, the Producer Price Index for Janaury rose 1.8 percent, the sharpest rise since 1974. But the ``core rate'' excluding food energy is viewed as a better measure of underlying inflationary pressure. Economists said the low core rate was interpreted to indicate that the Federal Reserve Board would not likely raise interest rates to try to cool off the economy and curb increasing costs. High inflation tends to erode prices of fixed-income securities such as bonds. ``It's now viewed the Fed does not have to overreact to the energy and food situation and it can probably continue to hold policy pretty steady,'' Wood said. In the secondary market for Treasury securities, prices of short-term government issues rose [ point to 5-16 point, intermediate maturities gained 13-32 point to 27-32 point and long-term issues climbed 29-32 point to 1 point, according to figures provided by Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, gained 6.52 to 1,166.99. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.99 percent as the discount declined 6 basis points to 7.74 percent. Yields on six-month bills slipped to 8.07 percent as the discount lost 7 basis points to 7.66 percent. Yields on one-year bills declined to 8.01 percent as the discount declined 7 basis points to 7.49 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8\ percent, up from 8 3-16 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 92\, up 9-16 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.38 percent from 7.43 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Committee Drops Objections to Allied Financing
DOC.TEXT: Unsecured creditors of Allied Stores Corp. fell in line Friday and dropped their objections to $1 billion in new financing for the Cincinnati-based retailer. Lawyers for Allied and for the creditors said they agreed to a compromise similar to the one forged Thursday by Federated Department Stores and its creditors committee. The Federated proposal is for $1.4 billion in financing. Both proposals have been submitted to U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who is overseeing the Chapter 11 reorganization of the two U.S. retail divisions of Toronto-based Campeau Corp. Aug, who heard nearly eight hours of testimony regarding Federated on Thursday and two hours Friday regarding Allied, said the company's arguments on behalf of both financing proposals met minimum requirements. But he said he would review the presentations before signing the orders. Officers of Federated and Allied testified that they negotiated the best deals possible and needed quick approval to meet a Wednesday deadline set by the banks providing the financing. Federated's deal includes $400 million in operating capital and a $1 billion financing package allowing Federated to sell credit card debts to a subsidiary, Federated Credit Corp. The credit division wasn't among those Campeau units that filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors Jan. 15. Citibank of New York heads a 90-bank group providing the $400 million. Allied's deal is for $300 million in operating capital and $700 million from selling receivables. Chemical Bank of New York would provide the $300 million, and Citibank would provide the $700 million. ``It's a very efficient way to finance receivables. Without it, there would not be enough to pay our bills on time,'' Allied treasurer Mark Kennedy testified Friday. ``We believe it's necessary to receive approval at this point in time. We need to keep up the vendor confidence we have right now,'' he said. The unsecured creditors had objected, contending that Allied could operate a while longer without rushing into a loan agreement, and argued that the banks would gain too much control by the conditions they put on the loans. Attorney Lawrence Gottlieb said the creditors committee would drop its objection in exchange for rewording of Federated's proposed order to give greater protection to the trade creditors. ``We have a great desire to work together. We have a lot of vendors who do a lot of business with the debtor. We just ask the debtor to work with us,'' Gottlieb said. Allied agreed to provide monthly financial reports on each division, said laywers, who continued to work out the final wording after the hearing. Aug called it ``a productive compromise.'' ``I hope that talks do not break down for some unforeseen reason,'' Aug said. Federated and Allied listed a total of $7.7 billion in debt when they filed for bankruptcy protection. The two retailers employ about 100,000 people and operate 260 stores in nine chains: Abraham and Straus and Bloomingdale's of New York, Burdine's of Miami, Lazarus of Cincinnati and Rich's of Atlanta in the Federated group; and The Bon Marche of Seattle, Jordan Marsh of Boston, Maas Brothers of Tampa and Stern's of Paramus, N.J., in the Allied group.

DOC.HEAD: German Governments Deny Imminent East German Economic Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to RECAST, clarifying that Kohl official was speaking privately, timing of statements. Picks up 5th, `The federal...'. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The deteriorating condition of the East German economy, crippled by a daily drain of 1,800 people leaving for the West, has heightened concern among officials but both German governments denied Friday that collapse is imminent. A top official in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, speaking privately, said earlier Friday the decline fueled by worker exodus, widespread strikes and high absenteeism at many industrial sites has accelerated to the point that ``insolvency could be within a few days.'' Kohl will discuss the need for immediate aid in the ``billions of marks'' (dollars) for East German neighbors during his weekend visit to Moscow, said the senior official. But Bonn government spokesman Hans Klein issued a statement later in the day saying Bonn was not officially predicting an East German collapse. ``The federal government is not of the opinion that East Germany in the next days will be insolvent,'' Klein said, but noted that some individual leaders ``fear such extreme possibilities.'' A spokesman for East Germany's Communist government of Premier Hans Modrow denied the nation of 16 million residents is in such dire circumstances. ``As long as the Modrow government exists, East Germany will remain solvent,'' spokesman Wolfgang Meyer told reporters in East Berlin. The senior Kohl official also said East Germany's first-ever free elections, set for March 18, are threatened by the economic disaster. ``Certain state offices don't exist any more. There are those in East Germany who doubt that the March election date can even be reached,'' the official said. ``The situation cannot be assessed dramatically enough.'' An accelerated decline would likely send more fleeing to West Germany, which is finding it hard to absorb hundreds of thousands of East Germans, many of them craftsmen, who already have fled seeking a better life. Kohl on Wednesday formed a Cabinet committee charged with working out unification of the two German states, including immediate efforts to make the West German mark the common currency in an effort to stabilize East Germany's economy. The East German currency is virtually worthless outside the country. Since the October ouster of hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker and the November opening of the Berlin Wall, reunification has become a major issue of debate. West Germany, with 61 million residents, has tried to dismiss fears that a single Germany would endanger the rest of Europe. In an address in the East German city of Potsdam, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher proposed the two German states jointly agree to issue border guarantees to their neighbors and renounce possession of atomic weapons as a prelude to unity. The Communist officials still running the East German government have reacted coolly to Kohl's currency union offer, as it hinges on wholesale adoption of market economics. But East German Economics Minister Christa Luft said Modrow would discuss the proposal when he visits Bonn next week. Bundesbank President Karl Otto Poehl met with reporters earlier Friday and emphasized the positive aspects of monetary union, although he had said after an East Berlin visit three days earlier that it was far too early to introduce hard currency to East Germany. Economic union with East Germany will mean major sacrifices for both populations, Poehl acknowledged. But he pointed to West Germans' prosperity and glowing economic forecasts in arguing that Bonn could afford such a bailout. Poehl made clear that he has strong doubts about the timing and pace of the monetary union proposed by Kohl, and said he was ``surprised'' that the chancellor announced the plan without talking to the central bank first. Economists are predicting higher interest rates and taxes for West Germans, but Poehl said there is no cause for alarm.

DOC.HEAD: Farley, WestPoint Pepperell Debt Downgraded
DOC.TEXT: Two major credit rating agencies on Friday downgraded the debt of Farley Inc. and WestPoint Pepperell Inc., citing Farley's difficulties in completing financing for its $3 billion acquisition. Standard & Poor's Corp. said in downgrading $1.14 billion of Farley debt that the outlook for the Chicago-based company remains negative. Separately, Moody's Investors Service Inc. downgraded about $96 million in long-term debt of West Point, Ga.-based Pepperell and its subsidiary J.P. Stevens & Co. ``The rating actions reflect an increasingly strained financial position precipitated by Farley's apparent inability to date to finance the purchase of the remainder of WestPoint Pepperell's common stock,'' S&P said in a statement. The New York-based credit rating agency said the problem has hampered Farley's ability to fund the purchase permanently. S&P said the situation threatens ``the viability of the entire group of companies unless refinanced.'' S&P noted that the pending sale of Pepperell's Cluett Peabody unit has been delayed for several months, and the purchase price has been reduced by $170 million, to $430 million. S&P lowered Farley's subordinated debt ratings to triple C and the senior debt of Pepperell to single B minus. The service also lowered its rating for other Farley and Pepperell subsidiaries, including Fruit of the Loom. Moody's said it downgraded the debt ratings of Pepperell and J.P. Stevens to CAA from BAA3 because of high leverage from the acquisition of Pepperell as well as the company's inability to quickly dispose of assets as plannned. ``Moody's believes that the flat retail environment will make it exceedingly difficult for WestPoint to sufficiently increase returns on its operations to adequately support the debt,'' the New York agency said. Farley acquired Pepperell early last year after a fierce battle with the West Point-based textile company's management.

DOC.HEAD: New Crop Forecast Slightly Better for Oranges
DOC.TEXT: The picture for Florida's ravaged citrus industry brightened just a bit Friday when agricultural statisticians projected a slightly better orange crop than in their first post-freeze analysis. The U.S. Agriculture Department revised its January figures upward by 8 million boxes of early and mid-season oranges, putting the overall orange total at 100 million boxes for the 1989-90 crop year. If the projection holds up, Florida's orange crop will still be one-third lower than the 146.6 million boxes produced last season, said officials of the USDA's Florida Agricultural Statistics Service in Orlando. Before the Christmas weekend freeze, the current year's orange harvest had been projected at 130 million 90-pound boxes. The state-federal crop inspectors said after the freeze that this could be slashed 29 percent to 92 million boxes _ the smallest estimated production in 25 years. But Friday's more optimistic forecast said the orange crop reduction from the pre-freeze forecast may be 23 percent, or 100 million boxes. The estimated juice yield was decreased to 1.29 gallons from the 1.30 gallons for each box of oranges projected last month. Citrus Statistician Paul N. Messenger of the Orlando office said analysts originally compared the Christmas freeze to the one in 1983 because they had been so similar in temperatures and duration, the time of year and the amount of the crop on the trees. The 1983 freeze reduced the orange crop by 30 percent. ``It is apparent that the early and mids did not have as great a loss as they did in the `83 freeze,'' Messenger said. Another reason for the slight upward revision in the forecast is ``the good salvage operations of the crop,'' he said. ``Utilization of freeze-damaged fruit has exceeded expectations of the first post-freeze forecast in January,'' the USDA report said. Harvesting and processing of the ice-bitten fruit is about 90 percent complete, with only a few southern areas remaining to be picked in the state's 700,000-acre citrus belt. The now-ripening Valencia orange crop forecast was unchanged from January's projection of 32 million boxes. Seedless grapefruit-harvest projections dropped even further, however, from a figure of 35.5 million boxes right after the freeze to 32.5 million. Last year's production was 51 million boxes. Messenger said there had been few reports of tree damage, but extensive evaluation will not be made until this summer. ``Most of the trees are coming out very well, with new growth and new bloom,'' said Messenger. But he and growers say such new growth makes trees vulnerable to any further cold weather. Some industry officials have estimated financial losses at the farm level at $200 million to $300 million. This does not include loss of added value from harvesting and processing.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Arrest of Eddie Antar for Contempt of Court
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday ordered U.S. marshals to arrest the founder of the collapsed electronics chain Crazy Eddie Inc. for contempt of court after he refused to return $52 million to the United States. U.S. District Judge Nicholas H. Politan angrily demanded the arrest of Eddie Antar after having given him three extensions to show up in court. ``I want this man brought before me,'' Politan said. ``Spare no expense. ... This court's integrity will not be flouted by Mr. Antar or anybody else.'' Politan issued the repatriation order at the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission, which says the money may constitute illegal profits from insider trading. The SEC sued Antar, who was chairman of Crazy Eddie, and other top former officials of the chain, accusing them of falsely inflating the company's income. The SEC said Antar transferred $52 million to bank accounts in Israel three years ago. Antar, through his lawyers, has denied the charges. Antar's attorneys late Friday sought recourse from to 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert E. Cowen in Trenton. Cowen stayed the repatriation order and contempt finding but let the arrest warrant stand, said Antar's attorney, Jack Arseneault. The effect is that Antar needs only to appear in court to remove the threat of arrest while a formal appeal of the repatriation order goes forward, he said. Politan had set a deadline of 4 p.m. Wednesday for the money to be returned and deposited with a trustee. When Antar defied it, he ordered him to court Thursday morning to respond to the contempt citation. Antar's lawyers said he needed a 24-hour extension for personal reasons. Politan granted the delay with the threat of an arrest warrant if Antar failed to appear Friday. In an affidavit submitted Friday, Antar said he was refusing the order because of his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. Antar's attorneys have argued that merely acknowledging the presence of the money could be used against him. Politan spurned the offer of the affidavit. ``We're not in a paper chase here. We're in a human chase. Human beings have a right to pursue a privilege ... (but) they can't do it by affidavit,'' he said. The U.S. attorney's office in Newark is seeking a criminal indictment against the Brooklyn, N.Y.-born Antar, a high school dropout who turned a single electronics store into a chain of 43. Crazy Eddie became widely known in the New York area for its frenetic commercials advertising ``insane'' prices. The company has entered bankruptcy proceedings and is facing a shareholder's lawsuit. Politan refused Arseneault's request for a stay on the arrest order pending appeal. He then closed the courtroom to ask Antar's lawyers for his recent addresses and phone numbers, and his whereabouts the last time he spoke to his lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: Mount Sterling Plant To Close; Danville Plant For Sale
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. announced Friday it will close its dishwasher plant here that employs 650 people by March 1991. ``It's going to hurt everybody,'' said United Auto Workers Local 1562 steward Frankie Allen. ``Everyone's going to suffer.'' ``You can't find another job like that here, and certainly not that many,'' said Bob Teegarden, who has worked at the plant 22 years. Whirlpool also announced it will sell its Danville plant and its floor-care operations, but will move the plant's ice-maker and trash compactor operation to other plants. The Danville plant, which opened 19 years ago, has more than 1,000 workers _ 700 in the floor-care division that manufactures Kenmore vacuum cleaners and 300 in the making of ice-makers and trash compactors. David Mitchell, vice president of the Danville division, said at a news conference Friday that Whirlpool is optimistic it can find a buyer for the plant's floor-care operations, preserving 700 jobs. ``We have over 10 percent of the floor-care business nationally, and we have an outstanding facility and employees,'' Mitchell said. However, Mitchell said most of the 300 jobs in the ice-maker and trash-compactor operation will be lost. Whirlpool said it will shift production of its KitchenAid dishwashers from Mount Sterling to its division in Findlay, Ohio, which already makes Whirlpool, Roper and Kenmore dishwashers and Whirlpool cooking ranges. Production of built-in cooking appliances will be moved from Findlay to Whirlpool's Oxford, Miss., plant, which makes built-in cooking products as well as components for Whirlpool and KitchenAid. Whirlpool officials said the company could save $7 million by moving operations to Findlay. Tom Reffett, president of Local 1562, said the union was willing to make concessions in its current contract to keep the plant open. ``I don't think anything we could have done would have mattered,'' said Reffett, who had worked at the plant for 18 years. Reffett said in small town like Mount Sterling, with about 6,000 residents, it would be impossible to replace the jobs at the plant, which paid an average of $9.72 an hour. William D. Marohn, executive vice president of Whirlpool's North American Appliance Group, said the moves would improve manufacturing efficiency and focus on the company's major appliance businesses. ``Clearly these were not easy decisions to make since they affect a number of our people,'' Marohn said. ``We believe they are the right ones for the company's North American business long term.'' The Mount Sterling plant will operate at least through the fourth quarter of 1990, and close by the end of the first quarter of 1991, Whirlpool spokeswoman Carol Sizer said. Some management jobs may be transferred to other Whirlpool facilities but most employees will be dismissed, Sizer said. The company will schedule meetings with United Auto Workers Local 1562 to negotiate the dismissal procedures, she said.

DOC.HEAD: National Labor Board Settles Coal Strike Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Also Friday ...,' to CORRECT spelling of ``McGlothlin''; INSERTS 4 new grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Also Friday ...,' to UPDATE with federal judge meeting with attorneys in Virginia. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The 1,700 Appalachia coal miners who have been on strike since April on Friday moved closer to a vote on returning to work as the National Labor Relations Board settled lawsuits filed by both sides during the bitter dispute. Bargainers for the United Mine Workers and Pittston Coal Co. reached a tentative settlement on New Year's Eve, but a contract ratification vote for rank-and-file union members in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky has been delayed until outstanding unfair labor practice charges were resolved. A UMW spokesman said it was unclear when miners, who have remained off the job pending ratification, would vote on the new contract. Under Friday's NLRB agreement, both sides will be allowed to drop all charges if the contract is ratified, miners return to work and the terms of the agreement are approved by federal courts. Also Friday, the UMW said it and the company would go before Russell County, Va., Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin on Monday to ask that he drop $64.5 million in fines levied against the union for illegal strike activities such as intimidating replacement workers and obstructing coal truck traffic. In Big Stone Gap, Va., U.S. District Judge Glen Williams also must settle nearly $1 million in fines against the union as a condition of ratification. Williams held a 90-minute, closed-door meeting in his chambers Friday afternoon with two attorneys each from the union and the board. After the session, Williams told reporters he was concerned about possible public reaction were he to issue a blanket forgiveness of the fines. ``I naturally don't want to do something that's going to block a settlement,'' Williams said, adding that he was nonetheless interested in ``protecting the integrity of the court.'' Williams said he probably would meet again with union attorneys Monday. In addition, trustees of the union's health retirement funds also must agree to changes required by the new contract. Details of the contract remain secret, but sources have said the union won on two key issues _ better health and retirement benefits and improved job security. The union struck after Pittston decided to end contributions to the UMW retirement and health plans for some 130,000 workers. The union said the decision could cause other coal companies to follow suit and retired miners would lose their benefits. Pittston, the nation's largest coal exporter, said it could not afford the payments because of high overseas shipping costs. The strike was punctuated by large labor rallies, vandalism and rock-throwing confrontations between strikers and other company workers. At one point, some 46,000 coal workers in 10 states walked off their jobs in sympathy strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Appeal Filed in Family Claim To Huge E&J Gallo Winery
DOC.TEXT: The younger brother of Ernest and Julio Gallo, owners of the world's largest winery, has filed a federal appeal renewing his claim to a one-third interest in the $1 billion-a-year business, and arguing to use the family name on his cheese products. Livingston rancher Joseph Gallo said in his 59-page filing before the U.S. 9th Circuit Court of Appeals that the First Amendment entitles him to use the Gallo name on his cheese, and that his older brothers used his inheritance to launch the Gallo wine empire. The filing, made last month, is an appeal of a decision by U.S. District Judge Robert E. Coyle last August. It held that Joseph's use of the Gallo name on his cheese packages violated the E&J Gallo trademark. He ordered Joseph to reduce the ``Gallo'' emphasis on labels and in ads. Joseph appealed to Coyle, asking for a new judge and a new trial. Coyle denied the motions. Joseph then launched his claim in the inheritance matter. Joseph alleged that his brothers once included him as an equal partner. The stakes are huge. E&J Gallo reputedly packs about 170 million gallons of wine annually, dominating the California wine industry and controlling more than 25 percent of the U.S. wine market. Joseph's claim was dismissed by U.S. District Judge Edward Dean Price, who had removed himself from the trademark case over a challenge of the judge's relationship with the Gallos. The new appeal charges that Coyle had a conflict in the trademark case because he owned vineyards in Fresno county and was a partner in a law firm that represented the winery in an earlier trademark case. Joseph, among other things, asked the appeals court to knock down Coyle's ruling and order a new trial with a different judge.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Activists Urge Boycott of P&G's Folgers Coffee
DOC.TEXT: Peace activists on Friday urged consumers to boycott Folgers coffee in an effort to persuade Procter & Gamble Co. to stop buying coffee from war-torn El Salvador. About a dozen members of Peaceworks, a coalition of Cincinnati peace activist organizations, picketed outside Procter & Gamble's corporate headquarters. The activists support a coffee boycott announced in November by the San Francisco-based group Neighbor to Neighbor, Peaceworks spokeswoman Kateri Koverman said. Demonstrators wore blue buttons reading ``Boycott Salvadoran Coffee: Stop Funding Death Squads.'' A P&G spokesman said the company would not change its coffee-buying policy. Activists met with P&G officials in December to urge the company to stop buying Salvadoran coffee. They said P&G is being targeted because it has appeared less responsive than rival coffee producers Hills Bros. Coffee and Nestle Foods Corp. about the issue. Hills Bros. and Nestle in December agreed to suspend coffee purchase from El Salvador for 30 days. Boycott supporters claim money from U.S. coffee buyers enriches wealthy Salvadoran families backing that country's civil war. But Procter & Gamble says purchase of Salvadoran coffee benefits workers in El Salvador. The company also says the Bush administration and the State Department encourage open trade with the U.S.-backed Salvadoran government. ``We believe the U.S. government is best equipped to make decisions on foreign policy and foreign governments for our country, and the Bush administration and the State Department strongly support our country's open trade with El Salvador,'' P&G spokesman Donald Tassone said. He said P&G buys coffee from at least 30 countries, and the Salvadoran product amounts to less than 2 percent of the coffee used to produce the Folgers blend. ``As a company, we can't let a very small but vocal group inject us into their dispute with the U.S. government, no matter how well intentioned it might be,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Major Iowa Savings and Loan Fails
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators took over the nearly $1 billion American Federal Savings and Loan Association of Des Moines on Friday over concern that it could not meet its capital requirements. Officials said it was the largest failure ever of an Iowa thrift. No depositor lost any money and all accounts remain federally insured, said Jerry Orman of the federal Office of Thrift Supervision. The thrift has $968 million in assets and $828.5 million on deposit at offices in 14 Iowa communities. The federal Resolution Trust Corp. seized all deposits, named a managing agent to supervise operations and said the thrift would re-open Saturday as American Federal Savings Association of Iowa. ``It became apparent with their continuing operating losses they were going to be unable to meet their capital requirements without some form of government assistance,'' Orman said. He said the thrift's liabilities exceed its assets by $28 million. The Resolution Trust Corp. and Office of Thrift Supervision were set up by Congress as part of a multibillion-dollar program to salvage failed thrifts. ``This would be by far the biggest takeover in Iowa,'' said Gregg Barcus, the superintendent of the state savings and loan division. Being placed in conservatorship means the thrift continues to operate while the Resolution Trust Corp. seeks to minimize losses and insure prudent operations. The government also will try to seek a buyer. A Resolution Trust Corp. managing agent, Jerry Brandt, was put in charge of the thrift, but Orman said no other management changes were anticipated. Orman said American Federal had been experiencing operating losses over several years as a result of out-of-state problem loans in the early 1980s. He said no wrong-doing is suspected.

DOC.HEAD: Railroad Announces Asset Sale Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The Pittsburgh & Lake Erie Railroad Co. on Friday announced an agreement in principle to sell most of its operating rail assets to the Railroad Development Corp. The sale is subject to finalization of a definitive purchase agreement and approval by P&LE's creditors and the Interstate Commerce Commission. Railroad Development, which is based in Pittsburgh, is willing to negotiate with unions representing P&LE employees, but the settlement of labor issues is not a condition of the completion of the transaction, P&LE said in a statement. Railroad Development creates, structures and finances transportation companies. It is an affiliate of Hawthorne Group, an investment company based in Pittsburgh.

Record price increases for vegetables and fuel oil combined in January to produce the highest monthly wholesale inflation rate in 15 years, the government reported, but analysts attributed almost all of it to the holiday cold snap. The Labor Department said Friday its Producer Price Index soared a seasonally adjusted 1.8 percent last month, the sharpest rise since a 2 percent gain in November 1974, in the midst of the OPEC oil embargo. January energy prices rocketed ahead 13.6 percent for the largest monthly gain since 1974. Food costs jumped 2.1 percent, their biggest increase in six years.

Bond prices rose sharply, rallying after the successful completion of the Treasury Department's $30 billion quarterly refunding auction. The newly issued 30-year government bond surged 1 25-32 points Friday, or $17.81 for every $1,000 in face value, from its level at Thursday's auction. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, tumbled to 8.33 percent from 8.50 percent. The jump in the price of the long bond, the most widely watched of government securities, was the largest since last Oct. 13.

The deteriorating condition of the East German economy has heightened concern among officials but both German governments denied that collapse is imminent. A top official in Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government, speaking privately, said earlier Friday the decline, fueled by worker exodus, widespread strikes and high absenteeism at many industrial sites, has accelerated to the point that ``insolvency could be within a few days.'' Kohl will discuss the need for immediate aid in the ``billions of marks'' for East German neighbors during his weekend visit to Moscow, said the senior official.

Daniel P. Kearney, a key official in the savings and loan bureaucracy, quit after only four months on the job, dealing another blow to President Bush's dissension-plagued bailout program. Kearney is the chief staff officer of the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, created to monitor the progress of and set the policy for government rescues of saving and loans. The job ``does not currently afford me the authority that I believe is essential to be effective in this process,'' Kearney said Friday.

Gibraltar Financial Corp. has filed for protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy law, nearly a year after regulators seized its main unit, Gibraltar Savings. Gibraltar Chairman James N. Thayer said Friday the thrift holding company was forced to make the filing Thursday to dissolve a claim against its assets by Bank of America, the trustee for the holders of $99.5 million in unsecured Gibraltar bonds. Thayer also said the move was prompted in part by the government's seizure of two of the company's savings and loan subsidiaries in March 1989.

Unsecured creditors of Allied Stores Corp. fell in line and dropped their objections to $1 billion in new financing for the retailer. Lawyers for Allied and for the creditors said Friday they agreed to a compromise similar to the one forged Thursday by Federated Department Stores and its creditors' committee. The Federated proposal is for $1.4 billion in financing. Both proposals have been submitted to U.S. Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr., who is overseeing the Chapter 11 reorganization of the two U.S. retail divisions of Toronto-based Campeau Corp.

The new chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said the board's image has been ``somewhat tarnished'' and promised a non-confrontational but firm approach to public safety. James L. Kolstad, whose confirmation by the Senate late Thursday ended 17 months of uncertainty for the five-member board, said Friday he would work to improve the timeliness, quality and efficiency of efforts to ensure safety of the nation's air, land and sea transportation. The NTSB investigates all plane crashes and other major transportation accidents.

A Food and Drug Administration proposal to limit food health claims was praised as ``a major victory for consumers,'' but one industry group called portions of the plan a ``bureaucratic nightmare.'' Allen Goldberg of the Grocery Manufacturers Association on Friday praised the FDA for moving ahead on health claims, but said the plan was ``unacceptable in its current form.'' He called a requirement for FDA clearance of health claims ``a bureaucratic nightmare'' and said the need for scientific agreement on a health benefit before a claim can be made is unfair.

Young & Rubicam Inc. pleaded guilty to making improper payments to a Jamaican businessman in its efforts to win the Jamaican government tourism account. In a plea agreement Friday, the government dropped racketeering and bribery charges against the advertising agency and two of its executives. The company had faced fines of up to $7.5 million on the bribery and racketeering charges. The company was fined $500,000 for conspiring to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

The stock market posted a small gain Friday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials edged up 3.83 points to close at 2,648.20. The dollar finished mixed against other major currencies. Bond prices rose sharply. Coffee futures prices surged to their highest levels in five months; near-month oil futures fell sharply; orange juice futures fell; precious metals slipped; grains and soybeans were higher; and livestock and meat futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Textron Lycoming to Eliminate 150 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Textron Lycoming, which makes engines for M-1 Army tanks, plans to lay off 150 people as part of an ongoing effort to streamline the operation, the company said. The jobs, almost all of them in management, will be eliminated by the end of March. The company said additional reductions will take place over the next two years as part of the streamlining effort. Officials said the announcement, made Thursday, was unrelated to the Defense Department's proposal to eliminate the M-1 tank. Textron said late last month that the proposal could lead to 1,500 layoffs for the Stratford-based company, which employs 4,300. Textron said at the time it has been trying for the last four years to reduce its defense-related operations, which comprise about 60 percent of its business. ``We have been reviewing our business over the past several months to assess our strengths and weaknesses, and to prepare ourselves to effectively compete in the 1990s,'' Textron President John R. Myers said Thursday in a prepared statement. ``Our traditional commercial and military markets are threatened by increasing competition. Defense spending is undergoing fundamental changes, and cost has become a critical element of competitiveness,'' he said. Textron spokesman William McDaniel said as many as 100 management jobs will be eliminated in Stratford, as well as 40 to 50 management jobs at Textron locations in Pennsylvania and South Carolina. McDaniel said the longer-range cuts would take place through layoffs, attrition and planned retirements.

DOC.HEAD: FDA Move to Limit Health Claims Praised, Criticized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 17-18: ``The American,'' with heart association comments. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Food and Drug Administration proposal to limit food health claims was praised Friday as ``a major victory for consumers,'' but one industry group called portions of the plan a ``bureaucratic nightmare.'' Allen Goldberg of the Grocery Manufacturers Association praised the FDA for moving ahead on health claims, but said the plan was ``unacceptable in its current form.'' He called a requirement for FDA clearance of health claims ``a bureaucratic nightmare'' and said the need for scientific agreement on a health benefit before a claim can be made is unfair. ``Scientific consensus is an oxymoron,'' he said. ``We believe a claim should be able to be made if strong scientific evidence exists to support the claim.'' Another industry group, the National Food Processors Association, also said it had some concerns, but spokeswoman Ellen Morton said ``overall our reaction is pretty positive.'' The group's major complaint is that the plan will let states regulate health claims, which could lead to different rules in different states. ``Our members market their products on an interstate basis,'' she said. The policy will allow some health claims to be made, but will end what even federal officials say has been three years under rules that have allowed overly broad and ill-founded claims. ``The rule is a major victory for consumers and responsible members of the food industry,'' said Bruce Silverglade of the Center for Science in the Public Interest. ``This new regulation probably means the end of claims that oat bran doughnuts reduce cholesterol, that vitamin A in butter keeps your skin soft and smooth and that B vitamins in cereals help provide energy.'' The proposal is to be published in the Federal Register next week. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan said in announcing the plan Friday that it is a ``mid-course correction'' of regulations that have allowed food sellers to make health claims since 1987, when the Reagan administration abandoned a long-standing prohibition against such claims. ``Only with such a consistent set of standards can Americans be sure of the meaning of health information on food labels,'' he said. The FDA's proposal would let companies make specific health claims if the claims fall within a narrow range of messages concerning the relationship between diet and health benefits. The principle reference points for scientific backup to the claims would be studies by the U.S. Surgeon General and the National Academy of Sciences. Claims outside that narrow range would be allowed only in certain circumstances. Sullivan said that as science finds more links between diet and health, the regulation could be updated. The policy will allow health claims about fiber and colon cancer, fiber and heart disease, fats and cancer, fats and heart disease, sodium and high blood pressure and calcium and osteoporosis, a softening of the bones sometimes found in the elderly. The American Heart Association, whose program of special ``Heart Healthy'' labels on foods has been sharply criticized by the FDA, said the new regulation was welcome but ``does not address all of the important nutrition issues facing the American public.'' The association said it was trying to address how individual foods fit in to a healthy diet, re-formulation of foods to eliminate excessive amounts of harmful substances, independent testing and availability of accurate information in the supermarket. Despite predictions that the rules could enable the FDA to act against a proliferation of claims about oat bran because recent studies have thrown doubt its benefits, the proposal doesn't worry Quaker Oats Co. ``We have 27 years of research showing that oatmeal and oat bran when consumed in connection with a low fat diet will lower cholesterol,'' said Luther McKinney, a senior vice president for law and corporate affairs. But while the company is ``happy the rules have been issued,'' McKinney said he was concerned about a provision that would allow states to impose more stringent rules on health claims. Texas is suing Quaker Oats over the company's cholesterol-lowering claim for one of its products. The new policy could take a year to be fully implemented. Until then, claims will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement on More Italy-U.S. Flights
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Italy have agreed to expand air service between the two countries starting this fall, the Transportation Department announced Friday. The agreement, initialed in Rome on Thursday, allows three more U.S. airlines to fly to Italy. Currently, two U.S. airlines, Pan American and TWA, fly to Italy, while Federal Express is authorized to make freight flights. The Italian airline Alitalia also serves the United States. Under the new pact: _On Oct. 29, Alitalia may chose an additional two U.S. cities to serve with four flights a week and seven a week as of April 1, 1991. _Starting April 1, 1991, American Airlines will begin daily flights from Chicago to Milan and Rome, and U.S. airlines will be permitted to fly on from Milan to Dubrovnik and Zagreb, Yugoslavia. _As of Nov. 1, 1992, the United States may designate a fifth airline to serve Italy with five flights a week for the first year and seven thereafter as long as the planes used have 300 or fewer seats. Frequency of service must be less with larger planes. _On the same day Alitalia may serve an additional two U.S. cities with the same frequency that the fifth U.S. carrier flies to Italy. _On April 1, 1994, a sixth U.S. company may serve Italy if traffic growth has met specified expectations; if not, the sixth carrier may not begin until April 1, 1996. _Alitalia may chose another U.S. destination when the sixth carrier begins service.

DOC.HEAD: Goldberg Takes Over Di Giorgio Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Investor Arthur M. Goldberg said Friday that his DIG Holding Corp. has acquired Di Giorgio Corp., a $1 billion-a-year food and building materials company, with the purchase of 80 percent of its outstanding stock for about $124.5 million in cash. Di Giorgio accepted DIG's $30-a-share offer, which expired at noon Thursday, Goldberg said in a press release. About 4.15 million of Di Giorgio's 5.17 million outstanding shares were sold to Goldberg, who already owned about 14 percent of the company. Last August, the San Francisco-based company rejected as inadequate an unsolicited $32-a-share offer from Goldberg and urged its shareholders not to sell him their stock. It had rejected a $30-a-share offer in June, but that bid was extended. The two companies will merge, Goldberg said in his statement. Neither he nor Di Giorgio returned phone calls by The Associated Press. Di Giorgio stock, not traded Friday because of a hold by the New York Stock Exchange, closed at $29.75 Thursday, up $2.50 from Wednesday. Di Giorgio is engaged in food distribution through its New York-based White Rose Food Division and processes and sells speciality meats through its Cerando Division. Di Giorgio also makes and sells a variety of building materials through its DG Mouldings, BiltBest Windows and Las Plumas Lumber Divisions. DIG Holding Corp. is owned by Rose Partners L.P., a partnership of investors led by Goldberg.

DOC.HEAD: Armstrong Sues Takeover Family
DOC.TEXT: Armstrong World Industries Inc. filed a federal lawsuit Friday accusing an unwanted suitor of using inside information in buying and selling the company's stock, the company said. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Reading, names First City Fiancial Corp. of Vancouver, British Columbia, an investment company primarily owned by the Belzberg family of Canada. The Belzberg family first targeted the floor-covering company last summer, announcing it purchased 9.85 percent of its stock and wished to take over Armstrong. Armstrong resisted the attempt, and the Belzbergs have not made a tender offer. The family also has announced it intends to try to appoint four sympathetic board members during Armstrong's annual shareholders meeting April 30. The lawsuit asks the court to force First City to relinquish $225,000, which, the lawsuit contends, the company made in trades on Armstrong stock in December and January. As of about the end of November, First City owned 10 percent of Armstrong's outstanding shares, Armstrong spokesman John Scheldrup said. Last week, the family purchased 250,000 additional Armstrong shares, increasing its stake to 10.6 percent, Scheldrup said. A call Friday evening to First City for comment was directed to a spokesman in New York, Ned Scharff, who was said to have left the office for the day. Armstrong stock closed Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at $34.37{, up 12.5 cents.
